titleStmt.title: Marginalia in Piers Plowman B-Text Manuscripts
titleStmt.author: Christine Schott, et al., eds.

publicationStmt.p: Produced in coordination with the Rare Book School and the Piers Plowman Electronic Archive

sourceDesc.p: The main text is taken from the Beta version of PPEA's B Archetype, based on MS L. Marginalia is drawn from each of the B-text manuscripts to which PPEA currently has access.

marginalia.note: The heading is written in a similar ink to that of the text but in a much less formal style, and is probably later than the main scribe. Though rubbed, it appears originally to have read Assit principio Sancta Maria meo with Sancta then deleted by way of underlining and replaced by filius, and Maria altered to Mariae.

lg.l: In a somer seson &punctuselevatus; whan soft was the sonne
I shope me in shroudes &punctuselevatus; as i a shepe were
In habite as an heremite &punctuselevatus; vnholy of workes
Went wyde in þis world wondres to here
Ac on a May mornyng &punctuselevatus; on Maluerne hulles
Me byfel a ferly &punctuselevatus; of fairy me thouȝte
I was wery forwandred &raisedpoint; and went me to reste
Vnder a brode banke &punctuselevatus; bi a bornes side
And as I lay and lened &punctuselevatus; and loked in þe wateres
I slombred in a slepyng &punctuselevatus; it sweyued so merye
Thanne gan I to meten &punctuselevatus; a merueilouse sweuene
That I was in a wildernesse &punctuselevatus; wist I neuer where
As I bihelde in-to þe est &punctuselevatus; an hiegh to þe sonne
I seigh a toure on a toft &punctuselevatus; trielich ymaked
A depe dale binethe &punctuselevatus; a dongeon þere-Inne
With depe dyches & derke &punctuselevatus; and dredful of sight
A faire felde ful of folke &punctuselevatus; fonde I there bytwene
Of alle maner of men &punctuselevatus; þe mene and þe riche

Ry
vont vont
John rich
RychardA later fifteenth-century scribe. Kane and Donaldson report bond John Rychard.
lg.l: Worchyng and wandryng &punctuselevatus; as þe worlde asketh
Some put hem to þe plow &punctuselevatus; pleyed ful selde
In settyng and in sowyng &punctuselevatus; swonken ful harde
And wonnen that wastours &punctuselevatus; with glotonye destruyeth
And some putten hem to pruyde &punctuselevatus; apparailed hem þere-after
In contenaunce of clothyng comen disgised
In prayers and in penance &punctuselevatus; putten hem manye
Al for loue of owre lorde &raisedpoint; lyueden ful streyte
In hope forto haue &raisedpoint; heueneriche blisse
As ancres and heremites &raisedpoint; that holden hem in here selles
And coueiten nought in contre to kairen aboute
For no likerous liflode &raisedpoint; her lykam to plese
And somme chosen chaffare &raisedpoint; they cheuen the bettere
As it semeth to owre syȝt &raisedpoint; that suche men thryueth
And somme murthes to make &raisedpoint; as mynstralles conneth
And geten gold with here glee &raisedpoint; synneles I leue
Ac iapers & iangelers &raisedpoint; Iudas chylderen
Feynen hem fantasies &raisedpoint; and foles hem maketh
And han here witte at wille &raisedpoint; to worche ȝif þei sholde
That Poule precheth of hem &raisedpoint; I nel nought preue it here
Qui turpiloquium loquitur &raisedpoint; &c
Bidders and beggeres &raisedpoint; fast aboute ȝede
With her bely and her bagge &raisedpoint; of bred ful ycrammed
Fayteden for here fode &raisedpoint; fouȝten atte ale
In glotonye god it wote &raisedpoint; gon hij to bedde
And risen with ribaudye &raisedpoint; tho roberdes knaues
Slepe and sori sleuthe &raisedpoint; seweth hem eure
¶ Pilgrymes and palmers &raisedpoint; pliȝted hem togidere
To seke seynt Iames &raisedpoint; and seyntes in rome
Thei went forth in here wey &raisedpoint; with many wise tales
And hadden leue to lye &raisedpoint; al here lyf after
I seigh somme that seiden &raisedpoint; þei had ysouȝt seyntes
To eche a tale þat þei tolde &raisedpoint; here tonge was tempred to lye
More þan to sey soth &raisedpoint; it semed bi here speche
¶ Heremites on an heep &raisedpoint; with hoked staues
Wenten to walsyngham &raisedpoint; and here wenches after
Grete lobyes and longe &raisedpoint; that loth were to swynke
Clotheden hem in copis &raisedpoint; to ben knowen fram othere
And shopen hem heremites &raisedpoint; here ese to haue

marginalia.note: This I is one of the capitals which indicate the beginnings of chapters.

lg.l: ¶ I fonde þere Freris alle þe foure ordres
Preched þe peple &raisedpoint; for profit of hem-seluen
Glosed þe gospel &raisedpoint; as hem good lyked
For coueitise of copis &raisedpoint; construed it as þei wolde
Many of þis maistres Freris mowe clothen hem at lykyng
For here money and marchandise &raisedpoint; marchen togideres
For sith charite haþ be chapman &raisedpoint; and chief to shryue lordes
Many ferlis han fallen &raisedpoint; in a fewe ȝeris
But holychirche and hij &raisedpoint; holde better togideres
The moste my[s]chief on molde &raisedpoint; is mountyng wel faste
¶ Þere preched a Pardonere &raisedpoint; as he a prest were
Brouȝte forth a bulle &raisedpoint; with bishopes seles
And seide þat hym-self myȝte &raisedpoint; assoilen hem alle
Of falshed of fastyng &raisedpoint; of vowes ybroken
¶ Lewed men leued hym wel &raisedpoint; and lyked his wordes
Comen vp knelyng &raisedpoint; to kissen his bulles
He bonched hem with his breuet &raisedpoint; & blered here eyes
And rauȝte with his ragman &raisedpoint; rynges and broches
Thus þey geuen here golde &raisedpoint; glotones to kepe
And leneth such loseles &raisedpoint; þat lecherye haunten
Were þe bischop yblissed &raisedpoint; and worth bothe his eres
His seel shulde nouȝt be sent &raisedpoint; to deceyue þe peple
Ac it is nauȝt by þe bischop &raisedpoint; þat þe boy precheth
For the parisch prest and þe pardonere &raisedpoint; parten þe siluer
That þe poraille of þe parisch &raisedpoint; sholde haue ȝif þei nere
¶ Persones and parisch prestes &raisedpoint; pleyned hem to þe bischop &raisedpoint;
Þat here parisshes were pore &raisedpoint; sith þe pestilence tyme
To haue a lycence and a leue &raisedpoint; at London to dwelle
And syngen þere for symonye &raisedpoint; for siluer is swete
¶ Bischopes and bachelers &raisedpoint; bothe maistres and doctours
Þat han cure vnder criste &raisedpoint; and crounyng in tokne
And signe þat þei sholden &raisedpoint; shryuen here paroschienes
Prechen and prey for hem &raisedpoint; and þe pore fede
Liggen in London &raisedpoint; in lenten an elles
Somme seruen þe kyng &raisedpoint; and his siluer tellen
In cheker and in chancerye &raisedpoint; chalengen his dettes
Of wardes and wardmotes &raisedpoint; weyues and streyues
¶ And some seruen as seruantz &raisedpoint; lordes and ladyes
And in stede of stuwardes &raisedpoint; sytten and demen
Here messe and here matynes &raisedpoint; and many of here oures
Arn don vndeuoutlych &raisedpoint; drede is at þe laste
Lest crist in constorie &raisedpoint; acorse ful manye
I parceyued of þe power &raisedpoint; þat Peter had to kepe
To bynde and to vnbynde &raisedpoint; as þe boke telleth
How he it left wiþ loue &raisedpoint; as owre lorde hight
Amonges foure vertues &raisedpoint; þe best of alle vertues
Þat cardinales ben called &raisedpoint; & closyng ȝatis
Þere crist is in kyngdome &raisedpoint; to close and to shutte
And to opne it to hem &raisedpoint; and heuene blisse shewe
Ac of þe cardinales atte Courte &raisedpoint; þat cauȝt of þat name
And power presumed in hem &raisedpoint; a Pope to make
To han þat power þat peter hadde &raisedpoint; inpugnen I nelle
For in loue and letterure &raisedpoint; þe eleccioun bilongeth
For-þi I can and can nauȝte &raisedpoint; of courte speke more
¶ Þanne come þere a kyng &raisedpoint; knyȝthod hym ladde
Miȝt of þe comunes &raisedpoint; made hym to regne
And þanne cam kynde wytte &raisedpoint; and clerkes he made
For to conseille þe kyng &raisedpoint; and þe comune saue
¶ The kyng and knyȝthode &raisedpoint; and clergye bothe
Casten þat þe comune shulde hem-self fynde
¶ Þe comune contreued &raisedpoint; of kynde witte craftes
And for profit of alle þe poeple &raisedpoint; plowmen ordeygned
To tilie and trauaile &raisedpoint; as trewe lyf askeþ
Þe kynge and þe comune &raisedpoint; and kynde witte þe thridde
Shope lawe & lewte &raisedpoint; eche man to knowe his owne
¶ Þanne loked vp a lunatik &raisedpoint; a lene þing with-alle
And knelyng to þe kyng &raisedpoint; clergealy he seyde
Crist kepe þe sire kyng &raisedpoint; and þi kyngriche
And lene þe lede þi londe &raisedpoint; so leute þe louye
And for þi riȝtful rewlyng &raisedpoint; be rewarded in heuene
¶ And sithen in þe eyre an hiegh &raisedpoint; an angel of heuene
Lowed to speke in latyn &raisedpoint; for lewed men ne coude .
Iangle ne iugge &raisedpoint; þat iustifie hem shulde
But suffren & seruen &raisedpoint; for-thi seyde þe angel
Sum Rex sum Princeps &raisedpoint; neutrum fortasse deinceps
O qui iura regis &raisedpoint; cristi specialia regis
Hoc quod agas melius &raisedpoint; iustus es esto pius
Nudum ius a te &raisedpoint; vestiri vult pietate
Qualia vis metere &raisedpoint; talia grana sere
Si ius nudatur &raisedpoint; nudo de iure metatur &raisedpoint;
Si seritur pietas &raisedpoint; de pietate metas &raisedpoint;
¶ Thanne greued hym a Goliardeys &raisedpoint; a glotoun of wordes
And to þe angel an heiȝ &raisedpoint; answeres after
Dum rex a regere &raisedpoint; dicatur nomen habere
Nomen habet sine re &raisedpoint; nisi studet iura tenere &raisedpoint;
¶ And þanne gan alle þe comune &raisedpoint; crye in vers of latin
To þe kynges conseille &raisedpoint; construe ho-so wolde
lg.marginalia:
The tale
of the rat
tons .
lg.l: Precepta Regis &raisedpoint; sunt nobis vincula legis &raisedpoint;
¶ Wiþ þat ran þere a route of ratones at ones
And smale mys with hem mo þen a þousande
And comen to a conseille &raisedpoint; for here comune profit
For a cat of a courte &raisedpoint; cam whan hym lyked
And ouerlepe hem lyȝtlich &raisedpoint; and lauȝte hem at his wille
And pleyde wiþ hem perilouslych &raisedpoint; and possed aboute
For doute of dyuerse dredes &raisedpoint; we dar nouȝte wel loke
And ȝif we grucche of his gamen &raisedpoint; he wil greue vs alle
Cracche vs or clowe vs &raisedpoint; and in his cloches holde
That vs lotheth þe lyf &raisedpoint; or he lete vs passe
Myȝte we wiþ any witte &raisedpoint; his wille withstonde
We myȝte be lordes aloft &raisedpoint; and lyuen at owre ese
¶ A raton of renon most renable of tonge
¶ Seide for a souereygne &raisedpoint; help to hym-selue
I haue ysein segges quod he &raisedpoint; in þe cite of london
Beren biȝes ful briȝte &raisedpoint; abouten here nekkes
And some colers of crafty werk vncoupled þei wenden
Boþe in wareine & in waste &raisedpoint; where hem leue lyketh
And otherwhile þei aren elles-where &raisedpoint; as I here telle
Were þere a belle on here beiȝ &raisedpoint; bi Ihesu as me thynketh

marginalia.note: Likey a guide for alteration to renne.

lg.l: Men myȝte wite where þei went &raisedpoint; and awei renne
And riȝt so quod þat ratoun &raisedpoint; reson me sheweth
To bugge a belle of brasse &raisedpoint; or of briȝte syluer
And knitten on a colere &raisedpoint; for owre comune profit
And hangen it vp-on þe cattes hals &raisedpoint; þanne here we mowen
Where he ritt or rest &raisedpoint; or renneth to playe
And ȝif him list for to laike &raisedpoint; þenne loke we mowen
And peren in his presence &raisedpoint; þer-while hym plaie liketh
And ȝif him wrattheth be ywar &raisedpoint; and his weye shonye
¶ Alle þis route of ratones &raisedpoint; to þis reson þei assented
Ac þo þe belle was ybouȝt &raisedpoint; and on þe beiȝe hanged
Þere ne was ratoun in alle þe route &raisedpoint; for alle þe rewme of Fraunce
Þat dorst haue ybounden þe belle &raisedpoint; aboute þe cattis nekke
Ne hangen aboute þe cattes hals &raisedpoint; al Engelonde to wynne
And helden hem vnhardy &raisedpoint; and here conseille feble
lg.marginalia: *Omnium doctissimorum suffragio dicuntur Hec de lassiuis, fatuis, aut ineptis principibus, non de etate tenellis, Quasi dicat, vbi rex puerilis est.
lg.l: And leten here laboure lost &raisedpoint; & alle here longe studye

lg.l: ¶ A mous þat moche good &raisedpoint; couthe as me thouȝte
Stroke forth sternly &raisedpoint; and stode biforn hem alle
And to þe route of ratones &raisedpoint; reherced þese wordes
Thouȝ we culled þe catte &raisedpoint; ȝut sholde þer come an-other
To cracchy vs and al owre kynde &raisedpoint; þouȝ we croupe vnder benches
For-þi I conseille alle þe comune &raisedpoint; to lat þe catte worthe
And be we neuer so bolde &raisedpoint; þe belle hym to shewe
For I herde my sire seyn &raisedpoint; is seuene ȝere ypassed
Þere þe catte is a kitoun &raisedpoint; þe courte is ful elyng
Þat witnisseth holiwrite &raisedpoint; who-so wil it rede
Ve terre vbi puer rex est &c
For may no renke þere rest haue &raisedpoint; for ratones bi nyȝte
Þe while he caccheþ conynges &raisedpoint; he coueiteth nouȝt owre caroyne
But fet hym al with venesoun &raisedpoint; defame we hym neuere

marginalia.note: Later hand, perhaps meaning "a verse, proverb," also at W1.38 and W1.86 (KD1.36 and KD1.85).

lg.l: For better is a litel losse &raisedpoint; þan a longe sorwe
Þe mase amonge vs alle &raisedpoint; þouȝ we mysse a schrewe
For many mannus malt &raisedpoint; we mys wolde destruye
And also ȝe route of ratones &raisedpoint; rende mennes clothes
Nere þat cat of þat courte &raisedpoint; þat can ȝow ouerlepe
For had ȝe rattes ȝowre wille &raisedpoint; ȝe couthe nouȝt reule ȝowre-selue
I sey for me quod þe mous &raisedpoint; I se so mykel after
Shal neuer þe cat ne þe kitoun &raisedpoint; bi my conseille be greued
Ne carpyng of þis coler &raisedpoint; þat costed me neure
And þouȝ it had coste me catel &raisedpoint; biknowen it I nolde
But suffre as hym-self wolde &raisedpoint; to do as hym liketh
Coupled & vncoupled &raisedpoint; to cacche what thei mowe
For-þi vche a wise wiȝte I warne &raisedpoint; wite wel his owne
¶ What þis meteles bemeneth &raisedpoint; ȝe men þat be merye
Deuine ȝe for I ne dar &raisedpoint; bi dere god in heuene
¶ Ȝit houed þere an hondreth &raisedpoint; in houues of selke
Seriauntz it semed &raisedpoint; þat serueden atte barre
lg.marginalia: # Momming off Men off law For Mone
lg.l: Plededen for penyes &raisedpoint; and poundes þe lawe
And nouȝt for loue of owre lorde &raisedpoint; vnlese here lippes onis
Þow myȝtest better mete þe myste &raisedpoint; on maluerne hulles
Þan gete a momme of here mouthe &raisedpoint; but monoy were shewed
¶ Barones an burgeis &raisedpoint; and bonde-men als
I seiȝ in þis assemble &raisedpoint; as ȝe shul here after
Baxsteres & brewesteres &raisedpoint; and bocheres manye
Wollewebsteres &raisedpoint; and weueres of lynnen
Taillours and tynkeres &raisedpoint; & tolleres in marketes
Masons and mynours &raisedpoint; and many other craftes
Of alkin libbyng laboreres &raisedpoint; lopen forth somme
As dykers & delueres &raisedpoint; þat doth here dedes ille
And dryuen forth þe dere day &raisedpoint; with dieu vous saue dame Emme &raisedpoint;
Cokes and here knaues &raisedpoint; crieden hote pies hote
Gode gris a gees &raisedpoint; go we dyne go we
¶ Tauerners vn-til hem &raisedpoint; tolde þe same
White wyn of Oseye &raisedpoint; and red wyn of Gascoigne
Of þe Ryne and of þe Rochel &raisedpoint; þe roste to defye
Al þis seiȝ I slepyng &raisedpoint; and seuene sythes more
What this montaigne bymeneth &raisedpoint; and þe merke dale
And þe felde ful of folke &raisedpoint; I shal ȝow faire schewe
A loueli ladi of lere &raisedpoint; in lynnen yclothed
Come down fram a castel &raisedpoint; and called me faire
And seide sone slepestow &raisedpoint; sestow þis poeple
How bisi þei ben &raisedpoint; abouten þe mase
Þe moste partie of þis poeple &raisedpoint; þat passeth on þis erthe
lg.marginalia: # off them þat will non other heven but this
lg.l: Haue þei worschip in þis worlde &raisedpoint; þei wilne no better
Of other heuene þan here &raisedpoint; holde þei no tale
¶ I was aferd of her face &raisedpoint; þeiȝ she faire were
And seide mercy Madame &raisedpoint; what is þis to mene
Þe toure vp þe toft quod she &raisedpoint; treuthe is þere-Inne
And wolde þat ȝe wrouȝte &raisedpoint; as his worde techeth
For he is fader of feith &raisedpoint; fourmed ȝow alle
Bothe with fel and with face &raisedpoint; and ȝaf ȝow fyue wittis
Forto worschip hym þer-with &raisedpoint; þe while þat ȝe ben here
And þerfore he hyȝte þe erthe &raisedpoint; to help ȝow vchone
Of wollen of lynnen &raisedpoint; of lyflode at nede
In mesurable manere &raisedpoint; to make ȝow at ese
¶ And comaunded of his curteisye in comune þree þinges
Arne none nedful but þo &raisedpoint; and nempne hem I thinke
And rekne hem bi resoun &raisedpoint; reherce þow hem after
That one is vesture &raisedpoint; from chele þe to saue
And mete atte mele &raisedpoint; for myseise of þi-selue
And drynke whan þow dryest &raisedpoint; ac do nouȝt out of resoun
That þow worth þe werse &raisedpoint; whan þow worche shuldest

lg.marginalia: Loth , Cr1.1.27: The final <-h> appears to be malformed , and it is possible that the comma is a stray mark.
lg.l: ¶ For loth in his lifdayes &raisedpoint; for likyng of drynke
Dede bi his douȝtres &raisedpoint; þat þe deuel lyked
Delited hym in drynke &raisedpoint; as þe deuel wolde
And lecherye hym lauȝt &raisedpoint; and lay bi hem boþe
And al he witt it wyn &raisedpoint; þat wikked dede
Inebriamus eum vino &raisedpoint; dormiamus-que cum eo
Vt seruare possimus de patre nostro semen &raisedpoint;
Thorw wyn and þorw &raisedpoint; women &raisedpoint; þere was loth acombred
And þere gat in glotonye &raisedpoint; gerlis þat were cherlis
For-þi drede delitable drynke &raisedpoint; and þow shalt do þe bettere
Mesure is medcyne &raisedpoint; þouȝ þow moche ȝerne
It is nauȝt al gode to þe goste &raisedpoint; þat þe gutte axeþ
Ne liflode to þi likam &raisedpoint; for a lyer him techeth
That is þe wrecched worlde &raisedpoint; wolde þe bitraye
For þe fende and þi flesch &raisedpoint; folweth þe to-gidere
This and þat seest þi soule &raisedpoint; and seith it in þin herte
And for þow sholdest ben ywar &raisedpoint; I wisse þe þe beste
¶ Madame mercy quod I &raisedpoint; me liketh wel ȝowre wordes
Ac þe moneye of þis molde &raisedpoint; þat men so faste holdeth
Telle me to whom Madame &raisedpoint; þat tresore appendeth
¶ Go to þe gospel quod she &raisedpoint; þat god seide hym-seluen
lg.marginalia: pepleO1.47. A solidus/punctus above temple and another above the marginal addition indicate that it is intended as a substitution, although such a reading is unattested elsewhere and to adopt it would destroy the sense of the line.
lg.l: Tho þe poeple hym apposed &raisedpoint; wiþ a peny in þe temple
Whether þei shulde þer-with &raisedpoint; worschip þe kyng Sesar
And god axed of hem &raisedpoint; of whome spake þe lettre
And þe ymage ilyke þat þere-inne stondeth
Cesaris þei seide we sen hym wel vchone
¶ Reddite cesari quod god &raisedpoint; þat cesari bifalleth
Et que sunt dei deo &raisedpoint; or elles ȝe done ille
For riȝtful reson &raisedpoint; shulde rewle ȝow alle
And kynde witte be wardeyne &raisedpoint; ȝowre welthe to kepe
And tutour of ȝoure tresore &raisedpoint; and take it ȝow at nede
For housbonderye & hij &raisedpoint; holden togideres
Þanne I frained hir faire &raisedpoint; for hym þat hir made
That dongeoun in þe dale þat dredful is of siȝte
What may it be to mene &raisedpoint; ma-dame I ȝow biseche
¶ Þat is þe castel of care &raisedpoint; who-so cometh þerinne
May banne þat he borne was &raisedpoint; to body or to soule
Þerinne wonieth a wiȝte &raisedpoint; þat wronge is yhote
Fader of falshed &raisedpoint; and founded it hym-selue
Adam and Eue &raisedpoint; he egged to ille
Conseilled caym &raisedpoint; to kullen his brother
Iudas he iaped &raisedpoint; with iuwen siluer
And sithen on an eller honged hym after
He is letter of loue &raisedpoint; and lyeth hem alle
That trusten on his tresor &raisedpoint; bitrayeth he sonnest
¶ Thanne had I wonder in my witt &raisedpoint; what womman it were
Þat such wise wordes &raisedpoint; of holywrit shewed
And asked hir on þe hieȝe name &raisedpoint; ar heo þennes ȝeode
What she were witterli &raisedpoint; þat wissed me so faire
¶ Holicherche I am quod she &raisedpoint; þow ouȝtest me to knowe
I vnderfonge þe firste &raisedpoint; and þe feyth tauȝte
And brouȝtest me borwes &raisedpoint; my biddyng to fulfille

marginalia.note: M1.80, added and erased material is illegible under ultra-violet light. Most likely it indicated the alteration leally.

lg.l: And to loue me lelly &raisedpoint; þe while þi lyf dureth

marginalia.note: M1.81, added and erased material is illegible under ultra-violet light. Most likely it indicated the alteration &.

lg.l: ¶ Thanne I courbed on my knees &raisedpoint; and cryed hir of grace
And preyed hir pitousely &raisedpoint; prey for my synnes

marginalia.note: M1.83, added and erased material is illegible. Most likely it indicated the alteration kenne me.

lg.l: And also ken[n]e me kyndeli &raisedpoint; on criste to bileue
That I miȝte worchen his wille &raisedpoint; þat wrouȝte me to man
Teche me to no tresore &raisedpoint; but telle me þis ilke
How I may saue my soule &raisedpoint; þat seynt art yholden

marginalia.note: W1.86, more cursive hand than scribe

lg.l: ¶ Whan alle tresores aren tried quod she &raisedpoint; trewthe is þe best
I do it on deus caritas &raisedpoint; to deme þe soþe
It is as derworth a drewery &raisedpoint; as dere god hym-seluen

marginalia.note: G2.89 The word trew is underlined in the text (see G2.89), suggesting that the marginal annotation may refer to this word.

lg.l: ¶ Who-so is trewe of his tonge &raisedpoint; & telleth none other
And doth þe werkis þer-with &raisedpoint; and wilneth no man ille
He is a god bi þe gospel &raisedpoint; agrounde and aloft
And ylike to owre lorde &raisedpoint; bi seynte lukes wordes
Þe clerkes þat knoweþ þis &raisedpoint; shulde kenne it aboute
For cristene and vncristne &raisedpoint; clameþ it vchone
¶ Kynges & kniȝtes &raisedpoint; shulde kepe it bi resoun
Riden and rappe down &raisedpoint; in reumes aboute
And taken tran[s]gressores &raisedpoint; and tyen hem faste
Til treuthe had ytermyned &raisedpoint; her trespas to þe ende
And þat is þe professioun appertly &raisedpoint; þat appendeth for knyȝtes
And nouȝt to fasten a fryday &raisedpoint; in fyue score wynter
But holden wiþ him & with hir &raisedpoint; þat wolden al treuthe
And neuer leue hem for loue &raisedpoint; ne for lacchyng of syluer
¶ For dauid in his dayes &raisedpoint; dubbed kniȝtes
And did hem swere on here swerde &raisedpoint; to serue trewthe euere
And who-so passed þat poynte &raisedpoint; was apostata in þe ordre
¶ But criste kingene kynge &raisedpoint; kniȝted ten
Cherubyn and seraphin &raisedpoint; suche seuene and an othre
And ȝaf hem myȝte in his maieste &raisedpoint; þe murger hem þouȝte
And ouer his mene meyne &raisedpoint; made hem archangeles
Tauȝte hem bi þe Trinitee &raisedpoint; treuthe to knowe
To be buxome at his biddyng &raisedpoint; he bad hem nouȝte elles
¶ Lucifer wiþ legiounes &raisedpoint; lerned it in heuene

was caste
out of hea
uen bicause
of hys
pride . Cr1.1.112
lg.l: But for he brake buxumnesse &raisedpoint; his blisse gan he tyne
And fel fro þat felawship &raisedpoint; in a fendes liknes
In-to a depe derke helle &raisedpoint; to dwelle þere for eure
And mo þowsandes wiþ him &raisedpoint; þan man couthe noumbre
Lopen out wiþ Lucifer &raisedpoint; in lothelich forme
For þei leueden vpon hym &raisedpoint; þat lyed in þis manere
Ponam pedem in aquilone &raisedpoint; et similis ero altissimo &raisedpoint;
¶ And alle þat hoped it miȝte be so &raisedpoint; none heuene miȝte hem holde
But fellen out in fendes liknesse &raisedpoint; nyne dayes togideres
Til god of his goodnesse &raisedpoint; gan stable and stynte
And garte þe heuene to stekye &raisedpoint; and stonden in quiete
¶ Whan thise wikked went out &raisedpoint; wonderwise þei fellen
Somme in eyre somme in erthe &raisedpoint; & somme in helle depe
Ac lucifer lowest lith of hem alle &raisedpoint;
For pryde þat he pult out &raisedpoint; his peyne hath none ende
And alle þat worche with wronge &raisedpoint; wenden hij shulle
After her deth-day &raisedpoint; and dwelle wiþ þat shrewe
Ac þo þat worche wel &raisedpoint; as holiwritt telleth
And enden as I ere seide &raisedpoint; in treuthe þat is þe best
Mowe be siker þat her soule &raisedpoint; shal wende to heuene
Þer treuthe is in Trinitee &raisedpoint; and troneth hem alle
For-þi I sey as I seide ere &raisedpoint; bi siȝte of þise textis
Whan alle tresores arne ytried &raisedpoint; treuthe is þe beste
Lereth it þis lewde men &raisedpoint; for lettred men it knowen
lg.marginalia:

sure . Cr1.1.136
lg.l: Þat treuthe is tresore &raisedpoint; þe triest on erþe
¶ Ȝet haue I no kynde knowing quod I &raisedpoint; ȝet mote ȝe kenne me better
By what craft in my corps &raisedpoint; it comseth and where
¶ Þow doted daffe quod she &raisedpoint; dulle arne þi wittes
To litel latyn þow lernedest &raisedpoint; lede in þi ȝouthe
Heu michi quia sterilem duxi vitam iuuenilem
¶ It is a kynde knowyng quod he
For to louye þi lorde &raisedpoint; leuer þan þi-selue
lg.marginalia: # dye rather then do dedly synM1.146
lg.l: No dedly synne to do &raisedpoint; dey þouȝ þow sholdest
This I trowe be treuthe &raisedpoint; who can teche þe better
¶ Loke þow suffre hym to sey &raisedpoint; and sithen lere it after
For thus witnesseth his worde &raisedpoint; worcheth þow þere-after
For trewthe telleþ þat loue &raisedpoint; is triacle of heuene
May no synne be on him sene &raisedpoint; þat vseth þat spise
And alle his werkes he wrouȝte &raisedpoint; with loue as him liste
And lered it Moises for þe leuest þing and moste like to heuene
And also þe plente of pees &raisedpoint; moste precious of vertues
¶ For heuene myȝte nouȝte holden it &raisedpoint; it was so heuy of hym-self
Tyl it hadde of þe erthe &raisedpoint; yeten his fylle
¶ And whan it haued of þis folde flessh & blode taken
Was neuere leef vpon lynde &raisedpoint; liȝter þer-after
And portatyf and persant &raisedpoint; as þe poynt of a nedle
That myȝte non armure it lette &raisedpoint; ne none heiȝ walles
¶ For-þi is loue leder of þe lordes folke of heuene
And a mene as þe Maire is &raisedpoint; bitwene þe kyng and þe comune
Riȝt so is loue a ledere &raisedpoint; and þe lawe shapeth
Vpon man for his mysdedes &raisedpoint; þe merciment he taxeth
And for to knowe it kyndely &raisedpoint; it comseth bi myght

marginalia.note: M1.166, erased word is legible with ultraviolet light.

lg.l: And in þe herte þere is þe heuede &raisedpoint; and þe heiȝ welle
¶ For in kynde knowynge in herte &raisedpoint; þere a myȝte bigynneth
And þat falleth to þe fader &raisedpoint; þat formed vs alle
Loked on vs with loue &raisedpoint; and lete his sone deye
Mekely for owre mysdedes &raisedpoint; to amende vs alle
And ȝet wolde he hem no woo &raisedpoint; þat wrouȝte hym þat peyne
But mekelich with mouthe &raisedpoint; mercy he bisouȝte
To haue pite of þat poeple &raisedpoint; þat peyned hym to deth
¶ Here myȝtow see ensamples &raisedpoint; in hym-selue one
That he was miȝtful & meke &raisedpoint; and mercy gan graunte
To hem þat hongen him an heiȝ &raisedpoint; and his herte þirled
¶ For-thi I rede ȝow riche &raisedpoint; haueth reuthe of þe pouere
Thouȝ ȝe be myȝtful to mote &raisedpoint; beth meke in ȝowre werkes
¶ For þe same mesures þat ȝe mete &raisedpoint; amys other elles
Ȝe shullen ben weyen þer-wyth &raisedpoint; whan ȝe wende hennes
Eadem mensura qua mensi fueritis &raisedpoint; remecietur vobis &raisedpoint;
¶ For þouȝ ȝe be trewe of ȝowre tonge &raisedpoint; and trewliche wynne
And as chaste as a childe &raisedpoint; þat in cherche wepeth
But if ȝe louen lelliche &raisedpoint; and lene þe poure
Such goed as god ȝow sent godelich parteth
Ȝe ne haue na more meryte &raisedpoint; in masse ne in houres
lg.marginalia: off Malkyns maydenhedM1.187, Notabile is in a different hand from the rest of this marginal insertion.
lg.l: Þan Malkyn of hire maydenhode &raisedpoint; þat no man desireth
¶ For Iames þe gentil &raisedpoint; iugged in his bokes
That faith with-oute þe faite &raisedpoint; is riȝte no-þinge worthi
And as ded as a dore-tre &raisedpoint; but ȝif þe dedes folwe
Fides sine operibus mortua est &c
¶ For-thi chastite with-oute charite &raisedpoint; worth cheyned in helle
It is as lewed as a laumpe &raisedpoint; þat no liȝte is Inne
¶ Many chapeleynes arne chaste &raisedpoint; ac charite is awey
Aren no men auarousere þan hij &raisedpoint; whan þei ben auaunced
Vnkynde to her kyn &raisedpoint; and to alle cristene
Chewen here charite &raisedpoint; and chiden after more
Such chastite wiþ-outen charite &raisedpoint; worth cheyned in helle
¶ Many curatoures kepen hem &raisedpoint; clene of here bodies
Thei ben acombred wiþ coueitise &raisedpoint; þei konne nouȝt don it fram hem
So harde hath auarice &raisedpoint; yhasped hem togideres
And þat is no treuthe of þe trinite &raisedpoint; but treccherye of helle
And lernyng to lewde men &raisedpoint; þe latter for to dele
¶ For-þi þis wordes ben &raisedpoint; wryten in þe gospel
Date & dabitur vobis &raisedpoint; for I dele ȝow alle
And þat is þe lokke of loue &raisedpoint; and lateth oute my grace
To conforte þe careful &raisedpoint; acombred wiþ synne
¶ Loue is leche of lyf &raisedpoint; and nexte owre lorde selue
And also þe graith gate &raisedpoint; þat goth in-to heuene
For-þi I sey as I seide &raisedpoint; ere by þe textis
Whan alle tresores ben ytryed &raisedpoint; treuthe is þe beste
Now haue I tolde þe what treuthe is &raisedpoint; þat no tresore is bettere
I may no lenger lenge þe with &raisedpoint; now loke þe owre lorde

div1.head: Passus secundus de visione vt supra

lg.l: Ȝet I courbed on my knees &raisedpoint; and cryed hir of grace
And seide mercy Madame &raisedpoint; for Marie loue of heuene
That bar þat blisful barne &raisedpoint; þat bouȝte vs on þe Rode
Kenne me bi somme crafte &raisedpoint; to knowe þe fals
¶ Loke vppon þi left half &raisedpoint; and lo where he standeth
Bothe fals and fauel &raisedpoint; and here feres manye
¶ I loked on my left half &raisedpoint; as þe lady me taughte
And was war of a womman &raisedpoint; wortheli yclothed
Purfiled with pelure &raisedpoint; þe fynest vpon erthe
Ycrounede with a corone &raisedpoint; þe kyng hath non better
Fetislich hir fyngres &raisedpoint; were fretted with golde wyre
And þere-on red rubyes &raisedpoint; as red as any glede
And diamantz of derrest pris &raisedpoint; and double manere safferes
Orientales and ewages &raisedpoint; enuenymes to destroye
¶ Hire robe was ful riche &raisedpoint; of red scarlet engreyned
With ribanes of red golde &raisedpoint; and of riche stones
Hire arraye me rauysshed &raisedpoint; suche ricchesse saw I neuere
I had wondre what she was &raisedpoint; and whas wyf she were
¶ What is þis womman &raisedpoint; quod I so worthily atired
¶ That is Mede þe Mayde quod she &raisedpoint; hath noyed me ful oft
And ylakked my lemman &raisedpoint; þat lewte is hoten
And bilowen hire to lordes &raisedpoint; þat lawes han to kepe
In þe popis paleys &raisedpoint; she is pryue as my-self
But sothenesse wolde nouȝt so &raisedpoint; for she is a bastarde
¶ For fals was hire fader &raisedpoint; þat hath a fykel tonge
And neuere sothe seide &raisedpoint; sithen he come to erthe
¶ And Mede is manered after hym &raisedpoint; riȝte as kynde axeth
Qualis pater talis filius &raisedpoint; bonus arbor &raisedpoint; bonum fructum facit
I auȝte ben herre þan she &raisedpoint; I cam of a better
¶ Mi fader þe grete god is &raisedpoint; and grounde of alle graces
O god with-oute gynnynge &raisedpoint; & I his gode douȝter
And hath ȝoue me mercy &raisedpoint; to marye with my-self
And what man be merciful &raisedpoint; and lelly me loue
Shal be my lorde and I his leef &raisedpoint; in þe heiȝe heuene
¶ And what man taketh Mede &raisedpoint; myne hed dar I legge
That he shal lese for hir loue &raisedpoint; a lappe of caritatis
how construeth dauid þe kynge &raisedpoint; of men þat taketh Mede
And men of þis molde &raisedpoint; þat meynteneth treuthe
And how ȝe shal saue ȝow-self &raisedpoint; þe Sauter bereth witnesse
Domine quis habitabit in tabernac[u]lo tuo &c
¶ And now worth þis Mede ymaried &raisedpoint; al to a mansed schrewe
To one fals fikel tonge &raisedpoint; a fendes biȝete
Fauel þorw his faire speche &raisedpoint; hath þis folke enchaunted
And al is lyeres ledyng &raisedpoint; þat she is þus ywedded
¶ To-morwe worth ymade &raisedpoint; þe maydenes bruydale
And þere miȝte þow wite &raisedpoint; if þow wolt &raisedpoint; which þei ben alle
That longeth to þat lordeship &raisedpoint; þe lasse and þe more
Knowe hem þere if þow canst &raisedpoint; and kepe þi tonge
And lakke hem nouȝt &raisedpoint; but lat hem worth &raisedpoint; til lewte be iustice
And haue powere to punyschen hem &raisedpoint; þanne put forth þi resoun
¶ Now I bikenne þe criste quod she &raisedpoint; and his clene moder
And lat no conscience acombre þe &raisedpoint; for coueitise of Mede
¶ Thus left me þat lady &raisedpoint; liggyng aslepe
And how Mede was ymaried &raisedpoint; in meteles me þouȝte
Þat alle þe riche retenauns &raisedpoint; þat regneth with þe false
Were boden to þe bridale &raisedpoint; on bothe two sydes
Of alle maner of men &raisedpoint; þe mene and þe riche
To marie þis maydene &raisedpoint; was many man assembled
As of kniȝtes and of clerkis &raisedpoint; and other comune poeple
As sysours and sompnours &raisedpoint; Shireues and here clerkes
Bedelles and Bailliues &raisedpoint; and brokoures of chaffre
Forgoeres and vitaillers &raisedpoint; and vokates of þe arches
I can nouȝt rekene þe route &raisedpoint; þat ran aboute mede
¶ Ac symonye and cyuile &raisedpoint; and sisoures of courtes
Were moste pryue with Mede &raisedpoint; of any men me þouȝte
Ac fauel was þe first &raisedpoint; þat fette hire out of boure
And as a brokour brouȝte hir to be with fals enioigned
Whan symonye and cyuile &raisedpoint; seiȝ here beire wille
Thei assented for siluer &raisedpoint; to se as bothe wolde
Thanne lepe lyer forth &raisedpoint; and seide lo here a chartre
That gyle with his gret othes &raisedpoint; gaf hem togidere
And preide cyuile to se &raisedpoint; and symonye to rede it
Thanne symonye and cyuile &raisedpoint; stonden forth bothe
And vnfoldeth þe feffement &raisedpoint; þat fals hath ymaked
And þus bigynneth þes gomes &raisedpoint; to greden ful heiȝ

lg.l: Sciant presentes & futuri &c &raisedpoint;
¶ Witeth and witnesseth &raisedpoint; þat wonieth vpon þis erthe
Þat Mede is ymaried &raisedpoint; more for here goodis
Þan for ani vertue or fairenesse &raisedpoint; or any free kynde
Falsenesse is faine of hire &raisedpoint; for he wote hire riche
And fauel with his fikel speche &raisedpoint; feffeth bi þis chartre
To be prynces in pryde &raisedpoint; and pouerte to dispise
To bakbite &raisedpoint; and to bosten &raisedpoint; and bere fals witnesse
To scorne and to scolde &raisedpoint; and sclaundere to make
Vnboxome and bolde &raisedpoint; to breke þe ten hestes
¶ And þe Erldome of enuye &raisedpoint; and wratthe togideres
With þe chastelet of chest &raisedpoint; and chateryng oute of resoun
Þe counte of coueitise &raisedpoint; and alle þe costes aboute
That is vsure and auarice &raisedpoint; alle I hem graunte
In bargaines and in brokages &raisedpoint; with al þe borgtheborg[h]e of theft
¶ And al þe lordeship of lecherye &raisedpoint; in lenthe and in brede
As in werkes and in wordes &raisedpoint; and waitynges with eies
And in wedes and in wisshynges &raisedpoint; and with ydel thouȝtes
There as wille ne wolde &raisedpoint; wer[k]manship failleth
¶ Glotonye he gaf hem eke &raisedpoint; and grete othes togydere
And alday to drynke &raisedpoint; at dyuerse tauernes
And there to iangle and to iape &raisedpoint; and iugge here euene-cristene
And in fastyngdayes to frete &raisedpoint; ar ful tyme were
And þanne to sitten and soupen &raisedpoint; til slepe hem assaille
And bredun as burgh-swyn &raisedpoint; and bedden hem esily
Tyl sleuth and slepe &raisedpoint; slyken his sides
lg.marginalia:
Robart Bente you shalbe with vs at
Budworthe and there to Testyfy
youre knowlegh in a materR2.61, secretary hand. This note may explain the cropped margins of the first few pages of the manuscript: someone appears to have been using them for occasional short notes. Budworth probably refers to one of two ancient parishes in Cheshire, Great Budworth and Little Budworth.
lg.l: And þanne wanhope to awake hym so &raisedpoint; with no wille to amende
For he leueth be lost &raisedpoint; þis is here last ende
¶ And þei to haue and to holde &raisedpoint; and here eyres after
A dwellyng with þe deuel &raisedpoint; and dampned be for eure
Wiþ al þe purtenaunces of purgatorie &raisedpoint; in-to þe pyne of helle
Ȝeldyng for þis þinge &raisedpoint; at one ȝeres ende
Here soules to sathan &raisedpoint; to suffre with hym peynes
And with him to wonye with wo &raisedpoint; whil god is in heuene
¶ In witnesse of which þing &raisedpoint; wronge was þe first
And Pieres þe pardonere &raisedpoint; of paulynes doctrine
Bette þe bedel &raisedpoint; of Bokyngham-shire
Rainalde þe Reue &raisedpoint; of Rotland sokene
Munde þe Mellere &raisedpoint; and many moo other
In þe date of þe deuel þis dede I assele
Bi siȝte of sire symonye &raisedpoint; and cyuyles leue
¶ Þenne tened hym theologye &raisedpoint; whan he þis tale herde
And seide to cyuile &raisedpoint; now sorwe mot þow haue
Such we[d]dynges to worche to wratthe with treuthe
And ar þis weddyng be wrouȝte &raisedpoint; wo þe bityde
¶ For Mede is moylere &raisedpoint; of amendes engendreth
And god graunteth to gyf &raisedpoint; Mede to treuthe
And þow hast gyuen hire to a gyloure &raisedpoint; now god gyf þe sorwe
Thi tixt telleth þe nouȝt so &raisedpoint; treuthe wote þe sothe
lg.marginalia: Luke x. Who it is that shameth holy church.Cr3.2.125
lg.l: For dignus est operarius &raisedpoint; his hyre to haue
And þow hast fest hire to fals &raisedpoint; fy on þi lawe
For al by lesynges þow lyuest &raisedpoint; and lecherouse werkes
Symonye and þi-self &raisedpoint; schenden holicherche
Þe notaries and ȝee &raisedpoint; noyeth þe peple
Ȝe shul abiggen it bothe &raisedpoint; bi god þat me made
Wel ȝe witen wernardes &raisedpoint; but if ȝowre witte faille
That fals is faithlees &raisedpoint; and fikel in his werkes
And was a bastarde ybore &raisedpoint; of belsabubbes kynne
And Mede is moylere &raisedpoint; a mayden of gode
And myȝte kisse þe kynge &raisedpoint; for cosyn an she wolde
¶ For-þi worcheth bi wisdome &raisedpoint; and bi witt also
And ledeth hire to londoun &raisedpoint; þere lawe is yshewed
If any lawe wil loke &raisedpoint; þei ligge togederes
And þouȝ Iustices iugge hir &raisedpoint; to be ioigned with fals
Ȝet beth war of weddyng &raisedpoint; for witty is truthe &raisedpoint;
And conscience is of his conseille &raisedpoint; and knoweth ȝow vchone
And if he fynde ȝow in defaute &raisedpoint; and with þe fals holde
It shal bisitte ȝowre soules &raisedpoint; ful soure atte laste
¶ Here-to assenteth cyuile &raisedpoint; ac symonye ne wolde
Tyl he had siluer for his seruise &raisedpoint; and also þe notaries
¶ Thanne fette fauel forth &raisedpoint; floreynes ynowe
And bad gyle to gyue &raisedpoint; golde al aboute
And namelich to þe notaries &raisedpoint; þat hem none ne faille
And feffe false witnes &raisedpoint; with floreines ynowe
For he may mede amaistrye &raisedpoint; and maken at my wille
¶ Tho þis golde was gyue &raisedpoint; grete was þe þonkynge
To fals and to fauel &raisedpoint; for her faire ȝiftes
And comen to conforte fram care þe fals
And seiden certis sire &raisedpoint; cesse shal we neuere
Til Mede be þi wedded wyf &raisedpoint; þorw wittis of vs alle
For we haue Mede amaistried &raisedpoint; with owre mery speche
That she graunteth to gon with a gode wille
To Londoun to loke &raisedpoint; ȝif þat þe lawe wolde
Iugge ȝow ioyntly &raisedpoint; in ioye for euere
¶ Thanne was falsenesse fayne &raisedpoint; and fauel as blithe
And leten sompne alle segges &raisedpoint; in schires aboute
And bad hem alle be bown &raisedpoint; beggeres and othere

lg.l: To wenden wyth hem to westmynstre &raisedpoint; to witnesse þis dede

lg.marginalia: What horses thei þat rid wyth mede hadCr3.2.164
lg.l: ¶ Ac þanne cared þei for caplus &raisedpoint; to kairen hem þider
And fauel fette forth þanne &raisedpoint; folus ynowe
And sette Mede vpon a schyreue &raisedpoint; shodde al newe
And fals sat on a sisoure &raisedpoint; þat softlich trotted
And fauel on a flatere &raisedpoint; fetislich atired
¶ Tho haued notaries none &raisedpoint; annoyed þei were
For symonye and cyuile &raisedpoint; shulde on hire fete gange
¶ Ac þanne swore symonye &raisedpoint; and cyuile bothe
That sompnoures shulde be sadled and serue hem vchone
And lat apparaille þis prouisoures &raisedpoint; in palfreis wyse
Sire symonye hym-seluen &raisedpoint; shal sitte vpon here bakkes

lg.marginalia: TomthR2.133. Between R2.133 and 134 (KD2.172 and 173) is what seems to be a pen trial of uncertain age
lg.l: ¶ Denes and suddenes &raisedpoint; drawe ȝow togideres
Erchdekenes and officiales &raisedpoint; and alle ȝowre Regystreres
Lat sadel hem with siluer &raisedpoint; owre synne to suffre
As auoutrie and deuoses &raisedpoint; and derne vsurye
To bere bischopes aboute &raisedpoint; abrode in visytynge
¶ Paulynes pryues &raisedpoint; for pleyntes in þe consistorie
Shul serue my-self &raisedpoint; þat cyuile is nempned
And cartesadel þe comissarie &raisedpoint; owre carte shal he lede
And fecchen vs vytailles &raisedpoint; at fornicatores
¶ And maketh of lyer a longe carte &raisedpoint; to lede alle þese othere
As Freres and faitours &raisedpoint; þat on here fete rennen
And thus fals and fauel &raisedpoint; fareth forth togideres
And Mede in þe myddes &raisedpoint; and alle þise men after
¶ I haue no tome to telle þe taille þat hem folweth
Of many maner man &raisedpoint; þat on þis molde libbeth
lg.marginalia: Trueth maketh haste to þe kynge.Cr3.2.190
John naylleR2.149. A sixteenth-century secretary hand: signature written vertically upwards
lg.l: Ac gyle was forgoer &raisedpoint; and gyed hem alle
¶ Sothenesse seiȝ hym wel &raisedpoint; and seide but a litel
And priked his palfrey &raisedpoint; and passed hem alle
And come to þe kynges courte &raisedpoint; and conscience it tolde
And conscience to þe kynge &raisedpoint; carped it after

lg.marginalia: # quo modo Rex Iurauit punicionem maleffactorumM2.195
lg.l: ¶ Now by cryst quod þe kynge &raisedpoint; and I cacche myȝte
Fals or fauel &raisedpoint; or any of his feres
I wolde be wroke of þo wrecches &raisedpoint; þat worcheth so ille
And don hem hange by þe hals &raisedpoint; and alle þat hem meynteneth
Shal neure man of molde &raisedpoint; meynprise þe leste
But riȝte as þe lawe wil loke &raisedpoint; late falle on hem alle
¶ And comanded a constable &raisedpoint; þat come atte furst
To attache þo tyrauntz &raisedpoint; for eny thynge I hote
And fettereth fast falsenesse &raisedpoint; for enykynnes ȝiftes
And gurdeth of gyles hed &raisedpoint; and lat hym go no furthere
And ȝif ȝe lacche lyer &raisedpoint; late hym nouȝt ascapen
Er he be put on þe pilorye &raisedpoint; for eny preyere &raisedpoint; I hote
And bryngeth Mede to me &raisedpoint; maugre hem alle
¶ Drede atte dore stode &raisedpoint; and þe dome herde
lg.marginalia: # drede stetit ad hostium & audiuit mandatum Regis
lg.l: And how þe kynge comaunded &raisedpoint; constables and seriantz
Falsenesse and his felawschip &raisedpoint; to fettren an to bynden
Þanne drede went wiȝtliche &raisedpoint; and warned þe fals
And bad hym flee for fere &raisedpoint; and his felawes alle

marginalia.note: The symbol for a musical note to represent nota. Same in other margin.

lg.marginalia:
how falsnesse
fley to þe freris.O2.212. The two lines of the rubric are connected by a bracket on the right.
lg.l: ¶ Falsenesse for fere þanne &raisedpoint; fleiȝ to þe freres
And gyle doþ hym to go &raisedpoint; agast for to dye
Ac marchantz mette with hym &raisedpoint; and made hym abide
And bishetten hym in here shope &raisedpoint; to shewen here ware
And apparailled hym as a prentice &raisedpoint; þe poeple to serue
¶ Liȝtlich lyer &raisedpoint; lepe awey þanne
Lorkynge thorw lanes &raisedpoint; to-lugged of manye
He was nawhere welcome &raisedpoint; for his manye tales
Ouer al yhowted &raisedpoint; and yhote trusse
Tyl pardoneres haued pite &raisedpoint; and pulled hym in-to house
They wesshen hym and wyped hym &raisedpoint; and wonden hym in cloutes
And sente hym with seles &raisedpoint; on sondayes to cherches
And gaf pardoun for pens &raisedpoint; poundmel aboute
¶ Thanne loured leches &raisedpoint; and lettres þei sent
Þat he sholde wonye with hem &raisedpoint; wateres to loke
Spiceres spoke with hym &raisedpoint; to spien here ware
For he couth of here craft &raisedpoint; and knewe many gommes
¶Ac mynst[r]alles and messageres &raisedpoint; mette with hym ones
And helden hym an halfȝere &raisedpoint; and elleuene dayes
¶ Freres with faire speche &raisedpoint; fetten hym þennes
And for knowyng of comeres &raisedpoint; coped hym as a frere
Ac he hath leue to lepe out &raisedpoint; as oft as hym liketh
And is welcome whan he wil &raisedpoint; and woneth wyth hem oft
¶ Alle fledden for fere &raisedpoint; and flowen in-to hernes
Saue Mede þe Mayde &raisedpoint; na mo durst abide
Ac trewli to telle &raisedpoint; she trembled for drede
And ek wept and wronge &raisedpoint; whan she was attached

lg.marginalia: The king wil know of Mede whom she loueth best.
lg.l: Now is Mede þe Maide &raisedpoint; and namo of hem alle
With bedellus & wiþ bayllyues &raisedpoint; brouȝt bifor þe kyng
The kyng called a clerke &raisedpoint; can I nouȝt his name
To take Mede þe mayde &raisedpoint; and make hire at ese
I shal assaye hir my-self &raisedpoint; and sothelich appose
What man of þis molde &raisedpoint; þat hire were leueste
And if she worche bi my witte &raisedpoint; and my wille folwe
I wil forgyue hir þis gilte &raisedpoint; so me god help
¶ Curteysliche þe clerke þanne as þe Kyng hight
Toke Mede bi þe Middel &raisedpoint; and brouȝte hir in-to chaumbre
And þere was myrthe and mynstralcye &raisedpoint; Mede to plese
¶ They þat wonyeth in westmynstre &raisedpoint; worschiped hir alle
Gentelliche wiþ ioye &raisedpoint; þe Iustices somme
Busked hem to þe boure &raisedpoint; þere þe birde dwelled
To conforte hire kyndely &raisedpoint; by clergise leue
And seiden mourne nought Mede &raisedpoint; ne make þow no sorwe
For we wisse þe kynge &raisedpoint; and þi wey shape
To be wedded at þi wille &raisedpoint; and where þe leue liketh
For al conscience caste &raisedpoint; or craft as I trowe
¶ Mildeliche Mede þanne &raisedpoint; mercyed hem alle
Of þeire gret goodnesse &raisedpoint; and gaf hem vchone
Coupes of clene golde &raisedpoint; and coppis of siluer
Rynges with rubies &raisedpoint; and ricchesses manye
The leste man of here meyne &raisedpoint; a motoun of golde
Thanne lauȝte þei leue &raisedpoint; þis lordes at Mede
¶ With that comen clerkis &raisedpoint; to conforte hir þe same
And beden hire be blithe &raisedpoint; for we beth þine owne
Forto worche þi wille &raisedpoint; þe while þow myȝte laste
Hendeliche heo þanne &raisedpoint; bihight hem þe same
To loue ȝow lelli &raisedpoint; and lordes to make
And in þe consistorie atte courte &raisedpoint; do calle ȝowre names
Shal no lewdnesse lette &raisedpoint; þe leode þat I louye
That he ne worth first auanced &raisedpoint; for I am biknowen
Þere konnyng clerkes &raisedpoint; shul clokke bihynde
¶ Þanne come þere a confessoure &raisedpoint; coped as a Frere
To Mede þe mayde &raisedpoint; he mellud þis wordes
And seide ful softly &raisedpoint; in shrifte as it were
Theiȝ lewed men &raisedpoint; and lered men &raisedpoint; had leyne by þe bothe
And falsenesse haued yfolwed þe al þis fyfty wyntre
I shal assoille þe my-selue &raisedpoint; for a seme of whete
And also be þi bedeman &raisedpoint; and bere wel þi message
Amonges kniȝtes and clerkis &raisedpoint; conscience to torne
¶ Thanne Mede for here mysdedes &raisedpoint; to þat man kneled
And shroue hire of hire shrewednesse &raisedpoint; shamelees I trowe
Tolde hym a tale &raisedpoint; and toke hym a noble
Forto ben hire bedeman &raisedpoint; and hire brokour als
¶ Thanne he assoilled hir sone &raisedpoint; and sithen he seyde
We han a wyndowe a-wirchyng wil sitten vs wel heigh
Woldestow glase þat gable &raisedpoint; and graue þere-inne þi name
Siker sholde þi soule be &raisedpoint; heuene to haue
Wist I that quod þat womman &raisedpoint; I wolde nouȝt spare
For to be ȝowre frende frere &raisedpoint; and faille ȝow neure
Whil ȝe loue lordes &raisedpoint; þat lechery haunteþ
And lakkeþ nouȝt ladis &raisedpoint; þat loueþ wel þe same
It is a frelete of flesche &raisedpoint; ȝe fynde it in bokes
And a course of kynde &raisedpoint; wher-of we komen alle
Who may scape þe sklaundre &raisedpoint; þe skaþe is sone amended
It is synne of seuene &raisedpoint; sonnest relessed
¶ Haue mercy quod Mede &raisedpoint; of men þat it haunte
And I shal keure ȝowre kirke &raisedpoint; ȝowre cloystre do maken
Wowes do whitten &raisedpoint; and wyndowes glasen
Do peynten and purtraye &raisedpoint; and paye for þe makynge
That eury segge shal seyn &raisedpoint; I am sustre of ȝowre hous
¶ Ac god to alle good folke &raisedpoint; suche grauynge defendeth
To writen in wyndowes &raisedpoint; of here wel-dedes
On auenture pruyde be peynted þere &raisedpoint; and pompe of þe worlde
For crist knoweþ þi conscience &raisedpoint; and þi kynde wille
And þi coste and þi coueitise &raisedpoint; and who þe catel ouȝte
¶ For-þi I lere ȝow lordes &raisedpoint; leueþ suche werkes
To writen in wyndowes &raisedpoint; of ȝowre wel-dedes
Or to greden after goddis men &raisedpoint; whan ȝe delen doles
An auenture ȝe han ȝowre hire here &raisedpoint; and ȝoure heuene als
Nesciat sinistra quid faciat dextra &raisedpoint;
Lat nouȝte þi left half &raisedpoint; late no rathe
Wyte what þow worchest &raisedpoint; with þi riȝt syde
For þus bit þe gospel &raisedpoint; gode men do here almesse
¶ Meires and maceres &raisedpoint; that menes ben bitwene
Þe kynge and þe comune to kepe þe lawes
To punyschen on pillories &raisedpoint; and pynynge stoles
Brewesteres and bakesteres &raisedpoint; bocheres and cokes
lg.marginalia: What harme yll vitiliers do & what abuseis in regrating.Cr3.3.82
lg.l: For þise aren men on þis molde &raisedpoint; þat moste harme worcheth
To þe pore peple þat parcel-mele buggen
¶ For they poysoun þe peple &raisedpoint; priueliche and oft
Thei rychen þorw regraterye &raisedpoint; and rentes hem buggen
With þat þe pore people shulde put in here wombe
For toke þei on trewly &raisedpoint; þei tymbred nouȝt so heiȝe
Ne bouȝte non burgages &raisedpoint; be ȝe ful certeyne
¶ Ac Mede þe Mayde þe Maire hath bisouȝte
Of alle suche sellers &raisedpoint; syluer to take
Or presentz withoute pens &raisedpoint; as peces of siluer
Ringes or other ricchesse &raisedpoint; þe regrateres to maynetene
¶ For my loue quod that lady loue hem vchone
And soffre hem to selle &raisedpoint; somdele aȝeins resoun
¶ Salamon þe sage &raisedpoint; a sarmoun he made
For to amende Maires &raisedpoint; and men þat kepen lawes
And tolde hem þis teme &raisedpoint; þat I telle thynke
Ignis deuorabit tabernacula eorum qui libenter accipiunt munera &c
Amonge þis lettered ledes &raisedpoint; þis latyn is to mene
That fyre shal falle and berne &raisedpoint; al to blo askes
The houses and þe homes &raisedpoint; of hem [þat] desireth
Ȝiftes or ȝeresȝyues &raisedpoint; bi-cause of here offices
¶ The kynge fro conseille cam &raisedpoint; and called after Mede
And ofsent hir alswythe &raisedpoint; with seriauntes manye
That brouȝten hir to bowre &raisedpoint; with blisse and with ioye
¶ Curteisliche þe kynge þanne &raisedpoint; comsed to telle
To Mede þe mayde &raisedpoint; melleth þise wordes
Vnwittily womman &raisedpoint; wrouȝte hastow oft
Ac worse wrouȝtestow neure &raisedpoint; þan þo þow fals toke
But I forgyue þat gilte &raisedpoint; and graunte þe my grace
Hennes to þi deth-day &raisedpoint; do so namore

lg.marginalia: # vtrum Mede vult maritare cum conciencieM3.111
lg.l: ¶ I haue a knyȝte conscience &raisedpoint; cam late fro biȝunde
Ȝif he wilneth þe to wyf &raisedpoint; wyltow hym haue
¶ Ȝe lorde quod þat lady &raisedpoint; lorde forbede elles
But I be holely at ȝowre heste &raisedpoint; lat hange me sone
¶ And þanne was conscience calde &raisedpoint; to come and appiere
Bifor þe Kynge and his conseille &raisedpoint; as clerkes and othere
Knelynge conscience &raisedpoint; to þe kynge louted
To wite what his wille were &raisedpoint; and what he do shulde
¶ Woltow wedde þis womman quod þe kynge &raisedpoint; ȝif I wil assente
For she is fayne of þi felawship &raisedpoint; for to be þi make

lg.marginalia: Conscience forsaketh Mede for hir euyll condition.Cr3.3.122
lg.l: ¶ Quod conscience to þe kynge &raisedpoint; cryst it me forbede
lg.marginalia: # Consciencie contradicit matrimonium et accusat MedeM3.122
lg.l: Ar I wedde suche a wyf &raisedpoint; wo me bityde
For she is frele of hir feith &raisedpoint; fykel of here speche
And maketh men &raisedpoint; mysdo &raisedpoint; many score tymes
Truste of hire tresore &raisedpoint; treieth ful manye
Wyues and widewes &raisedpoint; wantounes she techeth
And lereth hem leccherye &raisedpoint; that loueth hire ȝiftes
Ȝowre fadre she felled &raisedpoint; þorw fals biheste
And hath apoysounde popis &raisedpoint; peired holicherche
Is nauȝt a better baude &raisedpoint; bi hym þat me made
Bitwene heuene and helle &raisedpoint; in erthe þough men souȝte
For she is tikil of hire taile &raisedpoint; talwis of hir tonge
As comune as a cartwey &raisedpoint; to eche a knaue þat walketh
To monkes to mynst[r]alles &raisedpoint; to meseles in hegges
Sisoures and sompnoures &raisedpoint; suche men hir preiseth
Shireues of shires &raisedpoint; were shent ȝif she nere
For she doþ men lese here londe &raisedpoint; and here lyf bothe
She leteth passe prisoneres &raisedpoint; and payeth for hem ofte
And gyueth þe gailers golde &raisedpoint; and grotes togideres
To vnfettre þe fals fle where hym lyketh
And takeþ þe trewe bi þe toppe &raisedpoint; and tieth hym faste
And hangeth hym for hatred &raisedpoint; þat harme dede neure
¶ To be cursed in consistorie &raisedpoint; she counteth nouȝte a russhe
For she copeth þe comissarie &raisedpoint; and coteth his clerkis
She is assoilled as sone &raisedpoint; as hir-self liketh
And may neiȝe as moche do &raisedpoint; in a moneth one
As ȝowre secret seel &raisedpoint; in syx score dayes
For she is priue with þe pope &raisedpoint; prouisoures it knoweth
For sire symonye and hir-selue &raisedpoint; seleth hire bulles
¶ She blesseth þise bisshopes &raisedpoint; þeiȝe þey be lewed
Prouendreth persones &raisedpoint; and prestes meynteneth
To haue lemmannes and lotebies &raisedpoint; alle here lif-dayes
And bringen forth barnes &raisedpoint; aȝein forbode lawes
There she is wel with þe kynge &raisedpoint; wo is þe rewme
For she is fauorable to þe fals &raisedpoint; and fouleth trewthe ofte
¶ Bi ihesus with here ieweles &raisedpoint; ȝowre iustices she shendeth
And lith aȝein þe lawe &raisedpoint; and letteth hym þe gate
That feith may nouȝte haue his forth &raisedpoint; here floreines go so þikke
She ledeth þe lawe as hire list &raisedpoint; and louedayes maketh
And doth men lese þorw hire loue &raisedpoint; þat lawe myȝte wynne
Þe mase for a mene man &raisedpoint; þouȝ he mote hir eure
Lawe is so lordeliche &raisedpoint; and loth to make ende
With-oute presentz or pens &raisedpoint; she pleseth wel fewe
¶ Barounes and burgeys &raisedpoint; she bryngeth in sorwe
And alle þe comune in kare &raisedpoint; þat coueyten lyue in trewthe
For clergye and coueitise &raisedpoint; she coupleth togideres
Þis is þe lyf of that lady &raisedpoint; now lorde ȝif hir sorwe
And alle that meynteneth here men &raisedpoint; meschaunce hem bityde
For pore men mowe haue no powere &raisedpoint; to pleyne hem þouȝ þei smerte
Suche a maistre is Mede &raisedpoint; amonge men of gode
¶ Thanne morned Mede &raisedpoint; and mened hire to the kynge
To haue space to speke &raisedpoint; spede if she myȝte
¶ The kynge graunted hir grace with a gode wille
Excuse þe ȝif þow canst &raisedpoint; I can namore seggen
For conscience acuseth þe &raisedpoint; to congey þe for euere
¶ Nay lorde quod þat lady &raisedpoint; leueth hym þe worse
Whan ȝe wyten witterly &raisedpoint; where þe wronge liggeth
There þat myschief is grete &raisedpoint; Mede may helpe
And þow knowest conscience &raisedpoint; I cam nouȝt to chide
Ne depraue þi persone &raisedpoint; with a proude herte
Wel þow wost wernard &raisedpoint; but ȝif þow wolt gabbe
Þow hast hanged on myne half &raisedpoint; elleuene tymes
And also griped my golde &raisedpoint; gyue it where þe liked
And whi þow wratthest þe now &raisedpoint; wonder me thynketh
Ȝit I may as I myȝte &raisedpoint; menske þe with ȝiftes
And mayntene þi manhode &raisedpoint; more þan þow knoweste
¶ Ac þow hast famed me foule &raisedpoint; bifor þe Kynge here
For kulled I neuere no kynge &raisedpoint; ne conseilled þer-after
Ne dede as þow demest &raisedpoint; I do on þe kynge

lg.marginalia: Mede reherseth what she hath doneCr3.3.192
lg.l: ¶ In normandye was he nouȝte &raisedpoint; noyed for my sake
Ac þow þi-self sothely &raisedpoint; shamedest hym ofte
Crope in-to a kaban &raisedpoint; for colde of þi nailles
Wendest þat wyntre &raisedpoint; wolde haue lasted euere
And draddest to be ded &raisedpoint; for a dym cloude
And hiedest homeward &raisedpoint; for hunger of þi wombe
¶ Wiþ-out pite piloure &raisedpoint; pore men þow robbedest
And bere here bras at þi bakke &raisedpoint; to caleys to selle
There I lafte with my lorde &raisedpoint; his lyf for to saue
I made his men meri &raisedpoint; and mornyng lette
I batered hem on þe bakke &raisedpoint; and bolded here hertis
And dede hem hoppe for hope &raisedpoint; to haue me at wille
Had I ben Marschal of his men &raisedpoint; bi Marie of heuene
I durst haue leyde my lyf &raisedpoint; and no lasse wedde
He shulde haue be lorde of þat londe &raisedpoint; a lengthe and a brede
And also Kyng of þat kitthe &raisedpoint; his kynne for to helpe
Þe leste brolle of his blode &raisedpoint; a barounes pere
¶ Cowardliche þow conscience &raisedpoint; conseiledest hym þennes
To leuen his lordeship &raisedpoint; for a litel siluer
That is þe richest rewme &raisedpoint; þat reyne ouer-houeth
¶ It bicometh to a kynge &raisedpoint; þat kepeth a rewme
To ȝiue Mede to men &raisedpoint; þat mekelich hym serueth
lg.marginalia: Mede telleth how neadful she is to all men.Cr3.3.214
lg.l: To alienes and to alle men to honoure hem with ȝiftes
Mede maketh hym biloued &raisedpoint; and for a man holden
Emperoures and Erlis &raisedpoint; and al manere lordes
for ȝiftes han ȝonge men &raisedpoint; to renne and to ride
The pope and alle prelatis &raisedpoint; presentz vnderfongen
And medeth men hem-seluen &raisedpoint; to meyntene here lawes
Seruauntz for her seruise &raisedpoint; we seth wel þe sothe
Taken Mede of here maistre &raisedpoint; as þei mowe acorde
Beggeres for here biddynge &raisedpoint; bidden men Mede
Mynstralles for here murthe &raisedpoint; mede þei aske
Þe kynge hath mede of his men &raisedpoint; to make pees in londe
Men þat teche chyldren &raisedpoint; craue of hem mede
Prestis þat precheth þe poeple &raisedpoint; to gode asken mede
And masse-pans and here mete &raisedpoint; at þe mele-tymes
Alkynnes crafty men &raisedpoint; crauen Mede for here prentis
Marchauntz and Mede &raisedpoint; mote nede go togideres
No wiȝte as I wene &raisedpoint; with-oute Mede may libbe
¶ Quatȝ þe kynge to conscience &raisedpoint; bi criste as me thynketh
Mede is wel worthi &raisedpoint; þe maistrye to haue

lg.marginalia: Conscience telleth þe king of . ii maner of Medes.Cr3.3.233
lg.l: ¶ Nay quod conscience to þe Kynge &raisedpoint; and kneled to þe erthe
lg.marginalia: Ther ar ijtwo maner of medes
lg.l: There aren two manere of Medes &raisedpoint; my lorde with ȝowre leue

marginalia.note: R3.223. Brown contemporary hand, extending R3.223-225 (KD3.232-234).

lg.l: Þat one god of his grace &raisedpoint; graunteth in his blisse
To þo þat wel worchen &raisedpoint; whil þei ben here
The prophete precheth þer-of &raisedpoint; and put it in þe sautere
Domine quis habitabit in tabernaculo tuo
Lorde who shal wonye in þi wones &raisedpoint; and with þine holi seyntes
Or resten on þi holy hilles &raisedpoint; þis asketh dauid
¶ And dauyd assoileth it hym-self as þe sauter telleth
lg.marginalia: psal xivR3.230, citation by early reader.
lg.l: Qui ingreditur sine macula &raisedpoint; & operatur iusticiam
Tho þat entren of o colour &raisedpoint; and of on wille
And han wrouȝte werkis &raisedpoint; with riȝte and with reson
And he þat ne vseth nauȝte &raisedpoint; þe lyf of vsurye
And enfourmeth pore men &raisedpoint; and pursueth treuthe
Qui pecuniam suam non dedit ad vsuram & munera super innocentem &c &raisedpoint;
And alle þat helpeth þe innocent &raisedpoint; and halt with þe riȝtful
Withoute mede doth hem gode &raisedpoint; and þe trewthe helpeth
lg.marginalia: RichardR3.238-244 (KD3.244-250). A sixteenth-century secretary hand, pen trial, written vertically downward
lg.l: Suche manere men my lorde &raisedpoint; shal haue þis furst Mede
Of god at a grete nede &raisedpoint; whan þei gone hennes
There is an other Mede mesurelees &raisedpoint; þat maistres desireth
To meyntene mysdoers &raisedpoint; Mede þei take
And þere-of seith þe sauter &raisedpoint; in a salmes ende
In quorum manibus iniquitates sunt dextera eorum repleta est muneribus
And he þat gripeth her golde &raisedpoint; so me god helpe
Shal abie it bittere &raisedpoint; or þe boke lyeth
¶ Prestes and parsones &raisedpoint; þat plesynge desireth
That taketh Mede and mone &raisedpoint; for messes þat þei syngeth
Taketh here mede here &raisedpoint; as Mathew vs techeth
Amen amen recipiebant mercedem suam &raisedpoint;
¶ That laboreres and lowe folke &raisedpoint; taketh of her maistres
It is no manere Mede &raisedpoint; but a mesurable hire
In marchandise is no mede &raisedpoint; I may it wel avowe
It is a permutacioun apertly &raisedpoint; a penyworth for an othre
¶ Ac reddestow neuere Regum &raisedpoint; þow recrayed Mede
lg.marginalia: sauvleG4.265, u and v added by hand 1.1. Initial <s> of original saul is cropped.
lg.l: Whi þe veniaunce fel &raisedpoint; on saul and on his children
God sent to saul &raisedpoint; bi samuel þe prophete
Þat agag of amaleke &raisedpoint; and al his peple aftre
Shulde deye for a dede &raisedpoint; þat done had here aldres
¶ For-þi seid samuel to saul &raisedpoint; god hym-self hoteth
The &raisedpoint; be boxome at his biddynge &raisedpoint; his wille to fulfille
Wende to amalec with þyn oste &raisedpoint; and what þow fyndest þere slee it
Biernes and bestes &raisedpoint; brenne hem to ded
Wydwes and wyues &raisedpoint; wommen and children
Moebles and vnmoebles &raisedpoint; and al þat þow myȝte fynde
Brenne it bere it nouȝte awey &raisedpoint; be it neuere so riche
For mede ne for mone &raisedpoint; loke þow destruye it
Spille it and spare it nouȝte &raisedpoint; þow shalt spede þe bettere
¶ And for he coueyted her catel &raisedpoint; and þe kynge spared
Forbare hym and his bestes bothe &raisedpoint; as þe bible witnesseth
Otherwyse þan he was &raisedpoint; warned of þe prophete
God seide to samuel þat saul shulde deye
And al his sede for þat synne &raisedpoint; shenfullich ende
Such a myschief Mede made saul þe kynge to haue
That god hated hym for euere &raisedpoint; and alle his eyres after
¶ The culorum of þis cas &raisedpoint; kepe I nouȝte to shewe
An auenture it noyed men &raisedpoint; none ende wil I make
For so is þis worlde went &raisedpoint; wiþ hem þat han powere
That who-so seyth hem sothes &raisedpoint; is sonnest yblamed

lg.marginalia: This is no prophecy, but a resonable gathering.Cr3.3.291

kynde wytt techeth
consyenceL3.289, 16th C hand entered the gloss in the left margin.
lg.l: ¶ I conscience knowe þis &raisedpoint; for kynde witt me it tauȝte
Þat resoun shal regne &raisedpoint; and rewmes gouerne
And riȝte as agag hadde &raisedpoint; happe shul somme
Samuel shal sleen hym &raisedpoint; and saul shal be blamed
And dauid shal be diademed &raisedpoint; and daunten hem alle
And one cristene Kynge &raisedpoint; kepen hem alle
¶ Shal namore Mede &raisedpoint; be maistre as she is nouthe
lg.marginalia: IR3.286, probably an I or Q in this hand, though it is unclear what it signifies.
lg.l: Ac loue and lowenesse &raisedpoint; and lewte togederes
Þise shul be maistres on molde &raisedpoint; treuthe to saue
¶ And who-so trespasseth ayein treuthe &raisedpoint; or taketh aȝein his wille
Leute shal don hym lawe &raisedpoint; and no lyf elles
Shal no seriaunt for here seruyse &raisedpoint; were a silke howue
Ne no pelure in his cloke &raisedpoint; for pledyng atte barre
Mede of mys-doeres &raisedpoint; maketh many lordes
And ouer lordes lawes &raisedpoint; reuleth þe rewmes
¶ Ac kynde loue shal come ȝit &raisedpoint; and conscience togideres
lg.marginalia: Thys is no prophecye, but a [?] of the scriptures.Cr3.3.307
lg.l: And make of lawe a laborere &raisedpoint; suche loue shal arise
And such a pees amonge þe peple &raisedpoint; and a parfit trewthe
Þat iewes shal wene in here witte &raisedpoint; and waxen wonder glade
Þat Moises or Messie &raisedpoint; be come in-to þis erthe
And haue wonder in here hertis &raisedpoint; þat men beth so trewe
¶ Alle þat bereth baslarde brode swerde or launce
Axe [o]ther hachet &raisedpoint; or eny wepne ellis
Shal be demed to þe deth &raisedpoint; but if he do it smythye
In-to sikul or to sithe &raisedpoint; to schare or to kulter
Conflabunt gladios suos in vomeres &c
Eche man to pleye with a plow &raisedpoint; pykoys or spade
Spynne or sprede donge &raisedpoint; or spille hym-self with sleuthe
¶ Prestes and parsones &raisedpoint; with placebo to hunte
And dyngen vpon dauid &raisedpoint; eche a day til eue
lg.marginalia: # prestes to lese ther beneffys For huntyngM3.319
lg.l: Huntynge or haukynge &raisedpoint; if any of hem vse
His boste of his benefys &raisedpoint; worth bynome hym after
Shal neither kynge ne knyȝte constable ne Meire
Ouer-lede þe comune &raisedpoint; ne to þe courte sompne
Ne put hem in panel &raisedpoint; to don hem pliȝte here treuthe
But after þe dede þat is don &raisedpoint; one dome shal rewarde
Mercy or no mercy &raisedpoint; as treuthe wil acorde

lg.marginalia: [flag-like design]G4.326. This sign also appears in the Table of Contents see f.101v and is clearly intended to enable the reader to find the passage referred to in the Table. As Benson and Blanchfield observe (Manuscripts, 42) there is a tendency for such marks to occur next to references to prophecy.
lg.l: ¶ Kynges courte and comune courte &raisedpoint; consistorie and chapitele
Al shal be but one courte &raisedpoint; and one baroun be iustice
Thanne worth trewe tonge a tidy man &raisedpoint; þat tened me neuere
Batailles shal non be &raisedpoint; ne no man bere wepne
And what smyth &raisedpoint; þat ony smyteth &raisedpoint; be smyte þer-with to dethe
Non leuabit gens contra gentem gladium &c &raisedpoint;
¶ And er þis fortune falle fynde men shal þe worste
lg.marginalia: # propheciam de vj sunnis & a shipM3.333
lg.l: By syx sonnes and a schippe &raisedpoint; and half a shef of arwes
And þe myddel of a mone &raisedpoint; shal make þe iewes to torne
And saracenes for þat siȝte &raisedpoint; shulle synge gloria in excelsis &c
For Makomet & Mede &raisedpoint; myshappe shal þat tyme
For melius est bonum nomen quam diuicie multe
¶ Also wroth as þe wynde &raisedpoint; wex Mede in a while
I can no latyn quod she &raisedpoint; clerkis wote þe sothe
Se what salamon seith in sapience bokes
That hij þat ȝiueth ȝiftes &raisedpoint; þe victorie wynneth
& moche worschip had þer-with &raisedpoint; as holiwryt telleth
Honorem adquiret qui dat munera &c
¶ I leue wel lady quod conscience &raisedpoint; þat þi latyne be trewe
lg.marginalia: That scripture should be read whole. i.I ell .v.Cr3.3.347
lg.l: Ac þow art like a lady &raisedpoint; þat redde a lessoun ones
Was omnia probate &raisedpoint; and þat plesed here herte
For þat lyne was no lenger atte leues ende
Had ȝe loked þat other half &raisedpoint; and þe lef torned
Ȝe shulde haue founden fele wordis &raisedpoint; folwyng þer-after
Quod bonum est tenete &raisedpoint; treuthe þat texte made
¶ And so ferde ȝe madame &raisedpoint; ȝe couthe namore fynde
Tho ȝe loked on sapience &raisedpoint; sittynge in ȝoure studie
Þis tixte þat ȝe han tolde &raisedpoint; were gode for lordes
Ac ȝow failled a cunnyng clerke &raisedpoint; þat couthe þe lef haue torned
And if ȝe seche sapience eft &raisedpoint; fynde shal ȝe þat folweth
A ful teneful tixte &raisedpoint; to hem þat taketh Mede
And þat is animam autem aufert accipientium &raisedpoint; &c &raisedpoint;
And þat is þe taille of þe tixte &raisedpoint; of þat þat ȝe schewed
Þat þeiȝe we wynne worschip &raisedpoint; and wiþ mede haue victorie
Þe soule þat þe soude taketh &raisedpoint; bi so moche is bounde
Cesseth seith þe kynge &raisedpoint; I suffre ȝow no lengere
Ȝe shal sauȝtne for-sothe &raisedpoint; and serue me bothe
kisse hir quod þe kynge &raisedpoint; conscience I hote
¶ Nay bi criste quod conscience &raisedpoint; congeye me for euere
But resoun rede me þer-to &raisedpoint; rather wil I deye
¶ And I comaunde þe quod þe Kynge &raisedpoint; to conscience þanne
Rape þe to ride &raisedpoint; and resoun þow fecche
Comaunde hym þat he come &raisedpoint; my conseille to here
For he shal reule my rewme &raisedpoint; and rede me þe beste
And acounte with þe conscience &raisedpoint; so me cryst helpe
How þow lernest þe peple &raisedpoint; þe lered and þe lewede
¶ I am fayne of þat forwarde &raisedpoint; seyde þe freke þanne
And ritte riȝte to resoun &raisedpoint; and rowneth in his ere
And seide as þe kynge badde &raisedpoint; and sithen toke his leue
¶ I shal arraye me to ride quod resoun reste þe a while
And called catoun his knaue &raisedpoint; curteise of speche
lg.marginalia: #M4.17, text from here to the end of the page is marked with a bracket in the left margin (KD4.18-23).
lg.l: And also tomme trewe tonge &raisedpoint; telle me no tales
Ne lesyng to lawȝe of &raisedpoint; for I loued hem neuere
And sette my sadel vppon suffre &raisedpoint; til I se my tyme
And lete warrok it wel &raisedpoint; with witty wordes gerthes
And hange on hym þe heuy brydel &raisedpoint; to holde his hed lowe
For he wil make wehe &raisedpoint; tweye er he be there
¶ Thanne conscience vppon his caple &raisedpoint; kaireth forth faste
And resoun with hym ritte &raisedpoint; rownynge togideres
Whiche maistries Mede &raisedpoint; maketh on þis erthe
¶ One waryn wisdom &raisedpoint; and witty his fere
Folwed hem faste &raisedpoint; haued to done
In þe cheker and at þe chauncerie &raisedpoint; to be discharged of þinges
And riden fast for resoun shulde rede hem þe beste
For to saue hem for siluer &raisedpoint; fro shame and fram harmes
¶ And conscience knewe hem wel &raisedpoint; þei loued coueitise
And bad resoun ride faste &raisedpoint; and recche of her noither
Þere aren wiles in here wordes &raisedpoint; and with Mede þei dwelleth
There as wratthe and wranglyng is &raisedpoint; þere wynne þei siluer
¶ Ac þere is loue and lewte &raisedpoint; þei wil nouȝte come þere
Contricio & infelicitas in vijs eorum &c
Þei ne gyueth nouȝte of god &raisedpoint; one gose wynge
Non est timor dei ante oculos eorum
For wot god þei wolde do more &raisedpoint; for a dozeine chickenes
Or as many capones &raisedpoint; or for a seem of otes
Þan for loue of owre lorde &raisedpoint; or alle hise leue seyntes
For-þi resoun lete hem ride &raisedpoint; þo riche bi hem-seluen
For conscience knoweth hem nouȝte &raisedpoint; ne cryst as I trowe
And þanne resoun rode faste &punctuselevatus; þe riȝte heiȝe gate
As conscience hym kenned &raisedpoint; til þei come to þe Kynge
¶ Curteisliche þe kynge þanne &raisedpoint; come aȝein resoun
And bitwene hym-self and his sone &raisedpoint; sette hym on benche
And wordeden wel wyseli &raisedpoint; a gret while togideres
¶ And þanne come pees in-to parlement &raisedpoint; and put forth a bille
How wronge aȝeines his wille &raisedpoint; had his wyf taken
And how he rauisshed Rose &raisedpoint; Reginoldes loue
And Margarete of hir maydenhode &raisedpoint; maugre here chekis
Bothe my gees & my grys &raisedpoint; his gadelynges feccheth
I dar nouȝte for fere of hym &raisedpoint; fyȝte ne chyde
He borwed of me bayard &raisedpoint; he brouȝte hym home neure
Ne no ferthynge þer-fore &raisedpoint; for nauȝte I couthe plede
He meyneteneth his men &raisedpoint; to morther myne hewen
Forstalleth my feyres &raisedpoint; and fiȝteth in my chepynge
And breketh vp my bernes dore &raisedpoint; and bereth aweye my whete
And taketh me but a taile &raisedpoint; for ten quarteres of otes
And ȝet he bet me þer-to &raisedpoint; and lyth bi my Mayde
I nam nouȝte hardy for hym &raisedpoint; vneth to loke &raisedpoint;
¶ The kynge knewe he seide sothe &raisedpoint; for conscience hym tolde
Þat wronge was a wikked luft &raisedpoint; and wrouȝte moche sorwe
¶ Wronge was afered þanne &raisedpoint; and wisdome he souȝte
To make pees with his pens &raisedpoint; and profered hym manye
And seide had I loue of my lorde þe kynge &raisedpoint; litel wolde I recche
Theiȝe pees and his powere &raisedpoint; pleyned hym eure
¶ Þo wan wisdome &raisedpoint; and sire waryn þe witty
For þat wronge had ywrouȝte &raisedpoint; so wikked a dede
And warned wronge þo &raisedpoint; with suche a wyse tale
Who-so worcheth bi wille &raisedpoint; wratthe maketh ofte
I seye it bi þi-self &raisedpoint; þow shalt it wel fynde
But if Mede it make &raisedpoint; þi myschief is vppe
For bothe þi lyf and þi londe &raisedpoint; lyth in his grace
¶ Thanne wowed wronge &raisedpoint; wisdome ful ȝerne
To make his pees with his pens &raisedpoint; handi-dandi payed
Wisdome and witte þanne wenten togideres
And toke Mede myd hem mercy to winne
¶ Pees put forþ his hed &raisedpoint; and his panne blody
Wyth-outen gilte god it wote &raisedpoint; gat I þis skaþe
Conscience and þe comune &raisedpoint; knowen þe sothe
¶ Ac wisdom and witte &raisedpoint; were about faste
To ouercome þe kynge &raisedpoint; with catel ȝif þei myȝte
¶ Þe kynge swore bi crist &raisedpoint; and bi his crowne bothe
Þat wronge for his werkis &raisedpoint; sholde wo þolye
And comaunded a constable &raisedpoint; to casten hym in yrens
And late hym nouȝte þis seuene ȝere &raisedpoint; seen his feet ones
¶ God wot quod wysdom &raisedpoint; þat were nauȝte þe beste
And he amendes mowe make &raisedpoint; late meynprise hym haue
And be borwgh for his bale &raisedpoint; and biggen hym bote
And so amende þat is mysdo &raisedpoint; and euermore þe bettere

lg.marginalia: # notaM4.93, paragraph is marked with lines in the right margin.
lg.l: ¶ Witt acorded þer-with &raisedpoint; and seide þe same
Bettere is þat bote &raisedpoint; bale adoun brynge
Þan bale be ybette &raisedpoint; & bote neuere þe bettere
¶ And þanne gan Mede to mengen here &raisedpoint; and mercy she bisought
And profred pees a present &raisedpoint; al of pure golde
Haue þis man of me quod she &raisedpoint; to amende þi skaþe
For I wil wage for wronge &raisedpoint; he wil do so namore
¶ Pitously pees þanne &raisedpoint; prayed to þe kynge
To haue mercy on þat man &raisedpoint; þat mys-did hym so ofte
For he hath waged me wel &raisedpoint; as wisdome hym tauȝte
And I forgyue hym þat gilte &raisedpoint; with a goode wille
So þat þe kynge assent &raisedpoint; I can seye no bettere
For Mede hath made me amendes &raisedpoint; I may namore axe
¶ Nay quod þe Kynge þo &raisedpoint; so me cryst helpe
Wronge wendeth nouȝte so awaye &raisedpoint; arst wil I wite more
For loupe he so liȝtly &raisedpoint; laughen he wolde
And efte þe balder be &raisedpoint; to bete myne hewen
But resoun haue reuthe on hym &raisedpoint; he shal rest in my stokkes
And þat as longe as he lyueth &raisedpoint; but lowenesse hym borwe
¶ Somme men redde Resoun þo &raisedpoint; to haue reuthe on þat schrewe
And for to conseille þe Kynge &raisedpoint; and conscience after
That Mede moste be meynpernour &raisedpoint; resoun þei bisouȝte
¶ Rede me nouȝte quod resoun &raisedpoint; no reuthe to haue

marginalia.note: C4.113, B/B list this at KD4.113 instead

lg.l: Til lordes and ladies &raisedpoint; louien alle treuthe
lg.marginalia: Reasons aduice in the punyshynge of Wronge.Cr3.4.119
lg.l: And haten al harlotrye &raisedpoint; to heren it &raisedpoint; or to mouthen it

marginalia.note: M4.118; M4.118-125 (KD4.116-123) marked with a bracket in the right margin.

lg.l: Tyl pernelles purfil &raisedpoint; be put in here hucche
And childryn cherissyng &raisedpoint; be chastyng with ȝerdes
And harlotes holynesse &raisedpoint; be holden for an hyne
Til clerken coueitise be &raisedpoint; to clothe þe pore and to fede
And religious romares &raisedpoint; recordare in here cloistres &raisedpoint;
As seynt Benet hem bad &raisedpoint; Bernarde and Fraunceys &raisedpoint;
And til prechoures prechyng &raisedpoint; be preued on hem-seluen
Tyl þe kynges conseille &raisedpoint; be þe comune profyte
Tyl bisschopes baiardes &raisedpoint; ben beggeres chambres &raisedpoint;
Here haukes and her houndes &raisedpoint; helpe to pore Religious &raisedpoint;
¶ And til seynt Iames be souȝte &raisedpoint; þere I shal assigne
That no man go to Galis &raisedpoint; but if he go for euere
And alle Rome-renneres &raisedpoint; for robberes of byȝende
Bere no siluer ouer see &raisedpoint; þat signe of kynge sheweþ &raisedpoint;
Noyther graue ne vngraue &raisedpoint; golde noither siluer
Vppon forfeture of þat fee &raisedpoint; who-so fynt hym at Douere
But if it be marchaunt or his man &raisedpoint; or messagere with lettres
Prouysoure or prest &raisedpoint; or penaunt for his synnes &raisedpoint;
¶ And ȝet quod resoun bi þe Rode &raisedpoint; I shal no reuthe haue
While Mede hath þe maistrye &punctuselevatus; in þis moot halle
Ac I may shewe ensaumples &raisedpoint; as I se other-while
I sey it bi my-self quod he &raisedpoint; and it so were
That I were kynge with crowne &raisedpoint; to kepen a Rewme
Shulde neuere wronge in þis worlde &raisedpoint; þat I wite myȝte
Ben vnpunisshed in my powere &raisedpoint; for peril of my soule
Ne gete my grace for giftes &raisedpoint; so me god saue
Ne for no Mede haue mercy &raisedpoint; but mekenesse it make
¶ For nullum malum þe man &raisedpoint; mette with inpunitum
And badde nullum bonum &raisedpoint; be irremuneratum &raisedpoint;
¶ Late ȝowre confessoure sire Kynge &raisedpoint; construe þis vnglosed &raisedpoint;
lg.marginalia: # quod lex laborabit & lede a-Feld dongM4.148
lg.l: And ȝif ȝe worken it in werke &raisedpoint; I wedde myne eres &raisedpoint;
That lawe shal ben a laborere &raisedpoint; and lede a-felde donge
And loue shal lede þi londe &raisedpoint; as þe lief lyketh
¶ Clerkes þat were confessoures &raisedpoint; coupled hem togideres
Alle to construe þis clause &raisedpoint; and for þe kynges profit
Ac nouȝte for conforte of þe comune &raisedpoint; ne for þe kynges soule
¶ For I seiȝe mede in þe moot halle &raisedpoint; on men of lawe wynke
And þei lawghyng lope to hire &raisedpoint; and lafte resoun manye
¶ Waryn wisdome &raisedpoint; wynked vppon Mede
And seide Madame I am ȝowre man &raisedpoint; what-so my mouth iangleth
I falle in floreines quod þat freke &raisedpoint; an faile speche ofte
¶ Alle riȝtful recorded &raisedpoint; þat resoun treuthe tolde
And witt acorded þer-with &raisedpoint; and comended his wordes
