And þe moste peple in þe halle &raisedpoint; and manye of þe grete
And leten mekenesse a maistre &raisedpoint; and Mede a mansed schrewe
¶ Loue lete of hir liȝte &raisedpoint; and lewte ȝit lasse
And seide it so heiȝe þat al þe halle it herde
Who-so wilneth hir to wyf &raisedpoint; for welth of her godis
But he be knowe for a kokewolde &raisedpoint; kut of my nose
¶ Mede mourned þo &raisedpoint; and made heuy chere
lg.marginalia: # þat mede is Callyd a horeM4.168
lg.l: For þe moste comune of þat courte called hire an hore
Ac a sysoure and a sompnoure &raisedpoint; sued hir faste
And a schireues clerke &raisedpoint; byschrewed al þe route
For ofte haue I quod he &raisedpoint; holpe ȝow atte barre
And ȝit ȝeue ȝe me neuere &raisedpoint; þe worthe of a russhe
¶ The kynge called conscience &raisedpoint; and afterwardes resoun
And recorded þat resoun had riȝtfullich schewed
And mowdilich vppon Mede &raisedpoint; with myȝte þe Kynge loked
lg.marginalia: The lawiers kepe the kinge from hys right,Cr3.4.178
lg.l: And gan wax wrothe with lawe &raisedpoint; for Mede almoste had shent it
And seide þorw ȝowre lawe as I leue &raisedpoint; I lese many chetes
Mede ouer-maistrieth lawe &raisedpoint; and moche treuthe letteth
Ac resoun shal rekene with ȝow &raisedpoint; ȝif I regne any while
And deme ȝow bi þis day &raisedpoint; as ȝe han deserued
Mede shal nouȝte meynprise ȝow &raisedpoint; bi þe Marie of heuene
I wil haue leute in lawe &raisedpoint; and lete be al ȝowre ianglyng
And as moste folke witnesseth wel &raisedpoint; wronge shal be demed
¶ Quod conscience to þe kynge &raisedpoint; but þe comune wil assent
It is ful hard bi myn hed &raisedpoint; here-to to brynge it
Alle ȝowre lige leodes &raisedpoint; to lede þus euene
¶ By hym þat rauȝte on þe rode &raisedpoint; quod resoun to þe kynge
lg.marginalia: Reason taketh vpon hym to rule the realme.Cr3.4.190
lg.l: But if I reule þus ȝowre rewme &raisedpoint; rende out my guttes
Ȝif ȝe bidden buxomnes &raisedpoint; be of myne assente
¶ And I assent seith þe kynge &raisedpoint; by seynte Marie my lady
Be my conseille comen of clerkis &raisedpoint; and of erlis
Ac redili resoun þow shalt nouȝte ride fro me
For as longe as I lyue &raisedpoint; lete þe I nelle
¶ I am aredy quod resoun &raisedpoint; to reste with ȝow euere
So conscience be of owre conseille &raisedpoint; I kepe no bettere
And I graunt quod the kynge &raisedpoint; goddes forbode it faile
Als longe as owre lyf lasteth &raisedpoint; lyue we togideres
The kyng and his knightes &raisedpoint; to the kirke wente
To here matynes of þe day &raisedpoint; and þe masse after
Þanne waked I of my wynkynge and wo was with-alle
Þat I ne hadde sleped sadder &raisedpoint; and yseiȝen more
Ac er I hadde faren a fourlonge &raisedpoint; feyntise me hente
That I ne myȝte ferther a foot &raisedpoint; for defaute of slepynge
And sat softly adown &raisedpoint; and seide my bileue
And so I babeled on my bedes &raisedpoint; þei brouȝte me a-slepe
¶ And þanne saw I moche more &raisedpoint; þan I bifore tolde
For I say þe felde ful of folke &raisedpoint; þat I bifore of seyde
And how resoun gan arrayen hym &raisedpoint; alle þe reume to preche
And with a crosse afor þe kynge &raisedpoint; comsed þus to techen
¶ He preued þat þise pestilences &raisedpoint; was for pure synne
And þe southwest wynde &raisedpoint; on saterday at euene
Was pertliche for pure pryde &raisedpoint; and for no poynt elles
Piries and plomtrees &raisedpoint; were puffed to þe erthe
In ensample ȝe segges &raisedpoint; ȝe shulden do þe bettere
Beches and brode okes &raisedpoint; were blowen to þe grounde
Torned vpward her tailles &raisedpoint; in tokenynge of drede
Þat dedly synne ar domesday &raisedpoint; shal fordon hem alle
¶ Of þis matere I myȝte &raisedpoint; mamely ful longe
Ac I shal seye as I saw &raisedpoint; so me god helpe
How pertly afor þe poeple &raisedpoint; resoun gan to preche
¶ He bad wastoure go worche &raisedpoint; what he best couthe
And wynnen his wastyng &raisedpoint; with somme manere crafte
¶ And preyed peronelle &raisedpoint; her purfyle to lete
And kepe it in hir cofre &raisedpoint; for catel at hire nede
¶ Thomme stowue he tauȝte &raisedpoint; to take two staues
And fecche filice home &raisedpoint; fro þe wyuen pyne

lg.marginalia: # þat wattis wyff was to blame
lg.l: ¶ He warned watt &raisedpoint; his wyf was to blame
Þat hire hed was worth halue a marke &raisedpoint; his hode nouȝte worth a grote
And bad bette kut &raisedpoint; a bow other tweyne
And bete betoun þer-with &raisedpoint; but if she wolde worche
And þanne he charged chapmen &raisedpoint; to chasten her childeren
Late no wynnynge hem forweny &raisedpoint; whil þei be ȝonge
Ne for no pouste of pestilence &raisedpoint; plese hem nouȝte out of resoun
¶ My syre seyde so to me &raisedpoint; and so did my dame
Þat þe leuere childe &raisedpoint; þe more lore bihoueth
And Salamon seide þe same &raisedpoint; þat sapience made
Qui parcit virge odit filium
Þe Englich of þis latyn is &raisedpoint; who-so wil it knowe
Who-so spareth þe sprynge &raisedpoint; spilleth his children
¶ And sithen he preyed prelatz &raisedpoint; and prestes togideres

marginalia.note: M5.44, resembles a few instances below.

lg.l: Þat ȝe prechen to þe peple &raisedpoint; preue &raisedpoint; it on ȝowre-seluen
And doth it in dede &raisedpoint; it shal drawe ȝow to good
If ȝe lyuen as ȝe leren vs we shal leue ȝow þe bettere
¶ And sithen he radde Religioun &raisedpoint; here reule to holde
lg.marginalia: The suppression of Abbayes . Good counsell.Cr3.4.48
lg.l: Leste þe kynge and his conseille &raisedpoint; ȝowre comunes appayre
And ben stuwardes of ȝowre stedes &raisedpoint; til ȝe be ruled bettre
¶ And sithen he conseilled þe kynge &raisedpoint; þe comune to louye
It is þi tresore if tresoun ne were &raisedpoint; and triacle at þi nede
And sithen he prayed þe pope &raisedpoint; haue pite on holicherche
And er he gyue any grace &raisedpoint; gouerne firste hym-selue
¶ And ȝe that han lawes to kepe &raisedpoint; late treuthe be ȝowre coueytise
More þan golde or other gyftes &raisedpoint; if ȝe wil god plese
For who-so contrarieth treuthe &raisedpoint; he telleth in þe gospel
That god knoweth hym nouȝte &raisedpoint; ne no seynte of heuene
Amen dico vobis nescio vos &raisedpoint;
¶ And ȝe þat seke seynte Iames &raisedpoint; and seintes of Rome
Seketh seynt treuthe &raisedpoint; for he may saue ȝow alle
Qui cum patre & filio &raisedpoint; þat feire hem bifalle
Þat suweth my sermon &raisedpoint; and þus seyde resoun
¶ Thanne ran repentance &raisedpoint; and reherced his teme
And gert wille to wepe &raisedpoint; water with his eyen
¶ Peronelle proude-herte &raisedpoint; platte hir to þe erthe
And lay longe ar she loked &raisedpoint; and lorde mercy cryed

marginalia.note: Bx5.67: The beta scribes have Latin titles for the sins in the main hand in the margin, and marked out by rubrication from other marginal annotations, but the alpha scribes do not have them.

lg.l: And byhiȝte to hym &raisedpoint; þat vs alle made
She shulde vnsowen hir serke &raisedpoint; and sette þere an heyre
To affaiten hire flessh &raisedpoint; þat fierce was to synne
Shal neuere heiȝe herte &raisedpoint; me hente &raisedpoint; but holde me lowe
And suffre to be myssayde &raisedpoint; and so did I neuere
But now wil I meke me &raisedpoint; and mercy biseche
For al þis I haue &raisedpoint; hated in myne herte
¶ Þanne lecchoure seyde allas &raisedpoint; and on owre lady he cryed
To make mercy for his mis-dedes &raisedpoint; bitwene god and his soule
With þat he shulde þe saterday &raisedpoint; seuene ȝere þere-after
Drynke but myd þe doke &raisedpoint; and dyne but ones
¶ Enuye with heuy herte &raisedpoint; asked after scrifte
And carefullich mea culpa &raisedpoint; he comsed to shewe
He was as pale as a pelet &raisedpoint; in þe palsye he semed
And clothed in a caurimaury &raisedpoint; I couthe it nouȝte discreue
In kirtel and kourteby &raisedpoint; and a knyf bi his syde
Of a freres frokke &raisedpoint; were þe forsleues
And as a leke hadde yleye &raisedpoint; longe in þe sonne
lg.marginalia: id est emptiO5.85, gloss for lere.
lg.l: So loked he with lene chekes &raisedpoint; lourynge foule
¶ His body was to-bolle for wratthe &raisedpoint; þat he bote his lippes &raisedpoint;
And wryngynge he ȝede with þe fiste &raisedpoint; to wreke hym-self he þouȝte
With werkes or with wordes &raisedpoint; whan he seighe his tyme
Eche a worde þat he warpe &raisedpoint; was of an addres tonge
Of chydynge and of chalangynge &raisedpoint; was his chief lyflode
With bakbitynge and bismer &raisedpoint; and beryng of fals witnesse
Þis was al his curteisye &raisedpoint; where þat euere he shewed hym
¶ I wolde ben yshryue quod þis schrewe &raisedpoint; and I for shame durst
I wolde be gladder bi god &raisedpoint; þat gybbe had meschaunce
Than þouȝe I had þis woke ywonne &raisedpoint; a weye of essex chese
¶ I haue a neighbore neyȝe me &raisedpoint; I haue ennuyed hym ofte
And lowen on hym to lordes &raisedpoint; to don hym lese his siluer
And made his frendes ben his foon &raisedpoint; thorw my false tonge
His grace and his good happes &raisedpoint; greueth me ful sore
Bitwene many &raisedpoint; and many &raisedpoint; I make debate ofte
Þat bothe lyf and lyme &raisedpoint; is lost þorw my speche
¶ And whan I mete him in market &raisedpoint; þat I moste hate
I hailse hym hendeliche &raisedpoint; as I his frende were
For he is douȝtier þan I &raisedpoint; I dar do non other
Ac hadde I maystrye and myȝte &raisedpoint; god wote my wille
¶ And whan I come to þe kirke &raisedpoint; and sholde knele to þe Rode
And preye for þe pople &raisedpoint; as þe prest techeth
For pilgrimes and for palmers &raisedpoint; for alle þe poeple after
Þanne I crye on my knees &raisedpoint; þat cryste ȝif hem sorwe
Þat bar awey my bolle &raisedpoint; and my broke schete
¶ Awey fro þe auter þanne &raisedpoint; turne I myn eyghen
And biholde how Eleyne &raisedpoint; hath a newe cote
I wisshe þanne it were myne &raisedpoint; and al þe webbe after
¶ And of mennes lesynge I laughe &raisedpoint; þat liketh myn herte
And for her wynnynge I wepe &raisedpoint; and waille þe tyme
¶ And deme þat hij don ille &raisedpoint; þere I do wel worse
Who-so vndernymeth me here-of &raisedpoint; I hate hym dedly after
I wolde þat vche a wyght &raisedpoint; were my knaue
For who-so hath more þan I &raisedpoint; þat angreth me sore
And þus I lyue louelees &raisedpoint; lyke a luther dogge
That al my body bolneth &raisedpoint; for bitter of my galle
¶ I myȝte nouȝte eet many ȝeres &raisedpoint; as a man ouȝte
For enuye and yuel wille &raisedpoint; is yuel to defye
May no sugre ne swete þinge &raisedpoint; asswage my swellynge
Ne no diapenidion &raisedpoint; dryue it fro myne herte
Ne noyther schrifte ne shame &raisedpoint; but ho-so schrape my mawe
¶ Ȝus redili quod repentaunce &raisedpoint; and radde hym to þe beste
Sorwe of synnes &raisedpoint; is sauacioun of soules
¶ I am sori quod þat segge &raisedpoint; I am but selde other
And þat maketh me þus megre &raisedpoint; for I ne may me venge
Amonges Burgeyses haue I be &raisedpoint; dwellynge at Londoun
And gert bakbitinge be a brocoure &raisedpoint; to blame mennes ware
Whan he solde and I nouȝte &raisedpoint; þanne was I redy
To lye and to loure on my neighbore &raisedpoint; and to lakke his chaffare
I wil amende þis ȝif I may &raisedpoint; þorw myȝte of god almyȝty

marginalia.note: L5.136, 3 dots arranged in a triangle inside a red box with the gloss.

lg.l: ¶ Now awaketh wratthe &raisedpoint; with two whyte eyen
And nyuelynge with þe nose &raisedpoint; and his nekke hangynge

marginalia.note: C5.138, B/B have mark this at KD5.135 instead.

lg.marginalia: nota#M5.138. M5.138-143 paragraph is bracketed in the left margin (KD5.137-142).
lg.l: ¶ I am wrath quod he &raisedpoint; I was sum-tyme a frere
And þe couentes Gardyner &raisedpoint; for to graffe ympes
On limitoures and listres &raisedpoint; lesynges I ymped
Tyl þei bere leues of low speche &raisedpoint; lordes to plese
And sithen þei blosmed obrode &raisedpoint; in boure to here shriftes
And now is fallen þer-of a frute &raisedpoint; þat folke han wel leuere
Schewen her schriftes to hem &raisedpoint; þan shryue hem to her persones

lg.marginalia: # the Cause off grugge betwen Curatis & FrerisM5.145
lg.l: ¶ And now persones parceyued &raisedpoint; þat Freres parte with hem
Þise possessioneres preche &raisedpoint; and depraue freres
And freres fyndeth hem in defaute &raisedpoint; as folke bereth witnes
That whan þei preche þe poeple &raisedpoint; in many place aboute
I wrath walke with hem &raisedpoint; and wisse hem of my bokes
Þus þei speken of spiritualte &raisedpoint; þat eyther despiseth other
Til þei be bothe beggers &raisedpoint; and by my spiritualte libben
Or elles alle riche and riden aboute
I wrath rest neuere &raisedpoint; þat I ne moste folwe
This wykked folke &raisedpoint; for suche is my grace
¶ I haue an aunte to nonne &raisedpoint; and an abbesse bothe
Hir were leuere swowe or swelte &raisedpoint; þan soeffre any peyne
I haue be cook in hir kichyne &raisedpoint; and þe couent serued
Many monthes with hem &raisedpoint; and with monkes bothe
I was þe priouresses potagere &raisedpoint; and other poure ladyes
And made hem ioutes of iangelynge &raisedpoint; þat dame Iohanne was a bastard
And dame Clarice a kniȝtes douȝter &raisedpoint; ac a kokewolde was hire syre
And dame Peronelle a prestes file &raisedpoint; Priouresse worth she neuere
For she had childe in chirityme &raisedpoint; al owre chapitere it wiste
¶ Of wykked wordes I wrath &raisedpoint; here wortes I-made
Til þow lixte and þow lixte &raisedpoint; lopen oute at ones
And eyther hitte other &raisedpoint; vnder þe cheke
Hadde þei had knyues bi cryst &raisedpoint; her eyther had killed other

lg.marginalia: Gregory wold not suffer womenne to bear confession.Cr3.5.167
lg.l: ¶ Seynt Gregorie was a gode pope &raisedpoint; and had a gode forwit
Þat no Priouresse were prest &raisedpoint; for þat he ordeigned
Þei had þanne ben infamis þe firste day &raisedpoint; þei can so yuel hele conseille
¶ Amonge monkes I miȝte be &raisedpoint; ac many tyme I shonye
For þere ben many felle frekis &raisedpoint; my feres to aspye
Bothe Prioure an supprioure &raisedpoint; and owre pater abbas
And if I telle any tales &raisedpoint; þei taken hem togyderes
And do me faste frydayes &raisedpoint; to bred and to water
And am chalanged in þe chapitelhous &raisedpoint; as I a childe were
And baleised on þe bare ers &raisedpoint; and no breche bitwene
For-þi haue I no lykyng &raisedpoint; with þo leodes to wonye
I ete there vnthende fisshe &raisedpoint; and fieble ale drynke
Ac otherwhile whan wyn cometh &raisedpoint; whan I drynke wyn at eue
lg.marginalia: # the Flix off the Foule mowthM5.181
lg.l: I haue a fluxe of a foule mouthe &raisedpoint; wel fyue dayes after
Al þe wikkednesse þat I wote &raisedpoint; bi any of owre bretheren
I couth it in owre cloistre &raisedpoint; þat al owre couent wote it
¶ Now repent þe quod Repentaunce &raisedpoint; and reherce þow neure
Conseille þat þow cnowest &raisedpoint; bi contenaunce ne bi riȝte
And drynke nouȝte ouer-delicatly &raisedpoint; ne to depe noyther
Þat þi wille bi cause þer-of to wrath myȝte torne
Esto sobrius he seyde &raisedpoint; and assoilled me after
And bad me wilne to wepe &raisedpoint; my wikkednesse to amende

marginalia.note: C5.190, word is divided over two lines. B/B mark "Auari|cia" at KD5.186 instead.
L5.190, 3 dots arranged in a triangle to the left.

lg.l: ¶ And þanne cam coueytise &raisedpoint; can I hym nouȝte descryue
So hungriliche and holwe &raisedpoint; sire henri hym loked
He was bitelbrowed &raisedpoint; and baberlipped also
With two blered eyghen &raisedpoint; as a blynde hagge
And as a letheren purs &raisedpoint; lolled his chekes
Wel sydder þan his chyn &raisedpoint; þei chiueled for elde
And as a bondman of his bacoun &raisedpoint; his berde was bidraueled
With an hode on his hed &raisedpoint; a lousi hatte aboue
And in a tauny tabarde &raisedpoint; of twelue wynter age
Al totorne and baudy &raisedpoint; and ful of lys crepynge
But if þat a lous couthe &raisedpoint; haue lopen þe bettre
She sholde nouȝte haue walked on þat welche &raisedpoint; so was it thredebare
¶ I haue ben coueytouse quod þis caityue &raisedpoint; I biknowe it here
For some tyme I serued &raisedpoint; symme atte stile
And was his prentis ypliȝte &raisedpoint; his profit to wayte
First I lerned to lye &raisedpoint; a leef other tweyne
Wikkedlich to weye &raisedpoint; was my furst lessoun
lg.marginalia: fareO5.206. A solidus/punctus above marginal fare and a caret/punctus beside it indicate that it was intended as a substitution for feyre, although the reading is unattested elsewhere.
lg.l: To wy and to wynchestre &raisedpoint; I went to þe faire
With many manere marchandise &raisedpoint; as my Maistre me hiȝte
Ne had þe grace of gyle ygo &raisedpoint; amonge my ware
It had be vnsolde þis seuene ȝere &raisedpoint; so me god helpe
¶ Thanne drowe I me amonges draperes &raisedpoint; my donet to lerne
To drawe þe lyser alonge þe lenger it semed
Amonge þe riche rayes &raisedpoint; I rendred a lessoun
To broche hem with a bat-nedle &raisedpoint; and plaited hem togyderes
And put hem in a presse &raisedpoint; and pyned hem þerinne
Tyl ten ȝerdes or twelue &raisedpoint; tolled out threttene
¶ My wyf was a webbe &raisedpoint; and wollen cloth made
She spak to spynnesteres &raisedpoint; to spynnen it oute
Ac þe pounde þat she payed by &raisedpoint; poised a quarteroun more
Than myne owne auncere &raisedpoint; who-so weyȝed treuthe
¶ I bouȝte hir barly malte &raisedpoint; she brewe it to selle
Peny ale and podyng ale &raisedpoint; she poured togideres
For laboreres and for low folke &raisedpoint; þat lay by hym-selue
¶ The best ale lay in my boure &raisedpoint; or in my bedchambre
And who-so bummed þer-of &raisedpoint; bouȝte it þer-after
A galoun for a grote &raisedpoint; god wote na lesse
And ȝit it cam in cupmel &raisedpoint; þis crafte my wyf vsed
Rose þe regratere &raisedpoint; was hir riȝte name
She hath holden hokkerye &raisedpoint; al hire lyf-tyme
¶ Ac I swere now so the ik &raisedpoint; þat synne wil I lete
And neuere wikkedliche weye &raisedpoint; ne wikke chaffare vse
But wenden to walsyngham &raisedpoint; and my wyf als &raisedpoint;
And bidde þe Rode of bromeholme &raisedpoint; brynge me oute of dette
¶ Repentestow þe euere quod repentance &raisedpoint; ne restitucioun madest

lg.marginalia: The restitution that nowe is vsed.Cr3.5.235
lg.l: ¶ Ȝus ones I was herberwed quod he &raisedpoint; with an hep of chapmen
I roos whan þei were arest &raisedpoint; and yrifled here males
¶ That was no restitucioun quod repentance &raisedpoint; but a robberes thefte
Þow haddest better worthy &raisedpoint; be hanged þerfore
Þan for al þat &raisedpoint; þat þow hast here shewed &raisedpoint;
¶ I wende ryflynge were restitucioun quod he &raisedpoint; for I lerned neuere rede on boke
And I can no frenche in feith &raisedpoint; but of þe ferthest ende of norfolke
¶ Vsedestow euere vsurie quod repentaunce &raisedpoint; in alle þi lyf-tyme
¶ Nay sothly he seyde &raisedpoint; saue in my ȝouthe
I lerned amonge lumbardes &raisedpoint; and iewes a lessoun
To wey pens with a peys &raisedpoint; and pare þe heuyest
And lene it for loue of þe crosse &raisedpoint; to legge a wedde and lese it
Suche dedes I did wryte &raisedpoint; ȝif he his day breke
I haue mo maneres þorw rerages &raisedpoint; þan þorw miseretur & comodat
¶ I haue lent lordes &raisedpoint; and ladyes my chaffare
And ben her brocour after &raisedpoint; and bouȝte it my-self
Eschaunges and cheuesances &raisedpoint; with suche chaffare I dele
And lene folke þat lese wol &raisedpoint; a lyppe at euery noble
And with lumbardes lettres &raisedpoint; I ladde golde to Rome
And toke it by taille here &raisedpoint; and tolde hem þere lasse
Len[t]estow euere lordes &raisedpoint; for loue of her mayntenaunce
¶ Ȝe I haue lent lordes &raisedpoint; loued me neuere after
And haue ymade many a knyȝte &raisedpoint; bothe mercere & drapere
Þat payed neuere for his prentishode &raisedpoint; nouȝte a peire gloues
¶ Hastow pite on pore men &raisedpoint; þat mote nedes borwe
¶ I haue as moche pite of pore men &raisedpoint; as pedlere hath of cattes
Þat wolde kille hem yf he cacche hem myȝte &raisedpoint; for coueitise of here skynnes
¶ Artow manlyche amonge þi neiȝbores &raisedpoint; of þi mete and drynke
¶ I am holden quod he as hende &raisedpoint; as hounde is in kychyne
Amonges my neighbores namelich &raisedpoint; such a name ich haue
¶ Now god lene neure quod repentance &raisedpoint; but þow repent þe rather
Þe grace on þis grounde &raisedpoint; þi good wel to bisette
lg.marginalia: Ill gotten goodes muste be il spent,Cr3.5.267
lg.l: Ne þine ysue after þe &raisedpoint; haue ioye of þat þow wynnest
Ne þi excecutours wel bisett &raisedpoint; þe siluer þat þow hem leuest
And þat was wonne with wronge &raisedpoint; with wikked men be despended
For were I frere of þat hous &raisedpoint; þere gode faith and charite is
I nolde cope vs with þi catel &raisedpoint; ne owre kyrke amende
Ne haue a peny to my pitaunce &raisedpoint; of þyne bi my soule hele
For þe best boke in owre hous &raisedpoint; þeiȝe brent golde were þe leues
And I wyst wytterly &raisedpoint; þow were suche as þow telleth

marginalia.note: C5.276, B/B mark at 5.286a, which doesn't exist: are our numbers wrong?

lg.l: Seruus es alterius &raisedpoint; cum fercula pinguia queris
Pane tuo pocius &raisedpoint; vescere liber eris &raisedpoint;
¶ Thow art an vnkynde creature &raisedpoint; I can þe nouȝte assoille
Til þow make restitucioun &raisedpoint; and rekne with hem alle
And sithen þat resoun rolle it &raisedpoint; in þe regystre of heuene
That þow hast made vche man good &raisedpoint; I may þe nouȝte assoille
lg.marginalia: Forgette not that þe last date wil surely come.Cr3.5.281
lg.l: Non dimittitur peccatum &raisedpoint; donec restituatur ablatum &c
¶ For alle þat hath of þi good &raisedpoint; haue god my trouthe
Is holden at þe heighe dome &raisedpoint; to helpe þe to restitue
And who-so leueth nouȝte þis be soth &raisedpoint; loke in þe sauter glose
In miserere mei deus &raisedpoint; where I mene treuthe
Ecce enim veritatem dilexisti &c
¶ Shal neuere werkman in þis worlde &raisedpoint; þryue wyth þat þow wynnest
Cum sancto sanctus eris &raisedpoint; construe me þat on englische
¶ Thanne wex þat shrewe in wanhope &raisedpoint; and walde haue hanged himself
lg.marginalia: True repentaunce hath hope of mercy.Cr3.5.290
lg.l: Ne hadde repentaunce þe rather &raisedpoint; reconforted hym in þis manere
Haue mercye in þi mynde &raisedpoint; and with þi mouth biseche it
For goddes mercye is more &raisedpoint; þan alle hise other werkes
lg.marginalia: # quod misericordia eius super omnia operaM5.293
lg.l: Misericordia eius super omnia opera eius &c &raisedpoint;
¶ And al þe wikkednesse in þis worlde &raisedpoint; þat man myȝte worche or thynke
Ne is no more to þe mercye of god &raisedpoint; þan in þe see a glede
Omnis iniquitas quantum ad misericordiam dei &raisedpoint; est sintilla in medio maris
¶ For-þi haue mercy in þi mynde &raisedpoint; and marchandise leue it
For þow hast no good grounde &raisedpoint; to gete þe with a wastel
But if it were with thi tonge &raisedpoint; or ellis with þi two hondes
For þe good þat þow hast geten &raisedpoint; bigan al with falsehede
And as longe as þow lyuest þer-with &raisedpoint; þow ȝeldest nouȝte but borwest
¶ And if þow wite neuere to whiche &raisedpoint; ne whom to restitue
Bere it to þe bisschop &raisedpoint; and bidde hym of his grace
lg.marginalia: The Byshop shall answere for manyCr3.5.303
lg.l: Bisette it hym-selue &raisedpoint; as best is for þi soule
For he shal answere for þe &raisedpoint; at þe heygh dome
For þe and for many mo &raisedpoint; þat man shal ȝif a rekenynge
What he lerned ȝow in lente &raisedpoint; leue þow none other
And what he lent ȝow of owre lordes good &raisedpoint; to lette ȝow fro synne
¶ Now bigynneth glotoun &raisedpoint; for to go to schrifte
And kaires hym to kirke-ward &raisedpoint; his coupe to schewe
¶ Ac Beton þe brewestere &raisedpoint; bad hym good morwe
And axed of hym with þat &raisedpoint; whiderward he wolde
¶ To holicherche quod he &raisedpoint; forto here masse
And sithen I wil be shryuen &raisedpoint; and synne namore
¶ I haue gode ale gossib quod she &raisedpoint; glotown wiltow assaye
Hastow auȝte in þi purs &raisedpoint; any hote spices
¶ I haue peper and piones quod he &raisedpoint; and a pounde of garlike
A ferthyngworth of fenel-seed &raisedpoint; for fastyngdayes
¶ Þanne goth glotoun in &raisedpoint; and grete othes after
Cesse þe souteresse &raisedpoint; sat on þe benche
Watte þe warner &raisedpoint; and his wyf bothe
Tymme þe tynkere &raisedpoint; and tweyne of his prentis
Hikke þe hakeneyman &raisedpoint; and hugh þe nedeler
Clarice of cokkeslane &raisedpoint; and þe clerke of þe cherche
Dawe þe dykere and a dozeine other
Sire Piers of Pridie &raisedpoint; and Peronelle of Flaundres
A ribibour a ratonere &raisedpoint; a rakyer of chepe
A ropere a redyngkyng &raisedpoint; and Rose þe dissheres
Godfrey of garlekehithe &raisedpoint; and gryfin þe walsh
And vpholderes an hepe &raisedpoint; erly bi þe morwe
Geuen glotoun with glad chere &raisedpoint; good ale to hansel
¶ Clement þe cobelere &raisedpoint; cast of his cloke
And atte new faire &raisedpoint; he nempned it to selle
Hikke þe hakeneyman &raisedpoint; hitte his hood after
And badde bette þe bochere &raisedpoint; ben on his side
Þere were chapmen ychose &raisedpoint; þis chaffare to preise
Who-so haueth þe hood &raisedpoint; shuld haue amendes of þe cloke
¶ Two risen vp in rape &raisedpoint; and rouned togideres
And preised þese penyworthes &raisedpoint; apart bi hem-selue
Þei couth nouȝte bi her conscience &raisedpoint; acorden in treuthe
Tyl Robyn þe ropere &raisedpoint; arose bi þe southe
And nempned hym for a noumpere &raisedpoint; þat no debate nere
¶ Hikke þe hostellere &raisedpoint; hadde þe cloke
In couenaunte þat Clement shulde þe cuppe fille
And haue hikkes hode hostellere &raisedpoint; and holde hym yserued
And who-so repented rathest &raisedpoint; shulde arise after
And grete sire glotoun with a galoun ale
¶ Þere was laughyng and louryng &raisedpoint; and let go þe cuppe
And seten so til euensonge &raisedpoint; and songen vmwhile
Tyl glotoun had yglobbed &raisedpoint; a galoun an a Iille
His guttis gunne to godly &raisedpoint; as two gredy sowes
He pissed a potel &raisedpoint; in a pater noster while
And blew his rounde ruwet &raisedpoint; at his rigge-bon ende
That alle þat herde þat horne &raisedpoint; held her nose after
And wissheden it had be wexed &raisedpoint; with a wispe of firses
¶ He myȝte neither steppe ne stonde &raisedpoint; er he his staffe hadde
And þanne gan he go &raisedpoint; liche a glewmannes bicche
lg.marginalia: The description of a drunken man.Cr3.5.357
lg.l: Somme-tyme aside &raisedpoint; and somme-tyme arrere
As who-so leyth lynes &raisedpoint; forto lacche foules
¶ And whan he drowgh to þe dore &raisedpoint; þanne dymmed his eighen
He trembled on þe thresshewolde &raisedpoint; an threwe to þe erthe
Clement þe cobelere &raisedpoint; cauȝte hym bi þe myddel
For to lifte hym alofte &raisedpoint; and leyde him on his knowes
Ac glotoun was a gret cherle &raisedpoint; and a grym in þe liftynge
And coughed vp a caudel &raisedpoint; in clementis lappe
Is non so hungri hounde &raisedpoint; in Hertford-schire
Durst lape of þe leuynges &raisedpoint; so vnlouely þei smauȝte
¶ With al þe wo of þis worlde &raisedpoint; his wyf and his wenche
Baren hym home to his bedde &raisedpoint; and brouȝte hym þer-inne
And after al þis excesse &raisedpoint; he had an accidie
Þat he slepe saterday and sonday &raisedpoint; til sonne ȝede to reste
Þanne waked he of his wynkyng &raisedpoint; and wiped his eyghen
Þe fyrste worde þat he warpe &raisedpoint; was where is þe bolle
His witte gan edwite hym þo &raisedpoint; how wikkedlich he lyued
And repentance riȝte so &raisedpoint; rebuked hym þat tyme
¶ As þow with wordes and werkes &raisedpoint; hast wrouȝte yuel in þi lyue
Shryue þe and be shamed þer-of &raisedpoint; and shewe it with þi mouth
¶ I glotoun quod þe gome &raisedpoint; gylti me ȝelde
Þat I haue trespassed with my tonge &raisedpoint; I can nouȝte telle how ofte
Sworen goddes soule &raisedpoint; and so god me help and halidom
Þere no nede ne was &raisedpoint; nyne hundreth tymes
¶ And ouer-seye me at my sopere &raisedpoint; and some-tyme at nones
Þat I glotoun girt it vp &raisedpoint; er I hadde gone a myle
And yspilte þat myȝte be spared &raisedpoint; and spended on somme hungrie
Ouerdelicatly on fastyng-dayes &raisedpoint; drunken and eten bothe
And sat some-tyme so longe þere &raisedpoint; þat I slepe and ete at ones
For loue of tales in tauernes &raisedpoint; to drynke þe more I dyned
And hyed to þe mete er none &raisedpoint; whan fastyng-dayes were
¶ This shewyng shrifte quod repentance &raisedpoint; shal be meryte to þe
¶ And þanne gan glotoun grete &raisedpoint; and gret doel to make
For his lither lyf &raisedpoint; þat he lyued hadde
And avowed fast &raisedpoint; for hunger or for thurst
Shal neuere fisshe on þe fryday &raisedpoint; defien in my wombe
Tyl abstinence myn aunte &raisedpoint; haue ȝiue me leue
And ȝit haue I hated hir &raisedpoint; al my lyf-tyme
¶ Þanne come sleuthe al bislabered &raisedpoint; with two slymy eiȝen
I most sitte seyde þe segge &raisedpoint; or elles shulde I nappe
I may nouȝte stonde ne stoupe &raisedpoint; ne with-oute a stole knele
Were I brouȝte abedde &raisedpoint; but if my taille-ende it made
Sholde no ryngynge do me ryse &raisedpoint; ar I were rype to dyne
He bygan benedicite with a bolke &raisedpoint; and his brest knocked
And roxed and rored &raisedpoint; and rutte atte laste
What awake renke quod repentance &raisedpoint; and rape þe to shrifte
¶ If I shulde deye bi þis day &raisedpoint; me liste nouȝte to loke
I can nouȝte parfitly my pater noster &raisedpoint; as þe prest it syngeth
But I can rymes of Robyn hood &raisedpoint; and Randolf erle of Chestre
Ac neither of owre lorde ne of owre lady &raisedpoint; þe leste þat euere was made
¶ I haue made vowes fourty &raisedpoint; and forȝete hem on þe morne
I parfourned neure penaunce &raisedpoint; as þe prest me hiȝte
Ne ryȝte sori for my synnes &raisedpoint; ȝet was I neuere
And ȝif I bidde any bedes &raisedpoint; but if it be in wrath
Þat I telle with my tonge &raisedpoint; is two myle fro myne herte
I am occupied eche day &raisedpoint; haliday and other
With ydel tales atte ale &raisedpoint; and otherwhile in cherches
Goddes peyne and his passioun &raisedpoint; ful selde þynke I þere-on
¶ I visited neuere fieble men &raisedpoint; ne fettered folke in puttes
I haue leuere here an harlotrie &raisedpoint; or a somer game of souteres
Or lesynges to laughe at &raisedpoint; and belye my neighbore
Þan al þat euere Marke made &raisedpoint; Mathew Iohan & lucas
And vigilies and fastyng-dayes &raisedpoint; alle þise late I passe
And ligge abedde in lenten &raisedpoint; an my lemman in myn armes
Tyl matynes and masse be do &raisedpoint; and þanne go to þe freres
Come I to ite missa est &raisedpoint; I holde me yserued
I nam nouȝte shryuen some-tyme &raisedpoint; but if sekenesse it make
Nouȝt tweies in two ȝere &raisedpoint; and þanne vp gesse I shcryue me
¶ I haue be prest and parsoun &raisedpoint; passynge thretti wynter
Ȝete can I neither solfe ne synge &raisedpoint; ne seyntes lyues rede
But I can fynde in a felde &raisedpoint; or in a fourlonge an hare
Better þan in beatus vir &raisedpoint; or in beati omnes
Construe oon clause wel &raisedpoint; and kenne it to my parochienes
I can holde louedayes &raisedpoint; and here a Reues rekenynge
Ac in canoun ne in þe decretales &raisedpoint; I can nouȝte rede a lyne
¶ Ȝif I bigge and borwe it &raisedpoint; but ȝif it be ytailled
I forȝete it as ȝerne &raisedpoint; and ȝif men me it axe
Sixe sithes or seuene &raisedpoint; I forsake it with othes
And þus tene I trewe men &raisedpoint; ten hundreth tymes
¶ And my seruauntz some-tyme &raisedpoint; her salarye is bihynde
Reuthe is to here rekenynge &raisedpoint; whan we shal rede acompted
So with wikked wille and wraththe &raisedpoint; my werkmen I paye
¶ Ȝif any man doth me a benfait &raisedpoint; or helpeth me at nede
I am vnkynde aȝein his curteisye &raisedpoint; and can nouȝte vnderstonde it
For I haue and haue hadde &raisedpoint; some-dele haukes maneres
I nam nouȝte lured with loue &raisedpoint; but þere ligge auȝte vnder þe thombe
¶ The kyndenesse þat myne euene-cristene &raisedpoint; kidde me farnere
Sixty sythes I sleuthe &raisedpoint; haue fo[r]ȝete it sith
In speche and in sparynge of speche &raisedpoint; yspilte many a tyme
Bothe flesche & fissche &raisedpoint; and many other vitailles
Bothe bred and ale &raisedpoint; butter melke and chese
Forsleuthed in my seruyse &raisedpoint; til it myȝte serue noman
¶ I ran aboute in ȝouthe &raisedpoint; and ȝaf me nouȝte to lerne
And euere sith be beggere &raisedpoint; for my foule sleuthe
Heu michi quia sterilem vitam duxi Iuuenilem
¶ Repentestow þe nauȝte &raisedpoint; quod repentance &raisedpoint; and riȝte with þat he swowned
lg.marginalia: An admonition to beware of dispair in repentaunceCr3.5.451
lg.l: Til vigilate þe veille &raisedpoint; fette water at his eyȝen
And flatte it on his face &raisedpoint; and faste on hym criede
And seide ware þe fram wanhope &raisedpoint; wolde þe bitraye
I am sori for my synnes &raisedpoint; sey so to þi-selue
And bete þi-selue on þe breste &raisedpoint; and bidde hym of grace
For is no gult here so grete &raisedpoint; þat his goodnesse nys more
¶ Þanne sat sleuthe vp &raisedpoint; and seyned hym swithe
And made avowe to-fore god &raisedpoint; for his foule sleuthe
Shal no sondaye be þis seuene ȝere &raisedpoint; but sykenesse it lette
Þat I ne shal do me er day &raisedpoint; to þe dere cherche
And heren matines and masse &raisedpoint; as I a monke were
Shal none ale after mete &raisedpoint; holde me þennes
Tyl I haue euensonge herde &raisedpoint; I behote to þe Rode
And ȝete wil I ȝelde aȝein &raisedpoint; if I so moche haue
Al þat I wikkedly wan &raisedpoint; sithen I wytte hadde
¶ And þough my liflode lakke &raisedpoint; leten I nelle
Þat eche man ne shal haue his &raisedpoint; ar I hennes wende
And with þe residue &raisedpoint; and þe remenaunt &raisedpoint; bi þe Rode of chestre
I shal seke treuthe arst &raisedpoint; ar I se Rome
¶ Robert þe robbere &raisedpoint; on reddite lokede
And for þer was nouȝte &raisedpoint; where-of he wepe
Ac ȝet þe synful shrewe &raisedpoint; seyde to hym-selue
Cryst þat on caluarye &raisedpoint; vppon þe crosse deydest
Tho dismas my brother &raisedpoint; bisouȝte ȝow of grace
And haddest mercy on þat man &raisedpoint; for memento sake
So rewe on þis robbere &raisedpoint; þat reddere ne haue
Ne neuere wene to wynne &raisedpoint; with crafte þat I owe
But for þi mykel mercy &raisedpoint; mitigacioun I biseche
Ne dampne me nouȝte at domesday &raisedpoint; for þat I did so ille
¶ What bifel of þis feloun &raisedpoint; I can nouȝte faire schewe
Wel I wote he wepte faste &raisedpoint; water with boþe his eyen
And knowleched his gult &raisedpoint; to cryst ȝete eftsones
Þat penitencia his pyke &raisedpoint; he shulde polsche newe
And lepe with hym ouer londe &raisedpoint; al his lyf-tyme
For he had leyne bi latro &raisedpoint; luciferes aunte
¶ And þanne had repentaunce reuthe &raisedpoint; and redde hem alle to knele
For I shal biseche for al synful &raisedpoint; owre saueoure of grace
To amende vs of owre mysdedes &raisedpoint; and do mercy to vs alle
¶ Now god quod he &raisedpoint; þat of þi goodnesse &raisedpoint; gonne þe worlde make
And of nauȝte madest auȝte &raisedpoint; and man moste liche to þi-selue
And sithen suffredest for to synne &raisedpoint; a sikenesse to vs alle
And al for þe best as I bileue &raisedpoint; what-euere þe boke telleth

foreign.hi: o felex Culpa o necessarium peccatum ade &c

lg.l: O felix culpa o necessarium peccatum ade &c
For þourgh þat synne þi sone &raisedpoint; sent was to þis erthe
And bicam man of a mayde &raisedpoint; mankynde to saue
And madest þi-self with þi sone &raisedpoint; and vs synful yliche
Faciamus hominem ad ymaginem et similitudinem nostram
Et alibi qui manet in caritate &raisedpoint; in deo manet & deus in eo
¶ And sith with þi-self sone &raisedpoint; in owre sute deydest
On gode fryday for mannes sake &raisedpoint; at ful tyme of þe daye
Þere þi-self ne þi sone &raisedpoint; no sorwe in deth feledest
But in owre secte was þe sorwe &raisedpoint; and þi sone it ladde
Captiuam duxit captiuitatem
¶ Þe sonne for sorwe þer-of &raisedpoint; les syȝte for a tyme
Aboute mydday whan moste liȝte is &raisedpoint; and mele-tyme of seintes
Feddest with þi fresche blode &raisedpoint; owre forfadres in derknesse
Populus qui ambulabat in tenebris &raisedpoint; vidit lucem magnam
And thorw þe liȝte þat lepe oute of þe &raisedpoint; lucifer was blent
And blewe alle þi blissed &raisedpoint; in-to þe blisse of paradise
¶ Þe thrydde daye after &raisedpoint; þow ȝedest in owre sute

marginalia.note: M5.515, ink of nota differs from that of Sinffull Mare.

lg.l: A synful Marie þe seighe &raisedpoint; ar seynte Marie þi dame
And al to solace synful &raisedpoint; þow suffredest it so were
Non veni vocare iustos &raisedpoint; set peccatores ad penitenciam
¶ And al þat Marke hath ymade mathew Iohan and lucas
Of þyne douȝtiest dedes &raisedpoint; were don in owre armes
Verbum caro factum est et habitauit in nobis
And bi so moche me semeth &raisedpoint; þe sikerere we mowe
Bydde and biseche &raisedpoint; if it be þi wille
Þat art owre fader and owre brother be merciable to vs
And haue reuthe on þise Ribaudes &raisedpoint; þat repente hem here sore
Þat euere þei wratthed þe in þis worlde &raisedpoint; in worde þouȝte or dedes
¶ Þanne hent hope an horne &raisedpoint; of deus tu conuersus viuificabis
And blew it with &raisedpoint; Beati quorum &raisedpoint; remisse sunt iniquitates
Þat alle seyntes in heuene &raisedpoint; songen at ones
Homines & iumenta saluabis quemadmodum multiplicasti misericordiam tuam deus &c &raisedpoint;
¶ A thousand of men þo &raisedpoint; thrungen togyderes
Criede vpward to cryst &raisedpoint; and to his clene moder
To haue grace to go with hem treuthe to seke
¶ Ac þere was wyȝte non so wys &raisedpoint; þe wey þider couthe
But blustreden forth as bestes &raisedpoint; ouer bankes and hilles
Til late was and longe &raisedpoint; þat þei a lede mette
Apparailled as a paynym &raisedpoint; in pylgrymes wyse
He bare a burdoun ybounde &raisedpoint; with a brode liste
In a withewyndes wise &raisedpoint; ywounden aboute
A bolle and a bagge &raisedpoint; he bare by his syde
An hundreth of ampulles &raisedpoint; on his hatt seten
Signes of synay and shelles of galice
And many a cruche on his cloke &raisedpoint; and keyes of Rome
And þe vernicle bifore &raisedpoint; for men shulde knowe
And se bi his signes &raisedpoint; whom he souȝte hadde
¶ Þis folke frayned hym firste &raisedpoint; fro whennes he come
¶ Fram synay he seyde &raisedpoint; and fram owre lordes sepulcre
In bethleem and in babiloyne &raisedpoint; I haue ben in bothe
In ermonye in alisaundre &raisedpoint; in many other places
Ȝe may se bi my signes &raisedpoint; þat sitten on myn hatte
Þat I haue walked ful wyde &raisedpoint; in wete and in drye
And souȝte gode seyntes &raisedpoint; for my soules helth
¶ Knowestow ouȝte a corseint &raisedpoint; þat men calle treuthe
Coudestow auȝte wissen vs þe weye &raisedpoint; where þat wy dwelleth
¶ Nay so me god helpe &raisedpoint; seide þe gome þanne
I seygh neuere palmere &raisedpoint; with pike ne with scrippe
Axen after hym &raisedpoint; er til now in þis place
Peter quod a plowman &raisedpoint; and put forth his hed
I knowe hym as kyndely &raisedpoint; as clerke doþ his bokes
lg.marginalia: # quia dicit Petrus ploughman optime cognoscere veritatemM5.559
lg.l: Conscience and kynde witte &raisedpoint; kenned me to his place
And deden me suren hym sikerly &raisedpoint; to serue hym for euere
Bothe to sowe and to sette þe while I swynke myghte
I haue ben his folwar &raisedpoint; al þis fourty wyntre
Bothe ysowen his sede &raisedpoint; and sued his bestes
With-Inne and with-outen &raisedpoint; wayted his profyt
I dyke and I delue &raisedpoint; I do þat treuthe hoteth
Some-tyme I sowe &raisedpoint; and some-tyme I thresche
In tailoures crafte and tynkares crafte &raisedpoint; what treuthe can deuyse
I weue an I wynde &raisedpoint; and do what treuthe hoteth
¶ For þouȝe I seye it my-self &raisedpoint; I serue hym to paye
Ich haue myn huire wel &raisedpoint; and otherwhiles more
He is þe prestest payer &raisedpoint; þat pore men knoweth
He ne with-halt non hewe his hyre &raisedpoint; þat he ne hath it at euen
He is as low as a lombe &raisedpoint; and loueliche of speche
lg.marginalia: # quomodo docet viam viamviam ad veritatemM5.574
lg.l: And ȝif ȝe wilneth to wite &raisedpoint; where þat he dwelleth
I shal wisse ȝow witterly &raisedpoint; þe weye to his place
¶ Ȝe leue Pieres quod þis pilgrymes &raisedpoint; and profered hym huire
For to wende with hem &raisedpoint; to treuthes dwellyng-place
¶ Nay bi my soules helth quod pieres &raisedpoint; and gan forto swere
I nolde fange a ferthynge &raisedpoint; for seynt Thomas shryne
Treuthe wolde loue me þe lasse &raisedpoint; a longe tyme þere-after

how þou shalt go
on pilgrimage

lg.marginalia:
. nota . how þou schalt goo
on pilgrymageO5.582
lg.l: Ac if ȝe wilneth to wende wel &raisedpoint; þis is þe weye thider

lg.marginalia:
How piers
teachethe
the waye
to trewthCr1.5.576
lg.l: Ȝe mote go þourgh mekenesse &raisedpoint; bothe men and wyues

marginalia.note: C2.5.585m1: An otiose tilde appears above the <a> in comamdementes.

lg.marginalia: How Piers teacheth the waye to trueth.Cr3.5.578
lg.l: Tyl ȝe come in-to conscience þat cryst wite þe sothe
Þat ȝe louen owre lorde god &raisedpoint; leuest of alle þinges
And þanne ȝowre neighbores nexte &raisedpoint; in non wise apeyre
Otherwyse þan þow woldest &raisedpoint; he wrouȝte to þi-selue
¶ And so boweth forth bi a broke &raisedpoint; beth buxum of speche
Tyl ȝe fynden a forth &raisedpoint; ȝowre fadres honoureth
Honora patrem & matrem &c &raisedpoint;
Wadeþ in þat water and wascheth ȝow wel þere
And ȝe shul lepe þe liȝtloker &raisedpoint; al ȝowre lyf-tyme

marginalia.note: L5.591: The gloss is in a sixteenth-century hand.

lg.l: And so shaltow se swere nouȝte &raisedpoint; but if it be for nede
And namelich an ydel &raisedpoint; þe name of god almyȝti
¶ Þanne shaltow come by a crofte &raisedpoint; but come þow nouȝte þere-Inne
That crofte hat coueyte nouȝte &raisedpoint; mennes catel ne her wyues
Ne none of her seruauntes &raisedpoint; þat noyen hem myȝte
Loke ȝe breke no bowes þere &raisedpoint; but if it be ȝowre owne
¶ Two stokkes þere stondeth &raisedpoint; ac stynte ȝe nouȝte þere
They hat stele nouȝte ne slee nouȝte stryke forth by bothe
And leue hem on þi left halfe &raisedpoint; and loke nouȝte þere-after
And holde wel þyne haliday heighe &raisedpoint; til euen
Thanne shaltow blenche at a bergh &raisedpoint; bere no false witnesse
He is frithed in with floreines &raisedpoint; and other foes many
Loke þow plukke no plante þere &raisedpoint; for peril of þi soule
¶ Þanne shal ȝe se sey soth &raisedpoint; so it be to done
In no manere ellis nauȝte &raisedpoint; for no mannes biddyng
¶ Þanne shaltow come to a courte &raisedpoint; as clere as þe sonne
Þe mote is of mercy &raisedpoint; þe manere &raisedpoint; aboute
And alle þe wallis ben of witte &raisedpoint; to holden wille oute
And kerneled with crystendome &raisedpoint; man-kynde to saue
Boterased with bileue so &raisedpoint; or þow beest nouȝte ysaued
¶ And alle þe houses ben hiled &raisedpoint; halles and chambres
Wit no lede but with loue &raisedpoint; and lowe speche as bretheren
Þe brugge is of bidde wel &raisedpoint; þe bette may þow spede
Eche piler is of penaunce &raisedpoint; of preyeres to seyntes
Of almes-dedes ar þe hokes &raisedpoint; þat þe gates hangen on
¶ Grace hatte þe gateward &raisedpoint; a gode man for-sothe
Hys man hatte amende ȝow &raisedpoint; for many man him knoweth
Telleth hym þis tokene &raisedpoint; þat treuthe wite þe sothe
I parfourned þe penaunce &raisedpoint; þe preest me enioyned
And am ful sori for my synnes &raisedpoint; and so I shal euere
Whan I þinke þere-on &raisedpoint; þeighe I were a pope
¶ Biddeth amende ȝow meke him &raisedpoint; til his maistre ones
To wayue vp þe wiket &raisedpoint; þat þe womman shette
Tho Adam and Eue &raisedpoint; eten apples vnrosted
Per euam cuntis clausa est &raisedpoint; & per mariam virginem patefacta est
¶ For he hath þe keye and þe clikat &raisedpoint; þouȝ þe kynge slepe
And if grace graunte þe &raisedpoint; to go in in þis wise
Þow shalt see in þi-selue &raisedpoint; treuthe sitte in þine herte
In a cheyne of charyte &raisedpoint; as þow a c[h]ilde were
To suffre hym and segge nouȝte &raisedpoint; aȝein þi sires wille
¶ Ac bewar þanne of wrath þe &raisedpoint; þat is a wikked shrewe
He hath enuye to hym &raisedpoint; þat in þine herte sitteth
And pukketh forþ pruyde to prayse þi-seluen

marginalia.note: M5.635, likely a guide for the correction þe boldnesse.

lg.l: Þe boldnesse of þi bienfetes &raisedpoint; maketh þe blynde þanne
And þanne worstow dryuen oute as dew &raisedpoint; and þe dore closed
Kayed and clikated &raisedpoint; to kepe þe with-outen
Happily an hundreth wyntre &raisedpoint; ar þow eft entre
Þus myght þow lesen his loue &raisedpoint; to late wel by þi-selue
And neuere happil[i]che efte entre &raisedpoint; but grace þow haue

marginalia.foreign: Septem sorores que seruiunt ad veritatem

lg.l: ¶ Ac þere ar seuene sustren &raisedpoint; þat seruen treuthe euere
And aren porteres of þe posternes &raisedpoint; that to þe place longeth
Þat one hat abstenence &raisedpoint; and humilite an-other
Charite and chastite &raisedpoint; ben his chief maydenes
Pacience and pees &raisedpoint; moche poeple þei helpeth
Largenesse þe lady &raisedpoint; heo let in ful manye
Heo hath hulpe a þousande oute &raisedpoint; of þe deueles ponfolde
¶ And who is sibbe to þis seuene &raisedpoint; so me god helpe
He is wonderliche welcome &raisedpoint; and faire vnderfongen
And but if ȝe be syb &raisedpoint; to summe of þise seuene
It is ful harde bi myne heued quod Peres &raisedpoint; for any of ȝow alle
To geten ingonge at any gate þere &punctuselevatus; but grace be þe more
¶ Now bi cryst quod a cutpurs &raisedpoint; I haue no kynne þere
Ne I quod an apewarde &raisedpoint; bi auȝte þat I knowe

¶ I wote wel quod hunger &raisedpoint; what sykenesse ȝow eyleth
Ȝe han maunged ouer-moche &raisedpoint; and þat maketh ȝow grone
Ac I hote þe quod hunger &raisedpoint; as ȝow þyne hele wilnest
Þat þow drynke no day &raisedpoint; ar þow dyne somwhat
Ete nouȝte I hote þe &raisedpoint; ar hunger þe take
And sende þe of his sauce &raisedpoint; to sauoure with þi lippes
And kepe some tyl soper tyme &raisedpoint; and sitte nouȝt to longe
Arise vp ar appetit &raisedpoint; haue eten his fulle
Lat nouȝt sire surfait sitten at þi borde
Leue him nouȝt for he is lecherous &raisedpoint; and likerous of tonge
And after many manere metes &raisedpoint; his maw is afyngred
¶ And ȝif þow diete þe þus &raisedpoint; I dar legge myne eres
Þat phisik shal his furred hodes &raisedpoint; for his fode selle
And his cloke of calabre &raisedpoint; with alle þe knappes of golde
And be fayne bi my feith &raisedpoint; his phisik to lete
And lerne to laboure with londe &raisedpoint; for lyflode is swete
For morthereres aren mony leches &raisedpoint; lorde hem amende
Þei do men deye þorw here drynkes &raisedpoint; ar destine it wolde
¶ By seynt Poule quod pieres &raisedpoint; þise aren profitable wordis
Wende now hunger whan þow wolt &raisedpoint; þat wel be þow euere
For þis is a louely lessoun &raisedpoint; lorde it þe forȝelde
¶ By-hote god quod hunger &raisedpoint; hennes ne wil I wende
Til I haue dyned bi þis day &raisedpoint; and ydronke bothe
¶ I haue no peny quod peres &raisedpoint; poletes &raisedpoint; forto bigge
Ne neyther gees ne grys &raisedpoint; but two grene cheses
A fewe cruddes and creem &raisedpoint; and an hauer cake
And two loues of benes and bran &raisedpoint; ybake for my fauntis
And ȝet I sey by my soule &raisedpoint; I haue no salt bacoun
Ne no kokeney bi cryst coloppes forto maken
Ac I haue percil and porettes &raisedpoint; and many kole plantes
And eke a cow &raisedpoint; and a kalf &raisedpoint; and a cart mare
To drawe afelde my donge &raisedpoint; þe while þe drought lasteth
And bi þis lyflode we mot lyue &raisedpoint; til lammasse tyme
And bi þat I hope to haue &raisedpoint; heruest in my croft
And þanne may I diȝte þi dyner &raisedpoint; as me dere liketh
Alle þe pore peple þo &raisedpoint; pesecoddes fetten
Benes and baken apples &raisedpoint; þei brouȝte in her lappes

lg.l: Chibolles and cheruelles &raisedpoint; and ripe chiries manye
And profred peres þis present &raisedpoint; to plese with hunger
¶ Al hunger eet in hast &raisedpoint; and axed after more
Þanne pore folke for fere &raisedpoint; fedde hunger ȝerne
With grene poret and pesen &raisedpoint; to poysoun hunger þei þouȝte
By þat it neighed nere heruest &raisedpoint; newe corne cam to chepynge
Þanne was folke fayne &raisedpoint; and fedde hunger with þe best
With good ale as glotoun tauȝte &raisedpoint; and gerte hunger go slepe
¶ And þo wolde wastour nouȝt werche &raisedpoint; but wandren aboute
Ne no begger ete bred &raisedpoint; þat benes Inne were
But of coket or clerematyn &raisedpoint; or elles &raisedpoint; of clene whete
Ne none halpeny ale &raisedpoint; in none wise drynke
But of þe best and of þe brounest &raisedpoint; þat in borgh is to selle
¶ Laboreres þat haue no lande &raisedpoint; to lyue on but her handes
Deyned nouȝt to dyne a-day &raisedpoint; nyȝt-olde wortes
May no peny-ale hem paye &raisedpoint; ne no pece of bakoun &raisedpoint;
But if it be fresch flesch other fische &raisedpoint; fryed other bake
And þat chaude or plus chaud &raisedpoint; for chillyng of here mawe
¶ And but if he be hieghlich huyred &raisedpoint; ellis wil he chyde
And þat he was werkman wrouȝt &raisedpoint; waille þe tyme
Aȝeines catones conseille &raisedpoint; comseth he to iangle

lg.l: Paupertatis onus pacienter ferre memento
¶ He greueth hym aȝeines god &raisedpoint; and gruccheth aȝeines resoun
And þanne curseth he þe kynge &raisedpoint; and al his conseille after
Suche lawes to loke &raisedpoint; laboreres to greue
Ac whiles hunger was her maister &raisedpoint; þere wolde none of hem chyde
Ne stryue aȝeines his statut &raisedpoint; so sterneliche he loked
¶ Ac I warne ȝow werkemen &raisedpoint; wynneth while ȝe mowe
For hunger hide[r]ward &raisedpoint; hasteth hym faste
He shal awake with water &raisedpoint; wastoures to chaste
Ar fyue be fulfilled &raisedpoint; suche famyn shal aryse

lg.l: Whan ȝe se þe sonne amys &raisedpoint; and two monkes hedes
And a Mayde haue þe maistrie &raisedpoint; and multiplied bi eight
Þanne shal deth withdrawe &raisedpoint; and derthe be iustice
And dawe þe dyker &raisedpoint; deye for hunger
But if god of his goodnesse &raisedpoint; graunt vs a trewe
Treuthe herde telle her-of &raisedpoint; and to peres he sent
To taken his teme and tulyen þe erthe

lg.l: And purchaced hym a pardoun &raisedpoint; a pena & a culpa
For hym and for his heires &raisedpoint; for euermore after
And bad hym holde hym at home &raisedpoint; and eryen his leyes
And alle þat halpe hym to erie &raisedpoint; to sette or to sowe
Or any other myster &raisedpoint; þat myȝte pieres auaille &raisedpoint;
Pardoun with pieres plowman &raisedpoint; treuthe hath ygraunted
¶ Kynges and knyȝtes &raisedpoint; þat kepen holycherche
And ryȝtfullych in reumes &raisedpoint; reulen þe peple
Han pardoun thourgh purgatorie &raisedpoint; to passe ful lyȝtly
With patriarkes and prophetes &raisedpoint; in paradise to be felawes
¶ Bisshopes yblessed &raisedpoint; ȝif þei ben as þei shulden
Legistres of bothe þe lawes &raisedpoint; þe lewed þere-with to preche
And in as moche as þei mowe &raisedpoint; amende alle synful

lg.l: ¶ Marchauntz in þe margyne &raisedpoint; hadden many ȝeres
Ac none a pena & a culpa &raisedpoint; þe Pope nolde hem graunte
For þei holde nouȝt her halidayes &raisedpoint; as holicherche techeth
And for þei swere by her soule &raisedpoint; and so god moste hem helpe
Aȝein clene conscience &raisedpoint; her catel to selle
¶ Ac vnder his secret seel &raisedpoint; treuthe sent hem a lettre
That þey shulde bugge boldely &raisedpoint; þat hem best liked
And sithenes selle it aȝein &raisedpoint; and saue þe wynnyge

And wikked wayes &raisedpoint; wiȝtlich hem amende
And do bote to brugges þat to-broke were
Marien maydenes &raisedpoint; or maken hem nonnes
Pore peple and prisounes &raisedpoint; fynden hem here fode
And sette scoleres to scole &raisedpoint; or to somme other craftes
Releue Religioun &raisedpoint; and renten hem bettere

And witen ȝow fro wanhope &raisedpoint; if ȝe wil þus worche

¶ Þanne were Marchauntz mery &raisedpoint; many wepten for ioye
And preyseden Pieres þe plowman &raisedpoint; þat purchaced þis bulle

lg.l: For þe sauter saueth hem nouȝte &raisedpoint; such as taketh ȝiftes

Super innocentem munera non accipies
Pledoures shulde peynen hem &raisedpoint; to plede for such an helpe
Prynces and prelates &raisedpoint; shulde paye for her trauaille
A regibus & pryncipibus erit merces eorum
¶ Ac many a iustice an iuroure &raisedpoint; wolde for Iohan do more
Þan pro dei pietate &raisedpoint; leue þow none other
Ac he þat spendeth his speche and spekeþ for þe pore
Þat is Innocent and nedy &raisedpoint; and no man appeireth
Conforteth hym in þat cas &raisedpoint; with-oute coueytise of ȝiftes
And scheweth lawe for owre lordes loue &raisedpoint; as he it hath lerned
Shal no deuel at his ded-day &raisedpoint; deren hym a myte
Þat he ne worth sauf and his sowle &raisedpoint; þe sauter bereth witnesse
Domine quis habitabit in tabernaculo tuo &c &raisedpoint;
¶ Ac to bugge water ne wynde &raisedpoint; ne witte ne fyre þe fierthe

lg.l: Þise foure þe fader of heuene &raisedpoint; made to þis folde in comune
Þise ben treuthes tresores &raisedpoint; trewe folke to helpe
Þat neuere shal wax ne wanye &raisedpoint; with-oute god hym-selue
¶ Whan þei drawen on to deye &raisedpoint; and Indulgences wolde haue
Her pardoun is ful petit &raisedpoint; at her partyng hennes
Þat any Mede of mene men for her motyng taketh
Ȝe legistres and lawyeres &raisedpoint; holdeth þis for treuthe
Þat ȝif þat I lye &raisedpoint; Mathew is to blame
For he bad me make ȝow þis &raisedpoint; and þis prouerbe me tolde
Quodcumque vultis vt faciant vobis homines &raisedpoint; facite eis
¶ Alle lybbyng laboreres &raisedpoint; þat lyuen with her hondes
Þat trewlich taken &raisedpoint; and trewlich wynnen
And lyuen in loue and in lawe &raisedpoint; for her lowe hertis

lg.l: Haueth þe same absolucioun &raisedpoint; þat sent was to peres
¶ Beggeres ne bidderes &raisedpoint; ne beth nouȝte in þe bulle
But if þe suggestioun be soth &raisedpoint; þat shapeth hem to begge
For he þat beggeth or bit &raisedpoint; but if he haue nede
He is fals with þe fende &raisedpoint; and defraudeth þe nedy
And also he bigileth þe gyuer ageines his wil
For if he wist he were nouȝte nedy &raisedpoint; he wolde ȝiue þat an other
Þat were more nedy þan he &raisedpoint; so þe nediest shuld be hulpe
Catoun kenneth men þus &raisedpoint; and þe clerke of þe stories

And in þe stories he techeth &raisedpoint; to bistowe þyn almes

¶ Ac Gregori was a gode man &raisedpoint; and bad vs gyuen alle
Þat asketh for his loue &raisedpoint; þat vs alle leneth
Non eligas cui miserearis &raisedpoint; ne forte pretereas illum qui meretur accipere

lg.l: In hym þat taketh is þe treccherye &raisedpoint; if any tresoun walke
For he þat ȝiueth ȝeldeth &raisedpoint; and ȝarketh hym to reste

For beggeres borwen euermo &raisedpoint; and her borgh is god almyȝti
To ȝelden hem þat ȝiueth hem &raisedpoint; and ȝet vsure more
Quare non dedisti peccuniam meam ad mensam vt ego veniens cum vsuris exigerem &raisedpoint;
¶ For-þi biddeth nouȝt ȝe beggeres &raisedpoint; but if ȝe haue gret nede
For who-so hath to buggen hym bred &raisedpoint; þe boke bereth witnesse
He hath ynough þat hath bred ynough &raisedpoint; þough he haue nouȝt elles
Satis diues est qui non indiget pane
¶ Late vsage be ȝowre solace &raisedpoint; of seyntes lyues redyng
Þe boke banneth beggarie &raisedpoint; and blameth hem in þis manere

lg.l: Iunior fui etenim senui &raisedpoint; et non vidi iustum derelictum nec semen eius &c
¶ For ȝe lyue in no loue &raisedpoint; ne no lawe holde
lg.marginalia: # quia mendicantes operantur tanquam bestie Cum we heM7.100
lg.l: Many of ȝow ne wedde nouȝt &raisedpoint; þe wommen þat ȝe with delen
But as wilde bestis with wehe &raisedpoint; worthen vppe and worchen
And bryngeth forth barnes &raisedpoint; þat bastardes men calleth
Or þe bakke or some bone &raisedpoint; he breketh in his ȝouthe
A sitthe gon faiten with ȝoure fauntes &raisedpoint; for euermore after
Þere is moo mysshape peple &raisedpoint; amonge þise beggeres
Þan of alle maner men &raisedpoint; þat on þis molde walketh
And þei þat lyue þus here lyf &raisedpoint; mowe lothe þe tyme
Þat euere he was man wrouȝt &raisedpoint; whan he shal hennes fare
¶ Ac olde men & hore &raisedpoint; þat helplees ben of strengthe
And women with childe &raisedpoint; þat worche ne mowe
Blynde and bedered &raisedpoint; and broken her membres
Þat taketh þis myschief mekelych &raisedpoint; as meseles and othere
Han as pleyne pardoun as þe plowman hym-self
For loue of her lowe hertis &raisedpoint; owre lorde hath hem graunted
Here penaunce and here purgatorie &raisedpoint; here on þis erthe
¶ Pieres quod a prest þo &raisedpoint; þi pardoun most I rede
For I wil construe eche clause &raisedpoint; and kenne it þe on englich
¶ And pieres at his preyere &raisedpoint; þe pardoun vnfoldeth
And I bihynde hem bothe &raisedpoint; bihelde al þe bulle
Al in two lynes it lay &raisedpoint; and nouȝt a leef more
And was writen riȝt þus &raisedpoint; in witnesse of treuthe
Et qui bona egerunt ibunt in vitam eternam
Qui vero mala in ignem eternum &raisedpoint;
¶ Peter quod þe prest þo &raisedpoint; I can no pardoun fynde
But dowel and haue wel &raisedpoint; and god shal haue þi sowle
And do yuel and haue yuel &raisedpoint; hope þow non other
Þat after þi ded-day &raisedpoint; þe deuel shal haue þi sowle
¶ And pieres for pure tene &raisedpoint; pulled it atweyne
lg.marginalia: Psal xxiiiCr3.7.128. This note belongs to KD7.121.
lg.l: And seyde si ambulauero in medio vmbre mortis &raisedpoint; non timebo mala quoniam tu mecum es
¶ I shal cessen of my sowyng quod pieres &raisedpoint; and swynk nouȝt so harde
Ne about my bely-ioye &raisedpoint; so bisi be namore
Of preyers and of penaunce &raisedpoint; my plow shal ben her-after
And wepen whan I shulde slepe &raisedpoint; þough whete bred me faille
¶ Þe prophete his payn ete &raisedpoint; in penaunce and in sorwe
By þat þe sauter seith &raisedpoint; so dede other manye
Þat loueth god lelly &raisedpoint; his lyflode is ful esy
Fuerunt michi lacrime mee &raisedpoint; panes die ac nocte
¶ And but if Luke lye &raisedpoint; he lereth vs bi foules
We shulde nouȝt be to bisy &raisedpoint; aboute þe worldes blisse
Ne solliciti sitis &raisedpoint; he seyth in þe gospel
And sheweth vs bi ensamples &raisedpoint; vs-selue to wisse
Þe foules on þe felde &raisedpoint; who fynt hem mete at wynter
Haue þei no gernere &raisedpoint; to go to &punctuselevatus; but god fynt hem alle
¶ What quod þe prest to perkyn &raisedpoint; peter as me þinketh
Þow art lettred a litel &raisedpoint; who lerned þe on boke
¶ Abstinence þe abbesse quod pieres &raisedpoint; myne abc &raisedpoint; me tauȝte
And conscience come afterward &raisedpoint; and kenned me moche more
¶ Were þow a prest pieres quod he &raisedpoint; þow miȝte preche where þow sholdest
As deuynour in deuynyte &raisedpoint; with dixit insipiens to þi teme
¶ Lewed lorel quod Pieres &raisedpoint; litel lokestow on þe bible
On salomones sawes &raisedpoint; selden þow biholdest
Ecce derisores et iurgia cum eis ne crescant &c
¶ Þe prest and perkyn &raisedpoint; apposeden eyther other
And I þorw here wordes awoke &raisedpoint; and waited aboute
And seighe þe sonne in þe south sitte þat tyme
Metelees and monelees &raisedpoint; on Maluerne hulles
Musyng on þis meteles &raisedpoint; and my waye ich ȝede
Many tyme þis meteles &raisedpoint; hath maked me to studye
Of þat I seigh slepyng &raisedpoint; if it so be myȝte
And also for peres þe plowman &raisedpoint; ful pensyf in herte
And which a pardoun peres hadde &raisedpoint; alle þe peple to conforte
And how þe prest impugned it with two propre wordes
Ac I haue no sauoure in songewarie &raisedpoint; for I se it ofte faille

lg.l: ¶ For-þi I rede ȝow renkes &raisedpoint; þat riche ben on þis erthe
Vppon trust of ȝowre tresoure &raisedpoint; triennales to haue
Be ȝe neuere þe balder &raisedpoint; to breke þe x hestes
And namelich ȝe maistres &raisedpoint; mayres and iugges
Þat han þe welthe of þis worlde &raisedpoint; and for wyse men ben holden

At þe dredeful dome &raisedpoint; whan ded shullen rise
And comen alle bifor cryst &raisedpoint; acountis to ȝelde
