marginalia.note: M7.216. The erasure damaged the passus heading for passus 8, which was subsequently repaired in brown ink.

lg.l: At þe day of dome &raisedpoint; we dede as he hiȝte

div1.head: Passus octauus de visione & primus de dowel

lg.l: Thus yrobed in russet &raisedpoint; I rowmed aboute
Al a somer sesoun &raisedpoint; for to seke dowel
And frayned ful oft &raisedpoint; of folke þat I mette
If ani wiȝte wiste &raisedpoint; where dowel was at Inne
And what man he miȝte be &raisedpoint; of many man I axed

lg.marginalia: # the questioun askyn of Freris of dowell
lg.l: ¶ Was neuere wiȝte as I went &raisedpoint; þat me wisse couthe
Where þis lede lenged &raisedpoint; lasse ne more
¶ Tyl it bifel on a fryday &raisedpoint; two freres I mette
Maistres of þe Menoures &raisedpoint; men of grete witte
I hailsed hem hendely as I hadde lerned
And preyed hem par charitee &raisedpoint; ar þei passed forther
If þei knewe any contre &raisedpoint; or costes as þei went
Where þat dowel dwelleth &raisedpoint; doth me to wytene
¶ For þei ben men on þis molde &raisedpoint; þat moste wyde walken
And knowen contrees &raisedpoint; and courtes &raisedpoint; and many kynnes places
Bothe prynces paleyses &raisedpoint; and pore mennes cotes
And dowel and doyuel &raisedpoint; where þei dwelle bothe
¶ Amonges vs quod þe Menours &raisedpoint; þat man is dwellyng
And euere hath as I hope &raisedpoint; and euere shal here-after
¶ Contra quod I as a clerke &raisedpoint; and comsed to disputen
And seide sothli sepcies &raisedpoint; in die cadit iustus
Seuene sythes seith þe boke &raisedpoint; synneth þe riȝtful .
And who-so synneth I seyde &raisedpoint; doth yuel as me þinketh
And dowel and do yuel &raisedpoint; mow nouȝt dwelle togideres
Ergo he nys nauȝt alway &raisedpoint; amonge ȝow freres
He is otherwhile ellis-where &raisedpoint; to wisse þe peple
¶ I shal sey þe my sone &raisedpoint; seide þe frere þanne
How seuene sithes þe sad man &raisedpoint; on þe day synneth
By a forbisene quod þe frere &raisedpoint; I shal þe faire shewe
¶ Lat brynge a man in a bote &raisedpoint; amydde a brode water
Þe wynde and þe water &raisedpoint; and þe bote waggynge
Maketh þe man many a tyme &raisedpoint; to falle and to stonde
For stonde he neuere so styf &raisedpoint; he stombleth ȝif he moeue
Ac ȝit is he sauf and sounde &raisedpoint; and so hym bihoueth
For ȝif he ne arise þe rather &raisedpoint; and rauȝte to þe stiere
Þe wynde wolde wyth þe water &raisedpoint; þe bote ouerthrowe
And þanne were his lyf loste &raisedpoint; þourgh lacchesse of hym-self
¶ And þus it falleth quod þe frere &raisedpoint; bi folke here on erthe
Þe water is likned to þe worlde &raisedpoint; þat wanyeth and wexeth
Þe godis of þis grounde aren like &raisedpoint; to þe grete wawes
Þat as wyndes and wederes &raisedpoint; walweth aboute
Þe bote is likned to owre body &raisedpoint; þat brutel is of kynde
Þat þorugh þe fende and þi flessh &raisedpoint; and þe frele worlde

marginalia.note: M8.44, deleted text is legible under ultraviolet light.

lg.l: Synneth þe sadman &raisedpoint; a day seuene sythes
¶ Ac dedly synne doth he nouȝt &raisedpoint; for dowel hym kepith
lg.marginalia: # quod Caritas maxime adiuuat contra peccatumM8.46
lg.l: And þat is charite þe champioun &raisedpoint; chief help aȝein synne
For he strengtheth man to stonde &raisedpoint; and stereth mannes soule
And þowgh þi body bow &raisedpoint; as bote doth in þe water
Ay is þi soule sauf &raisedpoint; but þi-self wole
Do a dedly synne &raisedpoint; and drenche so þi soule
God wole suffre wel þi sleuthe &raisedpoint; ȝif þi-self lyketh
For he ȝaf þe to ȝeresȝyue &raisedpoint; to ȝeme wel þi-selue
And þat is witte a fre wille &raisedpoint; to euery wyȝte a porcioun
To fleghyng foules &raisedpoint; to fissches & to bestes
Ac man hath moste þerof &raisedpoint; and moste is to blame
But if he worche wel þer-with &raisedpoint; as dowel hym techeth
¶ I haue no kynde knowyng quod I &raisedpoint; to conceyue alle ȝowre wordes
Ac if I may lyue and loke &raisedpoint; I shal go lerne bettere
I bikenne þe cryst &raisedpoint; þat on þe crosse deyde
And I seyde þe same &raisedpoint; saue ȝow fro myschaunce
And ȝiue ȝow grace on þis grounde &raisedpoint; good men to worthe
¶ And þus I went wide-where walkyng myne one
By a wilde wildernesse &raisedpoint; and bi a wode-syde
Blisse of þo briddes &raisedpoint; brouȝte me aslepe
And vnder a lynde vppon a launde &raisedpoint; lened I a stounde
To lythe þe layes &raisedpoint; þo louely foules made
Murthe of her mouthes &raisedpoint; made me þere to slepe
Þe merueillousest meteles &raisedpoint; mette me þanne
Þat euer [dremed] wyȝte &raisedpoint; in worlde as I wene

lg.marginalia: # quomodo thought primo apparuit in sompno
lg.l: ¶ A moche man as me þouȝte &raisedpoint; and lyke to my-selue
Come and called me &raisedpoint; by my kynde name
What artow quod I þo &raisedpoint; þat þow my name knowest
Þat þow wost wel quod he &raisedpoint; and no wyȝte bettere
¶ Wote I what þow art &punctuselevatus; þought &raisedpoint; seyde he þanne
I haue suwed þe þis seuene ȝere &raisedpoint; sey þow me no rather
¶ Art þow thought quod I þo &raisedpoint; þow couthest me wisse
Where þat dowel dwelleth &raisedpoint; and do me þat to knowe
¶ Dowel and dobet &raisedpoint; and dobest þe thridde quod he
Aren three faire vertues &raisedpoint; and beth nauȝte fer to fynde
Who-so is trewe of his tonge &raisedpoint; and of his two handes
And þorugh his laboure or þorugh his londe &raisedpoint; his lyflode wynneth
And is trusti of his tailende &raisedpoint; taketh but his owne
And is nouȝt dronkenlew ne dedeignous &raisedpoint; dowel hym folweth

lg.marginalia: dobettreG9.84. As Benson and Blanchfield point out (pp.42 and 132.1) the form of the letters here suggests that the scribe and rubricator are the same using different scripts.
lg.l: ¶ Dobet doth ryȝt þus &raisedpoint; ac he doth moche more
He is as low as a lombe &raisedpoint; and loueliche of speche
And helpeth alle men &raisedpoint; after þat hem nedeth
Þe bagges and þe bigurdeles &raisedpoint; he hath to-broken hem alle
Þat þe Erl auarous &raisedpoint; helde and his heires
And þus with Mammonaes mone &raisedpoint; he hath made hym frendes
And is ronne in-to Religioun &raisedpoint; and hath rendred þe bible
And precheth to þe poeple &raisedpoint; seynt Poules wordes
Libenter suffertis insipientes &raisedpoint; cum sitis ipsi sapientes
And suffreth þe vnwise &raisedpoint; with ȝow forto libbe
And with gladde wille doth hem gode &raisedpoint; for so god ȝow hoteth

lg.marginalia: # discripcio de do-best ad episcopos pertinetM8.95
lg.l: ¶ Dobest is aboue bothe &raisedpoint; and bereth a bisschopes crosse
Is hoked on þat one ende &raisedpoint; to halie men fro helle
A pyke is on þat potente &raisedpoint; to pulte adown þe wikked
Þat wayten any wikkednesse &raisedpoint; dowel to tene
And dowel and dobet amonges hem ordeigned
lg.marginalia: # On to be kyng & Rule allM8.100
lg.l: To croune one to be kynge to reule hem bothe
Þat ȝif dowel or dobet did aȝein dobest
Þanne shal þe kynge come &raisedpoint; and casten hem in yrens
And but if dobest bede for hem &raisedpoint; þei to be þere for euere
¶ Thus dowel and dobet &raisedpoint; and dobest þe thridde
Crouned one to be kynge &raisedpoint; to kepin hem alle
And to reule þe Reume &raisedpoint; bi her thre wittes
And none other wise &raisedpoint; but as þei thre assented
¶ I thonked thouȝt þo &raisedpoint; þat he me þus tauȝte
Ac ȝete sauoureth me nouȝt þi seggyng &raisedpoint; I coueite to lerne
How dowel dobet and dobest &raisedpoint; don amonges þe peple
¶ But witte conne wisse þe quod þouȝt &raisedpoint; where þo thre dwelle
Ellis wote I none þat can &raisedpoint; þat now is alyue

lg.marginalia: # quomodo will & thought primo obuiauerunt cum wittM8.113
lg.l: ¶ Þouȝte and I thus &raisedpoint; thre days we ȝeden
Disputyng vppon dowel &raisedpoint; day after other
And ar we were ywar &raisedpoint; with witte gan we mete
He was longe and lene &raisedpoint; liche to none other
Was no pruyde on his apparaille &raisedpoint; ne pouerte noyther
Sadde of his semblaunt &raisedpoint; and of soft chiere
I dorste meue no matere &raisedpoint; to make hym to iangle
lg.marginalia: erfleyHm.8.119, cursive pen trial that appears to be a family name or place name, written on the vertical axis, reading from top to bottom.
lg.l: But as I bad þouȝt þo &raisedpoint; be mene bitwene
And put forth somme purpos &raisedpoint; to prouen his wittes
What was dowel &raisedpoint; fro dobet &raisedpoint; and dobest fram hem bothe
¶ Þanne þouȝt in þat tyme seide þise wordes
Where dowel dobet and dobest ben in londe

marginalia.note: M8.125, illegible even under an ultraviolet lamp.

lg.l: Here is wille wolde ywyte &raisedpoint; ȝif witte couthe teche hym
And whether he be man &raisedpoint; or man &raisedpoint; þis man fayne wolde aspye
And worchen as þei thre wolde &raisedpoint; þis is his entente &raisedpoint;
Sire dowel dwelleth quod witte &raisedpoint; nouȝt a day hennes
In a castel þat kynde made &raisedpoint; of foure kynnes þinges
Of erthe and eyre is it made &raisedpoint; medled togideres
With wynde and with water &raisedpoint; witterly enioyned
Kynde hath closed þere-Inne &raisedpoint; craftily with-alle
A lemman þat he loueth &raisedpoint; like to hym-selue
Anima she hatte &raisedpoint; ac enuye hir hateth
A proude pryker of Fraunce &raisedpoint; prynceps huius mundi
And wolde winne hir awey &raisedpoint; with wyles and he myȝte
¶ Ac kynde knoweth þis wel &raisedpoint; and kepeth hir þe bettere
And hath do hir with sire dowel &raisedpoint; is duke of þis marches
Dobet is hir damoisele &raisedpoint; sire doweles douȝter
To serue þis lady lelly &raisedpoint; bothe late and rathe
Dobest is aboue bothe &raisedpoint; a bisschopes pere
Þat he bit mote be do &raisedpoint; he reuleth hem alle
Anima þat lady &raisedpoint; is ladde bi his lerynge
¶ Ac þe constable of þat castel &raisedpoint; þat kepeth al þe wacche
lg.marginalia:
Inwytte
See-Well
Saye-Well
Here-Well
Werke-Well
Goo-Well
...?...# quia Inwitt habet quinque Filios vt patet
lg.l: Is a wys kniȝte with-al &raisedpoint; sire Inwitte he hatte
And hath fyue feyre sones &raisedpoint; bi his first wyf
Sire sewel and saywel &raisedpoint; and herewel þe hende
Sire worche wel wyth þine hande &raisedpoint; a wiȝte man of strengthe
And sire godfrey gowel &raisedpoint; gret lordes for-sothe
Þise fyue ben sette &raisedpoint; to saue þis lady anima
Tyl kynde come or sende to saue hir for euere
¶ What kynnes thyng is kynde quod I &raisedpoint; canstow me telle

lg.marginalia: # quod natura est Creator omnium rerum
lg.l: ¶ Kynde quod witte is a creatour &raisedpoint; of alle kynnes þinges
Fader and fourmour &raisedpoint; of al þat euere was maked
And þat is þe gret god þat gynnynge had neuere
Lorde of lyf and of lyȝte &raisedpoint; of lysse and of peyne
Angeles and al þing aren at his wille
lg.marginalia: # quia dixit & facta sunt mandauit & Creata sunt
lg.l: Ac man is hym moste lyke &raisedpoint; of marke and of schafte
For þorugh þe worde þat he spake &raisedpoint; wexen forth bestes
Dixit & facta sunt

marginalia.note: Bx9.34: id est adam: This gloss appears above the line in LM, and was incorporated into the text in CrHmF. It was therefore presumably a feature of the archetypal text. In R man is a correction in a second hand, perhaps indicating the scribe's confusion.

lg.l: ¶ And made man likkest &raisedpoint; to hym-self one
And Eue of his ribbe-bon &raisedpoint; with-outen eny mene
For he was synguler hym-self &raisedpoint; and seyde faciamus
lg.marginalia: Goddes myghte must help his word.
lg.l: As who seith more mote here-to &raisedpoint; þan my worde one
My myȝte mote helpe &raisedpoint; now with my speche
Riȝte as a lorde sholde make lettres &raisedpoint; and hym lakked parchemyn
Þough he couth write neuere so wel &raisedpoint; ȝif he had no penne
Þe lettre for al þe lordship &raisedpoint; I leue were neuere ymaked
¶ And so it semeth &raisedpoint; bi hym &punctuselevatus; as þe bible telleth
lg.marginalia: # quia non solum verbo sed opere facta sunt
lg.l: Þere he seyde dixit &raisedpoint; & facta sunt
He moste worche with his worde &raisedpoint; and his witte shewe
And in þis manere was man made &raisedpoint; þorugh myȝte of god almiȝti
With his worde and werkemanschip &raisedpoint; and with lyf to laste
And þus god gaf hym a goost &raisedpoint; of þe godhed of heuene
And of his grete grace graunted hym blisse
And þat is lyf þat ay shal last &raisedpoint; to al lynage after
And þat is þe castel þat kynde made &raisedpoint; caro it hatte
lg.marginalia: # the makyng off man with the sowle
lg.l: And is as moche to mene &raisedpoint; as man with a soule
And þat he wrouȝt with werke &raisedpoint; and with worde bothe
Þorugh myȝte of þe maieste &raisedpoint; man was ymaked
¶ Inwit and alle wittes closed ben þer-inne
For loue of þe lady anima &raisedpoint; þat lyf is ynempned
Ouer-al in mannes body &raisedpoint; he walketh and wandreth
Ac in þe herte is hir home &raisedpoint; and hir moste reste
Ac Inwitte is in þe hed &raisedpoint; and to the herte he loketh
What anima is lief or loth &raisedpoint; he lat hir at his wille
For after þe grace of god &raisedpoint; þe grettest is Inwitte

lg.marginalia: # ..... de hijs quorum deus venter est
lg.l: ¶ Moche wo worth þat man &raisedpoint; þat mys-reuleth his Inwitte
And þat be glotouns globbares &raisedpoint; her god is her wombe
Quorum deus venter est
For þei seruen sathan &raisedpoint; her soule shal he haue
Þat liueth synful lyf here &raisedpoint; her soule is liche þe deuel
And alle þat lyuen good lyf &raisedpoint; aren like god almiȝti
Qui manet in caritate in deo manet &c
¶ Allas þat drynke shal for-do &raisedpoint; þat god dere bouȝte
And doth god forsaken hem &raisedpoint; þat he shope to his liknesse
Amen dico vobis nescio vos &raisedpoint; & alibi et dimisi eos secundum desideria eorum

lg.marginalia:
how bishops
shoulen besten
their gudesL9.71
lg.l: ¶ Foles þat fauten Inwitte &raisedpoint; I fynde þat holicherche
lg.marginalia: Wo be to þeou þat turn the tithes to priuate vse.Cr3.9.72
# that holy Church shuld help FolisM9.72
lg.l: Shulde fynden hem þat hem fauted &raisedpoint; and faderelees children
And wydwes þat han nouȝte wher-with &raisedpoint; to wynnen hem her fode
Madde men and maydenes &raisedpoint; þat helplees were
Alle þise lakken Inwitte &raisedpoint; and lore bihoueth
¶ Of þis matere I myȝte &raisedpoint; make a longe tale
And fynde fele witnesses &raisedpoint; amonges þe foure doctours
And þat I lye nouȝt of þat I lere þe &raisedpoint; luke bereth witnesse
¶ Godfader and godmoder &raisedpoint; þat sen her godchildren
At myseise and at mischief &raisedpoint; and mowe hem amende
Shal haue penaunce in purgatorie &raisedpoint; but ȝif þei hem helpe
lg.marginalia: # what belongyth to the litle BarnM9.82
lg.l: For more bilongeth to þe litel barne &raisedpoint; ar he þe lawe knowe
Þan nempnyng of a name &raisedpoint; and he neuere þe wiser
lg.marginalia: . . . nota .. .O9.84, accompanied by flourishes at right, left, and bottom.
lg.l: Shulde no crystene creature &raisedpoint; crien atte ȝate
lg.marginalia: Bestowe your tythes as you are bounde to do.Cr3.9.85
lg.l: Ne faille payn ne potage &raisedpoint; and prelates did as þei shulden
A Iuwe wolde nouȝte se a Iuwe &raisedpoint; go iangelyng for defaute
For alle þe moebles on þis molde &raisedpoint; and he amende it miȝte
¶ Allas þat a crestene creature &raisedpoint; shal be vnkynde til an other
lg.marginalia: # maiorem caritatem in Iudeis quam in cristianisM9.89
lg.l: Sitthen Iuwes þat we iugge &raisedpoint; Iudas felawes
Ayther of hem helpeth other &raisedpoint; of þat þat hym nedeth
Whi nel we cristene &raisedpoint; of cristes good be as kynde
As Iuwes þat ben owre lores-men &raisedpoint; shame to vs alle
Þe comune for her vnkyndenesse &raisedpoint; I drede me shul abye
¶ Bisschopes shul be blamed &raisedpoint; for beggeres sake
He is worse þan Iudas &raisedpoint; þat ȝiueth a iaper siluer
And biddeth þe begger go &raisedpoint; for his broke clothes
Proditor est prelatus cum Iuda &raisedpoint; qui patrimonium cristi minus distribuit // & alibi
Perniciosus dispensator est &raisedpoint; qui res pauperum cristi inutiliter consumit
He doth nouȝt wel þat doth þus &raisedpoint; ne drat nouȝt god almiȝty
Ne loueth nouȝt salamones sawes &raisedpoint; þat sapience tauȝte
Inicium sapiencie timor domini &raisedpoint;
¶ Þat dredeth god he doth wel &raisedpoint; þat dredeth hym for loue
And nouȝt for drede of veniaunce &raisedpoint; doth þer-fore þe bettere
He doth best þat with-draweth hym &raisedpoint; by day and bi nyȝte
To spille any speche or any space of tyme
Qui offendit in verbo in omnibus est reus
¶ Lesyng of tyme &raisedpoint; treuthe wote þe sothe
Is moste yhated vp erthe &raisedpoint; of hem þat beth in heuene
lg.marginalia: [Script written vertically with respect to the text, includes the word "will" as well as "william," the latter followed by more writing, illegible on the film.]Poor correspondence to KD; S reads "And Sithen that speche / is inspirid of grace".
lg.l: And sitthe to spille speche &raisedpoint; þat spyre is of grace
And goddes gleman &raisedpoint; and a game of heuene
Wolde neuere þe faithful fader &raisedpoint; his fithel were vntempred
Ne his gleman a gedelyng &raisedpoint; a goer to tauernes
¶ To alle trew tidy men &raisedpoint; þat trauaille desyren
Owre lorde loueth hem and lent &raisedpoint; loude other stille
Grace to go to hem &raisedpoint; and agon her lyflode
Inquirentes autem dominum non minuentur omni bono
¶ Trewe wedded libbing folk &raisedpoint; in þis worlde is dowel
For þei mote worche & wynne &raisedpoint; and þe worlde susteyne
For of her kynde þei come &raisedpoint; þat confessoures ben nempned
Kynges and kniȝtes &raisedpoint; kayseres and cherles
Maydenes and martires &raisedpoint; out of o man come
Þe wyf was made þe weye &raisedpoint; for to help worche
And þus was wedloke ywrouȝt &raisedpoint; with a mene persone
First bi þe faderes wille &raisedpoint; and þe frendes conseille
And sytthenes bi assent of hem-self &raisedpoint; as þei two myȝte acorde
And thus was wedloke ywrouȝte &raisedpoint; and god hym-self it made
In erthe þe heuene is &raisedpoint; hym-self was þe witnesse

lg.marginalia: # contra hos qui concipiuntur absque matrimonioM9.127
lg.l: ¶ Ac fals folke faithlees &raisedpoint; theues and lieres
Wastoures and wrecches &raisedpoint; out of wedloke I trowe
Conceyued ben in yuel tyme &raisedpoint; as caym was on Eue
Of such synful shrewes &raisedpoint; þe sauter maketh mynde
Concepit in dolore et peperit iniquitatem &c
And alle þat come of þat caym come to yuel ende
For god sent to seem &raisedpoint; and seyde bi an angel
Þyne issue in þyne issue &raisedpoint; I wil þat þei be wedded
lg.marginalia: Learn to chose the a wyfe.Cr3.9.135
lg.l: And nouȝt þi kynde with caymes &raisedpoint; ycoupled ne yspoused

lg.marginalia: # that Seem and Caymes kynd shuld not CopleM9.136
lg.l: ¶ Ȝet some aȝein þe sonde of owre saueoure of heuene
Caymes kynde & his kynde &raisedpoint; coupled togideres
Tyl god wratthed for her werkis &raisedpoint; and suche a worde seyde
Þat I maked man &raisedpoint; now it me athynketh
Penitet me fecisse hominem
¶ And come to Noe anon &raisedpoint; and bad hym nouȝt lette
Swithe go shape a shippe &raisedpoint; of shides and of bordes
Þiself and þi sones three &raisedpoint; and sithen ȝowre wyues
Buske ȝow to þat bote &raisedpoint; and bideth ȝe þer-inne
Tyl fourty dayes be fulfilde &raisedpoint; þat flode haue ywasshen
Clene awey þe cursed blode &raisedpoint; þat caym hath ymaked
¶ Bestes þat now ben &raisedpoint; shulle banne þe tyme
Þat euere þat cursed caym &raisedpoint; come on þis erthe
Alle shal deye for his dedes &raisedpoint; bi dales and bi hulles
And þe foules þat fleeghen &raisedpoint; for[th] with other bestes
Excepte oneliche of eche kynde a couple
Þat in þi shyngled shippe &raisedpoint; shul ben ysaued
Here abouȝt þe barne &raisedpoint; þe belsyres gultes
And alle for her forfadres &raisedpoint; þei ferden þe worse
Þe gospel is here-ageine &raisedpoint; in o degre I fynde
Filius non portabit iniquitatem patris & pater non portabit iniquitatem filij &c &raisedpoint;
¶ Ac I fynde if þe fader be false and a shrewe
Þat somdel þe sone &raisedpoint; shal haue þe sires tacches
¶ Impe on an ellerne &raisedpoint; and if þine apple be swete
Mochel merueile me þynketh &raisedpoint; & more of a schrewe
Þat bryngeth forth any barne &raisedpoint; but if he be þe same
And haue a sauoure after þe sire &raisedpoint; selde seestow other
Numquam colligitur de spinis vuas &raisedpoint; nec de tribulis fycus
And þus þourw cursed caym &raisedpoint; cam care vppon erthe
And al for þei wrouȝt wedlokes &raisedpoint; aȝein goddis wille
lg.marginalia: nota . Of wedlokO9.165. The word nota is surrounded by red and black flourishes at top right and left and beneath.
lg.l: For-þi haue þei maugre for here mariages &raisedpoint; þat marye so her childeren
For some as I se now &raisedpoint; soth forto telle
For coueitise of catel vnkyndeliche ben wedded
As careful concepcioun cometh of suche mariages
As bifel of þe folke &raisedpoint; þat I bifore of tolde
¶ For goode shulde wedde goode &raisedpoint; þough hij no good hadde
I am via & veritas seith cryst &raisedpoint; I may auaunce alle
¶ It is an oncomely couple &raisedpoint; bi cryst as me þinketh
To ȝyuen a ȝonge wenche · to an olde feble
Or wedden any widwe &raisedpoint; for welth of hir goodis
Þat neuere shal barne bere &raisedpoint; but if it be in armes
Many a peire sithen þe pestilence &raisedpoint; han pliȝt hom togideres
Þe fruit þat þei brynge forth &raisedpoint; aren foule wordes
In ialousye ioyeles &raisedpoint; and ianglyng on bedde
Haue þei no children but cheste &raisedpoint; an choppyng hem bitwene
¶ And þough þei don hem to donmowe &raisedpoint; but if þe deuel help
To folwen after þe flicche &raisedpoint; fecche þei it neuere
And but þei bothe be forsworne &raisedpoint; þat bacoun þei tyne
¶ For-þi I conseille alle crystene &raisedpoint; coueite nouȝt be wedded
For coueitise of catel &raisedpoint; ne of kynrede riche
Ac maydenes and maydenes &raisedpoint; macche ȝow togideres
Widwes and widwers &raisedpoint; worcheth þe same
For no londes but for loue &raisedpoint; loke ȝe be wedded
And þanne gete ȝe þe grace of god &raisedpoint; and good ynogh to lyue with
¶ And euery maner seculer þat may nouȝt continue
Wysly go wedde &raisedpoint; and war hym fro synne
For leccherye in likyng &raisedpoint; is lymeȝerde of helle
Whiles þow art ȝonge &raisedpoint; and þi wepne kene
Wreke þe with wyuynge &raisedpoint; ȝif þow wil ben excused
Dum sis vir fortis &raisedpoint; ne des tua robora scortis
Scribitur in portis &raisedpoint; meretrix est ianua mortis

marginalia.foreign: nota de puritate Coitus in matrimonio

lg.l: ¶ Whan ȝe haue wyued bewar &raisedpoint; and worcheth in tyme
lg.marginalia: The maryed couple muste kepe them-selues cleane.Cr3.9.198
lg.l: Nouȝt as Adam & Eue &raisedpoint; whan caym was engendred
For in vntyme trewli &raisedpoint; bitwene man & womman
Ne shulde no bourde on bedde be &raisedpoint; but if þei bothe were clene
Bothe of lyf & and of soule &raisedpoint; and in parfyte charitee
Þat ilke derne dede do &raisedpoint; noman ne sholde
And if þei leden þus her lyf &raisedpoint; it liked god almiȝti
For he made wedloke firste &raisedpoint; and him-self it seide
Bonum est vt vnusquisque vxorem suam habeat propter fornicacionem
¶ And þei þat oþergatis ben geten &raisedpoint; for gedelynges ben holden
As false folke fondelynges &raisedpoint; faitoures and lyars
Vngracious to gete goode &raisedpoint; or loue of þe poeple
Wandren and wasten &raisedpoint; what þei cacche mowe
Aȝeines dowel þei don yuel &raisedpoint; and þe deuel serue
And after her deth-day &raisedpoint; shulle dwelle with þe same
But god gyue hem grace here &raisedpoint; hem-self to amende
¶ Dowel my frende is &raisedpoint; to don as lawe techeth
To loue þi frende and þi foo &raisedpoint; leue me þat is dobet
To ȝiuen and to ȝemen &raisedpoint; bothe ȝonge and olde
To helen and to helpen &raisedpoint; is dobest of alle
¶ And dowel is to drede god &raisedpoint; and dobet to suffre
And so cometh dobest of bothe &raisedpoint; and bryngeth adoun þe mody
And þat is wikked wille &raisedpoint; þat many werke shendeth
And dryueth away dowel &raisedpoint; þorugh dedliche synnes
Thanne hadde witte a wyf &raisedpoint; was hote dame studye
Þat lene was of lere &raisedpoint; and of liche bothe
She was wonderly wroth &raisedpoint; þat witte me þus tauȝte
And al starynge dame studye &raisedpoint; sternelich seyde
Wel artow wyse quod she to witte &raisedpoint; any wysdomes to telle
To flatereres or to folis &raisedpoint; þat frantyk ben of wittes
lg.marginalia: # quod perlis non debent mitteri Coram porcis
lg.l: And blamed hym and banned hym &raisedpoint; and badde hym be stylle
With suche wise wordes &raisedpoint; to wissen any sottes
And seyde noli mittere man &raisedpoint; margerye perlis
Amanges hogges þat han &raisedpoint; hawes at wille
Þei don but dryuele þer-on draffe were hem leuere
Þan al þe precious perre &raisedpoint; þat in paradys wexeth
I sey it bi suche quod she þat sheweth bi her werkes
Þat hem were leuer londe &raisedpoint; and lordship on erthe
Or ricchesse or rentis &raisedpoint; and reste at her wille
Þan alle þe sothe sawes &raisedpoint; þat salamon seyde euere
¶ Wisdome and witte now is nouȝt worth a carse
But if it be carded with coueytise &raisedpoint; as clotheres kemben here wolle

lg.l: Who-so can contreue deceytes &raisedpoint; an conspire wronges
And lede forth a loue-day &raisedpoint; to latte with treuthe
He þat suche craftes can &raisedpoint; to conseille is clepid
Þei lede lordes with lesynges &raisedpoint; and bilyeth treuthe
¶ Iob þe gentel in his gestes witnesseth
Þat wikked men þei welden &raisedpoint; þe welthe of þis worlde
And þat þei ben lordes of eche a londe &raisedpoint; þat oute of lawe libbeth
Quare impij viuunt bene est omnibus qui preuaricantur & inique agunt
¶ Þe sauter seyth þe same &raisedpoint; bi suche þat don ille
Ecce ipsi peccatores habundantes in seculo optinuerunt diuicias
Lo seith holy letterrure whiche lordes beth þis shrewes
Þilke þat god moste gyueth &raisedpoint; leste good þei deleth
And moste vnkynde to þe comune &raisedpoint; þat moste catel weldeth
Que perfecisti destruxerunt &raisedpoint; iustus autem &c &raisedpoint;
Harlotes for her harlotrye &raisedpoint; may haue of her godis
And iaperes and iogeloures &raisedpoint; and iangelers of gestes

lg.l: ¶ Ac he þat hath holy writte &raisedpoint; ay in his mouth &raisedpoint;
And can telle of Tobye &raisedpoint; and of þe twelue apostles
Or prechen of þe penaunce &raisedpoint; þat pilat wrouȝt
To Ihesu þe gentil &raisedpoint; þat Iewes to-drowe
Litel is he loued &raisedpoint; þat suche a lessoun scheweth
Or daunted or drawe forth &raisedpoint; I do it on god hym-self
¶ But þo þat feynen hem folis &raisedpoint; and with faityng libbeth
Aȝein þe lawe of owre lorde &raisedpoint; and lyen on hem-selue
Spitten and spewen &raisedpoint; and speke foule wordes
Drynken and dryuelen &raisedpoint; and do men for to gape
Lickne men and lye on hem &raisedpoint; þat leneth hem no ȝiftes
Þei conne namore mynstralcye &raisedpoint; ne musyke men to glade
Than Munde þe mylnere &raisedpoint; of multa fecit deus
Ne were here vyle harlotrye &raisedpoint; haue god my treuthe
Shulde neuere Kyng ne kniȝt &raisedpoint; ne chanoun of seynt Poules
Ȝyue hem to her ȝeresȝiue &raisedpoint; þe ȝifte of a grote
¶ Ac murthe and mynstralcye &raisedpoint; amonges men is nouthe
Leccherye losengerye &raisedpoint; and loseles tales
Glotonye and grete othes &raisedpoint; þis murthe þei louieth
¶ Ac if þei carpen of cryst &raisedpoint; þis clerkis and þis lewed
lg.marginalia: # quod non laudatur disputare doctor in convijc convivijs #M10.55
lg.l: Atte mete in her murthes &raisedpoint; whan mynstralles ben stille
Þanne telleth þei of þe trinite &raisedpoint; a tale other tweyne
And bringen forth a balled resoun &raisedpoint; and taken Bernard to witnesse
And putten forth a presumpsioun &raisedpoint; to preue þe sothe
Þus þei dryuele at her deyse þe deite to knowe
And gnawen god with þe gorge &raisedpoint; whan her gutte is fulle
¶ Ac þe careful may crye &raisedpoint; and carpen atte ȝate
Bothe afyngred and a-thurst &raisedpoint; and for chele quake
Is none to nymen hym nere &raisedpoint; his noye to amende
But heon on hym as an hounde &raisedpoint; and hoten hym go þennes
Litel loueth he þat lorde &raisedpoint; þat lent hym al þat blisse
Þat þus parteth with þe pore &raisedpoint; a parcel whan hym nedeth
Ne were mercy in mene men &raisedpoint; more þan in riche
Mendinantz meteles &raisedpoint; miȝte go to bedde
God is moche in þe gorge &raisedpoint; of þise grete maystres
Ac amonges mene men &raisedpoint; his mercy and his werkis
And so seith þe sauter &raisedpoint; I haue yseye it ofte
Ecce audiuimus eam in effrata &raisedpoint; inuenimus eam in campis silue
Clerkes and other kynnes men &raisedpoint; carpen of god faste
And haue moche in þe mouthe &raisedpoint; ac mene men in herte
¶ Freres and faitoures &raisedpoint; han founde suche questiouns
To plese with proude men &raisedpoint; sithen þe pestilence tyme
And prechen at seint poules &raisedpoint; for pure enuye of clerkis
Þat folke is nouȝte fermed in þe feith &raisedpoint; ne fre of her goodes
Ne sori for her synnes &raisedpoint; so is pryde waxen
In religioun and in alle þe rewme &raisedpoint; amonges riche & pore

marginalia.note: W10.81, KD10.79-80 are not in W.

lg.l: Þat preyeres haue no power &raisedpoint; þe pestilence to lette
And ȝette þe wrecches of þis worlde &raisedpoint; is none ywar bi other
Ne for drede of þe deth &raisedpoint; withdrawe nouȝt her pryde
Ne beth plentyuous to þe pore &raisedpoint; as pure charite wolde
But in gaynesse and in glotonye &raisedpoint; for-glotten her goode hem-selue
And breken nouȝte to þe beggar &raisedpoint; as þe boke techeth
Frange esurienti panem tuum &c &raisedpoint;
And þe more he wynneth and welt &raisedpoint; welthes & ricchesse
And lordeth in londes &raisedpoint; þe lasse good he deleth
¶ Thobye telleth ȝow nouȝt so &raisedpoint; take hede ȝe riche
How þe boke bible &raisedpoint; of hym bereth witnesse
Si tibi sit copia habundanter tribue &raisedpoint; si autem exiguum illud impertiri stude libenter
Who-so hath moche spene manliche &raisedpoint; so meneth Thobie

marginalia.note: O10.94. The word nota is surrounded at right, left, and bottom with red and black punctuses and flourishes.

lg.l: And who-so litel weldeth &raisedpoint; reule him þer-after
For we haue no lettre of owre lyf &raisedpoint; how longe it shal dure
Suche lessounes lordes shulde &raisedpoint; louie to here
And how he myȝte moste meyne manliche fynde
¶ Nouȝt to fare as a fitheler or a frere &raisedpoint; forto seke festes
Homelich at other mennes house &raisedpoint; and hatyen her owne
Elyng is þe halle : vche daye in þe wyke
Þere þe lorde ne þe lady liketh nouȝte to sytte
Now hath vche riche a reule &raisedpoint; to eten bi hym-selue
In a pryue pa[r]loure &raisedpoint; for pore mennes sake
Or in a chambre with a chymneye &raisedpoint; and leue þe chief halle
Þat was made for meles &raisedpoint; men to eten Inne
And al to spare to spille &raisedpoint; þat spende shal an other
¶ I haue yherde hiegh men etyng atte table
Carpen as þei clerkes were &raisedpoint; of cryste and of his miȝtes
And leyden fautes vppon þe fader &raisedpoint; þat fourmed vs alle
And carpen aȝeine clerkes &raisedpoint; crabbed wordes
Whi wolde owre saueoure suffre suche a worme in his blisse
Þat bigyled þe womman &raisedpoint; and þe man after
Þorw whiche wyles and wordes &raisedpoint; þei went to helle
And al her sede for here synne &raisedpoint; þe same deth suffred
¶ Here lyeth ȝowre lore &raisedpoint; þise lordes gynneth dispute
Of þat ȝe clerkes vs kenneth &raisedpoint; of cryst by þe gospel
Filius non portabit iniquitatem patris &c &raisedpoint;
lg.marginalia: # why men perissh For Adams synM10.118
lg.l: Whi shulde we þat now ben &raisedpoint; for þe werkes of Adam
Roten and to-rende &raisedpoint; resoun wolde it neuere
Vnusquisque portabit onus suum &c
Suche motyues þei moeue &raisedpoint; þis maistres in her glorie
And maken men in mysbileue &raisedpoint; þat muse moche on her wordes
¶ Ymaginatyf her-after-ward &raisedpoint; shal answere to ȝowre purpos
¶ Augustyne to suche argueres &raisedpoint; he telleth hem þis teme
Non plus sapere quam oportet
Wilneth neuere to wite &raisedpoint; whi þat god wolde
Suffre sathan his sede to bigyle
Ac bileue lelly &raisedpoint; in þe lore of holicherche
And preye hym of pardoun &raisedpoint; and penaunce in þi lyue
And for his moche mercye &raisedpoint; to amende ȝow here
For alle þat wilneth to wyte &raisedpoint; þe weyes of god almiȝty
lg.marginalia: [pointing hand]F7.134, possibly the same hand that underlined "in his ers" in the text.
lg.l: I wolde his eye were in his ers &raisedpoint; and his fynger after
lg.marginalia: # quia talibus vellet oculum in anoM10.133
lg.l: Þat euere wilneth to wite &raisedpoint; whi þat god wolde
Suffre sathan &raisedpoint; his sede to bigile
Or iudas to þe iuwes &raisedpoint; ihesu bytraye
Al was as þow wolde &raisedpoint; lorde yworschiped be þow
And al worth as þow wolte &raisedpoint; what-so we dispute
¶ And þo þat vseth þis hauelounes &raisedpoint; to blende mennes wittes
What is dowel fro dobet &raisedpoint; now def mote he worthe
Sitthe he wilneth to wyte &raisedpoint; whiche þei ben bothe
But if he lyue in þe lyf &raisedpoint; þat longeth to dowel
For I dar ben his bolde borgh &raisedpoint; þat dobet wil he neuere
Þeigh dobest drawe on hym day after other
¶ And whan þat witte was ywar what dame studye tolde
He bicome so confus &raisedpoint; he couth nouȝte loke
And as doumbe a[s] deth &raisedpoint; and drowe hym arrere
¶ And for no carpyng I couth after &raisedpoint; ne knelyng to þe grounde
I myȝte gete no greyne &raisedpoint; of his grete wittis
But al laughyng he louted &raisedpoint; and loked vppon studye
lg.marginalia: The maner of \ them þat be in office,Cr3.10.150
lg.l: In signe þat I shulde &raisedpoint; biseche hir of grace
¶ And whan I was war of his wille &raisedpoint; to his wyf gan I loute
And seyde mercy madame ȝowre man shal I worthe
As longe as I lyue &raisedpoint; bothe late & rathe
Forto worche ȝowre wille &raisedpoint; þe while my lyf dureth
With þat ȝe kenne me kyndely &raisedpoint; to knowe what is dowel
¶ For þi mekenesse man quod she &raisedpoint; and for þi mylde speche
I shal kenne þe to my cosyn &raisedpoint; þat clergye is hoten
lg.marginalia: ScriptureC2.10.158m1: The preceding two marginal additions are linked at the right by a bracket.C2.10.158
lg.l: He hath wedded a wyf &raisedpoint; with-Inne þis syx monethes
Is sybbe to þe seuene artz &raisedpoint; scripture is hir name
Þei two as I hope &raisedpoint; after my techyng
Shullen wissen þe to dowel &raisedpoint; I dar it vndertake
¶ Þanne was I also fayne &raisedpoint; as foule of faire morwe
And gladder þan þe gleman &raisedpoint; þat golde hath to ȝifte

marginalia.note: O10.164. The word nota is accompanied by flourishes at left and beneath.

lg.l: And axed hir þe heighe weye &raisedpoint; where þat clergye dwelte
And telle me some token quod I &raisedpoint; for tyme is þat I wende
¶ Axe þe heighe waye quod she &raisedpoint; hennes to suffre
lg.marginalia:
Suffre is þe highe
waye to ClergieC2.10.167
lg.l: Bothe wel & wo &raisedpoint; ȝif þat þow wolt lerne
And ryde forth by ricchesse &raisedpoint; ac rest þow nauȝt þerinne
For if þow couplest þe þer-with &raisedpoint; to clergye comestow neuere

lg.marginalia: # qui claricare velit neque deuicijs neque luxurijs FrequentetM10.170
lg.l: ¶ And also þe likerouse launde &raisedpoint; þat leccherye hatte
Leue hym on þi left halue &raisedpoint; a large myle or more
Tyl þow come to a courte &raisedpoint; kepe wel þi tonge
Fro lesynges and lither speche &raisedpoint; and likerouse drynkes
Þanne shaltow se sobrete &raisedpoint; and symplete of speche
Þat eche wiȝte be in wille &raisedpoint; his witte þe to shewe
And þus shaltow come to clergye &raisedpoint; þat can many þinges
¶ Saye hym þis signe &raisedpoint; I sette hym to scole
And þat I grette wel his wyf &raisedpoint; for I wrote hir many bokes
And sette hir to sapience &raisedpoint; and to þe sauter glose
Logyke I lerned hir &raisedpoint; and many other lawes
And alle þe musouns in mu[si]ke &raisedpoint; I made hir to knowe
¶ Plato þe poete &raisedpoint; I put hym fyrste to boke
Arestotle and other moo &raisedpoint; to argue I tauȝte
Grammer for gerles &raisedpoint; I garte first wryte
And bette hem with a baleis &raisedpoint; but if þei wolde lerne
Of alkinnes craftes &raisedpoint; I contreued toles
Of carpentrie of kerueres and compassed masouns
And lerned hem leuel and lyne &raisedpoint; þough I loke dymme
¶ Ac theologie hath tened me &raisedpoint; ten score tymes
The more I muse þereInne &raisedpoint; þe mistier it semeth
And þe depper I deuyne &raisedpoint; þe derker me it þinketh

marginalia.note: G11.193. The reading Nota is that suggested by Benson and Blanchfield. The mark is, as they point out (132.IV.C), different from that on f.23v G6.541, but see note to that line.

lg.l: It is no science for-sothe &raisedpoint; forto sotyle Inne
A ful lethy þinge it were &raisedpoint; ȝif þat loue nere
Ac for it let best by loue &raisedpoint; I loue it þe bettre
For þere þat loue is leder &raisedpoint; ne lacked neuere grace
Loke þow loue lelly &raisedpoint; ȝif þe lyketh dowel
For dobet and dobest &raisedpoint; ben of loues kynne
¶ In other science it seyth &raisedpoint; I saye it in catoun
lg.marginalia: Cato.Cr3.10.198. This note properly belongs to a line combining KD10.195 and 196.
lg.l: Qui similat verbis vel corde est fidus amicus
Tu quoque fac simile &raisedpoint; sic ars deluditur arte
lg.marginalia: # quia non solum amicis sed eciam inimicis bona operemurM10.201
lg.l: Who-so gloseth as gylours don &raisedpoint; go me to þe same
And so shaltow false folke and faythlees bigyle
Þis is catounes kennyng &raisedpoint; to clerkes þat he lereth
Ac theologye techeth nouȝt so &raisedpoint; who-so taketh ȝeme
He kenneth vs þe contrarye aȝein catones wordes
For he bit vs be as bretheren &raisedpoint; and bidde for owre enemys
And louen hem þat lyen on vs &raisedpoint; and lene hem whan hem nedeth
And do good aȝeines yuel &raisedpoint; god hym-self it hoteth
Dum tempus habemus operemur bonum ad omnes maxime autem ad domesticos fidei
¶ Poule preched þe peple þat parfitnesse loued
To do good for goddes loue &raisedpoint; and gyuen men þat asked
And nameliche to suche &raisedpoint; þat sueth owre bileue
And alle þat lakketh vs or lyeth vs &raisedpoint; owre lorde techeth vs to louye
And nouȝt to greuen hem þat greueth vs &raisedpoint; god hym-self for-badde it
lg.marginalia: # quia amor maxime profficit ad salutem animeM10.215
lg.l: Michi vindictam & ego retribuam
For-þi loke þow louye &raisedpoint; as longe as þow durest
For is no science vnder sonne &raisedpoint; so souereyne for þe soule
¶ Ac astronomye is an harde þynge &raisedpoint; and yuel forto knowe
lg.marginalia: GC10.217It is likely that the marginal G is meant to clarify the inline correction to "Geometrie."
lg.l: Geometrie and geomesye is ginful of speche
Who-so thenketh werche with þo two &raisedpoint; thryueth ful late
For sorcerye is þe souereyne boke &raisedpoint; þat to þe science longeth
¶ Ȝet ar þere fybicches in forceres &raisedpoint; of fele mennes makyng
Experimentz of alkamye &raisedpoint; þe poeple to deceyue
If þow þinke to dowel &raisedpoint; dele þer-with neuere
Alle þise science I my-self &raisedpoint; sotiled and ordeyned
And founded hem formest &raisedpoint; folke to deceyue
¶ Telle clergye þise tokenes &raisedpoint; and scripture after
To conseille þe kyndely &raisedpoint; to knowe what is dowel &raisedpoint;
¶ I seide graunt mercy madame &raisedpoint; and mekeliche hir grette
And went wiȝtlich awey &raisedpoint; with-oute more lettynge
And til I come to clergye &raisedpoint; I couthe neuere stynte
And gret þe good man &raisedpoint; as studye me tauȝte
And afterwardes þe wyf &raisedpoint; and worshiped hem bothe
And tolde hem þe tokenes &raisedpoint; þat me tauȝte were
Was neuere gome vppon þis grounde &raisedpoint; sith god made þe worlde
Fairer vnder-fongen &raisedpoint; ne frendeloker at ese
Þan my-self sothly &raisedpoint; sone so he wist
Þat I was of wittis hous &raisedpoint; and with his wyf dame studye
I seyde to hem sothely &raisedpoint; þat sent was I þider
Dowel and dobet &raisedpoint; and dobest to lerne
¶ It is a comune lyf quod clergye &raisedpoint; on holycherche to bileue
With alle þe artikles of þe feithe &raisedpoint; þat falleth to be knowe
And þat is to bileue lelly &raisedpoint; bothe lered and lewed
On þe grete god &raisedpoint; þat gynnyng had neuere
And on þe sothfaste sone &raisedpoint; þat saued mankynde
Fro þe dedly deth &raisedpoint; and þe deueles power
Þorwgh þe helpe of þe holy goste &raisedpoint; þe whiche goste is of bothe
Three persones &raisedpoint; ac nouȝt in plurel noumbre
For al is but on god &raisedpoint; and eche is god hym-selue
Deus pater deus filius &raisedpoint; deus spiritus sanctus
God þe fader god þe sone &raisedpoint; god holigoste of bothe
Maker of mankynde &raisedpoint; and of bestes bothe
¶ Austyn þe olde &raisedpoint; here-of he made bokes
And hym-self ordeyned &raisedpoint; to sadde vs in bileue
Who was his autour &raisedpoint; alle þe foure euangelistes
And cryst clepid hym-self so &raisedpoint; þe ewangelistes bereth witnesse
Ego in patre & pater in me est & qui videt me &raisedpoint; videt et patrem meum
¶ Alle þe clerkes vnder cryst &raisedpoint; ne couthe þis assoille
But þus it bilongeth to bileue &raisedpoint; to lewed þat willen dowel
For had neuere freke fyne wytte &raisedpoint; þe feyth to dispute
Ne man had no merite &raisedpoint; myȝte it ben yproued
Fides non habet meritum vbi humana racio prebet experimentum
¶ Þanne is dobet to suffre &raisedpoint; for þi soules helth
Al þat þe boke bit &raisedpoint; by holycherche techyng
And þat is man bi þi miȝte &raisedpoint; for mercies sake
Loke þow worche it in werke &raisedpoint; þat þi worde sheweth
Suche as þow semest in syȝte &raisedpoint; be in assay yfounde
Appare quod es vel esto quod appares
And lat no-body be &raisedpoint; bi þi beryng bygyled
But be suche in þi soule &raisedpoint; as þow semest with-oute
¶ Þanne is dobest to be bolde &raisedpoint; to blame þe gylty
Sithenes þow seest þi-self &raisedpoint; as in soule clene
Ac blame þow neuere body &raisedpoint; and þow be blame-worthy
lg.marginalia: [bracket linking this Latin line and the next]Y10.276
lg.l: Si culpare velis &raisedpoint; culpabilis esse cauebis
Dogma tuum sordet &raisedpoint; cum te tua culpa remordet
God in þe gospel &raisedpoint; grymly repreueth
Alle þat lakken any lyf &raisedpoint; and lakkes han hem-selue
Quid consideras festucam in oculo fratris tui trabem in oculo tuo &c
Why meuestow þi mode for a mote &raisedpoint; in þi brotheres eye
Sithen a beem in þine owne &raisedpoint; ablyndeth þi-selue
Eice primo trabem de oculo tuo &c
Whiche letteth þe to loke &raisedpoint; lasse other more
¶ I rede eche a blynde bosarde &raisedpoint; do bote to hym-selue
For abbotes and for prioures &raisedpoint; and for alle manere prelates
As parsones and parissh prestes &raisedpoint; þat preche shulde and teche
Alle manere men &raisedpoint; to amenden &raisedpoint; by here myȝte
This tixte was tolde ȝow &raisedpoint; to ben war ar ȝe tauȝte
Þat ȝe were suche as ȝe seyde &raisedpoint; to salue with othere
For goddis worde wolde nouȝt be loste &raisedpoint; for þat worcheth euere
If it auailled nouȝt þe comune &raisedpoint; it myȝte auaille ȝow-seluen &raisedpoint;
¶ Ac it semeth now sothly &raisedpoint; to þe worldes syght
Þat goddes worde worcheth nauȝte &raisedpoint; on lered ne on lewede
But in suche a manere &raisedpoint; as Marke meneth in þe gospel
Dum cecus ducit cecum ambo in foueam cadunt
¶ Lewed men may likne ȝow þus &raisedpoint; þat þe beem lithe in ȝowre eyghen
And þe festu is fallen &raisedpoint; for ȝowre defaute
In alle manere men &raisedpoint; þourgh mansed prestes
Þe bible bereth witnesse þat alle þe folke of israel
Byttere abouȝte þe gultes &raisedpoint; of two badde prestes
Offyn and Fynes &raisedpoint; for her coueytise
Archa dei myshapped &raisedpoint; and ely brake his nekke
¶ For-þi ȝe corectoures claweth her-on &raisedpoint; and corecteth fyrst ȝow-seluen
And þanne mowe ȝe saufly seye &raisedpoint; as dauid made þe sauter
Existimasti inique quod ero tui similis &raisedpoint; arguam te & statuam contra faciem tuam &raisedpoint;
¶ And þanne shal borel clerkes ben abasched &raisedpoint; to blame ȝow or to greue
And carpen nouȝte as þei carpen now &raisedpoint; and calle ȝow doumbe houndes
Canes non valentes latrare
And drede to wratthe ȝow in any worde &raisedpoint; ȝowre werkemanship to lette
And be prestiore at ȝowre prayere &raisedpoint; þan for a pounde of nobles
And al for ȝowre holynesse &raisedpoint; haue ȝe þis in herteHereafter follow 10.297-308 in KD; however, none of these lines are annotated; could that argue to their lateness?
¶ In scole þere is scorne &raisedpoint; but if a clerke wil lerne
And grete loue and lykynge &raisedpoint; for eche of hem loueth other
Ac now is religioun a ryder &raisedpoint; a rowmer bi stretes
A leder of louedayes &raisedpoint; and a londe-bugger
A priker on a palfray &raisedpoint; fro manere to maner

And bete ȝow as þe bible telleth &raisedpoint; for brekynge of ȝowre reule
And amende monyales &raisedpoint; monkes and chanouns

lg.l: ¶ And þanne shal þe abbot of Abyndoun &raisedpoint; and alle [his] issu for euere
Haue a knokke of a kynge &raisedpoint; and incurable þe wounde
¶ That þis worth soth seke ȝe &raisedpoint; þat oft ouer-se þe bible
Quomodo cessauit exactor &raisedpoint; quieuit tributum &raisedpoint; contriuit dominus baculum impiorum | et virgam dominancium cedencium plaga insanabili &c
¶ Ac ar þat kynge come &raisedpoint; cayme shal awake
Ac dowel shal dyngen hym adoune &raisedpoint; and destruyen his myȝte

lg.marginalia: # quod kynghod helpith not to heuenwardM10.342

helpeth nouȝt to heueneward &raisedpoint; one heres ende
Ne ricchesse riȝt nouȝt &raisedpoint; ne reaute of lordes
¶ Poule preueth it inpossible &raisedpoint; riche men haue heuene
Salamon seith also &raisedpoint; þat syluer is worst to louye
Nichil iniquius quam amare peccuniam
And caton kenneth vs to coueiten it &raisedpoint; nauȝt but as nede techeth
Dilige denarium set parce dilige formam
And patriarkes and prophetes &raisedpoint; and poetes bothe
Wryten to wissen vs &raisedpoint; to wilne no ricchesse
And preyseden pouerte with pacience &raisedpoint; þe apostles bereth witnesse
Þat þei han heritage in heuene &raisedpoint; and bi trewe riȝte
Þere riche men no riȝte may clayme &raisedpoint; but of reuthe and grace
¶ Contra quod I bi cryste &raisedpoint; þat can I repreue
And preue it bi Peter &raisedpoint; and bi poule bothe
Þat is baptized beth sauf &raisedpoint; be he riche or pore
¶ Þat is in extremis quod scripture &raisedpoint; amonges saracenes and iewes
Þei mowen be saued so &raisedpoint; and þat is owre byleue
lg.marginalia: # quod inffidelis in casu potest Baptizare inffedelisM10.360
lg.l: Þat an vncristene in þat cas &raisedpoint; may crysten an hethen
And for his lele byleue &raisedpoint; whan he þe lyf tyneth
Haue þe heritage of heuene &raisedpoint; as any man crystene
¶ Ac crysten men with-oute more &raisedpoint; may nouȝt come to heuene
For þat cryst for cristen men &raisedpoint; deyde &punctuselevatus; and confermed þe lawe
Þat who-so wolde and wylneth &raisedpoint; with cryste to aryse
Si cum cristo surrexistis &c &raisedpoint;
He shulde louye & lene &raisedpoint; and þe lawe fulfille
Þat is loue þi lorde god &raisedpoint; leuest aboue alle
And after alle crystene creatures &raisedpoint; in comune eche man other
And þus bilongeth to louye &raisedpoint; þat leueth to be saued
And but we do þus in dede &raisedpoint; ar þe daye of dome
I[t] shal bisitten vs ful soure &raisedpoint; þe siluer þat we kepen

lg.l: And owre bakkes þat moth-eten be &raisedpoint; and sen beggers go naked
Or delyte in wyn and wylde foule &raisedpoint; and wote any in defaute
For euery cristene creature shulde be kynde til other
And sithen hethen to helpe &raisedpoint; in hope of amendement
God hoteth bothe heigh and lowe þat no man hurte other
And seith slee nouȝt þat semblable is &raisedpoint; to myne owen liknesse
But if I sende þe sum tokne &raisedpoint; and seith non necaberis
Is slee nouȝt but suffre &raisedpoint; and al for þe beste
For I shal punysshen hem in purgatorie &raisedpoint; or in þe putte of helle
Vche man for his mysdedes &raisedpoint; but mercy it lette
¶ Þis is a longe lessoun quod I &raisedpoint; and litel am I þe wyser
Where dowel is or dobet &raisedpoint; derkelich ȝe shewen
Many tales ȝe tellen &raisedpoint; þat theologye lerneth
And þat I man made was &raisedpoint; and my name yentred
In þe legende of lyf &raisedpoint; longe er I were
Or elles vnwriten for somme wikkednesse as holywrit wytnesseth
Nemo ascendit ad celum nisi qui de celo decendit
¶ I leue it wel quod I bi owre lorde and on no letterure bettere
For salamon þe sage &raisedpoint; þat sapience tauȝte
God gaf hym grace of witte &raisedpoint; and alle his godes after
He demed wel & wysely as holy writte telleth
lg.marginalia: # opinionem quomodo Salamoun et Aristotill dampnanturM10.394
lg.l: Aristotle & he &raisedpoint; who wissed men bettere
Maistres þat of goddis mercy &raisedpoint; techen men and prechen
Of here wordes þei wissen vs &raisedpoint; for wisest as in here tyme
And al holicherche &raisedpoint; holdeth hem bothe ydampned
¶ And if I shulde worke bi here werkes to wynne me heuene
Þat for her werkes and witte &raisedpoint; now wonyeth in pyne
Þanne wrouȝte I vnwysely &raisedpoint; what-so-euere ȝe preche
¶ Ac of fele witty in feith &raisedpoint; litel ferly I haue
Þough her goste be vngraciouse &raisedpoint; god for to plese
For many men on þis molde &raisedpoint; more sette here hertis
In good þan in god &raisedpoint; for-þi hem grace failleth
At here moste myschief &raisedpoint; whan þei shal lyf lete
As salamon dede and such other &raisedpoint; þat shewed gret wittes

lg.l: Ac her werkes as holy wrytte seyth &raisedpoint; was euere þe contrarye
For-þi wyse witted men &raisedpoint; and wel ylettred clerkes
As þei seyen hem-self &raisedpoint; selden done þer-after
Super cathedra moysy &c &raisedpoint;
¶ Ac I wene it worth of many &raisedpoint; as was in Noes tyme

Was neuere wriȝte saued þat wrouȝt þer-on &raisedpoint; ne oþer werkman elles
But briddes and bestes &raisedpoint; and þe blissed Noe
And his wyf with his sones &raisedpoint; and also here wyues
Of wriȝtes þat it wrouȝte was none of hem ysaued
¶ God lene it fare nouȝt so bi folke &raisedpoint; þat þe feith techen
Of holicherche þat he[r]berwe is &raisedpoint; and goddes hous to saue
And shelden vs fram shame þer-inne &raisedpoint; as noes shippe did bestes
And men þat maden it &raisedpoint; amydde þe flode adreynten
Þe culorum of þis clause &raisedpoint; curatoures is to mene
Þat ben carpenteres holykirke to make &raisedpoint; for crystes owne bestes
Homines & iumenta saluabis domine &raisedpoint; &c &raisedpoint;
¶ On gode fridaye I fynde &raisedpoint; a feloun was ysaued
Þat had lyued al his lyf with lesynges and with thefte
And for he biknewe on þe crosse &raisedpoint; and to cryste s[h]rof hym

lg.l: A robbere was yraunceouned &raisedpoint; rather þan þei alle
With-outen any penaunce &raisedpoint; of purgatorie &punctuselevatus; to perpetuel blisse
¶ Þanne Marye Magdaleyne &raisedpoint; what womman dede worse
Or who worse þan dauid &raisedpoint; þat vries deth conspired
Or Poule þe apostle &raisedpoint; þat no pitee hadde
Moche crystene kynde &raisedpoint; to kylle to deth
And ben þise as souereynes &raisedpoint; wyth seyntes in heuene
Þo þat wrouȝte wikkedlokest &raisedpoint; in worlde þo þei were
¶ And þo þat wisely wordeden &raisedpoint; and wryten many bokes
Of witte and of wisdome &raisedpoint; with dampned soules wonye
Þat salamon seith I trowe be soth &raisedpoint; and certeyne of vs alle
Sine iusti atque sapientes &raisedpoint; & opera eorum in manu dei sunt &c
¶ Þere aren witty and wel libbyng ac her werkes ben yhudde
In þe hondes of almiȝty god &raisedpoint; and he wote þe sothe
Wher for loue a man worth allowed þere &raisedpoint; and his lele werkes
Or elles for his yuel wille &raisedpoint; & enuye of herte
And be allowed as he lyued so &raisedpoint; for bi lyther &raisedpoint; men knoweth þe gode
¶ And wherby wote men whiche is whyte &raisedpoint; if alle þinge blake were
And who were a gode man &raisedpoint; but if þere were some shrewe
For-þi lyue we forth with lither men &raisedpoint; I leue fewe ben gode
For qant oportet vyent en place &raisedpoint; yl nyad que pati
And he þat may al amende &raisedpoint; haue mercy on vs alle
For sothest worde þat euere god seyde &raisedpoint; was þo he seyde nemo bonus
¶ Clergye þo of crystes mouth &raisedpoint; commended was it litel
For he seyde to seynt Peter &raisedpoint; and to suche as he loued
Dum steteritis ante Reges et presides &c &raisedpoint;
Þough ȝe come bifor kynges &raisedpoint; and clerkes of þe lawe
Beth nouȝte abasched &raisedpoint; for I shal be in ȝoure mouthes
And ȝyue ȝow witte at wille &raisedpoint; and kunnynge to conclude
Hem alle þat aȝeines ȝow &raisedpoint; of crystenedome disputen
¶ Dauyd maketh mencioun &raisedpoint; he spake amonges kynges
And miȝte no kynge ouercome hym &raisedpoint; as bi kunnyng of speche
But witte ne wisdome &raisedpoint; wan neuere þe maystrye
Whan man was at myschief &raisedpoint; with-oute þe more grace
¶ Þe doughtiest doctour &raisedpoint; and deuynoure of þe trinitee
Was augustyn þe olde &raisedpoint; and heighest of þe foure
Sayde þus in a sarmoun &raisedpoint; I seigh it writen ones
Ecce ipsi idioti rapiunt celum &raisedpoint; vbi nos sapientes in inferno mergimur &raisedpoint;
And is to mene to englissh men &raisedpoint; more ne lasse
Aren none rather yrauysshed &raisedpoint; fro þe riȝte byleue

lg.l: Þan ar þis cunnynge clerkes &raisedpoint; þat conne many bokes
¶ Ne none sonner saued &raisedpoint; ne sadder of bileue
Þan plowmen and pastoures &raisedpoint; & pore comune laboreres
Souteres and sheperdes &raisedpoint; suche lewed iottes
Percen with a pater noster þe paleys of heuene
And passen purgatorie penaunceles &raisedpoint; at her hennes-partyng

lg.l: ¶ I se ensamples my-self &raisedpoint; and so may many an other

Riȝt so lewed men &raisedpoint; & of litel knowyng
Selden falle þei so foule &raisedpoint; and so fer in synne
As clerkes of holikirke &raisedpoint; þat kepen crystes tresore
Þe which is mannes soule to saue &raisedpoint; as god seith in þe gospel
ite vos in vineam meam
