lg.l: Concupiscencia carnis &raisedpoint; men called þe elder mayde
And coueytise of eyes &raisedpoint; ycalled was þat oþer
Pryde of parfyte lyuynge &raisedpoint; pursued hem bothe
And badde me for my contenaunce &raisedpoint; acounte clergye liȝte
¶ Concupiscencia carnis &raisedpoint; colled me aboute þe nekke
And seyde þow art ȝonge and ȝepe &raisedpoint; and hast ȝeres ynowe
For to lyue longe &raisedpoint; and ladyes to louye
And in þis myroure þow myȝte se &raisedpoint; myrthes ful manye
Þat leden þe wil to lykynge &raisedpoint; al þi lyf-tyme
¶ Þe secounde seide þe same &raisedpoint; I shal suwe þi wille
Til þow be a lorde and haue londe &raisedpoint; leten þe I nelle
Þat I ne shal folwe þi felawship &raisedpoint; if fortune it lyke
He shal fynde me his frende &raisedpoint; quod fortune þer-after
Þe freke þat folwed my wille &raisedpoint; failled neuere blisse
¶ Thanne was þere one þat hiȝte elde þat heuy was of chere
Man quod he if I mete with þe &raisedpoint; bi Marie of heuene
Þow shalt fynde fortune þe faille &raisedpoint; at þi moste nede
And concupiscencia carnis &raisedpoint; clene þe forsake
Bitterliche shaltow banne þanne &raisedpoint; bothe dayes and niȝtes
Coueytise of eyghe &raisedpoint; þat euere þow hir knewe
And pryde of parfyt lyuynge &raisedpoint; to moche peril þe brynge
¶ Ȝee recche þe neuere quod recchelesnes &raisedpoint; stode forth in ragged clothes
Folwe forth þat fortune wole &raisedpoint; þow hast wel &raisedpoint; fer til elde
A man may stoupe tymes ynow &raisedpoint; whan he shal tyne þe croune
¶ Homo proponit quod a poete &raisedpoint; and plato he hyght
And deus disponit quod he &raisedpoint; lat god done his wille
If trewthe wil witnesse it be wel do &raisedpoint; fortune to folwe
Concupiscencia carnis &raisedpoint; ne coueityse of eyes
Ne shal nouȝt greue þe gretly &raisedpoint; ne bigyle þe but þow wolt
¶ Ȝee farewel phippe quod fauntelte and forth gan me drawe
Til concupiscencia carnis &raisedpoint; acorded alle my werkes
¶ Allas eye quod elde &raisedpoint; and holynesse bothe
Þat witte shal torne to wrecchednesse &raisedpoint; for wille to haue his lykyng
¶ Coueityse of eyghes &raisedpoint; conforted me anon after
And folwed me fourty wynter &raisedpoint; and a fyfte more
Þat of dowel ne dobet &raisedpoint; no deyntee me ne þouȝte
I had no lykynge leue me if þe leste &raisedpoint; of hem auȝte to knowe
¶ Coueytyse of eyes &raisedpoint; cam ofter in mynde
Þan dowel or dobet amonge my dedes alle
Coueytise of eyes conforted me ofte
And seyde haue no conscience how þow come to gode
Go confesse to sum frere &raisedpoint; and shewe hym þi synnes
For whiles fortune is þi frende &raisedpoint; Freres wil þe louye
And fecche þe to her fraternite &raisedpoint; and for þe biseke
To her priour prouyncial &raisedpoint; a pardoun forto haue
And preyen for þe pol bi pol &raisedpoint; ȝif þow be peccuniosus
Set pena pecuniar[i]a non sufficit pro spiritualibus delictis
¶ By wissynge of þis wenche I wrouȝte &raisedpoint; here wordes were so swete
Tyl I forȝat ȝouthe &raisedpoint; and ȝarn in-to elde
And þanne was fortune my foo &raisedpoint; for al hir faire biheste
And pouerte pursued me &raisedpoint; and put me lowe
And þo fonde I þe Frere aferde &raisedpoint; and flyttynge bothe
Aȝeines owre firste forward &raisedpoint; for I seyde I nolde
Be buryed at her hous &raisedpoint; but at my parissh cherche
lg.marginalia: # quia vbi baptizatur ibi sepeliri debetM11.67
lg.l: For I herde onys &raisedpoint; how conscience it tolde
Þat þere a man were crystened &raisedpoint; by kynde he shulde be buryed
Or where he were parisshene &raisedpoint; riȝt þere he shulde be grauen
And for I seyde þus to freres &raisedpoint; a fool þei me helden
And loued me þe lasse for my lele speche
Ac ȝet I cryed on my confessoure þat helde hym-self so kunnyng
lg.marginalia: Friers did not seke þe bodi but the monie.Cr3.11.73
lg.l: By my feith frere quod I &raisedpoint; ȝe faren lyke þise woweres
Þat wedde none wydwes &raisedpoint; but forto welde here godis
Riȝte so by þe Rode &raisedpoint; rouȝte ȝe neuere
Where my body were buryed &raisedpoint; bi so ȝe hadde my siluer
Ich haue moche merueille of ȝow &raisedpoint; and so hath many an other
Why ȝowre couent coueyteth &raisedpoint; to confesse and to burye
Rather þan to baptise barnes &raisedpoint; þat ben catekumelynges
Baptizyng and burying &raisedpoint; bothe ben ful nedeful
lg.marginalia: # quia magis conuenit Baptismum quam sepulcrumM11.81
lg.l: Ac moche more merytorie &raisedpoint; me þynke it is to baptize
For a baptized man &raisedpoint; may as maistres telleth
Þorugh contricioun come &raisedpoint; to þe heigh heuene
Sola contricio &c &raisedpoint;
¶ Ac a barne with-oute bapteme &raisedpoint; may nouȝt so be saued
lg.marginalia: Iohn.iii.Cr3.11.85. This note properly belongs to KD11.83.
lg.l: Nisi quis renatus fuerit loke ȝe lettred men &raisedpoint; whether I lye or do nouȝte
And lewte loked on me &raisedpoint; and I loured after
Wherfore lourestow quod lewte &raisedpoint; and loked on me harde
Ȝif I durste quod I amonges men &raisedpoint; þis meteles auowe
Ȝe bi peter and bi poule quod he &raisedpoint; and take hem bothe to witnesse
Non oderis fratres secrete in corde tuo &raisedpoint; set publice argue illos
¶ Þei wol alleggen also quod I &raisedpoint; and by þe gospel preuen
Nolite iudicare quemquam &raisedpoint;
¶ And wher-of serueth lawe quod lewte &raisedpoint; if no lyf vndertoke it
Falsenesse ne faytrye &raisedpoint; for sumwhat þe apostle seyde
Non oderis fratrem &raisedpoint; and in þe sauter also seithe dauid þe prophete
Existimasti inique quod ero tui similis &c
It is licitum for lewed men &raisedpoint; to segge þe sothe
If hem lyketh and leste &raisedpoint; eche a lawe it graunteth
Excepte parsones and prestes &raisedpoint; and prelates of holycherche
It falleth nouȝte for þat folke &raisedpoint; no tales to telle
Þough þe tale were trewe &raisedpoint; and it touched synne
¶ Þinge þat al þe worlde wote &raisedpoint; wherfore shuldestow spare
And reden it in Retoryke &raisedpoint; to arate dedly synne
Ac be neuere-more þe fyrste &raisedpoint; þe defaute to blame
Þouȝe þow se yuel sey it nouȝte fyrste &raisedpoint; be sorye it nere amended
No þinge þat is pryue &raisedpoint; publice þow it neuere
Neyther for loue laude it nouȝt &raisedpoint; ne lakke it for enuye
Parum lauda vitupera parcius
¶ He seith sothe quod scripture þo &raisedpoint; and skipte an heigh & preched
Ac þe matere þat she meued &raisedpoint; if lewed men it knewe
Þe lasse as I leue &raisedpoint; louyen it þei wolde
¶ This was her teme and her tyxte &raisedpoint; I toke ful gode hede
Multi to a maungerye &raisedpoint; and to þe mete were sompned
And whan þe peple was plenere comen &raisedpoint; þe porter vnpynned þe ȝate
And plukked in pauci priueliche &raisedpoint; and lete þe remenaunt go rowme
¶ Al for tene of her tyxte &raisedpoint; trembled myn herte
And in a were gan I waxe &raisedpoint; and with my-self to dispute
Whether I were chosen or nouȝt chosen &raisedpoint; on holicherche I þouȝte
Þat vnderfonge me atte fonte &raisedpoint; for one of goddis chosne
For cryste cleped vs alle &raisedpoint; come if we wolde
Sarasenes and scismatikes &raisedpoint; and so he dyd þe iewes
O vos omnes [si]cientes venite &c
And badde hem souke for synne &raisedpoint; saufly at his breste
And drynke bote for bale &raisedpoint; brouke it who-so myȝte
¶ Þanne may alle crystene come quod I &raisedpoint; and cleyme þere entre
By þe blode þat he bouȝte vs with &raisedpoint; and þorugh baptesme after
Qui crediderit & baptizatus fuerit &c

marginalia.note: M11.128, must have read "Renoying of Crestyndom."

lg.l: For þough a crystene man coueyted &raisedpoint; his crystenedome to reneye
Riȝtfulliche to renye &raisedpoint; no resoun it wolde

lg.marginalia: # quia Rusticus non debet seipsum manumiscere absque licencia domini suiM11.130
lg.l: ¶ For may no cherle chartre make &raisedpoint; ne his catel selle
With-outen leue of his lorde &raisedpoint; no lawe wil it graunte
Ac he may renne in arrerage &raisedpoint; and rowme so fro home
And as a reneyed caityf recchelesly gon aboute
Ac Resoun shal rekne with hym &raisedpoint; and casten hym in arrerage
And putten after in a prisone &raisedpoint; in purgatorie to brenne
For his arrerages rewarden hym þere &punctuselevatus; to þe daye of dome
But if contricioun wel come &raisedpoint; and crye bi his lyue
Mercy for his mysdedes &raisedpoint; with mouth or with herte
¶ Þat is soth seyde scripture may no synne lette
Mercy alle to amende &raisedpoint; and mekenesse hir folwe
For þey beth as owre bokes telleth &raisedpoint; aboue goddes werkes
Misericordia eius super omnia opera eius
¶ Ȝee baw for bokes quod one &raisedpoint; was broken oute of helle

marginalia.note: L11.145. Reading is unclear, but the scribe appears to have written first trooianus and then corrected the second <o> to <g>.

lg.l: Hiȝte troianus had ben a trewe knyȝte &raisedpoint; toke witnesse at a pope
How he was ded and dampned &raisedpoint; to dwellen in pyne
For an vncristene creature clerkis wyten þe sothe
Þat al þe clergye vnder cryste &raisedpoint; miȝte me cracche fro helle
But onliche loue and leaute &raisedpoint; and my lawful domes
¶ Gregorie wist þis wel &raisedpoint; and wilned to my soule
Sauacioun for sothenesse &raisedpoint; þat he seigh in my werkes
And after þat he wepte &raisedpoint; and wilned me were graunted
Grace wyth-outen any bede-byddynge &raisedpoint; his bone was vnderfonge
And I saued as ȝe may se &raisedpoint; with-oute syngyng of masses
By loue and by lernyng of my lyuyng in treuthe
Brouȝte me fro bitter peyne &raisedpoint; þere no biddyng myȝte
¶ Lo ȝe lordes what leute did &raisedpoint; by an Emperoure of Rome
Þat was an vncrystene creature &raisedpoint; as clerkes fyndeth in bokes
Nouȝt þorw preyere of a pope &raisedpoint; but for his pure treuthe
Was þat sarasene saued &raisedpoint; as seynt Gregorie bereth witnesse
Wel ouȝte ȝe lordes þat lawes kepe &raisedpoint; þis lessoun to haue in mynde
lg.marginalia:
Law . and knoleage without
Loue . availeth no thingeC2.11.163
# quia iusticia eius manet in seculum seculiM11.161
lg.l: And on troianus treuth to thenke &raisedpoint; and do treuthe to þe pepleHere follow 11.160-170 in KD, from alpha; however, none of the lines are annotated.

marginalia.note: O11.164. This rubric, written in a larger and more formal script than that of the rest of the text, may not be written in the main scribal hand.

lg.l: Lawe with-outen loue quod troianus leye þere a bene
lg.marginalia: I lefte hereR11.173. A sixteenth-century secretary hand inscribed for himself a personal bookmark. The note is in the same hand as the marginal note at 43v (R10.305, KD10.289) saying where he started.
lg.l: Or any science vnder sonne &raisedpoint; þe seuene artz and alle
lg.marginalia: # quia magis propter amorem quam pecunie stipendiumM11.164
lg.l: But if þei ben lerned for owre lordes loue &raisedpoint; loste is alle þe tyme
For no cause to cacche siluer þere-by &raisedpoint; ne to be called a mayster
But al for loue of owre lorde &raisedpoint; and þe bet to loue þe peple
For seynte Iohan seyde it &raisedpoint; and soth aren his wordes
Qui non diligit manet in morte
¶ Who-so loueth nouȝte leue me &raisedpoint; he lyueth in deth-deyinge
And þat alle manere men &raisedpoint; enemys and frendes
Louen her eyther other &raisedpoint; and lene hem as her-selue
Who-so leneth nouȝte &raisedpoint; he loueth nouȝte &raisedpoint; god wote þe sothe
And comaundeth eche creature &raisedpoint; to confourme hym to louye
And souereynelyche pore poeple &raisedpoint; and here ennemys after
For hem þat hateth vs &raisedpoint; is owre meryte to louye
And pore peple to plese &raisedpoint; here prayeres may vs helpe
lg.marginalia: # quia in similitudine pauperum visus erat IhesusM11.177
lg.l: For owre ioye and owre hele &raisedpoint; Ihesu cryst of heuene
In a pore mannes apparaille &raisedpoint; pursueth vs euere
And loketh on vs in her liknesse &raisedpoint; and þat with louely chere
To knowen vs by owre kynde herte &raisedpoint; and castyng of owre eyen
Wheþer we loue þe lordes here &raisedpoint; byfor owre lorde of blisse
¶ And exciteth vs bi þe euangelye &raisedpoint; þat when we maken festes
We shulde nouȝte clepe owre kynne þer-to &raisedpoint; ne none kynnes riche
Cum facitis conuiuia nolite inuitare amicos
Ac calleth þe careful þer-to þe croked and þe pore
For ȝowre frendes wil feden ȝow &raisedpoint; and fonde ȝow to quite
Ȝowre festynge and ȝowre faire ȝifte &raisedpoint; vche frende quyteth so other
¶ Ac for þe pore I shal paye &raisedpoint; and pure wel quyte her trauaille
Þat ȝiueth hem mete or moneye &raisedpoint; and loueth hem for my sake
For þe best ben somme riche &raisedpoint; and somme beggers and pore
For alle are we crystes creatures &raisedpoint; and of his coffres riche
And bretheren as of o blode &raisedpoint; as wel beggares as erles &raisedpoint;
For on caluarye of crystes blode &raisedpoint; crystenedome gan sprynge
And blody bretheren we bycome þere &raisedpoint; of o body ywonne
As quasi modo geniti &raisedpoint; and gentil men vche one
No beggere ne boye amonges vs &raisedpoint; but if it synne made
Qui facit peccatum seruus est peccati &c
¶ In þe olde lawe &raisedpoint; as holy lettre telleth
Mennes sones &raisedpoint; men called vs vchone
Of adames issue and Eue &raisedpoint; ay til god-man deyde
And after his resurreccioun &raisedpoint; Redemptor was his name
And we his bretheren þourgh hym ybouȝt &raisedpoint; bothe riche and pore
lg.marginalia: # quia Iocundum est habitare Fratres in vnumM11.203
lg.l: For-þi loue we as leue bretheren shal &raisedpoint; and vche man laughe vp other
And of þat eche man may forbere &raisedpoint; amende þere it nedeth
And euery man helpe other &raisedpoint; for hennes shal we alle
Alter alterius onera portate
And be we nouȝte vnkynde of owre catel &raisedpoint; ne of owre kunnynge neyther
For noet no man how neighe it is &raisedpoint; to be ynome fro bothe
For-þi lakke no lyf other &raisedpoint; þough he more latyne knowe
Ne vnder-nym nouȝte foule &raisedpoint; for is none with-oute faute
For what-euere clerkis carpe of crystenedome or elles
Cryst to a comune woman seyde &raisedpoint; in comune at a feste
lg.marginalia: # quia per Fidem saluata est peccatrixM11.213
lg.l: Þat fides sua shulde sauen hir and saluen hir of alle synnes
¶ Þanne is byleue a lele helpe aboue logyke or lawe
Of logyke ne of lawe in legenda sanctorum
Is litel allowaunce made &raisedpoint; but if bileue hem helpe
For it is ouerlonge ar logyke &raisedpoint; any lessoun assoille
And lawe is loth to louye &raisedpoint; but if he lacche syluer
Bothe logyke and lawe &raisedpoint; þat loueth nouȝte to lye
I conseille alle crystene &raisedpoint; cleue nouȝte þer-on to sore
For sum wordes I fynde ywryten &raisedpoint; were of faithes techyng
Þat saued synful men &raisedpoint; as seynt Iohan bereth wytnesse
Eadem mensura qua mensi fueritis remecietur vobis
¶ For-þi lerne we þe lawe of loue &raisedpoint; as owre lorde tauȝte
And as seynte Gregory seide &raisedpoint; for mannes soule helthe
Melius est scrutari scelera nostra &raisedpoint; quam naturas rerum
¶ Why I moue þis matere &punctuselevatus; is moste for þe pore
For in her lyknesse owre lorde &raisedpoint; ofte hath ben yknowe
Witnesse in þe Paske-wyke &raisedpoint; whan he ȝede to Emaus
Cleophas ne knewe hym nauȝte &raisedpoint; þat he cryste were
For his pore paraille &raisedpoint; and pylgrymes wedes
lg.marginalia: # quia in Fraccione panis cognouerunt eumM11.232
lg.l: Tyl he blessed and brak &raisedpoint; þe bred þat þei eten
So bi his werkes þei wisten &raisedpoint; þat he was Ihesus
Ac by clothyng þei knewe hym nouȝte &raisedpoint; ne bi carpynge of tonge
¶ And al was in ensample &raisedpoint; to vs synful here
Þat we shulde be low &raisedpoint; and loueliche of speche
And apparaille vs nouȝte ouer-proudly &raisedpoint; for pylgrymes ar we alle
And in þe apparaille of a pore man &raisedpoint; and pilgrymes lyknesse
Many tyme god hath ben mette &raisedpoint; amonge nedy peple
lg.marginalia: \ þeR11.251. Between R11.251-252 (KD11.245-246), Hand2 has tried to indicate an insertion point for þe in the previous line where the scribe had already written þe. Also Hand2 has drawn a tail on the original character's descender to make its identity more explicit. Apparently, he understood the scribe's form in line 251 (KD11.245) as ye and was attempting to fix it.
lg.l: Þere neuere segge hym seigh &raisedpoint; in secte of þe riche

lg.marginalia: pureO11.243. Because pore is accompanied by a solidus/punctus above, and marginal pure by a caret/punctus, it seems clear that substitution is intended.
lg.l: ¶ Seynt Iohan and other seyntes &raisedpoint; were seyne in pore clothynge
And as pore pilgrymes &raisedpoint; preyed mennes godis
Ihesu cryste on a iewes douȝter alyȝte &raisedpoint; gentil woman þough she were
lg.marginalia:
To ponyshe me
in shriftR11.255, secretary hand
lg.l: Was a pure pore mayde &raisedpoint; and to a pore man wedded
¶ Martha on Marye magdeleyne &raisedpoint; an huge pleynte she made
And to owre saueour self &raisedpoint; seyde þise wordes
Domine non est tibi cure quod soror mea reliquit me sola ministrare &c
¶ And hastiliche god answered &raisedpoint; and eytheres wille folwed
Bothe Marthaes and Maries &raisedpoint; as Mathew bereth witnesse
Ac pouerte god put bifore &raisedpoint; and preysed it þe bettre
Maria optimam partem elegit &raisedpoint; que non &c
¶ And alle þe wyse þat euere were &raisedpoint; by auȝte I can aspye
Preysen pouerte for best lyf &raisedpoint; if pacience it folwe
And bothe bettere and blisseder &raisedpoint; by many folde þan ricchesse
Although it be soure to suffre &raisedpoint; þere cometh swete after
As on a walnot with-oute is a bitter barke
And after þat bitter barke &raisedpoint; be þe shelle aweye
Is a kirnelle of conforte &raisedpoint; kynde to restore

marginalia.note: M11.259, illegible but likely a guide for the addition of penaunce to the line.

lg.l: So is after pouerte or penaunce &raisedpoint; pacientlyche ytake
For it maketh a man to haue mynde in gode &raisedpoint; and a grete wille
To wepe and to wel bydde &raisedpoint; wher-of wexeth mercy
Of which cryst is a kirnelle &raisedpoint; to conforte þe soule
And wel sykerer he slepyth &raisedpoint; þe man þat is pore
And lasse he dredeth deth &raisedpoint; and in derke to be robbed
Þan he þat is riȝte ryche &raisedpoint; resoun bereth wytnesse
Pauper ego ludo dum tu diues meditaris
¶ Alþough salamon seide &raisedpoint; as folke seeth in þe bible
Diuicias nec paupertates &c
Wyser þan salamon was &raisedpoint; bereth witnesse and tauȝte
Þat parfyte pouert was &raisedpoint; no possessioun to haue
And lyf moste lykynge to god &raisedpoint; as luke bereth witnesse
Si vis perfectus esse &raisedpoint; vade & vende &c
And is to mene to men &raisedpoint; þat on þis molde lyuen
Who-so wil be pure parfyt &raisedpoint; mote possessioun forsake
Or selle it as seith þe boke &raisedpoint; and þe syluer dele
To beggeres þat gone and begge &raisedpoint; and bidden good for goddes loue

lg.marginalia: . nota .O11.278, surrounded at left, right, and bottom by flourishes in black and red.
lg.l: ¶ For failled neuere man mete &raisedpoint; þat myȝtful god serued
As dauid seith in þe sauter &raisedpoint; to suche þat ben in wille
To serue god godeliche &raisedpoint; ne greueth hym no penaunce
Nichil inpossibile volenti
Ne lakketh neuere lyflode &raisedpoint; lynnen ne wollen
Inquirentes autem dominum &raisedpoint; non minuentur omni bono
If prestes weren parfyt &raisedpoint; þei wolde no syluer take
lg.marginalia:
Agaynste takynge of monay
for MassesC2.11.286
lg.l: For masses ne for matynes &raisedpoint; nouȝte her mete of vsureres
Ne neither kirtel ne cote &raisedpoint; þeigh þey for colde shulde deye
And þei her deuor dede &raisedpoint; as dauid seith in þe sauter
Iudica me deus & discerne causam meam
Spera in deo speketh of prestes &raisedpoint; þat haue no spendyng syluer
Þat ȝif þei trauaille trewlich &raisedpoint; and trusten in god almiȝti
Hem shulde lakke no lyflode &raisedpoint; noyther wollen ne lynnen
And þe title þat þei take ordres by &raisedpoint; telleth ȝe ben auaunced
Þanne nedeth nouȝte ȝow to take syluer &raisedpoint; for masses þat ȝe syngen
For he þat toke ȝow ȝowre tytle &raisedpoint; shulde take ȝow ȝowre wages
Or þe bisshop þat blesseth ȝow &raisedpoint; if þat ȝe ben worthy
¶ For made neuere no kynge no knyȝte &raisedpoint; but he hadde catel to spende
As bifel for a kniȝte &raisedpoint; or fonde hym for his strengthe
It is a careful knyȝte &raisedpoint; and of a caytyue kynges makynge
Þat hath no londe ne lynage riche &raisedpoint; ne good loos of his handes
Þe same I segge for sothe &raisedpoint; by alle suche prestes
Þat han noyther kunnynge ne kynne &raisedpoint; but a croune one
And a tytle a tale of nouȝte &raisedpoint; to his lyflode at myschief
lg.marginalia: Priestting was a occupation . to lyue byCr3.11.300
lg.l: He hath more bileue as I leue &raisedpoint; to lacche þorw his croune
Cure &raisedpoint; þan for konnyng &raisedpoint; or knowen for clene of berynge
I haue wonder & why &raisedpoint; and wher-fore þe bisshop
Maketh suche prestes &raisedpoint; þat lewed men bytrayen

lg.marginalia:
The title of
Prestes &cL11.284-324, sixteenth-century annotator, bracket on all text on the page (KD11.283-320).
lg.l: ¶ A chartre is chalengeable &raisedpoint; byfor a chief iustice
If false latyne be in þa lettre &raisedpoint; þe lawe it inpugneth
Or peynted parenterlinarie &raisedpoint; parceles ouer-skipped
Þe gome þat gloseth so chartres &raisedpoint; for a goky is holden
¶ So is it a goky by god &raisedpoint; þat in his gospel failleth
Or in masse or in matynes &raisedpoint; maketh any defaute
Qui offendit in vno in omnibus est reus &c
And also in þe sauter &raisedpoint; seyth dauyd to ouerskippers
Psallite deo nostro psallite quoniam rex terre deus israel psallite sapienter
Þe bisshop shal be blamed &raisedpoint; bifor god as I leue
Þat crouneth suche goddes kniȝtes &raisedpoint; þat conneth nouȝt sapienter
Synge ne psalmes rede &raisedpoint; ne segge a messe of þe day
Ac neuer neyther is blamelees &raisedpoint; þe bisshop ne þe chapleyne
For her eyther is endited &raisedpoint; and þat of ignorancia
Non excusat episcopos &raisedpoint; nec idiotes prestes
¶ Þis lokynge on lewed prestes &raisedpoint; haþ don me lepe fram pouerte
Þe whiche I preyse þere pacyence is &raisedpoint; more parfyt þan ricchesse

marginalia.note: L11.324, contemporary hand. An unrubricated paraph marker appears in the left margin.

lg.l: Ac moche more in metynge þus &raisedpoint; with me gan one dispute
And slepynge I seigh al þis &raisedpoint; and sithen cam kynde
And nempned me by my name &raisedpoint; and bad me nymen hede
And þorw þe wondres of þis worlde &raisedpoint; wytte for to take
And on a mountaigne þat mydelerd hyȝte &raisedpoint; as me þo þouȝte
I was fette forth &raisedpoint; by ensaumples to knowe
Þorugh eche a creature and kynde &raisedpoint; my creatoure to louye
I seigh þe sonne and þe see &raisedpoint; and þe sonde after
And where þat bryddes and bestes &raisedpoint; by here make þei ȝeden
Wylde wormes in wodes &raisedpoint; and wonderful foules
With flekked fetheres &raisedpoint; and of fele coloures
Man and his make &raisedpoint; I myȝte bothe byholde
Pouerte and plente &raisedpoint; bothe pees and werre
Blisse and bale &raisedpoint; bothe I seigh at ones
And how men token Mede &raisedpoint; and mercy refused
¶ Resoune I seighe sothly suen alle bestes
In etyng in drynkynge &raisedpoint; and in engendrynge of kynde
And after course of concepcioun &raisedpoint; none toke kepe of other
As whan þei hadde ryde in rotey-tyme &raisedpoint; anon riȝte þer-after
Males drowen hem to males &raisedpoint; a-mornynges bi hem-self
And in euenynges also &raisedpoint; [þ]e males fro femeles
Þere ne was cow ne cowkynde &raisedpoint; þat conceyued hadde
Þat wolde belwe after boles &raisedpoint; ne bore after sowe
Bothe horse and houndes &raisedpoint; and alle other bestes
Medled nouȝte wyth here makes &raisedpoint; þat with fole were
¶ Briddes I bihelde &raisedpoint; þat in buskes made nestes
Hadde neuere wye witte &raisedpoint; to worche þe leest
I hadde wonder at whom &raisedpoint; and where þe pye lerned
To legge þe stykkes &raisedpoint; in whiche she leythe and bredeth
Þere nys wriȝte as I wene &raisedpoint; shulde worche hir neste to paye
If any masoun made a molde þer-to &raisedpoint; moche wonder it were
¶ And ȝet me merueilled more &raisedpoint; how many other briddes
Hudden and hileden &raisedpoint; her egges ful derne
In mareys and mores &raisedpoint; for men sholde hem nouȝt fynde

marginalia.note: M11.357, belonging to the line in M that corresponds to KD11.354b, 353b. Likely a guide for the addition of þai to the line.

lg.l: And hudden here egges &raisedpoint; whan þei þere-fro wente
For fere of other foules &raisedpoint; and for wylde bestis
¶ And some troden her makes &raisedpoint; and on trees bredden
And brouȝten forth her bryddes so &raisedpoint; al aboue þe grounde
And some bryddes at þe bille &raisedpoint; þorwgh brethynge conceyued
And some kauked I toke kepe &raisedpoint; how pekokes bredden
Moche merueilled me &raisedpoint; what maister þei hadde
And who tauȝte hem on trees &raisedpoint; to tymbre so heigh
Þere noither buirn ne beste &raisedpoint; may her briddes rechen
¶ And sythen I loked vpon þe see &raisedpoint; and so forth vpon þe sterres
Many selcouthes I seygh &raisedpoint; ben nought to seye nouthe
¶ I seigh floures in þe fritthe &raisedpoint; and her faire coloures
And how amonge þe grene grasse &raisedpoint; grewe so many hewes
And somme soure and some swete &raisedpoint; selcouthe me þouȝte
Of her kynde and her coloure &raisedpoint; to carpe it were to longe
¶ Ac þat moste moeued me &raisedpoint; and my mode chaunged
lg.marginalia:
Reason Rewleth all beastes
save man and his make . C2.11.375
lg.l: Þat resoun rewarded &raisedpoint; and reuled alle bestes
Saue man and his make &raisedpoint; many tyme and ofte
No resoun hem folwed &raisedpoint; and þanne I rebukedThis line is condensed in L; in W it is two lines (KD11.372-373, with a "nota" marked by each.
I haue wonder of þe quod I &raisedpoint; þat witty art holden
Why þow ne suwest man and his make &raisedpoint; þat no mysfait hem folwe
¶ And resoun arated me &raisedpoint; and seyde recche þe neuere
Whi I suffre or nouȝt suffre &raisedpoint; þi-self hast nouȝt to done
Amende þow it if þow myȝte &raisedpoint; for my tyme is to abyde
Suffraunce is a souereygne vertue &raisedpoint; and a swyfte veniaunce
Who suffreth more þan god quod he &raisedpoint; no gome as I leue
lg.marginalia: id est mynuteC11.382, intended to change "litel" to "minute"
lg.l: He miȝte amende in a Minute-while &raisedpoint; al þat mys-standeth
Ac he suffreth for somme mannes good &raisedpoint; and so is owre bettreHereafter follow 11.383-93 in KD, from alpha, but they are not annotated.
¶ Þe wyse and þe witty &raisedpoint; wrote þus in þe bible
de re que te non molestat noly certare
lg.marginalia: # quod non decet Forma hominis vituperari quia non FormosaM11.388
lg.l: For be a man faire or foule &raisedpoint; it falleth nouȝte forto lakke
Þe shappe ne þe shafte &raisedpoint; þat god shope hym-selue
For al þat he did was wel ydo &raisedpoint; as holywrit witnesseth
Et vidit deus cunta que fecerat et erant valde bona
¶ And badde euery creature &raisedpoint; in his kynde encrees
Al to murthe with man &raisedpoint; þat most woo tholye
In fondynge of þe flesshe &raisedpoint; and of þe fende bothe
For man was made of suche a matere &raisedpoint; he may nouȝt wel astert
Þat ne some tymes hym bitit &raisedpoint; to folwen his kynde
Catoun acordeth þere-with &raisedpoint; nemo sine crimine viuit
¶ Tho cauȝte I coloure anon &raisedpoint; and comsed to ben aschamed
And awaked þer-with &raisedpoint; wo was me þanne
Þat I in meteles ne myȝte &raisedpoint; more haue yknowen
And þanne seyde I to my-self &raisedpoint; and chidde þat tyme
Now I wote what dowel is quod I &raisedpoint; by dere god as me þinketh
And as I caste vp myn eyghen &raisedpoint; one loked on me and axed
Of me what þinge it were &raisedpoint; ywisse sire I seide
To se moche and suffre more &raisedpoint; certes quod I is dowel
¶ Haddestow suffred he seyde &raisedpoint; slepyng þo þow were
Þow sholdest haue knowen þat clergye can &raisedpoint; and conceiued more þorugh resoun
For resoun wolde haue reherced þe &raisedpoint; riȝte as clergye saide
Ac for þine entermetyng &raisedpoint; here artow forsake
Philosophus esses si tacuisses
¶ Adam w[h]iles he spak nouȝt &raisedpoint; had paradys at wille
Ac whan he mameled aboute mete &raisedpoint; and entermeted to knowe
Þe wisdom and þe witte of god &raisedpoint; he was put fram blisse
And riȝt so ferde resoun bi the &raisedpoint; þow with rude speche
Lakkedest and losedest þinge &raisedpoint; þat longed nouȝt to be done
Þo hadde he no lykynge &raisedpoint; forto lere þe more
¶ Pruide now and presumpcioun &raisedpoint; par-auenture wole þe appele
That clergye þi compaignye &raisedpoint; ne kepeth nouȝt to sue
Shal neuere chalangynge ne chydynge &raisedpoint; chaste a man so sone
As shal shame and shenden hym &raisedpoint; and shape hym to amende
lg.marginalia: Shames is the best remedye for dronkardesCr3.11.418
lg.l: For lat a dronken daffe &raisedpoint; in a dyke falle
Late hym ligge loke nouȝte on hym &raisedpoint; til hym left to ryse

marginalia.note: W11.423, W combines KD11.423 and 431: "For þouȝ Reson rebuked hym þanne . it were but pure synne"

lg.l: For þough resoun rebuked hym þanne &raisedpoint; it were but pure synne

marginalia.note: W11.425, directly follows KD11.429 in W.

lg.l: Ac whan nede nymeth hym vp &raisedpoint; for doute lest he sterue
And shame shrapeth his clothes &raisedpoint; & his shynes wassheth
Þanne wote þe dronken daffe &raisedpoint; wherfore he is to blame
¶ Ȝe seggen soth quod I &raisedpoint; ich haue yseyne it ofte
Þere smitte no þinge so smerte &raisedpoint; ne smelleth so soure
As shame þere he sheweth him &raisedpoint; for euery man hym shonyeth
Why ȝe wisse me þus quod I &raisedpoint; was for I rebuked resoun
¶ Certes quod he þat is soth &raisedpoint; and shope hym forto walken
And I aros vp riȝt with þat &raisedpoint; and folwed hym after
And preyed hym of his curteisye &raisedpoint; to telle me his name
I am ymagynatyf quod he &raisedpoint; Idel was I neuere
Þouȝe I sitte bi my-self &raisedpoint; in sikenesse ne in helthe
I haue folwed þe in feithe &raisedpoint; þis fyue and fourty wyntre
And many tymes haue moeued þe &raisedpoint; to þinke on þine ende
And how fele fernȝeres are faren &raisedpoint; and so fewe to come
And of þi wylde wantounesse &raisedpoint; þo þow ȝonge were
To amende it in þi myddel age &raisedpoint; lest miȝte þe faylled
In þyne olde elde &raisedpoint; þat yuel can suffre
Pouerte or penaunce &raisedpoint; or preyeres bidde
Si non in prima vigilia &raisedpoint; nec in secunda &c
Amende þe while þow myȝte &raisedpoint; þow hast ben warned ofte
With poustees of pestilences with pouerte and with angres
And with þise bitter baleyses &raisedpoint; god beteth his dere childeren
Quem diligo castigo
And dauid in þe sauter seith &raisedpoint; of suche þat loueth Ihesus
Virga tua & baculus tuus ipsa me consolata sunt &c
Al-þough þow stryke me with þi staffe &raisedpoint; with stikke or with ȝerde
It is but murth as for me to amende my soule
And þow medlest þe with makynges &raisedpoint; and myȝtest go sey þi sauter
And bidde for hem þat ȝiueth þe bred &raisedpoint; for þere ar bokes ynowe
To telle men what dowel is &raisedpoint; dobet and dobest bothe
And prechoures to preue what it is &raisedpoint; of many a peyre freres
¶ I seigh wel he sayde me soth &raisedpoint; and somwhat me to excuse
Seid catoun conforted his sone &raisedpoint; þat clerke þough he were
To solacen hym sum-tyme &raisedpoint; as I do whan I make
Interpone tuis interdum gaudia curis &raisedpoint; &c &raisedpoint;
¶ And of holy men I herde quod I &raisedpoint; how þei otherwhile
Pleyden þe parfiter &raisedpoint; to be in many places
Ac if þere were any wight &raisedpoint; þat wolde me telle
What were / dowel / and / dobet / &raisedpoint; and dobest / atte laste
Wolde I neuere do werke &raisedpoint; but wende to holicherche
And þere bydde my bedes &raisedpoint; but whan ich eet or slepe
¶ Poule in his pistle quod he &raisedpoint; preueth what is dowel
Fides spes caritas & maior horum &c
Feith hope and charitee &raisedpoint; and alle ben good
And sauen men sundry tymes &raisedpoint; ac none so sone as charite
For he doth wel with-oute doute &raisedpoint; þat doth as lewte techeth
Þat is if þow be man maried &raisedpoint; þi make þow louye
And lyue forth as lawe wole &raisedpoint; while ȝe lyuen bothe
¶ Riȝt so if þow be Religious &raisedpoint; renne þow neuere ferther
To Rome ne to Rochemadore &raisedpoint; but as þi reule techeth
And holde þe vnder obedyence &raisedpoint; þat heigh wey is to heuene
¶ And if þow be mayden to marye &raisedpoint; and miȝte wel contynue
Seke þow neuere seynt forther &raisedpoint; for no soule helthe
For what made Lucyfer &raisedpoint; to lese þe heigh heuene
Or salamon his sapience &raisedpoint; or sampson his strengthe
Iob þe Iewe his ioye &raisedpoint; dere he it abouȝte
Arestotle and other mo &raisedpoint; ypocras & virgyle
Alisaundre þat al wan &raisedpoint; elengelich ended
¶ Catel and kynde witte &raisedpoint; was combraunce to hem alle
Felyce hir fayrnesse &raisedpoint; fel hir al to sklaundre
And Rosamounde riȝt so reufully bysette
Þe bewte of hir body &raisedpoint; in badnesse she dispended
Of many suche I may rede &raisedpoint; of men and of wommen
Þat wyse wordes wolde shewe &raisedpoint; and worche þe contraye
Sunt homines nequam bene de virtute loquentes
¶ And riche renkes riȝt so &raisedpoint; gaderen and sparen
And þo men þat þei moste haten &raisedpoint; mynistren it atte laste
And for þei suffren & se &raisedpoint; so many nedy folkes
And loue hem nouȝt as owre lorde bytte &raisedpoint; lesen her soules
Date & dabitur vobis &c &raisedpoint;Hereafter follow 12.55-57α in KD, but they are not annotated.
¶ And ricchesse riȝt so &raisedpoint; but if þe Rote be trewe
Ac grace is a grasse þer-of &raisedpoint; þo greuaunces to abate
Ac grace ne groweth nouȝte &raisedpoint; but amonges lowe
Pacience and pouerte &raisedpoint; þe place is þere it groweth
And in lele lyuynge men &raisedpoint; and in lyf-holy
And þorugh þe gyfte of þe holygoste &raisedpoint; as þe gospel telleth
Spiritus vbi vult spirat &c
Clergye and kynde witte &raisedpoint; comth of siȝte and techynge
As þe boke bereth witnesse &raisedpoint; to buirnes þat can rede
Quod scimus loquimur quod vidimus testamur
Of quod scimus cometh clergye &raisedpoint; and connynge of heuene
And of quod vidimus cometh kynde witte of siȝte of dyue[r]se peple
Ac grace is a gyfte of god &raisedpoint; and of gret loue spryngeth
Knewe neuere clerke how it cometh forth &raisedpoint; ne kynde witte þe weyes
Nescit aliquis vnde venit &raisedpoint; aut quo vadit &c
Ac ȝit is clergye to comende &raisedpoint; and kynde witte bothe
And namely clergye for crystes loue &raisedpoint; þat of clergye is rote
For Moyses witnesseth þat god wrote &raisedpoint; for to wisse þe peple
In þe olde lawe as þe lettre telleth &raisedpoint; þat was þe lawe of iewes
Þat what woman were in auoutrie taken &raisedpoint; were she riche or pore
With stones men shulde hir stryke &raisedpoint; and stone hir to deth
A womman as we fynden &raisedpoint; was gulty of þat dede
Ac cryste of his curteisye &raisedpoint; þorw clergye hir saued
For þorw carectus þat cryst wrot &raisedpoint; þe iewes knewe hem-seluen
Gultier as afor god &raisedpoint; and gretter in synne
Þan þe woman þat þere was &raisedpoint; and wenten awey for schame
Þe clergye þat þere was &raisedpoint; conforted þe womman
Holykirke knoweth þis &raisedpoint; þat crystes writyng saued
lg.marginalia: # quia sciencia scripturarum conffortat bonos // malos autem condempnatM12.90
lg.l: So clergye is conforte &raisedpoint; to creatures þat repenten
And to mansed men &raisedpoint; myschief at her ende
¶ For goddes body myȝte nouȝte be of bred &raisedpoint; with-outen clergye
Þe which body is bothe &raisedpoint; bote to þe riȝtful
And deth and dampnacioun &raisedpoint; to hem þat dyeth yuel
As crystes carecte conforted and bothe coupable shewed
Þe womman þat þe iewes brouȝte &raisedpoint; þat Ihesus þouȝte to saue
Nolite iudicare et non iudicabimini &c
Riȝt so goddes body bretheren &raisedpoint; but it be worthily taken
Dampneth vs atte daye of dome &raisedpoint; as þe carectes dede þe iewes
For-þi I conseille þe for cristes sake &raisedpoint; clergye þat þow louye
For kynde witte is of his kyn &raisedpoint; and neighe cosynes bothe
To owre lorde leue me &raisedpoint; for-þi loue hem I rede
For bothe ben as miroures &raisedpoint; to amenden owre defautes
And lederes for lewed men &raisedpoint; and for lettred bothe
¶ For-þi lakke þow neuere logyke &raisedpoint; lawe ne his custumes
Ne countreplede clerkes &raisedpoint; I conseille þe for eure
For as a man may nouȝt se &raisedpoint; þat mysseth his eyghen
Namore can no klerke &raisedpoint; but if he cauȝt it first þorugh bokes
Al-þough men made bokes &raisedpoint; god was þe maistre
lg.marginalia: The holy gost is the autour of bokesCr3.12.110
lg.l: And seynt spirit þe saumplarye &raisedpoint; and seide what men sholde write
And riȝt as syȝte serueth a man &raisedpoint; to se þe heighe strete
Riȝt so ledeth letterure &raisedpoint; lewed men to resoun
And as a blynde man in bataille &raisedpoint; bereth wepne to fiȝte
And hath none happ with his axe &raisedpoint; his enemye to hitte
Namore kan a kynde-witted man &raisedpoint; but clerkes hym teche
Come for al his kynde witte &raisedpoint; to crystendome and be saued
Whiche is þe coffre of crystes tresore &raisedpoint; and clerkes kepe þe keyes
To vnlouken it at her lykynge &raisedpoint; and to þe lewed peple
Ȝyue mercy for her mysdedes &raisedpoint; if men it wole aske
Buxomelich & benygneliche &raisedpoint; and bidden it of grace
¶ Archa dei in þe olde lawe &raisedpoint; leuites it kepten
Hadde neuere lewed man leue &raisedpoint; to leggen honde on þat chest
lg.marginalia: # quia in veteri testamento licitum erat presbiter procreare FiliosM12.123
lg.l: But he were preste or prestes sone &raisedpoint; patriarke or prophete
[¶ Saul for he sacrifised  sorwe hym be-tydde .KD12.116-125α are given here from R; they are lost in the beta tradition but annotated in R.
And his sones al-so  for þat synne myscheued .
And many mo other men  þat were no leuites .
Þat with archa dei ȝeden  in reuerence and in worchippe .
And leyden honde þeron to liften it vp  and loren her lif after .
For-þi I conseil alle creatures  no clergie to dispise .
Ne sette schorte be here science  what-so þei don hem-selue .
Take we her wordes at worthe  for here witnesse be trewe .
And ne medle we nauȝt muche with hem  to meuen any wrathe .
Lest cheste chasen vs  to choppe vche man other .
Nolite tangere christos meos  &cetera .]
¶ For clergye is kepere vnder cryst of heuene
Was þere neuere no knyȝte &raisedpoint; but clergye hym made
Ac kynde witte cometh of alkynnes siȝtes
Of bryddes and of bestes &raisedpoint; of tastes of treuthe and of deceytes
¶ Lyueres to-forn vs &raisedpoint; vseden to marke
Þe selkouthes þat þei seighen &raisedpoint; her sones for to teche
And helden it an heighe science &raisedpoint; her wittes to knowe
Ac þorugh her science sothely &raisedpoint; was neuere no soule ysaued
Ne brouȝte by her bokes &raisedpoint; to blisse ne to ioye
For alle her kynde knowynges &raisedpoint; come but of dyuerse sightes
¶ Patriarkes and prophetes &raisedpoint; repreued her science
And seiden her wordes ne her wisdomes &raisedpoint; nas but a folye
As to þe clergye of cryst &raisedpoint; counted it but a trufle
Sapiencia huius mundi &raisedpoint; stulticia apud deum
For þe heihe holigoste &raisedpoint; heuene shal to-cleue
And loue shal lepe out after &raisedpoint; in-to þis lowe erthe
And clennesse shal cacchen it &raisedpoint; and clerkes shullen it fynde
Pastores loquebantur ad inuicem
¶ He speketh þere of riche men riȝt nouȝt &raisedpoint; ne of riȝt witty
Ne of lordes þat were lewed men &raisedpoint; but of þe hexte lettred oute
Ibant magi ab oriente &c
¶ If any frere were founde þere &raisedpoint; Ich ȝif þe fyue shillynges
lg.marginalia: # quia non natus erat Cristus in diuersorio
lg.l: Ne in none beggares cote &raisedpoint; was þat barne borne
But in a burgeys place &raisedpoint; of bethlem þe best
Set non erat locus in diuersorio / & pauper non habet diuersorium
¶ To pastours and to poetes appiered þat aungel
And bad hem go to bethlem &raisedpoint; goddis burth &raisedpoint; to honoure
And songe a songe of solas &raisedpoint; gloria in excelsis deo
¶ Clerkes knewe it wel &raisedpoint; and comen with here presentz
And deden her homage honourablely &raisedpoint; to hym þat was almyȝty
Why I haue tolde al þis &raisedpoint; I toke ful gode hede
How þow contraryedest clergye &raisedpoint; with crabbed wordes
How þat lewed men liȝtloker &raisedpoint; þan lettred were saued
lg.marginalia: [illegible characters, with legible "a" and partially legible ". .g . ll"]F9.278. may have been intended to identify the speaker (the he of l.270) with the angel of l.268. The text of this line in F is "& Clerkys / þan cleer wittyd men / of þe cristene peple."
lg.l: Þan clerkes or kynde-witted men &raisedpoint; of crystene peple
¶ And þow seidest soth of somme &raisedpoint; ac se in what manere
Take two stronge men &raisedpoint; and in themese caste hem
And bothe naked as a nedle &raisedpoint; her none syker þan other
Þat one hath connynge and can swymmen and dyuen
Þat other is lewed of þat laboure &raisedpoint; lerned neuere swymme
Which trowestow of þo two &raisedpoint; in themese is in moste drede
He þat neuere ne dyued &raisedpoint; ne nouȝt can of swymmynge
Or þe swymmere þat is sauf &raisedpoint; bi so hym-self lyke
Þere his felaw flet forth &raisedpoint; as þe flode lyketh
And is in drede to drenche &raisedpoint; þat neuere dede swymme
¶ Þat swymme can nouȝt I seide &raisedpoint; it semeth to my wittes
¶ Riȝt so quod þe Renke resoun it sheweth
Þat he þat knoweth clergye can sonner aryse
Out of synne and be sauf &raisedpoint; þough he synne ofte
If hym lyketh and lest &raisedpoint; þan any lewed lelly
For if þe clerke be konnynge &raisedpoint; he knoweth what is synne
And how contricioun with-oute confessioun &raisedpoint; conforteth þe soule
As þow seest in þe sauter &raisedpoint; in psalme one or tweyne
How contricioun is commended &raisedpoint; for it caccheth awey synne
Beati quorum remisse sunt iniquitates & quorum tecta sunt &c &raisedpoint;
And þis conforteth vch a clerke &raisedpoint; and keuereth hym fram wanhope
In which flode þe fende &raisedpoint; fondeth a man hardest
Þere þe lewed lith stille &raisedpoint; and loketh after lente
And hath no contricioun ar he come to shryfte &raisedpoint; & þanne can he litel telle
And as his lores-man leres hym &raisedpoint; bileueth & troweth
And þat is after person or parisch prest &raisedpoint; and parauenture
Vnconnynge to lere lewed men &raisedpoint; as luk bereth witnesse
Dum cecus ducit cecum &c &raisedpoint;
¶ Wo was hym marked &raisedpoint; þat wade mote with þe lewed
lg.marginalia:
Clergie and Lettera-
ture . hathe saved
many a man from hangingC2.12.188
lg.l: Wel may þe barne blisse &raisedpoint; þat hym to boke sette
Þat lyuynge after letterure saued hym lyf and soule
Dominus pars hereditatis mee is a meri verset
Þat has take fro tybourne &raisedpoint; twenti stronge þeues
Þere lewed theues ben lolled vp &raisedpoint; loke how þei be saued
Þe thef þat had grace of god &raisedpoint; on gode fryday as þow speke
Was for he ȝelte hym creaunt to cryst on þe crosse &raisedpoint; & knewleched hym gulty
And grace axed of god &raisedpoint; and he is euer redy
Þat boxomeliche biddeth it &raisedpoint; and ben in wille to amenden hem
lg.marginalia:
Difference of blysse &
Ioye in hevenC2.12.197
lg.l: Ac þough þat þef had heuene &raisedpoint; he hadde none heigh blisse

marginalia.foreign:
in domo meo multe
sunt mansiones

lg.l: As seynt Iohan and other seyntes &raisedpoint; þat asserued hadde bettere
Riȝt as sum man ȝeue me mete &raisedpoint; and sette me amydde þe flore
Ich haue mete more þan ynough &raisedpoint; ac nouȝt so moche worship

marginalia.foreign: de latronibus pendentibus ad passionem domini

lg.l: As þo þat seten atte syde table &raisedpoint; or with þe souereignes of þe halle
But sitte as a begger bordelees &raisedpoint; bi my-self on þe grounde
So it fareth bi þat feloun &raisedpoint; þat a gode fryday was saued
He sitte neither with Seynt Iohan &raisedpoint; Symonde ne Iude
Ne wyth maydenes ne with martires confessoures ne wydwes
But by hym-self as a soleyne &raisedpoint; and serued on þe erthe
For he þat is ones a thef &raisedpoint; is euermore in daungere
And as lawe lyketh &raisedpoint; to lyue or to deye
De peccato propiciato noli esse sine metu
And forto seruen a seynt &raisedpoint; and such a thef togyderes
It were noyther resoun ne riȝt &raisedpoint; to rewarde hem bothe aliche
¶ And riȝt as troianus þe trewe knyȝt &raisedpoint; tilde nouȝt depe in helle
Þat owre lorde ne had hym liȝtlich oute &raisedpoint; so leue I þe thef be in heuene
For he is in þe lowest of heuene &raisedpoint; if owre bileue be trewe
And wel loselyche he lolleth þere &raisedpoint; by þe lawe of holycherche
Quia reddit vnicuique iuxta opera sua &c
¶ And why þat one thef on þe crosse &raisedpoint; creaunt hym ȝelt
Rather þan þat other thef &raisedpoint; þough þow wolde appose
Alle þe clerkes vnder cryst &raisedpoint; ne couthe þe skil assoille
Quare placuit quia voluit
And so I sey by þe &raisedpoint; þat sekest after þe whyes
And aresonedest resoun &raisedpoint; a rebukyng as it were
And of þe floures in þe fryth &raisedpoint; and of her feire hewes
Where-of þei cacche her coloures &raisedpoint; so clere and so briȝte
And willest of briddes and of bestes &raisedpoint; and of hire bredyng to knowe
Why somme be alowe and somme alofte &raisedpoint; þi lykyng it were
And of þe stones and of þe sterres &raisedpoint; þow studyest as I leue
lg.marginalia: Onli god knoweth þe causes of thyngsCr3.12.226
lg.l: How euere beste or brydde &raisedpoint; hath so breme wittes
¶ Clergye ne kynde witte ne knewe neuere þe cause
Ac kynde knoweth þe cause hym-selue &raisedpoint; no creature elles
He is þe pyes patroun &raisedpoint; and putteth it in hire ere
Þat þere þe þorne is thikkest &raisedpoint; to buylden and brede
And kynde kenned þe pecok &raisedpoint; to cauken in swich a kynde
And kenned Adam &raisedpoint; to knowe his pryue membres
And tauȝte hym and Eue &raisedpoint; to hylien hem with leues
¶ Lewed men many tymes &raisedpoint; maistres þei apposen
lg.marginalia: # why Adam couered his licam rather than his mowthM12.236
lg.l: Why Adam ne hiled nouȝt firste &raisedpoint; his mouth þat eet þe apple
Rather þan his lykam alow &raisedpoint; lewed axen þus clerkes
Kynde knoweth whi he dede so &raisedpoint; ac no clerke elles
Ac of briddes and of bestes &raisedpoint; men by olde tyme
Ensamples token and termes &raisedpoint; as telleth þis poetes
And þat þe fairest foule &raisedpoint; foulest engendreth
And feblest foule of flyght is &raisedpoint; þat fleegheth or swymmeth
lg.marginalia: Rych men be compared to the Pecocke .Cr3.12.242
lg.l: And þat is þe pekok & þe pohenne proude &raisedpoint; riche men þei bitokneth
For þe pekok and men pursue hym &raisedpoint; may nouȝte fleighe heighe
For þe traillyng of his taille &raisedpoint; ouertaken is he sone
And his flesshe is foule flesshe &raisedpoint; and his feet bothe
And vnlouelich of ledene &raisedpoint; and laith for to here
¶ Riȝt so þe riche if he his ricchesse kepe
And deleth it nouȝt tyl his deth-day &raisedpoint; þe taille of al sorwe
Riȝt as þe pennes of þe pecok &raisedpoint; payned hym in his fliȝte
So is possessioun payne &raisedpoint; of pens &raisedpoint; and of nobles
To alle hem þat it holdeth &raisedpoint; til her taille be plukked
And þough þe riche repente þanne &raisedpoint; and birewe þe tyme
Þat euere he gadered so grete &raisedpoint; and gaf þere-of so litel
Þough he crye to cryst þanne &raisedpoint; with kene wille I leue
His ledne be in owre lordes ere &raisedpoint; lyke a pyes
lg.marginalia: [A series of characters of the alphabet: a, b, c, d, e, f, I, g, h, i, m, n, o, p, ,etc.]S12.254
lg.l: And whan his caroigne shal come &raisedpoint; in caue to be buryed
I leue it flaumbe ful foule &raisedpoint; þe folde al aboute
And alle þe other þer it lyth &raisedpoint; enuenymed þorgh his attere
By þe [po feet] is vnderstonde &raisedpoint; as I haue lerned in auynet
[Ex]ecutoures &raisedpoint; fals frendes &raisedpoint; þat fulfille nouȝt his wille
Þat was writen and þei witnesse &raisedpoint; to worche riȝt as it wolde
Þus þe poete preues &raisedpoint; þat þe pecok for his fetheres is reuerenced
Riȝt so is þe riche &raisedpoint; bi resoun of his godis
¶ Þe larke þat is a lasse foule &raisedpoint; is more louelich of ledne
And wel awey of wenge swifter þan þe pecok
And of flesch by fele-folde &raisedpoint; fatter and swetter
To lowe-lybbyng men &raisedpoint; þe larke is resembled &raisedpoint;

lg.marginalia: # quia de aristotile dubitatum vtrum saluaturM12.269
lg.l: ¶ Arestotle þe grete clerke &punctuselevatus; suche tales he telleth
¶ Thus he lykneth in his logyk &raisedpoint; þe leste foule oute
And where he be sauf or nouȝt sauf &raisedpoint; þe sothe wote no clergye
Ne of sortes ne of salamon &raisedpoint; no scripture can telle
Ac god is so good I hope &raisedpoint; þat sitth he gaf hem wittis
To wissen vs weyes þere-with &raisedpoint; þat wissen vs to be saued
And þe better for her bokes &raisedpoint; to bidden we ben holden
Þat god for his grace gyue her soules reste
For lettred men were lewed men ȝut &raisedpoint; ne were lore of her bokes
¶ Alle þise clerkes quod I þo &raisedpoint; þat on cryst leuen
Seggen in her sarmones &raisedpoint; þat noyther sarasenes ne iewes
Ne no creature of cristes lyknesse &raisedpoint; with-outen crystendome worth saued
¶ Contra quod ymagynatyf þo &raisedpoint; and comsed for to loure
And seyde saluabitur vix iustus in die iudicij
¶ Ergo saluabitur quod he &raisedpoint; and seyde namore latyne
lg.marginalia: # quia Troianus saluatur propter iusticiamM12.284, over erased "Trojanus"
lg.l: Troianus was a trewe knyȝte &raisedpoint; and toke neuere cristendome
And he is sauf so seith þe boke &raisedpoint; and his soule in heuene
For þere is fullyng of fonte &raisedpoint; and fullyng in blode shedyng
And þorugh fuire is fullyng &raisedpoint; and þat is ferme bileue
Aduenit ignis diuinus non comburens sed illuminans &c &raisedpoint;
¶ Ac trewth þat trespassed neuere &raisedpoint; ne transuersed aȝeines his lawe
But lyueth as his lawe techeth &raisedpoint; and leueth þere be no bettere
And if þere were he wolde amende &raisedpoint; and in suche wille deyeth
Ne wolde neuere trewe god &raisedpoint; but treuth were allowed
And where it worth or worth nouȝt &raisedpoint; þe bileue is grete of treuth
And an hope hangyng þer-inne &raisedpoint; to haue a Mede for his treuth
For deus dicitur quasi dans vitam eternam &raisedpoint; suis hoc est fidelibus
et alibi si ambulauero in medio vmbre mortis
Þe glose graunteth vpon þat vers &raisedpoint; a gret mede to treuthe
And witt and wisdome quod þat wye &raisedpoint; was somme-tyme tresore
To kepe with a comune &raisedpoint; no katel was holde bettere
And moche murth and manhod &raisedpoint; and riȝt with þat he vanesched
And I awaked þere-with &raisedpoint; witles nerehande
And as a freke þat fre were &raisedpoint; forth gan I walke
In manere of a mendynaunt &raisedpoint; many a ȝere after
And of þis metyng many tyme &raisedpoint; moche þouȝt I hadde
First how fortune me failled &raisedpoint; at my moste nede
And how þat elde manaced me &raisedpoint; myȝt we euere meten
¶ And how þat freris folwed &raisedpoint; folke þat was riche
And folke þat was pore &raisedpoint; at litel prys þei sette
And no corps in her kirkeȝerde &raisedpoint; ne in her kyrke was buryed
But quikke he biquethe hem auȝte &raisedpoint; or shulde helpe quyte her dettes
And how þis coueitise ouercome &raisedpoint; clerkes and prestes
lg.marginalia: # quia in defectis Curatoribus multi periunt
lg.l: And how þat lewed men ben ladde &raisedpoint; but owre lorde hem helpe
Þorugh vnkonnyng curatoures &raisedpoint; to incurable peynes
¶ And how þat ymagynatyf &raisedpoint; in dremeles me tolde
Of kynde and of his connyng &raisedpoint; and how curteise he is to bestes
And how louynge he is to bestes &raisedpoint; on londe and on water
Leneth he no lyf &raisedpoint; lasse ne more
Þe creatures þat crepen &raisedpoint; of kynde ben engendred
And sitthen how ymagynatif seyde vix iustus saluabitur
And whan he had seyde so &raisedpoint; how sodeynelich he passed
¶ I lay down longe in þis þouȝte &raisedpoint; and atte laste I slepte
And as cryste wolde þere come conscience &raisedpoint; to conforte me þat tyme
And bad me come to his courte &raisedpoint; with clergye sholde I dyne
¶ And for conscience of clergye spake &raisedpoint; I come wel þe rather
And þere I say a maistre &raisedpoint; what man he was I neste
Þat lowe louted &raisedpoint; and loueliche to scripture
¶ Conscience knewe hym wel &raisedpoint; and welcomed hym faire
Þei wesshen and wypeden &raisedpoint; and wenten to þe dyner
Ac pacience in þe paleis stode in pilgrymes clothes
And preyde mete for charite &raisedpoint; for a pore heremyte
¶ Conscience called hym in &raisedpoint; and curteisliche seide
Welcome wye go and wasshe &raisedpoint; þow shalt sitte sone
¶ Þis maister was made sitte &raisedpoint; as for þe moste worthy
And þanne clergye and conscience &raisedpoint; and pacience cam after
¶ Pacience and I were put to be macches
And seten by owre-selue at a syde borde
¶ Conscience called after mete &raisedpoint; and þanne cam scripture
And serued hem þus sone &raisedpoint; of sondry metes manye
Of austyn of ambrose &raisedpoint; of alle þe foure euangelistes
Edentes & bibentes &raisedpoint; que apud eos sunt
Ac þis maister ne his man &raisedpoint; no manere flessh eten
Ac þei ete mete of more coste &raisedpoint; mortrewes and potages
Of þat men mys-wonne &raisedpoint; þei made hem wel at ese
Ac her sauce was ouer soure &raisedpoint; & vnsauourely grounde
In a morter post mortem &raisedpoint; of many bitter peyne
But if þei synge for þo soules &raisedpoint; and wepe salt teres

Vos qui peccata hominum comeditis nisi pro eis lacrimas & oraciones
effunderitis &raisedpoint; ea que in delicijs comeditis &raisedpoint; in tormentis euometis
Conscience ful curteisly þo &raisedpoint; comaunded scripture
Bifor pacience bred to brynge &raisedpoint; and me þat was his macche
He sette a soure lof to-for vs &raisedpoint; and seyde agite penitenciam
And sith he drough vs drynke &raisedpoint; dia perseuerans
As longe quod I as I lyue &raisedpoint; and lycame may dure
Here is propre seruice quod pacience &raisedpoint; þer fareth no prynce bettere
¶ And þanne he brouȝt vs forth a mees of other mete &punctuselevatus; of Mise[r]ere mei deus
And he brouȝte vs of Beati quorum of beatus virres makyng
Et quorum tecta sunt peccata in a dissh
Of derne shrifte dixi and confitebor tibi
Brynge pacience some pitaunce &raisedpoint; pryueliche quod conscience
¶ And þanne had pacience a pitaunce pro hac orabit ad te omnis sanctus in tempore oportuno
And conscience conforted vs &raisedpoint; and carped vs mery tales
Cor contritum & humiliatum deus non despicies
¶ Pacience was proude of þat propre seruice
And made hym muirth with his mete &raisedpoint; ac I morned euere
For þis doctoure on þe heigh dese &raisedpoint; dranke wyn so faste
Ve vobis qui potentes estis ad bibendum vinum
¶ He eet many sondry metes &raisedpoint; mortrewes and puddynges
Wombe cloutes and wylde braune &raisedpoint; & egges y-fryed with grece
Þanne seide I to my-self so &raisedpoint; pacience it herde
It is nouȝt foure dayes &raisedpoint; þat þis freke &raisedpoint; bifor þe den of poules
Preched of penaunces &raisedpoint; þat poule þe apostle suffred
In fame & frigore &raisedpoint; and flappes of scourges
Ter cesus sum & a iudeis quinquies quadragenas &c &raisedpoint;
¶ Ac o worde þei ouerhuppen &raisedpoint; at ech a tyme þat þei preche
Þat poule in his pistel &raisedpoint; to al þe peple tolde
Periculum est in falsis fratribus
holywrit bit men be war &raisedpoint; I wil nouȝt write it here
On englisch an auenture &raisedpoint; it sholde be reherced to ofte
And greue þere-with þat good men ben &raisedpoint; ac gramarienes shul rede
Vnusquisque a fratre se custodiat quia vt dicitur periculum est in falsis fratribus
¶ Ac I wist neuere freke þat as a frere ȝede &raisedpoint; bifor men on englissh
Taken it for her teme &raisedpoint; and telle it with-outen glosynge
Þei prechen þat penaunce is &raisedpoint; profitable to þe soule
And what myschief and malese &raisedpoint; cryst for man tholed
Ac þis goddes gloton quod I &raisedpoint; with his gret chekes
Hath no pyte on vs pore &raisedpoint; he perforneth yuel
Þat he precheth he preueth nouȝt &raisedpoint; to pacience I tolde
And wisshed witterly &raisedpoint; with wille ful egre
Þat disshes a dobleres &raisedpoint; bifor þis ilke doctour
Were moltoun led in his maw &raisedpoint; and Mahoun amyddes
I shal iangle to þis Iurdan &raisedpoint; with his iust wombe
To telle me what penaunce is &raisedpoint; of which he preched rather
Pacience parceyued what I thouȝt &raisedpoint; and wynked on me to be stille
And seyde þow shalt se þus sone &raisedpoint; whan he may no more
He shal haue a penaunce in his paunche &raisedpoint; and puffe at ech a worde
And þanne shullen his guttis godele &raisedpoint; and he shal galpen after
For now he hath dronken so depe &raisedpoint; he wil deuyne sone
And preuen it by her pocalips &raisedpoint; and passioun of seynt Auereys
Þat neither bacoun ne braune &raisedpoint; blanmangere ne mortrewes
Is noither fisshe no flesshe &raisedpoint; but fode for a penaunte
And þanne shal he testifye of a trinitee &raisedpoint; and take his felawe to witnesse
What he fonde in a freyel &raisedpoint; after a freres lyuyng
And but if þe fyrst lyue be lesyng &raisedpoint; leue me neuere after
And þanne is tyme to take &raisedpoint; and to appose þis doctoure
Of dowel and of dobet &raisedpoint; and if dobest be any penaunce
¶ And I sete stille as pacience seyde &raisedpoint; and þus sone þis doctour
As rody as a rose &raisedpoint; rubbed his chekes
Coughed and carped &raisedpoint; and conscience hym herde
And tolde hym of a trinite &raisedpoint; and toward vs he loked
¶ What is dowel sire doctour quod I &raisedpoint; is dowel any penaunce
¶ Dowel quod þis doctour &raisedpoint; and toke þe cuppe and dranke
Do non yuel to þine euenecrystene &raisedpoint; nouȝt by þi powere
¶ By þis day sire doctour quod I þanne be ȝe nouȝt in dowel
For ȝe han harmed vs two &raisedpoint; in þat ȝe eten þe puddyng
Mortrewes and other mete &raisedpoint; and we no mussel hade
And if ȝe fare so in ȝowre fermorie &raisedpoint; ferly me þinketh
But chest be þere charite shulde be &raisedpoint; & ȝonge childern dorste pleyne
I wolde permute my penaunce with ȝowre &raisedpoint; for I am in poynte to dowel
¶ Þanne conscience curteisliche &raisedpoint; a contenaunce he made
And preynte vpon pacience &raisedpoint; to preie me to be stille
And seyde hym-self sire doctour &raisedpoint; and it be ȝowre wille
What is dowel and dobet &raisedpoint; ȝe deuynours knoweth

lg.marginalia: decima discriptio de dowellM13.122. Arabic numeral "10" has been written 01, placing the numeral indicating units to the left of the numeral indicating tens. Treatises on computation instruct writers to begin writing numerals with the units and to proceed with the tens, hundreds, etc., moving, as Arabic scripts do, from right to left. The form here reflects that order of digits, but not that direction of the script. Cf. The Earliest Arithmetics in English, ed. Robert Steele. EETS ES 118, pp. 1-8.

lg.marginalia: Cleargye hath seuen sonnes, þat is the . vii sciences .Cr3.13.124
lg.l: ¶ Now þow clergye quod conscience carpest what is dowel
I haue seuene sones he seyde &raisedpoint; seruen in a castel
Þere þe lorde of lyf wonyeth &raisedpoint; to leren hym what is dowel
¶ Til I se þo seuene &raisedpoint; and my-self acorden
I am vnhardy quod he &raisedpoint; to any wyȝt to preue it
For one pieres þe ploughman hath inpugned vs alle
And sette alle sciences at a soppe &raisedpoint; saue loue one
And no tixte ne taketh to meyntene his cause
But dilige deum &raisedpoint; and domine quis habitabit &c
And seith þat dowel and dobet aren two infinites
Whiche infinites with a feith fynden oute dobest
Which shal saue mannes soule &raisedpoint; þus seith piers þe ploughman
¶ I can nouȝt her-on quod conscience &raisedpoint; ac I knowe wel pieres
He wil nouȝt aȝein holy writ speken &raisedpoint; I dar wel vndertake
Þanne passe we ouer til piers come &raisedpoint; and preue þis in dede
Pacience hath be in many place &raisedpoint; and par-auntre cnoweth
Þat no clerke ne can &raisedpoint; as cryst bereth witnesse
Pacientes vincunt &c
Ac ȝowre preyere quod pacyence þo &raisedpoint; so no man displese hym
Disce quod he doce &raisedpoint; dilige inimicos
Disce and dowel &raisedpoint; / doce / & dobet
Dilige / and dobest &raisedpoint; þus tauȝte me ones
A lemman þat I loued &raisedpoint; loue was hir name
With wordes and with werkes quod she &raisedpoint; and wille of þyne herte
Þow loue lelly þi soule al þi lyf-tyme
And so þow lere þe to louye &raisedpoint; for þe lordes loue of heuene
Þine enemye in al wyse &raisedpoint; euene-forth with þi-selue
Cast coles on his hed &raisedpoint; and al kynde speche
Bothe with werkes and with wordes fonde his loue to wynne
And lay on hym þus with loue &raisedpoint; til he laghe on þe
And but he bowe for þis betyng blynde mote he worthe
¶ Ac for to fare þus with þi frende &raisedpoint; foly it were
For he þat loueth þe lelly &raisedpoint; lyte of þyne coueiteth
Kynde loue coueiteth nouȝte &raisedpoint; no catel but speche
With half a laumpe lyne in latyne &raisedpoint; ex vi transicionis
¶ I bere þere-inne aboute &raisedpoint; fast ybounde dowel
In a signe of þe saterday &raisedpoint; þat sette firste þe kalendare
And al þe witte of þe wednesday &raisedpoint; of þe nexte wyke after
Þe myddel of þe mone is þe miȝte of bothe
And here-with am I welcome &raisedpoint; þere I haue it with me
¶ Vndo it late þis doctour deme &raisedpoint; if dowel be þer-inne
For bi hym þat me made &raisedpoint; miȝte neuere pouerte
Miseise ne myschief ne man with his tonge
Colde ne care ne compaignye of theues
Ne noither hete ne haille &raisedpoint; ne non helle pouke
Ne noither fuire ne flode &raisedpoint; ne fere of þine enemy
Tene þe eny tyme &raisedpoint; and þow take it with þe
Caritas nichil timetHereafter follows 13.164-171α in KD, but they are not annotated.
¶ It is but a dido quod þis doctour &raisedpoint; a dysoures tale
Al þe witt of þis worlde &raisedpoint; and wiȝte mennes strengthe
Can nouȝt confourmen a pees &raisedpoint; bytwene þe pope and his enemys
Ne bitwene two cristene kynges &raisedpoint; can no wiȝte pees make
Profitable to ayther peple &raisedpoint; and put þe table fro hym
And toke clergye and conscience &raisedpoint; to conseille as it were
Þat pacience þo moste passe &raisedpoint; for pilgrimes kunne wel lye
¶ Ac conscience carped loude and curteislich seide
Frendes fareth wel &raisedpoint; and faire spake to clergye
lg.marginalia: Cleargye is loth þat Conscience should go withpatienceCr3.13.179
lg.l: For I wil go with þis gome &raisedpoint; if god wil ȝiue me grace
And be pilgryme with pacience &raisedpoint; til I haue proued more
¶ What quod clergye to conscience &raisedpoint; ar ȝe coueitouse nouthe
After ȝeresȝyues or ȝiftes &raisedpoint; or ȝernen to rede redeles
I shal brynge ȝow a bible &raisedpoint; a boke of þe olde lawe
And lere ȝow if ȝow lyke &raisedpoint; þe leest poynte to knowe
Þat pacience þe pilgryme &raisedpoint; parfitly knewe neuere
¶ Nay bi cryste quod conscience to clergye god þe forȝelde
For al þat pacience me profreth &raisedpoint; proude am I litel
Ac þe wille of þe wye &raisedpoint; and þe wille folke here
Hath moeued my mode &raisedpoint; to mourne for my synnes
Þe good wille of a wiȝte &raisedpoint; was neure bouȝte to þe fulle
For þere nys no tresore þerto &raisedpoint; to a trewe wille
¶ Haued nouȝt Magdeleigne more &raisedpoint; for a boxe of salue
Þan zacheus for he seide &raisedpoint; dimidium bonorum meorum do pauperibus
And þe pore widwe for a peire of mytes
Þan alle þo that offreden &raisedpoint; in-to gazafilacium

lg.l: If pacience be owre partyng felawe &raisedpoint; and pryue with vs bothe
