I shal dwelle as I do &raisedpoint; my deuore to shewen
And confermen fauntekynes &raisedpoint; and other folke ylered
Tyl pacience haue preued þe &raisedpoint; and parfite þe maked
¶ Conscience þo with pacience passed &raisedpoint; pilgrymes as it were
lg.marginalia: # vitayles off paciens sobrete & soft spechM13.217
lg.l: Þanne had pacience as pylgrymes han &raisedpoint; in his poke vittailles
Sobrete and symple speche &raisedpoint; and sothfaste byleue
To conforte hym and conscience &raisedpoint; if þey come in place
Þere vnkyndenesse and coueytise is &raisedpoint; hungrye contrees bothe
¶ And as þei went by þe weye &raisedpoint; of dowel þei carped
Þei mette with a mynstral &raisedpoint; as me þo þouȝte
Pacience apposed hym fyrste &raisedpoint; and preyed hym he sholde hem telle
To conscience what crafte he couthe &raisedpoint; an to what contree he wolde
¶ I am a mynstral quod þat man &raisedpoint; my name is actiua vita
Alle ydel ich hatye &raisedpoint; for of actyf is my name
A wafrere wil ȝe wite &raisedpoint; and serue many lordes
And fewe robes I fonge &raisedpoint; or furred gounes
Couthe I lye to do men laughe &raisedpoint; þanne lacchen I shulde
Other mantel or money amonges lordes mynstralles
Ac for I can noither tabre ne trompe &raisedpoint; ne telle none gestes
Farten ne fythelen at festes ne harpen
Iape ne iogly &raisedpoint; ne gentlych pype
Ne noyther sailly ne saute &raisedpoint; ne synge with þe gyterne
I haue none gode gyftes &raisedpoint; of þise grete lordes &raisedpoint;
For no bred þat I brynge forth &raisedpoint; saue a beneson on þe sonday
Whan þe prest preyeth þe peple &raisedpoint; her pater noster to bidde
For peres þe plowman &raisedpoint; and þat hym profite wayten
And þat am I actyf &raisedpoint; þat ydelnesse hatye
For alle trewe trauaillours &raisedpoint; and tilieres of þe erthe
Fro mychelmesse to mychelmesse &raisedpoint; I fynde hem with wafres
¶ Beggeres and bidderes &raisedpoint; of my bred crauen
Faitoures and freres &raisedpoint; and folke with brode crounes
I fynde payne for þe pope &raisedpoint; and prouendre for his palfrey
And I hadde neuere of hym &raisedpoint; haue god my treuthe
Noither prouendre ne parsonage &raisedpoint; ȝut of the popis ȝifte
Saue a pardoun with a peys of led &raisedpoint; and two pollis amydde
Hadde iche a clerke þat couthe write &raisedpoint; I wolde caste hym a bille

marginalia.note: R13.256, 15th century hand, brace in left margin R13.256-257 (KD13.248-249)

lg.l: Þat he sent me vnder his seel &raisedpoint; a salue for þe pestilence
And þat his blessyng & his bulles &raisedpoint; bocches miȝte destroye
In nomine meo demonia eici[e]nt & super egros manus imponent & bene habebunt
And þanne wolde I be prest to peple &raisedpoint; paste for to make
And buxome and busy aboute bred and drynke
For hym and for alle his &raisedpoint; fonde I þat his pardoun
Miȝte lechen a man &raisedpoint; as I bileue it shulde
For sith he hath þe powere &raisedpoint; þat peter hym-self hadde
He hath þe potte with þe salue &raisedpoint; sothly as me þinketh
Argentum & aurum non est michi quod autem habeo tibi do in nomine domini surge & ambula
¶ Ac if miȝte of miracle hym faille &raisedpoint; it is for men ben nouȝt worthy
To haue þe grace of god &raisedpoint; & no gylte of þe pope
For may no blyssyng done vs bote &raisedpoint; but if we wil amende
Ne mannes masse make pees &raisedpoint; amonges cristene peple
Tyl pruyde be purelich fordo &raisedpoint; and þat þourgh payn defaute
¶ For ar I haue bred of mele &raisedpoint; ofte mote I swete
And ar þe comune haue corne ynough &raisedpoint; many a colde mornyng
So ar my wafres ben ywrouȝt &raisedpoint; moche wo I tholye
¶ Alle Londoun I leue &raisedpoint; liketh wel my wafres
And lowren whan þei lakken it &raisedpoint; it is nouȝt longe ypassed
Þere was a carful comune &raisedpoint; whan no carte come to toune

marginalia.note: W13.271, 16th century hand. A. I. Doyle noted it "is very like" that of the antiquarian John Stow in the introduction to KD (p. 14). The same hand supplied the same marginal note at R13.278 as well as the date "1350" in the margin beside W13.274 (KD13.269).

lg.l: With bred fro stretforth &raisedpoint; þo gan beggeres wepe
And werkmen were agaste a litel &raisedpoint; þis wil be þouȝte longe
In þe date of owre dryȝte &raisedpoint; in a drye apprile
A þousande and thre hondreth &raisedpoint; tweis thretty & ten
My wafres þere were gesen &raisedpoint; whan chichestre was Maire
¶ I toke gode kepe by cryst &raisedpoint; and conscience bothe
Of haukyn þe actyf man &raisedpoint; and how he was yclothed
He hadde a cote of crystendome &raisedpoint; as holykirke bileueth
Ac it was moled in many places &raisedpoint; with many sondri plottes
Of pruyde here a plotte &raisedpoint; and þere a plotte of vnboxome speche
Of scornyng and of scoffyng &raisedpoint; and of vnskilful berynge
As in aparaille and in porte &raisedpoint; proude amonges þe peple
Otherwyse þan he hath &raisedpoint; with herte or syȝte shewynge
Hym willynge þat alle men wende &raisedpoint; he were þat he is nouȝte
For-why he bosteth and braggeth &raisedpoint; with many bolde othes
And in-obedient to ben vndernome &raisedpoint; of any lyf lyuyng
And so syngulere by hym-self &raisedpoint; as to syȝte of þe poeple
Was none suche as hym-self &raisedpoint; ne none so pompe-holy
Yhabited as an hermyte &raisedpoint; an ordre by hym-selue
Religioun sanz reule &raisedpoint; and resonable obedience
Lakkyng lettred men &raisedpoint; and lewed men bothe
In lykyng of lele lyf &raisedpoint; and a lyer in soule
With Inwit and with outwitt &raisedpoint; ymagenen and studye
As best for his body be &raisedpoint; to haue a badde name
And entermeten hym ouer al &raisedpoint; þer he hath nouȝt to done
Wilnyng þat men wende &raisedpoint; his witte were þe bestHereafter follow 13.292-298 in KD from alpha, but they are not annotated.
And if he gyueth ouȝte pore gomes &raisedpoint; telle what he deleth
Pore of possessioun in purse &raisedpoint; and in coffre
And as a lyon on to loke &raisedpoint; and lordeliche of speche
¶ Baldest of beggeres a bostour þat nouȝt hath
In towne and in tauernes &raisedpoint; tales to telle
And segge þinge þat he neuere seigh &raisedpoint; and for soth sweren it
Of dedes þat he neuere dyd &raisedpoint; demen and bosten
And of werkes þat he wel dyd &raisedpoint; witnesse and seggen
Lo if ȝe leue me nouȝt &raisedpoint; or þat I lye wenen
Axeth at hym or at hym &raisedpoint; and he ȝow can telle
What I suffred and seighe &raisedpoint; and some tymes hadde
And what I couth and knewe &raisedpoint; and what kynne I come of
Al he wolde þat men wiste of werkes and of wordes
Which myȝte plese þe peple &raisedpoint; and praysen hym-seluen
Si hominibus placerem cristi seruus non essem
Et alibi nemo potest duobus dominis seruire
¶ Bi criste quod conscience þo &raisedpoint; þi best cote haukyn
Hath many moles and spottes &raisedpoint; it moste ben ywassh
¶ Ȝe who-so toke hede quod haukyn &raisedpoint; byhynde and bifore
What on bakke and what on bodyhalf &raisedpoint; & by þe two sydes
Men sholde fynde many frounces &raisedpoint; and many foule plottes
¶ And he torned hym as tyte &raisedpoint; and þanne toke I hede
It was fouler by felefolde &raisedpoint; þan it firste semed
It was bidropped with wratthe &raisedpoint; and wikked wille
With enuye and yuel speche entysyng to fyȝte
Lyinge and laughynge &raisedpoint; and leue tonge to chyde
Al þat he wist wykked &raisedpoint; by any wiȝte tellen it
And blame men bihynde her bakke &raisedpoint; and bydden hem meschaunce
And þat he wist bi wille &raisedpoint; tellen it watte
And þat watte wiste &raisedpoint; wille wiste it after
And made of frendes foes &raisedpoint; þorugh a false tonge
Or with myȝte of mouthe or þorugh mannes strengthe
Auenge me fele tymes &raisedpoint; other frete my-selue
Wyth-inne as a shepster shere &raisedpoint; I-shrewed men & cursed
Cuius maledictione os plenum est & amaritudine sub lingua eius labor & dolor
& alibi filij hominum dentes eorum arma & sagitte & lingua eorum gladius acutus
¶ Þere is no lyf þat I louye &raisedpoint; lastyng any while
For tales þat I telle &raisedpoint; no man trusteth to me
And whan I may nouȝt haue þe maistrye &raisedpoint; with malencolye I take
Þat I cacche þe crompe &raisedpoint; þe cardiacle some-tyme
Or an ague in suche an angre &raisedpoint; and some-tyme a feure
Þat taketh me al a twelf-moneth &raisedpoint; tyl þat I dispyse
Lechecrafte or owre lorde &raisedpoint; and leue on a wicche
And segge þat no clerke ne can &raisedpoint; ne cryste as I leue
lg.marginalia: nota sowter of sotwerkR13.356, 15th century hand
lg.l: To þe souter of southwerke &raisedpoint; or of shordyche dame emme
And segge þat no goddes worde &raisedpoint; gaf me neuere bote
But þorw a charme had I chaunce &raisedpoint; & my chief hele
¶ I wayted wisloker &raisedpoint; and þanne was it soiled
With lykyng of lecherye &raisedpoint; as by lokyng of his eye
For vche a mayde þat he mette &raisedpoint; he made hir a signe
Semynge to synne-ward &raisedpoint; and some-tyme he gan taste
Aboute þe mouth or bynethe &raisedpoint; bygynneth to grope
Tyl eytheres wille waxeth kene &raisedpoint; and to þe werke ȝeden
lg.marginalia: Yonge lechour old baude .Cr3.13.343. There is also a bracket?
lg.l: As wel in fastyng-days & frydayes &raisedpoint; and forboden nyȝtes
And as wel in lente as oute of lente &raisedpoint; alle tymes ylyche
Suche werkes with hem &raisedpoint; was neuere oute of sesoun
Tyl þei myȝte namore &raisedpoint; and þanne had merye tales
And how þat lechoures louyen &raisedpoint; lauȝen an iapen
And of her harlotrye and horedome &raisedpoint; in her elde tellen
¶ Thanne pacience parceyued of poyntes his cote
Was colmy þorw coueityse &raisedpoint; and v[n]kynde desyrynge
More to good þan to god &raisedpoint; þe gome his loue caste
And ymagyned how &raisedpoint; he it myȝte haue
With false mesures and mette &raisedpoint; and with false witnesse
Lened for loue of þe wedde &raisedpoint; and loth to do treuthe
And awaited þorwgh which wey to bigile
And menged his marchaundyse &raisedpoint; and made a gode moustre
Þe worste with-in was &raisedpoint; a gret witte I lete hit
And if my neighbore had any hyne &raisedpoint; or any beste elles
More profitable þan myne &raisedpoint; many sleightes I made
How I myȝte haue it &raisedpoint; al my witte I caste
And but I it had by other waye &raisedpoint; atte laste I stale it
Or pryuiliche his purse shoke &raisedpoint; vnpiked his lokkes
Or by nyȝt or by day &raisedpoint; aboute was ich euere
Þorwgh gyle to gadren þe good þat ich haue
¶ Ȝif I ȝede to þe plow &raisedpoint; I pynched so narwe
Þat a fote londe or a forwe &raisedpoint; fecchen I wolde
Of my nexte neighbore &raisedpoint; nymen of his erthe
And if [I] rope ouer-reche &raisedpoint; or ȝaf hem red þat ropen
To seise to me with her sykel &raisedpoint; þat I ne sewe neure
¶ And who-so borweth of me &raisedpoint; aboute þe tyme
With presentes priueliche &raisedpoint; or payed somme certeyne
So walde he or nouȝt wolde he &raisedpoint; wynnen I wolde
And bothe to kyth and to kyn &raisedpoint; vnkynde of þat ich hadde
¶ And who-so cheped my chaffare &raisedpoint; chiden I wolde
But he profred to paye &raisedpoint; a peny or tweyne
More þan it was worth &raisedpoint; and ȝet wolde I swere
Þat it coste me moche more &raisedpoint; swore manye othes
¶ In halydayes at holicherche &raisedpoint; whan ich herde masse
Hadde neuere wille wot god &raisedpoint; witterly to biseche
Mercye for my mysdedes &raisedpoint; þat I ne morned more
For losse of gode leue me &raisedpoint; þan for my lykames giltes
As if I had dedly synne done &raisedpoint; I dred nouȝt þat so sore
As when I lened and leued it lost &raisedpoint; or longe ar it were payed
So if I kydde any kyndenesse &raisedpoint; myn euen-cristene to helpe
Vpon a cruel coueityse &raisedpoint; myn herte gan hange
And if I sent ouer-see &raisedpoint; my seruauntz to Bruges
Or in-to Pruslonde my prentys &raisedpoint; my profit to wayten
To marchaunden with monoye &raisedpoint; and maken her eschaunges
Miȝte neuere me conforte &raisedpoint; in þe mene-tyme
Noither messe ne matynes &raisedpoint; ne none manere siȝtes
Ne neuere penaunce perfourned &raisedpoint; ne pater noster seyde
Þat my mynde ne was more &raisedpoint; on my gode in a doute
Þan in þe grace of god &raisedpoint; and his grete helpes
Vbi thesaurus tuus &raisedpoint; ibi & cor tuumHereafter follow 13.399-408 in KD, from alpha, but they are not annotated.

lg.marginalia:
The braunches þat brin-
geth a man to sloutheC2.13.400
lg.l: ¶ Which ben þe braunches &raisedpoint; þat bryngeth a man to sleuth
His woman morneth nouȝte for his mysdedes &raisedpoint; ne maketh no sorwe
Ac penaunce þat þe prest enioigneth &raisedpoint; perfourneth yuel
Doth none almes-dede &raisedpoint; dret hym of no synne
Lyueth aȝein þe bileue &raisedpoint; and no lawe holdeth
Vch day is haliday with hym &raisedpoint; or an heigh ferye

marginalia.note: M13.405, legible with ultraviolet light. The comment was rewritten in its proper place below.

lg.l: And if he auȝte wole here &raisedpoint; it is an harlotes tonge
Whan men carpeth of cryst &raisedpoint; or of clennesse of soule
He wexeth wroth & wil nouȝte here &raisedpoint; but wordes of myrthe
Penaunce and pore men &raisedpoint; and þe passioun of seyntes
He hateth to here þere-of &raisedpoint; and alle þat it telleth
Þise ben þe braunches beth war &raisedpoint; þat bryngeth a man to wanhope
Ȝe lordes and ladyes &raisedpoint; and legates of holicherche
Þat fedeth foles sages &raisedpoint; flatereres and lyeres
And han likynge to lythen hem &raisedpoint; to do ȝow to lawghe
Ve vobis qui ridetis &c
And ȝiueth hem mete and Mede &raisedpoint; and pore men refuse
In ȝowre deth-deyinge &raisedpoint; I drede me ful sore
Lest þo thre maner men &raisedpoint; to moche sorwe ȝow brynge
Consencientes & agentes pari pena punientur
Patriarkes & prophetes &raisedpoint; and prechoures of goddes wordes
Sauen þorw her sarmoun &raisedpoint; mannes soule fram helle
Riȝt so flateres and foles &raisedpoint; aren þe fendes disciples
To entice men þorw her tales to synne and harlotrye
Ac clerkes þat knowen holywryt &raisedpoint; shulde kenne lordes
What dauid seith of suche men &raisedpoint; as þe sauter telleth
Non habitabit in medio domus mee &raisedpoint; qui facit superbiam & qui loquitur iniqua
Shulde none harlote haue audience &raisedpoint; in halle ne in chambres
Þere wise men were &raisedpoint; witnesseth goddes wordes
Ne no mysproude man &raisedpoint; amonges lordes ben allowedHereafter follow 13.436-453 in KD, from alpha, but they are not annotated.
¶ Ac flateres and foles þorw her foule wordes
Leden þo þat louen hem &raisedpoint; to luciferes feste
With turpiloquio a lay of sorwe &raisedpoint; and luciferes fithele
Thus haukyn þe actyf man &raisedpoint; hadde ysoiled his cote
Til conscience acouped hym þere-of &raisedpoint; in a curteise manere
Whi he ne hadde wasshen it &raisedpoint; or wyped it with a brusshe
I Haue but one hatere quod haukyn &raisedpoint; I am þe lasse to blame
Þough it be soiled and selde clene &raisedpoint; I slepe þere-inne on niȝtes
And also I haue an houswyf &raisedpoint; hewen and children
Vxorem duxy & ideo non possum venire
Þat wolen bymolen it many tyme &raisedpoint; maugre my chekes

lg.marginalia: Haukins cote wyll not be cleane .Cr3.14.6
lg.l: ¶ It hath ben laued in lente &raisedpoint; and oute of lente bothe
With þe sope of sykenesse &raisedpoint; þat seketh wonder depe
And with þe losse of catel &raisedpoint; loth forto agulte
God or any gode man &raisedpoint; bi auȝte þat I wiste
And was shryuen of þe preste &raisedpoint; þat gaue me for my synnes
To penaunce pacyence &raisedpoint; and pore men to fede
Al for coueitise of my crystenedome &raisedpoint; in clennesse to kepen it
¶ And couthe I neuere by cryste &raisedpoint; kepen it clene an houre
Þat I ne soiled it with syȝte &raisedpoint; or sum ydel speche
Or þorugh werke or þorugh worde &raisedpoint; or wille of myn herte
Þat I ne flober it foule &raisedpoint; fro morwe tyl eue
¶ And I shal kenne þe quod conscience &raisedpoint; of contricioun to make
Þat shal clawe þi cote &raisedpoint; of alkynnes filthe
Cordis contricio &c
Dowel wasshen it and wryngen it &raisedpoint; þorw a wys confessour
Oris confessio &c
Dobet shal beten it and bouken it &raisedpoint; as briȝte as any scarlet
And engreynen it with good wille &raisedpoint; and goddes grace to amende þe
And sithen sende þe to satisfaccioun &raisedpoint; for to sowen it after
Satisfaccio dobest

lg.marginalia: - C14.26 (the line in C combines KD14.22-23.
lg.l: ¶ Shal neuere myste bimolen it &raisedpoint; ne moth after biten it
Ne fende ne false man defoulen it in þi lyue
Shal none heraude ne harpoure &raisedpoint; haue a fairere garnement
Þan haukyn þe actyf man &raisedpoint; and þow do by my techyng
Ne no mynstral be more worth &raisedpoint; amonges pore & riche
Þan Haukynnes wyf þe wafrere &raisedpoint; with his actiua vita

marginalia.foreign:
Si mea penna valet melior mea litera fiet
Dextera pars penna Brevior et lenior debit esse
marginalia.note: R14.32, secretary hand. Written horizontally bottom to top, R14.32-54 (KD14.29-46α)

lg.l: ¶ And I shal purueye þe paste quod pacyence &raisedpoint; þough no plow erie
And floure to fede folke with &raisedpoint; as best be for þe soule
Þough neuere greyne growed &raisedpoint; ne grape vppon vyne
Alle þat lyueth and loketh &raisedpoint; lyflode wolde I fynde
And þat ynough shal none faille &raisedpoint; of þinge þat hem nedeth
We shulde nouȝt be to busy &raisedpoint; abouten owre lyflode
Ne solliciti sitis &c volucres celi deus pascit &c pacientes vincunt &c
¶ Þanne laughed haukyn a litel &raisedpoint; and liȝtly gan swerye
Who-so leueth ȝow by owre lorde &raisedpoint; I leue nouȝte he be blissed

lg.marginalia: God geueth not lyfe, but he prouideth fode.Cr3.14.41
lg.l: ¶ No quod pacyence paciently &raisedpoint; and out of his poke hente
Vitailles of grete vertues &raisedpoint; for al manere bestes
And seyde lo here lyflode ynough &raisedpoint; if owre byleue be trewe
For lente neuere was lyf &raisedpoint; but lyflode were shapen
Wher-of or wherfore &raisedpoint; or where-by to lybbe
¶ Firste þe wylde worme &raisedpoint; vnder weet erthe
Fissch to lyue in þe flode &raisedpoint; and in þe fyre þe crykat
Þe corlue by kynde of þe eyre &raisedpoint; moste clennest flesch of bryddes
And bestes by grasse and by greyne &raisedpoint; and by grene rotis
In menynge þat alle men &raisedpoint; myȝte þe same
Lyue þorw lele byleue and loue &raisedpoint; as god witnesseth
Quodcumque pecieritis a patre in nomine meo &c & alibi
Non in solo pane viuit homo set in omni verbo quod procedit de ore dei
¶ But I loked what lyflode it was &raisedpoint; þat pacience so preysed
And þanne was it a pece of þe pater noster &raisedpoint; fiat voluntas tua &raisedpoint;
¶ Haue haukyn quod pacyence &raisedpoint; and ete þis whan þe hungreth
Or whan þow clomsest for colde &raisedpoint; or clyngest for drye
Shal neuere gyues þe greue &raisedpoint; ne grete lordes wrath
Prisone ne peyne &raisedpoint; for pacientes vincunt
¶ Bi so þat þow be sobre &raisedpoint; of syȝte and of tonge
In etynge and in handlyng &raisedpoint; and in alle þi fyue wittis
Darstow neuere care for corne &raisedpoint; ne lynnen cloth ne wollen
Ne for drynke ne deth drede &raisedpoint; but deye as god lyketh
Or þorw honger or þorw hete &raisedpoint; at his wille be it
For if þow lyuest after his lore &raisedpoint; þe sho[r]ter lyf þe better
Si quis amat cristum mundum non diligit istum
¶ For þorw his breth bestes wexen &raisedpoint; and abrode ȝeden
Dixit & facta sunt &c &raisedpoint;
Ergo þorw his breth mowen &raisedpoint; men & bestes lyuen
As holywrit witnesseth &raisedpoint; whan men segge her graces
Aperis tu manum tuam &raisedpoint; & imples omne animal benediccione
¶ It is founden þat fourty wynter &raisedpoint; folke lyued with-outen tulying
And oute of þe flynte spronge þe flode &raisedpoint; þat folke & bestes dronke
And in Elyes tyme &raisedpoint; heuene was yclosed
Þat no reyne ne rone &raisedpoint; þus rede men in bokes
Þat many wyntres men lyueden &raisedpoint; and no mete ne tulyeden
Seuene slepe as seith þe boke &raisedpoint; seuene hundreth wynter
¶ And lyueden with-oute lyflode &raisedpoint; and atte laste þei woken
And if men lyued as mesure wolde &raisedpoint; shulde neuere-more be defaute
lg.marginalia: Lacke of measure is cause of scarcitie .Cr3.14.79. There is also a bracket?
lg.l: Amonges cristene creatures &raisedpoint; if crystes wordes ben trewe
Ac vnkyndnesse carestia maketh &raisedpoint; amonges crystene peple
And ouer-plente maketh pruyde &raisedpoint; amonges pore & riche
Ac mesure is so moche worth &raisedpoint; it may nouȝte be to dere
For þe meschief and þe meschaunce &raisedpoint; amonges men of sodome
Wex þorw plente of payn &raisedpoint; & of pure sleuthe
Ociositas & habundancia panis peccatum turpissimum nutriuit
For þei mesured nouȝt hem-self &raisedpoint; of þat þei ete and dronke
Diden dedly synne þat þe deuel lyked
So vengeaunce fel vpon hem &raisedpoint; for her vyle synnes
Þei sonken in-to helle &raisedpoint; þo citees &raisedpoint; vchone
¶ For-þi mesure we vs wel &raisedpoint; and make owre faithe owre scheltroun
lg.marginalia: # quia contricio delit peccatum a Mortale in venialeM14.93
lg.l: And þorw faith cometh contricioun &raisedpoint; conscience wote wel
Whiche dryueth awey dedly synne &raisedpoint; and doth it to be venial
And þough a man myȝte nouȝte speke &raisedpoint; contricioun myȝte hym saue
And brynge his soule to blisse &raisedpoint; by so þat feith bere witnesse
Þat whiles he lyued he bileued &raisedpoint; in þe lore of holycherche
Ergo contricioun feith and conscience &raisedpoint; is kyndelich dowel
And surgienes for dedly synnes &raisedpoint; whan shrifte of mouth failleth
¶ Ac shrifte of mouth more worthy is &raisedpoint; if man be iliche contrit
For shrifte of mouth sleeth synne &raisedpoint; be it neuere so dedly
lg.marginalia: # quia per conffescionem occiduntur peccata sed per contricionem delentur in venialeM14.102
lg.l: Per confessionem to a prest &raisedpoint; peccata occiduntur
Þere contricioun doth but dryueth it doun &raisedpoint; in-to a venial synne
As dauid seith in þe sauter &raisedpoint; et quorum tecta sunt peccata
Ac satisfaccioun seketh oute þe rote &raisedpoint; and bothe sleeth and voideth
And as it neuere had ybe &raisedpoint; to nouȝt bryngeth dedly synne
Þat it neuere eft is seen ne sore &raisedpoint; but semeth a wounde yheled
¶ Where woneth charite quod haukyn &raisedpoint; I wiste neuere in my lyue
Man þat with hym spake &raisedpoint; as wyde as I haue passed
¶ Þere parfit treuthe and pouere herte is &raisedpoint; and pacience of tonge
Þere is charitee þe chief chaumbrere for god hym-selue

lg.marginalia:
Of the Riche and þe pooer
man . whether is more plesinge
to our SaviourC2.14.110
lg.l: ¶ Whether paciente pouerte quod haukyn &raisedpoint; be more plesaunte to owre driȝte
Þan ricchesse riȝtfulliche ywonne &raisedpoint; and resonablelich yspended
¶ Ȝe quis est ille quod pacience &raisedpoint; quik laudabimus eum
Þough men rede of richchesse &raisedpoint; riȝt to þe worldes ende
I wist neuere renke þat riche was &raisedpoint; þat whan he rekne sholde
Whan it drow to his deth-day &raisedpoint; þat he ne dred hym sore
And þat atte rekenyng in arrerage fel &raisedpoint; rather þan oute of dette
¶ There þe pore dar plede &raisedpoint; and preue by pure resoun
To haue allowaunce of his lorde &raisedpoint; by þe lawe he it cleymeth
Ioye þat neuere ioye hadde &raisedpoint; of riȝtful iugge he axeth
And seith lo briddes and bestes &raisedpoint; þat no blisse ne knoweth
And wilde wormes in wodes &raisedpoint; þorw wyntres þow hem greuest
And makest hem welnyegh meke &raisedpoint; and mylde for defaute
And after þow sendest hem somer &raisedpoint; þat is her souereigne Ioye
And blisse to alle þat ben &raisedpoint; bothe wilde and tame
Þanne may beggeres as bestes &raisedpoint; after bote waiten
lg.marginalia: Neuer creature was with out ioye here and hence to.Cr3.14.126
lg.l: Þat al her lyf han lyued &raisedpoint; in langour and in defaute
But god sent hem some-tyme &raisedpoint; some manere ioye
Other here or elles-where &raisedpoint; kynde wolde it neuere
For to wrotherhele was he wrouȝte &raisedpoint; þat neuere was ioye shaped
¶ Angeles þat in helle now ben &raisedpoint; hadden ioye some-tyme
lg.marginalia: # notabile bonum pro eo qui pacienter suffert paupertatemM14.133
lg.l: And diues in deyntees lyued &raisedpoint; and in douce vye
Riȝte so resoun sheweth &raisedpoint; þat þo men þat were riche
And her makes also &raisedpoint; lyued her lyf in murthe
¶ Ac god is of a wonder wille &raisedpoint; by þat kynde witte sheweth
To ȝiue many men his mercymonye &raisedpoint; ar he it haue deserued
Riȝt so fareth god by some riche &raisedpoint; reuthe me it þinketh
For þei han her hyre here &raisedpoint; an heuene as it were
And is gret lykyng to lyue &raisedpoint; with-oute laboure of body
And whan he deyeth ben disalowed &raisedpoint; as dauid seith in þe sauter
Dormierunt & nichil inuenerunt

And in an other stede also &raisedpoint; velud sompnum surgencium domine
in ciuitate tua & ad nichilum rediges
Allas þat ricchesse shal reue &raisedpoint; and robbe mannes soule
Fram þe loue of owre lorde &raisedpoint; at his laste ende
¶ Hewen þat han her hyre afore &raisedpoint; aren euermore nedy
And selden deieth he out of dette &raisedpoint; þat dyneth ar he deserue it
And til he haue done his deuor &raisedpoint; and his dayes iourne
For whan a werkman hath wrouȝte &raisedpoint; þanne may men se þe sothe
What he were worthi for his werke &raisedpoint; and what he hath deserued
And nouȝt to fonge bifore &raisedpoint; for drede of disalowynge
¶ So I segge by ȝow riche &raisedpoint; it semeth nouȝt þat ȝe shulle
Haue heuene in ȝowre here beyng &raisedpoint; and heuene her-after
Riȝt as a seruaunt taketh his salarye bifore &raisedpoint; & sitth wolde clayme more
As he þat none hadde &raisedpoint; and hath huyre atte laste
It may nouȝt be ȝe riche men &raisedpoint; or matheu on god lyeth
De delicijs ad delicias &raisedpoint; deficile est transire
¶ Ac if þe riche haue reuthe &raisedpoint; and rewarde wel þe pore
And lyuen as lawe techeth &raisedpoint; done leute to alle
Criste of his curteysie &raisedpoint; shal conforte ȝow atte laste
lg.marginalia: The rych that be mercyfull shal haue heauen.Cr3.14.158
lg.l: And rewarde alle dowble ricchesse &raisedpoint; þat reuful hertes habbeth
And as an hyne þat hadde &raisedpoint; his hyre ar he bygonne
And whan he hath done his deuor wel &raisedpoint; men doth hym other bounte
Ȝyueth hym a cote aboue his couenaunte &raisedpoint; riȝte so cryst ȝiueth heuene
Bothe to riche and to nouȝte riche &raisedpoint; þat rewfullich lybbeth
And alle þat done her deuor wel &raisedpoint; han dowble hyre for her trauaille
Here forȝyuenesse of her synnes &raisedpoint; and heuene blisse after
¶ Ac it nys but selde yseyn &raisedpoint; as by holy seyntes bokes
Þat god rewarded double reste &raisedpoint; to any riche wye
For moche murthe is amonges riche &raisedpoint; as in mete and clothyng
And moche murthe in Maye is &raisedpoint; amonges wilde bestes
And so forth whil somer lasteth &raisedpoint; her solace dureth
Ac beggeres aboute Midsomer &raisedpoint; bredlees þei soupe
And ȝit is wynter for hem worse &raisedpoint; for wete-shodde þei gange
Afyrst sore and afyngred &raisedpoint; and foule yrebuked
And arated of riche men &raisedpoint; þat reuthe is to here
Now lorde sende hem somer &raisedpoint; and some manere ioye
Heuene after her hennes-goynge &raisedpoint; þat here han suche defaute
For alle myȝtest þow haue made &raisedpoint; none mener þan other
And yliche witty & wyse &raisedpoint; if þe wel &raisedpoint; hadde lyked
And haue reuthe on þise riche men &raisedpoint; þat rewarde nouȝte þi prisoneres
Of þe good þat þow hem gyuest &raisedpoint; ingrati ben manye
Ac god of þi goodnesse &raisedpoint; gyue hem grace to amende
For may no derth ben hem dere &raisedpoint; drouth ne weet
Ne noyther hete ne haille &raisedpoint; haue þei here hele
Of þat þei wilne and wolde &raisedpoint; wanteth hem nouȝt here
¶ Ac pore peple þi prisoneres &raisedpoint; lorde in þe put of myschief
Conforte þo creatures &raisedpoint; þat moche care suffren
Þorw derth þorw drouth &raisedpoint; alle her dayes here
Wo in wynter tymes &raisedpoint; for wantyng of clothes
And in somer tyme selde &raisedpoint; soupen to þe fulle
Conforte þi careful cryst in þi ryche
For how þow confortest &raisedpoint; alle creatures &punctuselevatus; clerkes bereth witnesse
Conuertimini ad me & salui eritis
¶ Þus in genere of his genitrice &raisedpoint; Ihesu cryst seyde
To robberes and to reueres &raisedpoint; to riche and to pore
Þow tauȝtest hem in þe Trinitee &raisedpoint; to take baptesme
And be clene þorw þat crystennynge &raisedpoint; of alle kynnes [sinnes]
And vs fel þorw folye &raisedpoint; to falle in synne after
Confessioun and kn[o]wlechyng & crauyng þi mercy
Shulde amende vs as many sithes &raisedpoint; as man wolde desire
Ac if þe pope wolde plede here-aȝeine &raisedpoint; and punyssh vs in conscience
He shulde take þe acquitance as quik &raisedpoint; and to þe qued schewe it
Pateat &c per passionem domini
And putten of so þe pouke &raisedpoint; and preuen vs vnder borwe
Ac þe perchemyn of þis patent &raisedpoint; of pouerte be moste
And of pure pacience &raisedpoint; and parfit bileue
Of pompe and of pruyde &raisedpoint; þe parchemyn decorreth
And principaliche of alle peple &raisedpoint; but þei be pore of herte
Ellis is al an ydel &raisedpoint; al þat euere we writen
Pater nostres and penaunce &raisedpoint; and pilgrimage to Rome
But owre spences and spendyng sprynge &raisedpoint; of a trewe welle
Elles is al owre laboure loste &raisedpoint; lo how men writeth
In fenestres atte freres &raisedpoint; if fals be þe foundement
For-þi crystene sholde ben in comune riche &raisedpoint; none coueitouse for hym-selue
¶ For seuene synnes þat þere ben &raisedpoint; assaillen vs euere
Þe fende folweth hem alle &raisedpoint; and fondeth hem to helpe
Ac wiþ ricchesse þat Ribaude &raisedpoint; rathest men bigyleth
For þere þat richesse regneth &raisedpoint; reuerence folweth
And þat is plesaunte to pryde &raisedpoint; in pore and in riche
And þe riche is reuerenced &raisedpoint; by resoun of his richchesse
Þere þe pore is put bihynde and par-auenture can more
Of witte and of wysdom &raisedpoint; þat fer awey is better
Þan ricchesse or reaute &raisedpoint; and rather yherde in heuene
For þe riche hath moche to rekene &raisedpoint; and riȝte softe walketh
Þe heigh waye to heuene-ward &raisedpoint; oft ricchesse letteth
Ita possibile diuiti &c

lg.marginalia: # Audaciam paupertatis with a pak at his ruggeM14.228
lg.l: ¶ Þere þe pore preseth bifor þe riche &raisedpoint; with a pakke at his rugge
Opera enim illorum sequntur illos
Batauntliche as beggeres done &raisedpoint; and baldeliche he craueth
For his pouerte and his pacience &raisedpoint; a perpetuel blisse
Beati pauperes &raisedpoint; quoniam ipsorum est regnum celorum
¶ And pryde in ricchesse regneth &raisedpoint; rather þan in pouerte
Arst in þe Maister þan in þe man &raisedpoint; some mansioun he hath
Ac in pouerte þere pacyence is &raisedpoint; pryde hath no myȝte
Ne none of þe seuene synnes &raisedpoint; sitten ne mowe þere longe
Ne haue powere in pouerte &raisedpoint; if pacyence it folwe
For þe pore is ay prest &raisedpoint; to plese þe riche
And buxome at his byddyng &raisedpoint; for his broke loues
lg.marginalia: # Buxom & bost be euer at werreM14.240
lg.l: And buxomenesse and boste &raisedpoint; aren euer-more at werre
And ayther hateth other &raisedpoint; in alle manere werkes
If wratthe wrastel with þe pore &raisedpoint; he hath þe worse ende
For if þey bothe pleyne &raisedpoint; þe pore is but fieble
And if he chyde or chatre &raisedpoint; hym chieueth þe worseHereafter follow 14.228-238 in KD from alpha, but they are no annotated.
¶ And if coueitise wolde cacche þe pore &raisedpoint; þei may nouȝt come togideres
And by þe nekke namely &raisedpoint; her none may hente other
For men knoweth wel þat coueitise &raisedpoint; is of a kene wille
And hath hondes and armes &raisedpoint; of a longe lengthe
And pouerte nis but a petit þinge &raisedpoint; appereth nouȝt to his naule
And louely layke was it neuere &raisedpoint; bitwene þe longe and þe shorte
And þough auarice wolde angre þe pore &raisedpoint; he hath but litel myȝte
For pouerte hath but pokes &raisedpoint; to putten in his godis
Þere auarice hath almaries &raisedpoint; and yren-bounde coffres
And whether be liȝter to breke &raisedpoint; lasse boste it maketh
A beggeres bagge &raisedpoint; þan an yren-bounde coffre

lg.marginalia: Lecherye and glotony raigne not much in pouertye
lg.l: ¶ Lecherye loueth hym nouȝt &raisedpoint; for he ȝeueth but lytel syluer
Ne doth hym nouȝte dyne delycatly &raisedpoint; ne drynke wyn oft
A strawe for þe stuwes &raisedpoint; it stode nouȝt I trowe
Had þei none but of pore men &raisedpoint; her houses were vntyled
¶ And þough sleuthe suwe pouerte &raisedpoint; and serue nouȝt god to paye
Mischief is his maister &raisedpoint; and maketh hym to thynke
Þat god is his grettest helpe &raisedpoint; and no gome elles
And his seruaunt as he seith &raisedpoint; and of his sute bothe
And where he be or be nouȝte &raisedpoint; he bereth þe signe of pouerte
And in þat secte owre saueoure &raisedpoint; saued al mankynde
For-thi al pore þat paciente is &raisedpoint; may claymen and asken
After her endynge here &raisedpoint; heuene-riche blisse
¶ Moche hardier may he axen &raisedpoint; þat here myȝte haue his wille
In londe and in lordship &raisedpoint; and likynge of bodye
And for goddis loue leueth al &raisedpoint; an lyueth as a beggere
And as a mayde for mannes loue &raisedpoint; her moder forsaketh
lg.marginalia: # quia puella dimittit patrem & matrem pro viro suoM14.272
lg.l: Hir fader and alle her frendes &raisedpoint; and folweth hir make
Moche is suche a mayde to louie &raisedpoint; of hym þat such one taketh
More þan a mayden is &raisedpoint; þat is maried þorw brokage
As bi assent of sondry partyes &raisedpoint; and syluer to bote
More for coueitise of good &raisedpoint; þan kynde loue of bothe
¶ So it fareth bi eche a persone &raisedpoint; þat possessioun forsaketh
And put hym to be pacient &raisedpoint; and pouerte weddeth

marginalia.note: O14.277. This word is preceded by a parasign two lines in height, touched in red, and decorated with a flourish at the right and vertical slashes beneath. It may have been intended as a heading for O14.280 (KD14.276), since it appears over that portion of the line that extends into the right margin.

lg.l: Þe which is sybbe to god hym-self &raisedpoint; and so to his seyntes
¶ Haue god my trouthe quod Haukyn &raisedpoint; ȝe preyse faste pouerte
What is pouerte with pacience quod he &raisedpoint; proprely to mene
¶ Paupertas quod pacience &raisedpoint; est odibile bonum
Remocio curarum &raisedpoint; possessio sine calumpnia &raisedpoint; donum dei &raisedpoint; sanitatis mater
Absque solicitudine semita &raisedpoint; sapiencie temperatrix &raisedpoint; negocium sine dampno
Incerta fortuna &raisedpoint; absque solicitudine felicitas &raisedpoint;
¶ I can nouȝt construe al þis quod haukyn &raisedpoint; ȝe moste kenne þis on englisch
In englisch quod pacyence it is wel harde &raisedpoint; wel to expounen
Ac somdel I shal seyne it &punctuselevatus; by so þow vnderstonde
Pouerte is þe first poynte &raisedpoint; þat pryde moste hateth
Thanne is it good by good skil &raisedpoint; al þat agasteth pryde
Riȝte as contricioun is confortable þinge &raisedpoint; conscience wote wel
And a sorwe of hym-self &raisedpoint; and a solace to þe sowle
So pouerte propreliche penaunce and ioye
Is to þe body pure spiritual helthe
Ergo paupertas est odibile bonum
And contricioun confort & cura animarum
¶ Selde sitte pouerte &raisedpoint; þe sothe to declare
Or as iustyce to iugge men &raisedpoint; enioigned is no pore
Ne to be a Maire aboue men &raisedpoint; ne mynystre vnder kynges
Selden is any pore yput &raisedpoint; to punysshen any peple
Remocio curarum
Ergo pouerte and pore men &raisedpoint; parfornen þe comaundement
Nolite iudicare quemquam þe þridde
¶ Selde is any pore riche &raisedpoint; but of riȝtful heritage
Wynneth he nauȝt with weghtes fals &raisedpoint; ne with vnseled mesures
Ne borweth of his neghbores &raisedpoint; but þat he may wel paye
Possessio sine calumpnia &raisedpoint;
¶ Þe fierthe is a fortune &raisedpoint; þat florissheth þe soule
Wyth sobrete fram al synne &raisedpoint; and also ȝit more
It affaiteth þe flesshe &raisedpoint; fram folyes ful manye
A collateral conforte &raisedpoint; crystes owne ȝifte
Donum dei
¶ Þe fyfte is moder of helthe a frende in alle fondynges
And for þe land euere a leche &raisedpoint; a lemman of al clennesse
Sanitatis mater
¶ Þe sexte is a path of pees &raisedpoint; ȝe þorw þe pas of altoun
Pouerte myȝte passe &raisedpoint; with-oute peril of robbyng
For þere þat pouerte passeth &raisedpoint; pees folweth after
And euere þe lasse þat he bereth &raisedpoint; þe hardyer he is of herte
For-þi seith seneca &raisedpoint; paupertas est absque solicitudine semita
And an hardy man of herte &raisedpoint; amonge an hepe of þeues
Cantabit paupertas coram latrone viator
¶ Þe seueneth is welle of wisdome &raisedpoint; and fewe wordes sheweth
For lordes alloweth hym litel &raisedpoint; or lysteneth to his reson
He tempreth þe tonge to treuthe-ward &raisedpoint; and no tresore coueiteth
Sapiencie temperatrix
¶ The eigteth is a lele laborere &raisedpoint; and loth to take more
Þan he may wel deserue &raisedpoint; in somer or in wynter
And if [he] chaffareth he chargeth no losse &raisedpoint; mowe he charite wynne
Negocium sine dampno
¶ The nyneth is swete to þe soule &raisedpoint; no sugre is swettere
For pacyence is payn &raisedpoint; for pouerte hym-selue
And sobrete swete drynke &raisedpoint; and good leche in sykenesse
Þus lered me a lettred man &raisedpoint; for owre lordes loue
Seynt austyn a blissed lyf &raisedpoint; with-outen bysynesse
For body and for soule &raisedpoint; absque / solicitudine felicitas
Now god þat al good gyueth &raisedpoint; graunt his soule reste
Þat þus fyrst wrote to wyssen men &raisedpoint; what pouerte was to mene
¶ Allas quod haukyn þe actyf man þo &raisedpoint; þat after my crystendome
I ne hadde ben ded and doluen &raisedpoint; for doweles sake
lg.marginalia: # quia defficele est sine peccato viuereM14.338
lg.l: So harde it is quod haukyn &raisedpoint; to lyue and to do synne
Synne suweth vs euere quod he &raisedpoint; and sori gan wexe
And wepte water with his eyghen &raisedpoint; and weyled þe tyme
Þat euere he dede dede &raisedpoint; þat dere god displesed
Swowed and sobbed &raisedpoint; and syked ful ofte
Þat euere he hadde londe or lordship &raisedpoint; lasse other more
Or maystrye ouer any man &raisedpoint; mo þan of hym-self
I were nouȝt worthy wote god quod haukyn &raisedpoint; to were any clothes
Ne noyther sherte ne shone &raisedpoint; saue for shame one
To keure my caroigne quod he &raisedpoint; and cryde mercye faste
And wepte and weyled &raisedpoint; and þere-with I awaked

div1.head: Passus Quindecimus finit dowel & incipit dobet

lg.marginalia: [a pointing hand]CHECK FOR OTHER NOTES BY EDITOR AT TOP OF EACH PASSUS

It declareth what the soule is, and how of diuers offices it hath diuers names, that we shoulde not searche Gods secretes,
the preachers dutye, what shal become of euyll gotten goods, the true pylgrimage, what compenye charitye haunteth, that we
should take no giftes of wicked men, that it is sacrilege to spend the tithes otherwyse than vppon the poore, that no course is certaine, whan and howe Makometes law began, that the Apostles turned all the worlde to the faithe, that children differ not from wilde beastes, tyl they be instructed in Christ, that couetise of the cleargy wyl destroy the church, that possession poysoned the churche, what the Byshops duty is, and that Christ was declared by his miracles to be Messias.
lg.l: Ac after my wakyng &raisedpoint; it was wonder longe
Ar I couth kyndely &raisedpoint; knowe what was dowel
And so my witte wex and wanyed &raisedpoint; til I a fole were
And somme lakked my lyf &raisedpoint; allowed it fewe
And leten for a lorel &raisedpoint; and loth to reuerencen
Lordes or ladyes &raisedpoint; or any lyf elles
As persones in pellure &raisedpoint; with pendauntes of syluer
To seriauntz ne to suche &raisedpoint; seyde nouȝte ones
God loke ȝow lordes &raisedpoint; ne louted faire
Þat folke helden me a fole &raisedpoint; and in þat folye I raued
Tyl resoun hadde reuthe on me &raisedpoint; and rokked me aslepe
Tyl I seigh as it sorcerye were &raisedpoint; a sotyl þinge with-al
One with-outen tonge and teeth &raisedpoint; tolde me whyder I shulde
And wher-of I cam and of what kynde &raisedpoint; I conIured hym atte laste
If he were crystes creature &raisedpoint; for crystes loue me to tellen
¶ I am crystes creature quod he &raisedpoint; and crystene in many a place
In crystes courte &raisedpoint; I-knowe wel &raisedpoint; and of his kynne a partye
Is noyther peter þe porter &raisedpoint; ne poule with his fauchoune
Þa wil defende me þe dore &raisedpoint; dynge ich neure so late
At mydnyȝt at mydday &raisedpoint; my voice so is yknowe
Þat eche a creature of his courte &raisedpoint; welcometh me fayre

lg.marginalia: What are ye caldLater hand, not a gloss but a repetition (though MS spells "called")
lg.l: ¶ What ar ȝe called quod I in þat courte &raisedpoint; amonges crystes peple

foreign.hi:
Anima
Animus
Mens
Memoria
Racio
Sensus
Conscientia

lg.l: Þe whiles I quykke þe corps quod he &raisedpoint; called am I anima
And whan I wilne and wolde &raisedpoint; animus ich hatte
And for þat I can and knowe &raisedpoint; called am I mens
And whan I make mone to god &raisedpoint; memoria is my name
And whan I deme domes &raisedpoint; and do as treuthe techeth
Þanne is racio my riȝt name &raisedpoint; resoun an englissh
And whan I fele þat folke telleth &raisedpoint; my firste name is sensus
And þat is wytte and wisdome &raisedpoint; þe welle of alle craftes
And whan I chalange or chalange nouȝte &raisedpoint; chepe or refuse
lg.marginalia: the definition of the SowleGloss refers to L15.23-49 (KD15.23-47).
lg.l: Þanne am I conscience ycalde &raisedpoint; goddis clerke and his notarie
And whan I loue lelly &raisedpoint; owre lorde and alle other
Þanne is lele loue my name &raisedpoint; and in latyn amor
And whan I flye fro þe flesshe &raisedpoint; and forsake þe caroigne
Þanne am I spirit specheles &raisedpoint; and spiritus þanne ich hatte
Austyn and ysodorus ayther of hem bothe
Nempned me þus to name &raisedpoint; now þow myȝte chese
How þow coueitest to calle me &raisedpoint; now þow knowest alle my names

hi.hi:
nota . quod anima
habet ix nomina

lg.l:
Anima pro diuersis accionibus diuersa nomina sortitur &raisedpoint; dum viuificat corpus
anima est &raisedpoint; dum vult animus est &raisedpoint; dum scit mens est &raisedpoint; dum recolit memoria est &raisedpoint;

Dum iudicat racio est &raisedpoint; dum sentit sensus est &raisedpoint; dum amat amor est &raisedpoint; dum negat
vel consentit consciencia est &raisedpoint; dum spirat spiritus est
¶ Ȝe ben as a bisshop quod I &raisedpoint; al bourdynge þat tyme
For bisshopes yblessed &raisedpoint; þei bereth many names
lg.marginalia: [arabic 5 with line through it]G16.43, followed by ten medieval forms of this number as pen trials. See Benson and Blanchfield p.43.
lg.l: Presul and pontifex &raisedpoint; and metropolitanus
lg.marginalia: Jon RycW15.44, 15th century hand, the same as on folios 1r (KDP.19) and 147v (flyleaf?)
lg.l: And other names an hepe episcopus & pastor
¶ Þat is soth seyde he &raisedpoint; now I se þi wille
Þow woldest knowe and kunne &raisedpoint; þe cause of alle her names
And of myne if þow myȝtest &raisedpoint; me þinketh by þi speche
¶ Ȝe syre I seyde by so no man were greued
Alle þe sciences vnder sonne &raisedpoint; and alle þe sotyle craftes
I wolde I knewe and couth &raisedpoint; kyndely in myne herte
¶ Þanne artow inparfit quod he &raisedpoint; and one of prydes knyȝtes
For such a luste and lykynge &raisedpoint; lucifer fel fram heuene
Ponam pedem meum in aquilone & similis ero altissimo
¶ It were aȝeynes kynde quod he &raisedpoint; and alkynnes resoun
Þat any creature shulde kunne al &raisedpoint; excepte cryste one
Aȝein such salomon speketh &raisedpoint; and dispiseth her wittes
Sic qui scrutator est maiestatis opprimitur a gloria
To englisch men þis is to mene &raisedpoint; þat mowen speke & here
Þe man þat moche hony eteth &raisedpoint; his mawe it engleymeth
And þe more þat a man &raisedpoint; of good mater hereth
But he do þerafter &raisedpoint; it doth hym double scathe
Beatus est seith seynt Bernard / &raisedpoint; qui scripturas legit
Et verba vertit in opera &raisedpoint; fullich to his powere
Coueytise to kunne and to knowe science
Pulte out of paradys &raisedpoint; Adam and Eue
Sciencie appetitus hominem inmortalitatis gloriam spoliauit
And riȝte as hony is yuel to defye &raisedpoint; and engleymeth þe mawe
Riȝt so þat þorw resoun wolde þe rote knowe
Of god and of his grete myȝtes &raisedpoint; his graces it letteth
For in þe lykyng lith a pryde &raisedpoint; and a lycames coueitise
Aȝein crystes conseille &raisedpoint; and alle clerkes techyng
That is non plus sapere quam oportet sapere
Freres and fele other maistres &raisedpoint; þat to þe lewed men prechen
Ȝe moeuen materes inmesurables &raisedpoint; to tellen of þe Trinite
Þat ofte tymes þe lewed peple &raisedpoint; of her bileue douten
Bettere byleue were mony &raisedpoint; doctoures such techyng
And tellen men of þe ten comaundementz &raisedpoint; and touchen þe seuene synnes
And of þe braunches þat burgeouneth of hem &raisedpoint; and bryngeth men to helle
And how þat folke in folyes &raisedpoint; myspenden her fyue wittes
As wel freres as other folke &raisedpoint; folilich spenen
In housyng in haterynge &raisedpoint; and in-to hiegh clergye shewynge
More for pompe þan for pure charite &raisedpoint; þe poeple wote þe sothe
Þat I lye nouȝt loo &raisedpoint; for lordes ȝe plesen
And reuerencen þe riche &raisedpoint; þe rather for her syluer
Confundantur omnes qui adorant scul[p]tilia &raisedpoint; & alibi
Vt quid diligitis vanitatem & queritis mendacium
Go to þe glose of þe verse &raisedpoint; ȝe grete clerkes
If I lye on ȝow to my lewed witte &raisedpoint; ledeth me to brennynge

marginalia.note: Bx15.90: nota de fratribus: In L this is in the scribal hand and boxed in red. Since it is also in M, it is probably at least beta.

lg.l: For as it semeth ȝe forsaketh &raisedpoint; no mannes almesse
Of vsureres of hores &raisedpoint; of auarous chapmen
And louten to þis lordes &raisedpoint; þat mowen lene ȝow nobles
Aȝeine ȝowre reule and Religioun &raisedpoint; I take recorde at Ihesus
Þat seide to his disciples &raisedpoint; ne sitis personarum acceptores
¶ Of þis matere I myȝte &punctuselevatus; make a longe bible
Ac of curatoures of crystene peple &raisedpoint; as clerkes bereth witnesse
I shal tellen it for treuth sake &raisedpoint; take hede who-so lyketh
¶ As holynesse and honestete oute of holicherche spredeth
Þorw lele libbyng men &raisedpoint; þat goddes lawe techen
Riȝt so out of holicherche &raisedpoint; alle yueles spredeth
There inparfyt presthod is &raisedpoint; prechoures and techeres
lg.marginalia: Prechers muste do as they preachCr3.15.101
lg.l: And se it by ensample in somer tyme on trowes
Þere somme bowes ben leued &raisedpoint; and somme bereth none
Þere is a myschief in þe more &raisedpoint; of suche manere bowes
Riȝt so parsones and prestes &raisedpoint; and prechoures of holy cherche
Þat aren rote of þe riȝte faith &raisedpoint; to reule þe peple
Ac þere þe rote is roten &raisedpoint; reson wote þe sothe
Shal neure floure ne frute &raisedpoint; ne faire leef be grene
For-þi wolde ȝe lettred leue &raisedpoint; þe leccherye of clothynge
And be kynde as bifel for clerkes &raisedpoint; and curteise of crystes goodes
Trewe of ȝowre tonge &raisedpoint; and of ȝowre taille bothe
And hatien to here harlotrye &raisedpoint; and nouȝt to vnderfonge
Tythes of vntrewe þinge &raisedpoint; ytilied or chaffared &raisedpoint;
¶ Lothe were lewed men &raisedpoint; but þei ȝowre lore folwed
And amenden hem þat mysdon &raisedpoint; more for ȝowre ensamples
lg.marginalia:
ypocrysy is lykoned
to a dongehillC2.15.114
lg.l: Þan forto prechen & preue it nouȝt &raisedpoint; ypocrysie it semeth
For ypocrysie in latyn &raisedpoint; is lykned to a dongehul
Þat were bysnewed with snowe &raisedpoint; and snakes wyth-inne
¶ Or to a wal þat were whitlymed &raisedpoint; and were foule wyth-inne
Riȝt so many prestes &raisedpoint; prechoures and prelates
Ȝe aren enblaunched with bele paroles &raisedpoint; and with clothes also
Ac ȝowre werkes and ȝowre wordes þere-vnder &raisedpoint; aren ful vnlouelich
¶ Iohannes crysostomus &raisedpoint; of clerkes speketh and prestes
lg.marginalia: NBM15.124, same ornate abbreviation is found on fol. 73v.

lg.l: Sicut de templo omne bonum progreditur &raisedpoint; sic de templo &raisedpoint; omne malum procedit

Si sacerdocium integrum fuerit &punctuselevatus; tota floret ecclesia &raisedpoint; si autem coruptum fuerit &raisedpoint; omnium fides
marcida est / Si sacerdocium fuerit in peccatis &raisedpoint; totus populus co[n]uertitur ad peccandum
Sicut cum videris arborem pallidam & marcidam &raisedpoint; inteligis quod vicium habet in radice
Ita cum videris populum indisciplinatum &raisedpoint; & irreligiosum sine dubio sacerdocium eius non est sanum
¶ If lewed men wist &raisedpoint; what þis latyn meneth
And who was myn auctor &raisedpoint; moche wonder me þinketh
But if many a prest bere &raisedpoint; for here baselardes and here broches
A peyre bedes in her hande &raisedpoint; and a boke vnder her arme
Sire Iohan & sire Geffray &raisedpoint; hath a gerdel of syluer
A basellarde or a ballokknyf &raisedpoint; with botones ouergylte
Ac a portous þat shulde be his plow &raisedpoint; placebo to segge
Hadde he neure seruyse to saue syluer þer-to &raisedpoint; seith it with yvel wille
Allas ȝe lewed men &raisedpoint; moche lese ȝe on prestes
Ac þinge þat wykkedlich is wonne &raisedpoint; and with false sleigthes
Wolde neuere witte of witty god &raisedpoint; but wikked men it hadde
Þe which aren prestes inparfit &raisedpoint; and prechoures after syluer
Sectoures and sudenes &raisedpoint; somnoures and her lemmannes
Þis þat with gyle was geten &raisedpoint; vngraciouslich is spended
So harlotes and hores &raisedpoint; ar hulpen with such goodis
And goddes folke for defaute þer-of &raisedpoint; forfaren and spillen
¶ Curatoures of holykirke &raisedpoint; as clerkes þat ben auerouse
Liȝtlich þat þey leuen &raisedpoint; loselles it habbeth
Or dyeth intestate &raisedpoint; and þanne þe bisshop entreth
And maketh murthe þere-with &raisedpoint; and his men bothe

marginalia.note: The scribe appears to have offered marginal nyȝt to hypercorrect the alliteration.

lg.l: And seggen he was a nygarde &raisedpoint; þat no good myȝte asspare
To frende ne to fremmed &raisedpoint; þe fende haue his soule
For a wrecched hous he helde &raisedpoint; al his lyf-tyme
And þat he spared and bispered &raisedpoint; spene we in murthe
¶ By lered by lewed &raisedpoint; þat loth is to spende
Þus gone her godes &raisedpoint; be þe goste faren
Ac for good men god wote &raisedpoint; gret dole men maken
And bymeneth good mete-ȝyueres &raisedpoint; and in mynde haueth

marginalia.note: Bx15.153: quid est caritas: Written in the right-hand margin in the main hand in LM, so probably beta.

lg.l: In prayers and in penaunces &raisedpoint; and in parfyt charite
¶ What is charite quod I þo &raisedpoint; a childissh þinge he seide
Nisi efficiamini sicut paruuli &raisedpoint; non intrabitis in regnum celorum
With-outen fauntelte or foly &raisedpoint; a fre liberal wille
¶ Where shulde men fynde such a frende &raisedpoint; with so fre an herte
I haue lyued in londe quod I &raisedpoint; my name is longe wille
And fonde I neuere ful charite &raisedpoint; bifore ne bihynde
Men beth mercyable &raisedpoint; to mendynantz & to pore
And wolen lene þere þei leue &raisedpoint; lelly to ben payed
¶ Ac charite þat poule preyseth best &raisedpoint; and most plesaunte to owre saueoure
As non inflatu[r] non ambiciosa non querit que sua sunt
I seigh neuere such a man &raisedpoint; so me god helpe
That he ne wolde aske after his &raisedpoint; and otherwhile coueyte
Þinge þat neded hym nouȝt &raisedpoint; and nyme it if he myȝte
¶ Clerkis kenne me þat cryst &raisedpoint; is in alle places
Ac I seygh hym neuere sothly &raisedpoint; but as my-self in a miroure
It[a] in enigmate tunc facie ad faciem
And so I trowe trewly &raisedpoint; by þat men telleth of charite
It is nouȝt championes fyȝte &raisedpoint; ne chaffare as I trowe
¶ Charite quod he ne chaffareth nouȝte &raisedpoint; ne chalengeth ne craueth
As proude of a peny &raisedpoint; as of a pounde of golde
And is as gladde of a goune &punctuselevatus; of a graye russet
As of a tunicle of tarse &raisedpoint; or of trye scarlet
He is gladde with alle gladde &raisedpoint; and good ty[l] alle wykked
And leneth and loueth alle &raisedpoint; þat owre lorde made
Curseth he no creature &raisedpoint; ne he can bere no wratthe
Ne no lykynge hath to lye &raisedpoint; ne laughe men to scorne
Al þat men seith he let it soth &raisedpoint; and in solace taketh
And alle manere meschiefs &raisedpoint; in myldenesse he suffreth
Coueiteth he none erthly good &raisedpoint; but heuene-riche blisse
¶ Hath he any rentes or ricchesse &raisedpoint; or any riche frendes
¶ Of rentes ne of ricchesse &raisedpoint; ne reccheth he neuere
For a frende þat fyndeth hym &raisedpoint; failled hym neuere at nede
Fiat voluntas tua fynt hym euer-more
And if he soupeth ette but a soppe of spera in deo
He can purtreye wel þe pater noster &raisedpoint; and peynte it with aues
And other-while is his wone &raisedpoint; to wende in pilgrymage
Þere pore men and prisones liggeth &raisedpoint; her pardoun to haue
Þough he bere hem no bred &raisedpoint; he bereth hem swetter lyflode
Loueth hem as owre lorde biddeth &raisedpoint; and loketh how þei fare
¶ And whan he is wery of þat werke &raisedpoint; þanne wil he some-tyme
Labory in a lauendrye &raisedpoint; wel þe lengthe of a myle
And ȝerne in-to ȝouthe &raisedpoint; and ȝepliche speke
Pryde with al þe appurtenaunce &raisedpoint; and pakken hem togyderes
And bouken hem at his brest &raisedpoint; and beten hem clene
And leggen on longe &raisedpoint; with laboraui in gemitu meo
And with warme water at his eyghen &raisedpoint; wasshen hem after
And þanne he syngeth whan he doth so &raisedpoint; & some-tyme seith wepyng
Cor contritum & humiliatum deus non despicies
¶ By cryst I wolde þat I knewe hym quod I &raisedpoint; no creature leuere
¶ With-outen helpe of Piers plowman quod he &raisedpoint; his persone seestow neuere
¶ Where clerkes knowen hym quod I &raisedpoint; þat kepen holykirke
¶ Clerkes haue no knowyng quod he &raisedpoint; but by werkes and bi wordes
Ac piers þe plowman &raisedpoint; parceyueth more depper
Þat is þe wille and wherfore &raisedpoint; þat many wyȝte suffreth
Et vidit deus cogitaciones eorum
For þere ar ful proude-herted men &raisedpoint; paciente of tonge
And boxome as of berynge &raisedpoint; to burgeys and to lordes
And to pore peple &raisedpoint; han peper in þe nose
And as a lyoun he loketh &raisedpoint; þere men lakketh his werkes
¶ For þere ar beggeres and bidderes &raisedpoint; bedmen as it were
Loketh as lambren &raisedpoint; and semen lyf-holy
Ac it is more to haue her mete &raisedpoint; with such an esy manere
Þan for penaunce and parfitnesse &raisedpoint; þe pouerte þat such taketh
¶ Þere-fore by coloure ne by clergye &raisedpoint; knowe shaltow hym neuere
Noyther þorw wordes ne werkes &raisedpoint; but þorw wille one
And þat knoweth no clerke &raisedpoint; ne creature in erthe
But piers þe plowman &raisedpoint; petrus id est cristus
For he ne is nouȝte in lolleres &raisedpoint; ne in lande-leperes hermytes
Ne at ancres þere a box hangeth &raisedpoint; alle suche þei faiten
Fy on faitoures &raisedpoint; and in fautores suos
For charyte is goddis champioun &raisedpoint; and as a good chylde hende
And þe meryest of mouth &raisedpoint; at mete where he sitteth
Þe loue þat lith in his herte &raisedpoint; maketh hym lyȝte of speche
And is compenable &raisedpoint; and confortatyf &raisedpoint; as cryst bit hym-selue
Nolite fieri sicut ypocrite tristes &c
For I haue seyn hym in sylke &raisedpoint; and somme-tyme in russet
Bothe in grey and in grys &raisedpoint; and in gulte herneys
And as gladlich he it gaf &raisedpoint; to gomes þat it neded
¶ Edmonde and Edwarde &raisedpoint; eyther were kynges
And seyntes ysette &raisedpoint; tyl charite hem folwed
¶ I haue seyne charite also &raisedpoint; syngen and reden
Ryden and rennen &raisedpoint; in ragged wedes
Ac biddyng as beggeres &raisedpoint; bihelde I hym neuere
Ac in riche robes &punctuselevatus; rathest he walketh
Ycalled and ycrimiled &raisedpoint; and his crowne shaue
And in a freres frokke &raisedpoint; he was yfounde ones
Ac it is ferre agoo &raisedpoint; in seynt Fraunceys tyme
In þat secte sitthe &raisedpoint; to selde hath he be knowen
¶ Riche men he recomendeth &raisedpoint; and of her robes taketh
Þat with-outen wyles &raisedpoint; leden her lyues
Beatus est diues &raisedpoint; qui &c
¶ In kynges courte he cometh ofte &raisedpoint; þere þe conseille is trewe
Ac if coueityse be of þe conseille &raisedpoint; he wil nouȝt come þer-Inne
In courte amonge iaperes &raisedpoint; he cometh but selde
For braulyng and bakbytyng &raisedpoint; and beryng of fals witnesse
¶ In þe constorie bifor þe comissarie &raisedpoint; he cometh nouȝt ful ofte
lg.marginalia: XF11.257, drypoint corrector's mark indicating missing line
lg.l: For her lawe dureth ouer-longe &raisedpoint; but if þei lacchen syluer
And matrimoigne for monye &raisedpoint; maken & vnmaken
And þat conscience and cryst &raisedpoint; hath yknitte faste
Þei vndon it vnworthily &raisedpoint; þo doctours of laweHereafter follow 15.244-248 in KD, from alpha, but they are not annotated.
¶ Ac I ne lakke no lyf &raisedpoint; but lorde amende vs alle
And gyue vs grace good god &raisedpoint; charite to folwe
For who-so myȝte mete with hym &raisedpoint; such maneres hym eyleth
Noyther he blameth ne banneth &raisedpoint; bosteth ne prayseth
Lakketh ne loseth &raisedpoint; ne loketh vp sterne
Craueth ne coueiteth &raisedpoint; ne crieth after more
In pace in idipsum dormiam &c &raisedpoint;
Þe moste lyflode þat he lyueth by &raisedpoint; is loue in goddis passioun
Noyther he biddeth ne beggeth &raisedpoint; ne borweth to ȝelde
Misdoth he no man &raisedpoint; ne with his mouth greueth
¶ Amonges cristene men &raisedpoint; þis myldnesse shulde laste
In alle manere angres &raisedpoint; haue þis at herte
Þat þough þei suffred al þis &raisedpoint; god suffred for vs more
In ensample we shulde do so &raisedpoint; and take no veniaunce
Of owre foes þat doth vs falsenesse &raisedpoint; þat is owre fadres wille
For wel may euery man wite if god hadde wolde hym-selue
Sholde neuere Iudas ne iuwe &raisedpoint; haue Ihesu don on Rode
Ne han martired peter ne Poule &raisedpoint; ne in prisoun holden
Ac he suffred in ensample &raisedpoint; þat we shulde suffre also
And seide to suche þat suffre wolde &raisedpoint; þat pacientes vincunt
¶ Verbi gratia quod he &punctuselevatus; and verrey ensamples manye
lg.marginalia: The Legend of sayntes, beleue it ye luste.Cr3.15.274
lg.l: In legenda sanctorum &raisedpoint; þe lyf of holy seyntes
What penaunce and pouerte &raisedpoint; and passioun þei suffred
In hunger in hete &raisedpoint; in al manere angres
Antony and Egidie &raisedpoint; and other holi fadres
Woneden in wildernesse &raisedpoint; amonge wilde bestes
Monkes and mendynauntz &raisedpoint; men bi hem-selue
In spekes an in spelonkes &raisedpoint; selden speken togideres
Ac noyther antony ne Egidy &raisedpoint; ne hermite þat tyme
Of liouns ne of leoperdes &raisedpoint; no lyflode ne toke
But of foules þat fleeth &raisedpoint; þus fynt men in bokes
Excepte þat Egydie &raisedpoint; after an hynde cryede
And þorw þe mylke &raisedpoint; of þat mylde best &raisedpoint; þe man was susteyned
And day by day had he hir nouȝt &raisedpoint; his hunger forto slake
But selden and sondrie tymes &raisedpoint; as seith þe boke and techeth
¶ Antony adayes &raisedpoint; aboute none-tyme
Had a bridde þat brouȝte hym bred &raisedpoint; þat he by lyued
And þough þe gome hadde a geste &raisedpoint; god fonde hem bothe
¶ Poule primus heremita &raisedpoint; had parroked hym-selue
Þat no man miȝte hym se &raisedpoint; for mosse and for leues
Foules hym fedde &raisedpoint; fele wynteres with-alle
Til he founded freres &raisedpoint; of austines ordre
Poule after his prechyng &raisedpoint; panyers he made
And wan with his hondes &raisedpoint; þat his wombe neded
Peter fisched for his fode &raisedpoint; and his felawe andrewe
Some þei solde and some þei sothe &raisedpoint; and so þei lyued bothe
And also Marie Magdeleyne &raisedpoint; by mores lyued and dewes
Ac moste þorw deuocioun &raisedpoint; and mynde of god almiȝty
I shulde nouȝt þis seuene dayes &raisedpoint; seggen hem alle
Þat lyueden þus for owre lordes loue &raisedpoint; manye longe ȝeres
Ac þere ne was lyoun &raisedpoint; ne leopart &raisedpoint; þat on laundes wenten
Noyther bere ne bor &raisedpoint; ne other best wilde
Þat ne fel to her feet &raisedpoint; and fauned with þe tailles
And if þei couth han ycarped &raisedpoint; by cryst as I trowe
Þei wolde haue fedde þat folke &raisedpoint; bifor wilde foules
Ac god sent hem fode bi foules &raisedpoint; and by no fierse bestes
In menynge þat meke þinge &raisedpoint; mylde þinge shulde fede
lg.marginalia: A leson for them that take benifices at wycked men handesCr3.15.310
XF11.323, drypoint corrector's mark indicates error in line
lg.l: As who seith religious &raisedpoint; ryȝtful men shulde fynde
And lawful men to lyfholy men &raisedpoint; lyflode brynge
And þanne wolde lordes and ladyes be &raisedpoint; loth to agulte
And to take of her tenauntz &raisedpoint; more þan treuth wolde
Fonde þei þat Freres &raisedpoint; wolde forsake her almesses
And bidden hem bere it &raisedpoint; þere it was yborwed
For we ben goddes foules &raisedpoint; and abiden alwey
Tyl briddes brynge vs &raisedpoint; þat we shulde lyue by
For had ȝe potage and payn ynough &raisedpoint; and peny-ale to drynke
And a messe þere-mydde &raisedpoint; of o manere kynde
Ȝe had riȝt ynough &raisedpoint; ȝe Religious &raisedpoint; and so ȝowre reule me tolde
¶ If lewed men knewe þis latyn &raisedpoint; þei wolde loke whom þei ȝeue
And auyse hem bifore &raisedpoint; a fyue dayes or sexe
Or þei amortesed to monkes &raisedpoint; or chanouns her rentes

marginalia.note: O15.325, accompanied by a flourish beneath.

lg.l: Allas lordes and ladyes &raisedpoint; lewed conseille haue ȝe
To ȝyue fram ȝowre eyres &raisedpoint; þat ȝowre ayeles ȝow lefte
And ȝiueth to bidde for ȝow &raisedpoint; to such þat ben riche
And ben founded and feffed eke &raisedpoint; to bidde for other
¶ Who perfourneth þis prophecye &raisedpoint; of þe peple þat now lybbeth
Dispersit dedit pauperibus &c

marginalia.note: G16.331. This marginal comment is in the same hand as the addition by WH at the bottom of the previous page. A vertical line in the same ink runs from G16.333 to G16.347.

lg.l: If any peple perfourme þat texte &raisedpoint; it ar þis pore freres
For þat þei beggen abouten &raisedpoint; in buildynge þei spene
And on hem-self sum &raisedpoint; and such as ben her laboreres
And of hem þat habbeth þei taken &raisedpoint; and ȝyue hem þat ne habbeth
¶ Ac clerkes & knyȝtes &raisedpoint; and comuneres þat ben riche
Fele of ȝow fareth &raisedpoint; as if I a forest hadde
Þat were ful of faire trees &raisedpoint; and I fonded and caste
How I myȝte mo þer-inne &raisedpoint; amonges hem sette
Riȝt so ȝe riche &raisedpoint; ȝe robeth þat ben riche
And helpeth hem þat helpeth ȝow &raisedpoint; and ȝiueth þere no nede is
As who-so filled a toune &raisedpoint; of a fressh ryuer
And went forth with þat water &raisedpoint; to woke with themese
Riȝt so ȝe riche &raisedpoint; ȝe robeth and fedeth
lg.marginalia: . Of munkys .O15.344, accompanied by a flourish beneath.
lg.l: Hem þat han as ȝe han &raisedpoint; hem ȝe make at ese
¶ Ac Religious þat riche ben &raisedpoint; shulde rather feste beggeres
Þan burgeys þat riche ben &raisedpoint; as þe boke techeth
Quia sacrilegium est res pauperum non pauperibus dare
Item peccatoribus dare &raisedpoint; est demonibus immolare
Item monache si indiges et accipis pocius das quam accipis

lg.l: For-þi I conseille alle cristene &raisedpoint; to confourmen hem to charite
For charite with-oute chalengynge &raisedpoint; vnchargeth þe soule
And many a prisone fram purgatorie &raisedpoint; þorw his preyeres he delyureth
Ac þere is a defaute in þe folke &raisedpoint; þat þe faith kepeth
Wherfore folke is þe feblere &raisedpoint; and nouȝt ferme of bilieue
As in lussheborwes is a lyther alay &raisedpoint; and ȝet loketh he lyke a sterlynge
Þe merke of þat mone is good &raisedpoint; ac þe metal is fieble
And so it fareth by some folke now &raisedpoint; þei han a faire speche
Croune and crystendome &raisedpoint; þe kynges merke of heuene
Ac þe metal þat is mannes soule &raisedpoint; with synne is foule alayed
Bothe lettred and lewede &raisedpoint; beth allayed now with synne
That no lyf loueth other &raisedpoint; ne owre lorde as it semeth
For þorw werre and wykked werkes &raisedpoint; and wederes vnresonable
Wederwise shipmen &raisedpoint; and witti clerkes also
Han no bilieue to þe lifte &raisedpoint; ne to þe lore of philosofres
¶ Astrymyanes alday &raisedpoint; in her arte faillen
Þat whilum warned bifore &raisedpoint; what shulde falle after
Shipmen and sheperdes &raisedpoint; þat with shipp & shepe wenten
Wisten by þe walkene &raisedpoint; what shulde bityde
As of wederes and wyndes &raisedpoint; þei warned men ofte
Tilieres þat tiled þe erthe &raisedpoint; tolden her maistres
By þe sede þat þei sewe &raisedpoint; what þei selle miȝte
And what to leue and to lyue by &raisedpoint; þe londe was so trewe
Now failleth þe folke of þe flode &raisedpoint; and of þe londe bothe
Sheperdes and shipmen &raisedpoint; and so do þis tilieres
Noither þei kunneth ne knoweth &raisedpoint; one cours bi-for an other
Astrymyanes also &punctuselevatus; aren at her wittes ende
Of þat was calculed of þe element &raisedpoint; þe contrarie þei fynde
Gramer þe grounde of al &raisedpoint; bigyleth now children
For is none of þis newe clerkes &raisedpoint; who-so nymeth hede
Þat can versifye faire &raisedpoint; ne formalich enditen
Ne nouȝt on amonge an hundreth &raisedpoint; þat an auctour can construe
Ne rede a lettre in any langage &raisedpoint; but in latyn or in englissh
Go now to any degre &raisedpoint; and but if gyle be mayster
And flaterere his felawe &raisedpoint; vnder hym to fourmen
Moche wonder me thynketh &raisedpoint; amonges vs alle
Doctoures of decres &raisedpoint; and of diuinite Maistres
Þat shulde konne and knowe &raisedpoint; alkynnes clergye
And answere to argumentz &raisedpoint; and also to a quodlibet
I dar nouȝt seggen it for shame &raisedpoint; if suche weren apposed
Þei shulde faillen in her philosofye &raisedpoint; and in phisyk bothe
Wher-fore I am afered &raisedpoint; of folke of holikirke
Lest þei ouerhuppen as other don &raisedpoint; in offices & in houres
Ac if þei ouerhuppe as I hope nouȝte &raisedpoint; owre byleue suffiseth

lg.l: As clerkes in corpus cristi feste &raisedpoint; singen & reden
Þat sola fides sufficit &raisedpoint; to saue with lewed peple

Allas þanne but owre loresmen &raisedpoint; lyuen as þei leren vs
And for her lyuynge þat lewed men be &raisedpoint; þe lother god agulten
For sarasenes han somwhat &raisedpoint; semynge to owre bileue

lg.l: Ac one Makometh &raisedpoint; a man in mysbileue
Brouȝte sarasenes of surre &raisedpoint; and se in what manere
Þis Makometh was a crystene man &raisedpoint; and for he moste nouȝte be a pope
In-to surre he souȝte &raisedpoint; and þorw his sotil wittes
Daunted a dowue &raisedpoint; and day and nyȝte hir fedde
Þe corne þat she cropped &raisedpoint; he caste it in his ere
And if he amonge þe poeple preched &raisedpoint; or in places come
Þanne wolde þe coluer come &raisedpoint; to þe clerkes ere
Menynge as after meet &raisedpoint; þus Makometh hir enchaunted
A dide folke þanne falle on knees &raisedpoint; for he swore in his prechynge
Þat þe coluer þat come so &raisedpoint; come fram god of heuene
As messager to Makometh &raisedpoint; men forto teche
And þus þorw wyles of his witte and a whyte dowue
Makometh in mysbileue &raisedpoint; men and wommen brouȝte
Þat lered þere and lewed ȝit &raisedpoint; lyuen on his lawes
¶ And sitth owre saueoure suffred &raisedpoint; þe sarasenes so bigiled
Þorw a crystene clerke &raisedpoint; acursed in his soule

lg.l: Of tyrauntz þat teneth trewe men &raisedpoint; taken any almesse

Benet & Bernarde &raisedpoint; þe which hem firste tauȝte
To lyue bi litel & in lowe houses &raisedpoint; by lele mennes almesse
Grace sholde growe & be grene &raisedpoint; þorw her good lyuynge
And folkes sholde fynde &raisedpoint; þat ben in dyuerse sykenesse
Þe better for her byddynges &raisedpoint; in body and in soule
Her preyeres and her penaunces &raisedpoint; to pees shulde brynge
Alle þat ben at debate &raisedpoint; and bedemen were trewe
Petite & accipietis &c
Salt saueth catel &punctuselevatus; seggen þis wyues
Vos estis sal terre &c &raisedpoint;
Þe heuedes of holicherche &raisedpoint; and þei holy were
Cryst calleth hem salt &raisedpoint; for crystene soules
Et si sal euanuerit &raisedpoint; in quo salietur
Ac fressh flessh other fissh &raisedpoint; whan it salt failleth
It is vnsauory for soth &raisedpoint; ysothe or ybake
So is mannes soule sothly &raisedpoint; þat seeth no good ensaumple
Of hem of holycherche &raisedpoint; þat þe heigh weye shulde teche
And be gyde and go bifore &raisedpoint; as a good baneoure
And hardy hem þat bihynde ben &raisedpoint; and ȝiue hem good euydence
¶ Elleuene holy men &raisedpoint; al þe worlde torned

lg.l: In-to lele byleue &raisedpoint; þe liȝtloker me thynketh
Shulde al maner men &raisedpoint; we han so manye Maistres
Prestes and prechoures &raisedpoint; and a pope aboue
Þat goddes salt shulde be &raisedpoint; to saue mannes soule
¶ Al was hethenesse some-tyme &punctuselevatus; Ingelond and wales
Til Gregory gerte clerkes &raisedpoint; to go here and preche
Austyn at Caunterbury &raisedpoint; crystened þe kynge
And þorw myracles as men may rede &raisedpoint; al þat marche he torned
To cryst and to crystendome &raisedpoint; and crosse to honoure
And fulled folke faste &raisedpoint; and þe faith tauȝte
More þorw miracles &raisedpoint; þan þorw moche prechynge
As wel þorw his werkes &raisedpoint; as with his holy wordes
And seyde hem what fullynge &raisedpoint; and faith was to mene
¶ Cloth þat cometh fro þe weuyng &raisedpoint; is nouȝt comly to were
Tyl it is fulled vnder fote &raisedpoint; or in fullyng stokkes
Wasshen wel with water &raisedpoint; and with taseles cracched
Ytouked and ytented &punctuselevatus; & vnder tailloures hande

marginalia.note: M15.473, Kane and Donaldson argue that the sidenote indicates that "a corrector of M knew of a manuscript which possessed XV 472-85, missing from the larger group" (p. 51n7). This seems unlikely, since the note is placed ten lines too early, and furthermore Kane and Donaldson themselves admit that "there is no evidence that M was corrected to (RF)." The note may simply refer to the fact that M alone among B manuscripts lacks "how" before "a man".

lg.l: ¶ Ȝe nymmen wel how matheu seith &raisedpoint; how a man made a feste
He fedde hem with no venysoun &raisedpoint; ne fesauntes ybake
But with foules þat fram hym nolde &raisedpoint; but folwed his whistellynge
Ecce altilia mea & omnia parata sunt &c
And wyth calues flesshe he fedde &raisedpoint; þe folke þat he loued
Þe calfe bytokeneth clennesse &raisedpoint; in hem þat kepeth lawes
¶ For as þe cow þorw kynde mylke &raisedpoint; þe calf norissheth til an oxe
So loue [&] lewte &raisedpoint; lele men susteyneth
And maydenes and mylde men mercy desiren
Riȝt as þe cow calf &raisedpoint; coueyteth swete mylke
So don riȝtful men &raisedpoint; mercy & treutheHereafter follow 15.472-485 in KD, from alpha, but they are no annotated.
¶ Ac who beth þat excuseth hem &raisedpoint; þat aren persounes and prestes
Þat heuedes of holycherche ben &raisedpoint; þat han her wille here
With-oute trauaille þe tithe del &raisedpoint; þat trewe men biswynkyn
Þei wil be wroth for I write þus &raisedpoint; ac to witnesse I take
Bothe Mathew and Marke &raisedpoint; and Memento domine dauid
What Pope or prelate now &raisedpoint; perfourneth þat cryst hiȝte
Ite in vniuersum mundum & predicate & c &raisedpoint;
¶ Allas þat men so longe &raisedpoint; on Makometh shulde byleue
So many prelates to preche &raisedpoint; as þe Pope maketh
Of Nazareth of Nynyue &raisedpoint; of Neptalim and damaske
Þat þei ne went as cryst wisseth &raisedpoint; sithen þei wil a name
¶ To be pastours and preche &raisedpoint; þe passioun of Ihesus
And as hym-self seyde &raisedpoint; so to lyue and deye
Bonus pastor animam suam ponit & c
And seyde it in sauacioun &raisedpoint; of sarasenes & other
For crystene & vncristene &raisedpoint; cryst seide to prechoures
Ite vos in vineam meam &raisedpoint;
And sith þat þis sarasenes &raisedpoint; scribes & Iuwes
Han a lippe of owre byleue &raisedpoint; þe liȝtloker me thynketh
Þei shulde torne who-so trauaille wolde &raisedpoint; to teche hem of þe Trinite

Take her landes ȝe lordes &raisedpoint; and let hem lyue by dymes
If possessioun be poysoun &raisedpoint; & inparfit hem make
Good were to dischargen hem &raisedpoint; for holicherche sake
And purgen hem of poysoun &raisedpoint; or more perile falle
¶ Ȝif presthod were parfit &raisedpoint; þe peple solde amende
Þat contrarien crystes lawe &raisedpoint; and crystendome dispise
For al paynym prayeth &raisedpoint; and parfitly bileueth

¶ And ȝit knewe þei cryst &raisedpoint; þat crystendome tauȝte

Dede hym rise and rowme riȝt bifor þe iuwes

lg.l: Now faire falle ȝow quod I þo &raisedpoint; for ȝowre faire shewynge
For haukynnes loue þe actyf man euere I shal ȝow louye
Ac ȝet I am in a were &raisedpoint; what charite is to mene
¶ It is a ful trye tree quod he &raisedpoint; trewly to telle &raisedpoint;
Mercy is þe more þer-of &raisedpoint; þe myddel stokke is reuthe
Þe leues ben lele wordes &raisedpoint; þe lawe of holycherche
Þe blosmes beth boxome speche &raisedpoint; and benygne lokynge
Pacience hatte þe pure tre &raisedpoint; and pore symple of herte
And so þorw god and þorw good men &raisedpoint; groweth þe frute charite
¶ I wolde trauaille quod I þis tree to se &raisedpoint; twenty hundreth myle
And forto haue my fylle of þat frute &raisedpoint; forsake al other saulee
Lorde quod I if any wiȝte wyte &raisedpoint; whider oute it groweth
¶ It groweth in gardyne quod he &raisedpoint; þat god made hym-seluen
Amyddes mannes body &raisedpoint; þe more is of þat stokke
Herte hatte þe erber &raisedpoint; þat it in groweth
And liberum arbitrium &raisedpoint; hath þe londe to ferme
Vnder Piers þe plowman &raisedpoint; to pyken it &raisedpoint; and to weden it
Piers þe plowman quod I þo &raisedpoint; and al for pure ioye
Þat I herde nempne his name &raisedpoint; anone I swouned after
And laye longe in a loue-dreme &raisedpoint; and atte laste me þouȝte
Þat Pieres þe plowman &raisedpoint; al þe place me shewed
And bad me toten on þe tree &raisedpoint; on toppe and on rote
With þre pyles was it vnder-piȝte &raisedpoint; I perceyued it sone
Pieres quod I &raisedpoint; I preye þe &raisedpoint; whi stonde þise piles here
¶ For wyndes wiltow wyte quod he &raisedpoint; to witen it fram fallyng
Cum ceciderit iustus non collidetur &raisedpoint; quia dominus supponit manum suam
And in blowyng tyme abite þe floures &raisedpoint; but if þis piles helpe

lg.l: Þe worlde is a wykked wynde &raisedpoint; to hem þat wolden treuthe

And forfret neigh þe frute &raisedpoint; þorw many faire siȝtes
Þanne with þe firste pyle &raisedpoint; I palle hym down &raisedpoint; þat is potencia dei patris
Þe flesshe is a fel wynde &raisedpoint; and in flourynge tyme
Þorw lykyng and lustes &raisedpoint; so loude he gynneth blowe
Þat it norissheth nice siȝtes &raisedpoint; and some-tyme wordes
And wikked werkes þer-of &raisedpoint; wormes of synne
And forbiteth þe blosmes &raisedpoint; riȝt to þe bare leues
¶ Þanne sette I to þe secounde pile &raisedpoint; sapiencia dei patris
Þat is þe passioun and þe power &raisedpoint; of owre prynce Ihesu
Þorw preyeres and þorw penaunces &raisedpoint; and goddes passioun in mynde
I saue it til I se it rypen &raisedpoint; & somdel yfruited
And þanne fondeth þe fende &raisedpoint; my fruit to destruye
With alle þe wyles þat he can &raisedpoint; and waggeth þe rote
And casteth vp to þe croppe &raisedpoint; vnkynde neighbores
Bakbiteres breke-cheste &raisedpoint; brawleres and chideres
And leith a laddre þere-to &raisedpoint; of lesynges aren þe ronges
And feccheth away my floures sumtyme &raisedpoint; afor bothe myn eyhen
Ac liberum arbitrium &raisedpoint; letteth hym some-tyme
Þat is lieutenant to loken it wel &raisedpoint; by leue of my-selue
Videatis qui peccat in spiritum sanctum numquam remittetur &c
Hoc est idem qui peccat per liberum arbitrium non repugnat &raisedpoint;
Ac whan þe fende and þe flesshe &raisedpoint; forth with þe worlde
Manasen byhynde me &raisedpoint; my fruit for to fecche
Þanne liberum arbitrium laccheth þe thridde plante
And palleth adown þe pouke &raisedpoint; purelich þorw grace
And helpe of þe holy goste &raisedpoint; and þus haue I þe maystrie
¶ Now faire falle ȝow Pieres quod I &raisedpoint; so faire ȝe discryuen
Þe powere of þis postes &raisedpoint; and her propre myȝte
Ac I haue þouȝtes a threve &raisedpoint; of þis þre piles
In what wode þei woxen &raisedpoint; and where þat þei growed
For alle ar þei aliche longe &raisedpoint; none lasse þan other
And to my mynde as me þinketh &raisedpoint; on o More þei growed
And of o gretnesse &raisedpoint; and grene of greyne þei semen
¶ Þat is soth seide Pieres so it may bifalle
I shal telle þe as tite &raisedpoint; what þis tree hatte
Þe grounde þere it groweth &raisedpoint; goodnesse it hiȝte
And I haue tolde þe what hiȝte þe tree &raisedpoint; þe trinite it meneth
And egrelich he loked on me &raisedpoint; & þer-fore I spared
To asken hym any more ther-of &raisedpoint; and badde hym ful fayre
To discreue þe fruit &punctuselevatus; þat so faire hangeth
¶ Here now bineth quod he þo &raisedpoint; if I nede hadde
Matrymonye I may nyme &raisedpoint; a moiste fruit with-alle
Þanne contenence is nerre þe croppe &raisedpoint; as calwey bastarde
Þanne bereth þe croppe kynde fruite &raisedpoint; and clenneste of alle
Maydenhode angeles peres &raisedpoint; and rathest wole be ripe
And swete with-oute swellyng &raisedpoint; soure worth it neuere
¶ I prayed pieres to pulle adown &raisedpoint; an apple and he wolde
And suffre me to assaye &raisedpoint; what sauoure it hadde
¶ And pieres caste to þe croppe &raisedpoint; and þanne comsed it to crye
And wagged wydwehode &raisedpoint; and it wepte after
And whan it meued Matrimoigne &raisedpoint; it made a foule noyse
Þat I had reuth whan Piers rogged &raisedpoint; it gradde so reufulliche
For euere as þei dropped adown &raisedpoint; þe deuel was redy
