And gadred hem alle togideres &raisedpoint; bothe grete and smale
Adam & abraham &raisedpoint; and ysay þe prophete
Sampson and samuel &raisedpoint; and seynt Iohan þe baptiste
Bar hem forth boldely &raisedpoint; no-body hym letted
And made of holy men his horde &raisedpoint; in lymbo inferni
There is derkenesse and drede &raisedpoint; and þe deuel Maister
¶ And Pieres for pure tene &raisedpoint; þat o pile he lauȝte
And hitte after hym &raisedpoint; happe how it myȝte
Filius bi þe fader wille &raisedpoint; and frenesse of spiritus sancti
To go robbe þat raggeman &raisedpoint; and reue þe fruit fro hym
¶ And þanne spakke spiritus sanctus &raisedpoint; in Gabrieles mouthe
To a mayde þat hiȝte Marye &raisedpoint; a meke þinge with-alle
Þat one Ihesus a iustice sone &raisedpoint; moste iouke in her chambre
Tyl plenitudo temporis &raisedpoint; fully comen were
Þat Pieres fruit floured &raisedpoint; and fel to be ripe
And þanne shulde Ihesus iuste þere-fore &raisedpoint; bi iuggement of armes
Whether shulde fonde þe fruit &raisedpoint; þe fende or hym-selue
¶ Þe mayde myldeliche þo &raisedpoint; þe messager graunted
And seyde hendelich to hym &raisedpoint; lo me his hande-mayden
For to worchen his wille &raisedpoint; with-outen any synne
Ecce ancilla domini fiat michi &c
And in þe wombe of þat wenche &raisedpoint; was he fourty wokes
Tyl he wex a faunt þorw her flessh &raisedpoint; and of fiȝtyng couthe
To haue yfouȝte with þe fende &raisedpoint; ar ful tyme come
And Pieres þe plowman &raisedpoint; parceyued plenere tyme
And lered hym lechecrafte &raisedpoint; his lyf for to saue
Þat þowgh he were wounded &raisedpoint; with his enemye &punctuselevatus; to warisshe hym-self
And did hym assaye his surgerye &raisedpoint; on hem þat syke were
Til he was parfit practisoure &raisedpoint; of any peril fulle
And souȝte oute þe syke &raisedpoint; and synful bothe
And salued syke and synful &raisedpoint; bothe blynde & crokede
And comune wommen conuerted &raisedpoint; and to good torned
Non est sanis opus medicus set in &c
Bothe meseles & mute &raisedpoint; and in þe menysoun blody
Ofte he heled suche &raisedpoint; he ne helde for no maistrye
Saue þo he leched lazar þat hadde yleye in graue
Quatriduanus quelt &raisedpoint; quykke did hym walke
Ac as he made þe maistrye &raisedpoint; mestus cepit esse
And wepte water with his eyghen &raisedpoint; þere seyen it manye
Some þat þe siȝte seyne &raisedpoint; saide þat tyme
Þat he was leche of lyf &raisedpoint; and lorde of heigh heuene
Iewes iangeled þere-aȝeyne &raisedpoint; and iugged lawes
And seide he wrouȝte þorw wicchecrafte &raisedpoint; & with þe deueles miȝte
Demonium habes &c
¶ Þanne ar ȝe cherles quod ich &raisedpoint; and ȝowre children bothe
And sathan ȝowre saueoure &raisedpoint; ȝow-selue now ȝe witnessen
For I haue saued ȝow-self seith cryst &raisedpoint; and ȝowre sones after
Ȝowre bodyes ȝowre bestes &raisedpoint; and blynde men holpen
And fedde ȝow with fisshes &raisedpoint; and with fyue loues
And left baskettes ful of broke mete &raisedpoint; bere awey who-so wolde
And mysseide þe iewes manliche and manaced hem to bete
And knokked on hem with a corde &raisedpoint; and caste adown her stalles
Þat in cherche chaffareden &raisedpoint; or chaungeden any moneye
And seyde it in siȝte of hem alle &raisedpoint; so þat alle herden
I shal ouertourne þis temple &raisedpoint; and adown throwe
And in thre dayes after &raisedpoint; edifye it newe
And make it as moche other more &raisedpoint; in alle manere poyntes
As euere it was and as wyde &raisedpoint; wher-fore I hote ȝow
Of preyeres and of parfitnesse &raisedpoint; þis place þat ȝe callen
Domus mea domus oracionis vocabitur
Enuye and yuel wille &raisedpoint; was in þe iewes
Thei casten & contreueden &raisedpoint; to kulle hym whan þei miȝte
Vche daye after other &raisedpoint; þeire tyme þei awaited
Til it bifel on a fryday &raisedpoint; a litel bifor Paske
Þe þorsday byfore þere he made his maundee
Sittyng atte sopere &raisedpoint; he seide þise wordes
I am solde þorw one of ȝow &raisedpoint; he shal þe tyme rewe
Þat euere he his saueoure solde &raisedpoint; for syluer or elles
¶ Iudas iangeled þere-aȝein &raisedpoint; ac Ihesus hym tolde
It was hym[self] sothely &raisedpoint; and seide tu dicis
lg.marginalia: The maner of Iudas betrayng is vsedCr3.16.152
lg.l: Þanne went forth þat wikked man &raisedpoint; and with þe iewes mette
And tolde hem a tokne how to knowe with ihesus
And which tokne to þis day &raisedpoint; to moche is yvsed
Þat is kissyng and faire contenaunce &raisedpoint; & vnkynde wille
And so was with iudas þo &raisedpoint; þat Ihesus bytrayed
Aue raby quod þat ribaude &raisedpoint; and riȝt to hym he ȝede
And kiste hym to be cauȝt þere-by &raisedpoint; and kulled of þe iewes
¶ Þanne Ihesus to Iudas &raisedpoint; and to þe iewes seyde
Falsenesse I fynde &raisedpoint; in þi faire speche
And gyle in þi gladde chere &raisedpoint; and galle is in þi lawghyng
Þow shalt be myroure to manye men to deceyue
Ac þe wors and þi wikkednesse &raisedpoint; shal worth vpon þi-selue
Necesse est vt veniant scandala &raisedpoint; ve homini illi per quem scandalum venit
Þow I bi tresoun be ytake &raisedpoint; at ȝowre owne wille
Suffreth my postles in pays &raisedpoint; & in pees gange
On a thoresday in thesternesse &raisedpoint; þus was he taken
Þorw iudas and iewes &raisedpoint; ihesus was his name
Þat on þe fryday folwynge &raisedpoint; for mankynde sake
Iusted in ierusalem &raisedpoint; a ioye to vs alle
On crosse vpon caluarye &raisedpoint; cryst toke þe bataille
Aȝeines deth and þe deuel &raisedpoint; destruyed her botheres myȝtes
Deyde and deth fordid &raisedpoint; and daye of nyȝte made
¶ And I awaked þere-with &raisedpoint; & wyped myne eyghen
And after piers þe plowman &raisedpoint; pryed and stared
Estwarde and westwarde &raisedpoint; I awayted after faste
And ȝede forth as an ydiote &raisedpoint; in contre to aspye
After Pieres þe plowman &raisedpoint; many a place I souȝte
lg.marginalia: [scroll-like pattern]G17.178, extends downwards for approximately 7 lines.
lg.l: And þanne mette I with a man &raisedpoint; a mydlenten sondaye
As hore as an hawethorne &raisedpoint; and Abraham he hiȝte
I frayned hym first &raisedpoint; fram whennes he come

marginalia.note: R16.183. Between R16.183-184 (KD16.175-176), between two verse paragraphs, a sixteenth-century (secretary) pen trial, mostly erased.

lg.l: And of whennes he were &raisedpoint; and whider þat he þouȝte
¶ I am feith quod þat freke &raisedpoint; it falleth nouȝte to lye
And of Abrahames hous &raisedpoint; an heraud of armes
I seke after a segge &raisedpoint; þat I seigh ones
A ful bolde bacheler &raisedpoint; I knewe hym by his blasen
What bereth þat buirn quod I þo &raisedpoint; so blisse þe bityde
¶ Þre leodes in o lith &raisedpoint; non lenger þan other
Of one mochel & myȝte &raisedpoint; in mesure and in lengthe
Þat one doth alle doth &raisedpoint; & eche doth by his one
Þe firste hath miȝte and maiestee &raisedpoint; maker of alle þinges
Pater is his propre name &raisedpoint; a persone by hym-selue
Þe secounde of þat sire is &raisedpoint; sothfastnesse filius
Wardeyne of þat witte hath &raisedpoint; was euere with-oute gynnyng
Þe þridde hatte þe holygoost &raisedpoint; a persone by hym-selue
Þe liȝte of alle þat lyf hath &raisedpoint; a londe & a watre
Confortoure of creatures &raisedpoint; of hym cometh al blisse
So þre bilongeth for a lorde &raisedpoint; þat lordeship claymeth
Myȝte and a mene &raisedpoint; to knowe his owne myȝte
Of hym & of his seruaunt &raisedpoint; and what þei suffre bothe
So god þat gynnyng hadde neure &raisedpoint; but þo hym good þouȝte
Sent forth his sone as for seruaunt þat tyme
To occupien hym here &raisedpoint; til issue were spronge
Þat is children of charite &raisedpoint; & holicherche þe moder
Patriarkes & prophetes &raisedpoint; and aposteles were þe chyldren
And cryst and crystenedome &raisedpoint; and crystene holycherche
In menynge þat man moste &raisedpoint; on o god bileue
And þere hym lyked & loued &raisedpoint; in þre persones hym shewed
And þat it may be so & soth &raisedpoint; manhode it sheweth
Wedloke and widwehode &raisedpoint; with virgynyte ynempned
In toknynge of þe Trinite &raisedpoint; was taken oute of o man
Adam owre aller fader &raisedpoint; Eue was of hym-selue
lg.marginalia: S oppR16.214, near gutter, brown secretary hand pen trial
lg.l: And þe issue þat þei hadde &raisedpoint; it was of hem bothe
lg.marginalia:
John Sympson Smithe JohnJohn Sympson
William JohR16.215, secretary hand

Jhon
SympsonR16.215, top margin of fol. 84r. All of the pen trials appear to be in the same hand, but the different shades of ink and variations in cut of the stylus suggest that they were executed at different times.
lg.l: And either is otheres ioye &raisedpoint; in thre sondry persones
And in heuene & here &raisedpoint; one syngulere name
And þis is mankynde or manhede &raisedpoint; of matrimoigne yspronge
And bitokneth þe Trinite &raisedpoint; and trewe bileue
¶ Miȝte is matrimoigne &raisedpoint; þat multiplieth þe erthe
And bitokneth trewly &raisedpoint; telle if I dorste
He þat firste fourmed al &raisedpoint; þe fader of heuene
Þe sone if I it durst seye &raisedpoint; resembleth wel þe wydwe
Deus meus deus meus vt quid dereliquisti me
Þat is creatour wex creature &raisedpoint; to knowe what was bothe
As widwe with-oute wedloke &raisedpoint; was neure ȝete yseye
Na-more myȝte god be man &raisedpoint; but if he moder hadde
So wydwe with-oute wedloke &raisedpoint; may nouȝte wel stande
Ne matrimoigne withoute moillerye &raisedpoint; is nouȝt moche to preyse
Maledictus homo qui non reliquit semen in israel &c
Þus in þre persones &raisedpoint; is perfitliche manhede
Þat is man & his make &raisedpoint; & moillere her children
And is nouȝt but gendre of o generacioun &raisedpoint; bifor Ihesu cryst in heuene
So is þe fader forth with þe sone &raisedpoint; and fre wille of bothe
Spiritus procedens a patre & filio
Which is þe holygoste of alle &raisedpoint; and alle is but o god
Þus in a somer I hym seigh &raisedpoint; as I satte in my porche
I ros vp and reuerenced hym &raisedpoint; & riȝt faire hym grette
Thre men to my syȝte &raisedpoint; I made wel at ese
Wesche her feet & wyped hem &raisedpoint; and afterward þei eten
Calues flesshe & cakebrede &raisedpoint; and knewe what I thouȝte
Ful trewe tokenes bitwene vs is &raisedpoint; to telle whan me lyketh
Firste he fonded me &raisedpoint; if I loued bettere
Hym or ysaak myn ayre &raisedpoint; þe which he hiȝte me kulle
He wiste my wille by hym &raisedpoint; he wil me it allowe
I am ful syker in soule þer-of &raisedpoint; and my sone bothe
I circumcised my sone &raisedpoint; sitthen for his sake
My-self and my meyne &raisedpoint; and alle þat male were
Bledden blode for þat lordes loue &raisedpoint; and hope to blisse þe tyme
Myn affiaunce & my faith &raisedpoint; is ferme in þis bilieue
For hym-self bihiȝte to me &raisedpoint; and to myne issue bothe
Londe and lordship &raisedpoint; and lyf with-outen ende
To me and to myn issue &raisedpoint; more ȝete he me graunted .
Mercy for owre mysdedes &raisedpoint; as many tyme as we asken
Quam olim abrahe promisisti & semini eius
And sith he sent me to seye &raisedpoint; I sholde do sacrifise
And done hym worshipe with bred &raisedpoint; and with wyn bothe
And called me þe fote of his faith &raisedpoint; his folke forto saue
And defende hem fro þe fende &raisedpoint; folke þat on me leneden
Þus haue I ben his heraude &raisedpoint; here and in helle
And conforted many a careful &raisedpoint; þat after his comynge wayten
And þus I seke hym he seide &raisedpoint; for I [herde] seyne late
Of a barne þat baptised hym &raisedpoint; Iohan Baptiste was his name
Þat to patriarkes and to prophetes &raisedpoint; and to other peple in derknesse
Seyde þat he seigh here &raisedpoint; þat sholde saue vs alle
Ecce agnus dei &c &raisedpoint;
¶ I hadde wonder of his wordes &raisedpoint; and of his wyde clothes
For in his bosome he bar a thyng &raisedpoint; þat he blissed euere
And I loked on his lappe &raisedpoint; a lazar lay þere-Inne
Amonges patriarkes and profetes &raisedpoint; pleyande togyderes
What awaytestow quod he &raisedpoint; and what woldestow haue
I wolde wyte quod I þo what is in ȝowre lappe
¶ Loo quod he and lete me se &raisedpoint; lorde mercy I seide
Þis is present of moche prys &raisedpoint; what Prynce shal it haue
It is a preciouse present quod he &raisedpoint; ac þe pouke it hath attached
And me þere-myde quod þat man &raisedpoint; may no wedde vs quite
Ne no buyrn be owre borwgh &raisedpoint; ne bryng vs fram his daungere
Oute of þe poukes pondfolde &raisedpoint; no meynprise may vs fecche
Tyl he come þat I carpe of &raisedpoint; cryst is his name
Þat shal delyure vs some daye &raisedpoint; out of þe deueles powere
And bettere wedde for vs legge &raisedpoint; þan we ben alle worthy
Þat is lyf for lyf &raisedpoint; or ligge þus euere
Lollynge in my lappe &raisedpoint; tyl such a lorde vs fecche
¶ Allas I seyde þat synne &raisedpoint; so longe shal lette
Þe myȝte of goddes mercy &raisedpoint; þat myȝt vs alle amende
I wepte for his wordes &raisedpoint; with þat sawe I an other
Rapelich renne forth &raisedpoint; þe riȝte waye he went
I affrayned hym fyrste &raisedpoint; fram whennes he come
And what he hiȝte & whider he wolde &raisedpoint; and wightlich he tolde
I am spes quod he a spye &raisedpoint; and spire after a knyȝte
That toke me a maundement vpon þe mounte of synay
To reule alle rewmes with &raisedpoint; I bere þe writte here
Is it asseled I seyde &raisedpoint; may men se þi lettres
Nay he sayde I seke hym &raisedpoint; þat hath þe sele to kepe
¶ And þat is crosse and crystenedome &raisedpoint; and cryst þere-on to hange
And whan it is asseled so &raisedpoint; I wote wel þe sothe
Þat Lucyferes lordeship &raisedpoint; laste shal no lenger
Late se þi lettres quod I &raisedpoint; we miȝte þe lawe knowe
¶ Þanne plokked he forth a patent &raisedpoint; a pece of an harde roche
Wher-on was writen two wordes &raisedpoint; on þis wyse yglosed
Dilige deum & proximum tuum &c
Þis was þe tixte trewly &raisedpoint; I toke ful gode ȝeme
Þe glose was gloriousely writen &raisedpoint; with a gilte penne
In hijs duobus mandatis tota lex pendet & prophetia
¶ Is here alle þi lordes lawes quod I &raisedpoint; ȝe leue me wel he seyde
And who-so worcheth after þis writte &raisedpoint; I wil vndertaken
Shal neuere deuel hym dere &raisedpoint; ne deth in soule greue
For þough I seye it my-self &raisedpoint; I haue saued with þis charme
Of men & of wommen &raisedpoint; many score þousandes
¶ He seith soth seyde þis heraud &raisedpoint; I haue yfounde it ofte
Lo here in my lappe &raisedpoint; þat leued on þat charme
Iosue and Iudith &raisedpoint; and Iudas Macabeus
Ȝe and sexty þousande bisyde-forth &raisedpoint; þat ben nouȝt seyen here
¶ Ȝowre wordes aren wonderful quod I tho &raisedpoint; which of ȝow is trewest
And lelest to leue on &raisedpoint; for lyf and for soule
Abraham seith þat he seigh &raisedpoint; holy þe Trinite
lg.marginalia: Abraham saw thre distincte persons in trinityCr3.17.28
lg.l: Thre persones in parcelles &raisedpoint; departable fro other
And alle þre but o god &raisedpoint; þus abraham me tauȝte
And hath saued þat bileued so &raisedpoint; and sory for her synnes
He can nouȝte segge þe somme &raisedpoint; and some aren in his lappe
What neded it þanne &raisedpoint; a newe lawe to bigynne
Sith þe fyrst sufficeth &raisedpoint; to sauacioun & to blisse
¶ And now cometh spes and speketh &raisedpoint; þat hath aspied þe lawe
And telleth nouȝte of þe Trinitee &raisedpoint; þat toke hym his lettres
To byleue and louye &raisedpoint; in o lorde almyȝty
And sitthe riȝt as my-self &raisedpoint; so louye alle peple
¶ Þe gome þat goth with o staf &raisedpoint; he semeth in gretter hele
Þan he þat goth with two staues &raisedpoint; to syȝte of vs alle
And riȝte so by þe Rode &raisedpoint; resoun me sheweth
It is lyȝter to lewed men &raisedpoint; a lessoun to knowe
Þan for to techen hem two &raisedpoint; and to harde to lerne þe leest
It is ful harde for any man &raisedpoint; on abraham byleue
And welawey worse ȝit &raisedpoint; for to loue a shrewe
It is liȝtor to leue &raisedpoint; in þre louely persones
Þan for to louye and lene &raisedpoint; as wel lorelles as lele
Go þi gate quod I to spes &raisedpoint; so me god helpe
Þo þat lerneth þi lawe &raisedpoint; wil litel while vsen it
And as we wenten þus in þe weye &raisedpoint; wordyng togyderes
Þanne seye we a samaritan &raisedpoint; sittende on a mule
Rydynge ful rapely &raisedpoint; þe riȝt weye we ȝeden
Comynge fro a cuntre &raisedpoint; þat men called Ierico

marginalia.note: Bx17.54: id est cristus: This is written in the margin by the main hand in LM, and at the end of the line in R. Hm has it in the margin in another hand.

lg.l: To a iustes in iherusalem &raisedpoint; he chaced awey faste
Bothe þe heraud and hope &raisedpoint; and he mette at ones
Where a man was wounded &raisedpoint; and with þeues taken
He myȝte neither steppe ne stonde &raisedpoint; ne stere fote ne handes
Ne helpe hym-self sothely &raisedpoint; for semiuyf he semed
And as naked as a nedle &raisedpoint; and none helpe aboute hym
¶ Feith had first siȝte of hym &raisedpoint; ac he flegh on syde
And nolde nouȝt neighen hym &raisedpoint; by nyne londes lengthe
¶ Hope cam hippyng after &raisedpoint; þat hadde so ybosted
How he with Moyses maundement &raisedpoint; hadde many men yholpe
Ac whan he hadde siȝte of þat segge &raisedpoint; a-syde he gan hym drawe
Dredfully by þis day as duk &raisedpoint; doth fram þe faucoun
¶ Ac so sone so þe samaritan &raisedpoint; hadde siȝte of þis lede
He liȝte adown of lyard &raisedpoint; and ladde hym in his hande
And to þe wye he went &raisedpoint; his woundes to biholde
And parceyued bi his pous &raisedpoint; he was in peril to deye
And but if he hadde recourere &raisedpoint; þe rather &punctuselevatus; þat rise shulde he neure
Wyth wyn & with oyle &raisedpoint; his woundes he wasshed
Enbawmed hym and bonde his hed &raisedpoint; & in his lappe hym layde
And ladde hym so forth on lyard &raisedpoint; to lex cristi a graunge
Wel six myle or seuene &raisedpoint; biside þe newe market
Herberwed hym at an hostrye &raisedpoint; and to þe hostellere called
And sayde haue kepe þis man &raisedpoint; til I come fro þe iustes
And lo here syluer he seyde &raisedpoint; for salue to his woundes
And he toke hym two pans &raisedpoint; to lyflode as it were
And seide what he speneth more &raisedpoint; I make þe good hereafter
For I may nouȝt lette quod þat leode &raisedpoint; & lyarde he bistrydeth
And raped hym to iherusalem-ward &raisedpoint; þe riȝte waye to ryde
¶ Faith folweth after faste &raisedpoint; and fonded to mete hym
And spes spaklich hym spedde &raisedpoint; spede if he myȝte
To ouertake hym and talke to hym &raisedpoint; ar þei to toun come
¶ And whan I seyȝ þis I soiourned nouȝte &raisedpoint; but shope me to renne
And suwed þat samaritan &raisedpoint; þat was so ful of pite
And graunted hym to ben his grome &raisedpoint; gramercy he seyde
Ac þi frende and þi felawe quod he &raisedpoint; þow fyndest me at nede

lg.marginalia: Pierce orifereth Christ to be come his seruantCr3.17.88
lg.l: ¶ And I thanked hym þo &raisedpoint; and sith I hym tolde
How þat feith fleigh awey &raisedpoint; and spes his felaw bothe
For siȝte of þe sorweful man &raisedpoint; þat robbed was with þeues
Haue hem excused quod he &raisedpoint; her help may litel auaille
May no medcyn on molde &raisedpoint; þe man to hele brynge
Neither feith ne fyn hope &raisedpoint; so festred ben his woundis
With-out þe blode of a barn &raisedpoint; borne of a mayde
And be he bathed in þat blode &raisedpoint; baptised as it were
And þanne plastred with penaunce &raisedpoint; and passioun of þat babi
He shulde stonde and steppe &raisedpoint; ac stalworth worth he neure
Tyl he haue eten al þe barn &raisedpoint; and his blode ydronke
For went neuere wy in þis worlde þorw þat wildernesse
Þat he ne was robbed or rifled &raisedpoint; rode he þere or ȝede
Saue faith & his felaw &raisedpoint; spes and my-selue
And þi-self now &raisedpoint; and such as suwen owre werkis
¶ For outlawes in þe wode &raisedpoint; and vnder banke lotyeth
And may vch man se &raisedpoint; and gode merke take
Who is bihynde and who bifore &raisedpoint; and who ben on hors
For he halt hym hardyer on horse &raisedpoint; þan he þat is a-fote
For he seigh me þat am samaritan &raisedpoint; suwen feith & his felaw
On my caple þat hatte caro &raisedpoint; of mankynde I toke it
He was vnhardy þat harlot &raisedpoint; and hudde hym in inferno
Ac ar þis day þre dayes &raisedpoint; I dar vndertaken
Þat he worth fettred þat feloune &raisedpoint; fast with cheynes
And neure eft greue grome &raisedpoint; þat goth þis ilke gate
¶ And þanne shal feith be forester here &raisedpoint; and in þis fritth walke
And kennen out comune men &raisedpoint; þat knoweth nouȝte þe contre
Which is þe weye þat ich went &raisedpoint; and wherforth to iherusalem
And hope þe hostelleres man shal be &raisedpoint; þere þe man lith an helynge
And alle þat fieble and faynt be &raisedpoint; þat faith may nouȝt teche
Hope shal lede hem forth with loue &raisedpoint; as his lettre telleth
And hostel hem and hele &raisedpoint; þorw holicherche bileue
Tyl I haue salue for alle syke &raisedpoint; and þanne shal I retourne
And come aȝein bi þis contree &raisedpoint; and confort alle syke
Þat craueth it or coueiteth it &raisedpoint; and cryeth þere-after
For þe barne was born in bethleem &raisedpoint; þat with his blode shal saue
Alle þat lyueth in faith &raisedpoint; and folweth his felawes techynge
¶ A swete syre I seyde þo &raisedpoint; wher I shal byleue
As feith and his felawe &raisedpoint; enfourmed me bothe
In þre persones departable &raisedpoint; þat perpetuel were euere
And alle þre but o god &raisedpoint; þus abraham me tauȝte
And hope afterwarde &raisedpoint; he bad me to louye
O god wyth al my good &raisedpoint; and alle gomes after
Louye hem lyke my-selue &raisedpoint; ac owre lorde aboue alle
¶ After abraham quod he &raisedpoint; þat heraud of armes
Sette faste þi faith &raisedpoint; and ferme bileue
And as hope hiȝte þe &raisedpoint; I hote þat þow louye
Thyn euene-crystene euermore &raisedpoint; euene-forth with þi-self
And if conscience carpe þere-aȝein &raisedpoint; or kynde witte oyther

marginalia.foreign: Ostende manum quia deus assimulatur ad manum

lg.l: Or heretykes with argumentz &raisedpoint; þin honde þow hym shewe
For god is after an hande &raisedpoint; yhere now and knowe it
¶ Þe fader was fyrst as a fyst &raisedpoint; with o fynger foldynge
Tyl hym loued and lest &raisedpoint; to vnlosen his fynger
And profre it forth as with a paume &raisedpoint; to what place it sholde
Þe paume is purely þe hande &raisedpoint; and profreth forth þe fyngres
To mynystre and to make &raisedpoint; þat myȝte of hande knoweth
And bitokneth trewly &raisedpoint; telle who-so liketh
Þe holygost of heuene &raisedpoint; he is as þe paume
Þe fyngres þat fre ben &raisedpoint; to folde and to serue
Bitokneth sothly þe sone &raisedpoint; þat sent was til erthe
Þat toched and tasted &raisedpoint; atte techynge of þe paume
Seynt Marie a Mayde &raisedpoint; and mankynde lauȝte
Qui conceptus est de spiritu sancto &c
Þe fader is þanne as a fust &raisedpoint; with fynger to touche
Quia omnia traham ad me ipsum &c
Al þat þe paume parceyueth &raisedpoint; profitable to fele
Thus ar þei alle but one &raisedpoint; as it an hande were
And þre sondry siȝtes &raisedpoint; in one shewynge
Þe paume for he putteth forth fyngres and þe fust bothe
Riȝt so redily &raisedpoint; reson it sheweth
How he þat is holygoste &raisedpoint; sire & sone preueth
And as þe hande halt harde &raisedpoint; and al þynge faste
Þorw foure fyngres and a thombe &raisedpoint; forth with þe paume
Riȝte so þe fader and þe sone &raisedpoint; & seynt spirit þe þridde
Halt al þe wyde worlde &raisedpoint; with-in hem thre
Bothe welkne and þe wynde &raisedpoint; water and erthe
Heuene & helle &raisedpoint; and al þat þere is Inne
Þus it is &raisedpoint; nedeth no man &raisedpoint; to trowe non other
That thre þinges bilongeth &raisedpoint; in owre lorde of heuene
And aren serelepes by hem-self &raisedpoint; asondry were neure
Namore þan myn hande may meue with-outen fyngeres
¶ And as my fust is ful honde &raisedpoint; yfolde togideres
So is þe fader a ful god &raisedpoint; formeour and shepper
Tu fabricator omnium &c
And al þe myȝte myd hym is in makyng of þynges
¶ The fyngres fourrmen a ful hande &raisedpoint; to purtreye or peynten
Keruynge and compassynge &raisedpoint; as crafte of þe fyngres
Riȝt so is þe sone &raisedpoint; þe science of þe fader
And ful god as is þe fader &raisedpoint; no febler ne no better
Þe paume is purelich þe hande &raisedpoint; hath power bi hym-selue
Otherwyse þan þe wrythen fuste or werkmanschip of fyngres
For þe paume hath powere to put oute alle þe ioyntes
lg.marginalia: - C17.178. This line in C combines KD17.179 and 181.
lg.l: And to vnfolde þe folden fuste atte þe fyngres wille
So is þe holygoste god &raisedpoint; nother gretter ne lasse
Þan is þe sire and þe sone &raisedpoint; & in þe same myȝte
And alle ar þei but o god &raisedpoint; as is myn hande & my fyngres
Vnfolden or folden &raisedpoint; my fuste & myn paume
Al is but an hande &raisedpoint; how-so I torne it
Ac who is herte in þe hande &raisedpoint; euene in þe myddes
He may receyue riȝt nouȝte &raisedpoint; resoun it sheweth
For þe fyngres þat folde shulde &raisedpoint; and þe fuste make
For peyne of þe paume &punctuselevatus; powere hem failleth
To clicche or to clawe &raisedpoint; to clyppe or to holde
¶ Were þe myddel of myn honde &raisedpoint; ymaymed or ypersshed
I shulde receyue riȝte nouȝte &raisedpoint; of þat I reche myȝte
Ac þough my thombe & my fyngres bothe were to-shullen
And þe myddel of myn hande &raisedpoint; with-oute male-ese
In many kynnes maneres &raisedpoint; I myȝte my-self helpe
Bothe meue and amende &raisedpoint; þough alle my fyngres oke
Bi þis skil me þynke &raisedpoint; I se an euydence
Þat who-so synneth in þe seynt spirit assoilled worth he neure
Noither here ne elles-where &raisedpoint; as I herde telle
Qui peccat in spiritu sancto &c
For he prikketh god as in þe paume &raisedpoint; þat peccat in spiritu sancto
For god þe fader is as a fuste þe sone is as a fynger
The holy goste of heuene &raisedpoint; is as it were þe pawme
So who-so synneth in seynt spirit &raisedpoint; it semeth þat he greueth
God þat he grypeth with &raisedpoint; and wolde his grace quenche

lg.marginalia:
The Trinytie is ly-
koned to a torche
or a taporC2.17.204
# Aliam discripcionem trinitatis ad similitudinem Candeli
lg.l: ¶ And to a torche or a tapre &raisedpoint; þe trinitee is lykned
As wex and a weke &raisedpoint; were twyned togideres
And þanne a fyre flaumende &raisedpoint; forth oute of bothe
And as wex and weyke &raisedpoint; and hote fyre togyderes
Fostren forth a flaumbe &raisedpoint; and a feyre leye
So doth þe sire & þe sone &raisedpoint; & also spiritus sanctus
lg.marginalia: The holy gost shew so by simulitudsCr3.17.210
lg.l: Fostren forth amonges folke &raisedpoint; loue & bileue
Þat alkyn crystene clenseth of synnes
And as þow seest some-tyme sodeynliche a torche
The blase þere-of yblowe out &raisedpoint; ȝet brenneth þe weyke
With-oute leye or liȝte &raisedpoint; þat þe macche brenneth
So is þe holygost god &raisedpoint; & grace with-oute mercy
To alle vnkynde creatures &raisedpoint; þat coueite to destruye
Lele loue other lyf &raisedpoint; þat owre lorde shapte
¶ And as glowande gledes &raisedpoint; gladieth nouȝte þis werkmen
Þat worchen & waken in wyntres niȝtes
As doth a kex or a candel &raisedpoint; þat cauȝte hath fyre & blaseth
Namore doth sire ne sone &raisedpoint; ne seynt spirit togyderes
Graunteth no grace &raisedpoint; ne forȝifnesse of synnes
Til þe holi goste gynne &raisedpoint; to glowe and to blase
So þat þe holygoste &raisedpoint; gloweth but as a glede
Tyl þat lele loue &raisedpoint; ligge on hym & blowe
And þanne flaumbeth he as fyre on fader & on filius
And melteth her myȝte in-to mercy &raisedpoint; as men may se in wyntre
Ysekeles in eueses þorw hete of þe sonne
Melteth in a mynut-while &raisedpoint; to myst & to watre
So grace of þe holygoste &raisedpoint; þe grete myȝte of þe trinite
Melteth in-to mercy &raisedpoint; to mercyable & to non other
And as wex with-outen more &raisedpoint; on a warme glede
Wil brennen & blasen &raisedpoint; be þei to-gyderes
And solacen hem þat may se &raisedpoint; þat sitten in derkenesse
So wole þe fader forȝif folke of mylde hertes
Þat reufulliche repenten &raisedpoint; & restitucioun make
In as moche as þei mowen &raisedpoint; amenden & payen
lg.marginalia: [vertical script, different hand, the length of page.]S17.236
lg.l: And if it suffice nouȝte for assetz &raisedpoint; þat in suche a wille deyeth
Mercy for his mekenesse &raisedpoint; wil make good þe remenaunte
And as þe weyke and fyre &raisedpoint; wil make a warme flaumbe
For to myrthe men with &raisedpoint; þat in merke sitten
So wil cryst of his curteisye &raisedpoint; and men crye hym mercy
Bothe forȝiue & forȝete &raisedpoint; & ȝet bidde for vs
To þe fader of heuene &raisedpoint; forȝyuenesse to haue
¶ Ac hew fyre at a flynte &raisedpoint; fowre hundreth wyntre
Bot þow haue towe to take it with &raisedpoint; tondre or broches
Al þi laboure is loste &raisedpoint; and al þi longe trauaille
For may no fyre flaumbe make &raisedpoint; faille it his kynde
So is þe holy gost god &raisedpoint; & grace with-outen mercy
To alle vnkynde creatures &raisedpoint; cryst hym-self witnesseth
Amen dico vobis nescio vos &c &raisedpoint;
¶ Be vnkynde to þin euene-cristene &raisedpoint; and al þat þow canst bidden
Delen & do penaunce &raisedpoint; day & nyȝte euere
And purchace al þe pardoun of Pampiloun & Rome
And indulgences ynowe &raisedpoint; & be ingratus to þi kynde
Þe holy goste hereth þe nouȝt &raisedpoint; ne helpe may þe by resoun
For vnkyndenesse quencheth hym &raisedpoint; þat he can nouȝte shyne
Ne brenne ne blase clere &raisedpoint; for blowynge of vnkyndenesse
Poule þe apostle preueth wher I lye
Si linguis hominum loquar &c
For-thy beth war ȝe wyse men &raisedpoint; þat with þe wo[r]lde deleth
That riche ben & resoun knoweth &raisedpoint; reuleth wel ȝowre soule
Beth nouȝte vnkynde I conseille ȝow &raisedpoint; to ȝowre euene-crystene
For many of ȝow riche men &raisedpoint; bi my soule men telleth
Ȝe brenne but ȝe blaseth nouȝte &raisedpoint; þat is a blynde bekene
Non omnis qui dicit domine domine intrabit &c &raisedpoint;
¶ Diues deyed dampned &raisedpoint; for his vnkyndenesse
Of his mete & his moneye to men that it neded
Vch a riche I rede &raisedpoint; rewarde at hym take
And gyueth ȝowre good to þat god &raisedpoint; þat grace of ariseth
For þat ben vnkynde to his &raisedpoint; hope I none other
But þei dwelle þere diues is &raisedpoint; dayes with-outen ende
Þus is vnkyndenesse þe contrarie &raisedpoint; þat quencheth as it were
Þe grace of þe holy gooste &raisedpoint; goddes owne kynde
For þat kynde dothe vnkynde fordoth &raisedpoint; as þese cursed theues
Vnkynde cristene men &raisedpoint; for coueityse & enuye
Sleeth a man for his moebles &raisedpoint; wyth mouth or wyth handes
For þat þe holygoste hath to kepe &raisedpoint; þo harlotes destroyeth
Þe which is lyf & loue &raisedpoint; þe leye of mannes bodye
For euery manere good man &raisedpoint; may be likned to a torche
lg.marginalia: A good man is like a torche or a tapoure.Cr3.17.279
lg.l: Or elles to a tapre &raisedpoint; to reuerence þe Trinitee
And who morthereth a good man &raisedpoint; me thynketh by myn Inwyt
He fordoth þe leuest lyȝte &raisedpoint; þat owre lorde loueth
¶ Ac ȝut in many mo maneres &raisedpoint; men offenden þe holygoste
Ac þis is þe worste wyse &raisedpoint; þat any wiȝte myȝte
Synnen aȝein þe seynt spirit &raisedpoint; assenten to destruye
For coueityse of any kynnes þinge &raisedpoint; þat cryst dere bouȝte
How myȝte he axe mercy &raisedpoint; or any mercy hym helpe
Þat wykkedlich & willefullich &raisedpoint; wolde mercy anynte
Innocence is nexte god &raisedpoint; & nyȝte and day it crieth
Veniaunce veniaunce &raisedpoint; forȝiue be it neuere
That shent vs & shadde owre blode &raisedpoint; forshapte vs as it were
Vindica sanguinem iustorum
Thus veniaunce veniaunce verrey charite asketh
And sith holicherche & charite chargeth þis so sore
Leue I neure that owre lorde wil loue þat charite lakketh
Ne haue pite for any preyere &raisedpoint; þere þat he pleyneth

lg.marginalia: # questionem de peccato contra spiritum sanctumM17.300
lg.l: ¶ I pose I hadde synned so &raisedpoint; and shulde now deye
And now am sory þat so &raisedpoint; þe seint spirit agulte
Confesse me & crye his grace &raisedpoint; god þat al made
And myldliche his mercy axe &raisedpoint; myȝte I nouȝte be saued
¶ Ȝus seide þe Samaritan &raisedpoint; so wel þow myȝte repente
Þat riȝtwisnesse þorw repentance &raisedpoint; to reuthe myȝte torne
Ac it is but selden yseye &raisedpoint; þere sothenesse bereth witnesse
Any creature þat is coupable &raisedpoint; afor a kynges iustice
Be raunsoned for his repentaunce &raisedpoint; þere alle resoun hym dampneth
For þere þat partye pursueth &raisedpoint; þe pele is so huge
Þat þe kynge may do no mercy &raisedpoint; til bothe men acorde
And eyther haue equite &raisedpoint; as holywrit telleth

marginalia.note: M17.312, very faint mark, not unlike a squat arabic numeral 2

lg.l: Numquam dimittitur peccatum &c
Þus it fareth bi suche folke &raisedpoint; þat falsely al her lyues
Euel lyuen & leten nouȝte &raisedpoint; til lyf hem forsake
Good hope þat helpe shulde &raisedpoint; to wanhope torneth
Nouȝt of þe nounpowere of god &raisedpoint; þat he ne is myȝtful
To amende al þat amys is &raisedpoint; and his mercy grettere
Þan alle owre wykked werkes &raisedpoint; as holiwrit telleth
Misericordia eius super omnia opera eius
Ac ar his riȝtwisnesse to reuthe tourne &raisedpoint; some restitucioun bihoueth
His sorwe is satisfaccioun for hym þat may nouȝte paye

lg.marginalia: Thre thinges dryue a man out of hys house .Cr3.17.319

marginalia.foreign:
Fumus Mulier & stillicidia
Expellunt hominem a domo proverbia......

lg.l: ¶ Thre þinges þere ben &raisedpoint; þat doth a man by strengthe
Forto fleen his owne hous &raisedpoint; as holy wryt sheweth
Þat one is a wikked wyf &raisedpoint; þat wil nouȝt be chasted
Her fiere fleeth fro hyr &raisedpoint; for fere of her tonge
And if his hous be vnhiled &raisedpoint; and reyne on his bedde
He seketh and seketh &raisedpoint; til he slepe drye
And whan smoke & smolder smyt in his syȝte
It doth hym worse þan his wyf &raisedpoint; or wete to slepe
For smoke & smolder &raisedpoint; smyteth his eyen
Til he be blere-nyed or blynde &raisedpoint; and hors in þe throte
Cougheth and curseth &raisedpoint; þat cryst gyf hem sorwe
Þat sholde brynge in better wode &raisedpoint; or blowe it til it brende
¶ Þise thre þat I telle of &raisedpoint; ben þus to vnderstonde
The wyf is owre wikked flesshe &raisedpoint; þat wil nouȝt be chasted
For kynde cleueth on hym euere &raisedpoint; to contrarie þe soule
And þowgh it falle it fynt skiles &raisedpoint; þe frelete it made
And þat is liȝtly forȝeuen &raisedpoint; and forȝeten bothe
To man þat mercy asketh &raisedpoint; and amende þenketh
¶ The reyne þat reyneth &raisedpoint; þere we reste sholde
Ben sikenesses & sorwes &raisedpoint; þat we suffren oft
As Powle þe Apostle &raisedpoint; to þe peple tauȝte
Virtus in infirmitate perficitur &c &raisedpoint;
And þowgh þat men make &punctuselevatus; moche deol in her angre
And inpacient in here penaunce &raisedpoint; pure resoun knoweth
lg.marginalia: # pro hijs qui male possunt patiM17.346
lg.l: Þat þei han cause to contrarie &raisedpoint; by kynde of her sykenesse
And liȝtlich owre lorde &raisedpoint; at her lyues ende
Hath mercy on suche men &raisedpoint; þat so yuel may suffre
¶ Ac þe smoke and þe smolder þat smyt in owre eyghen
Þat is coueityse and vnkyndenesse &raisedpoint; þat quencheth goddes mercy
For vnkyndenesse is þe contrarie &raisedpoint; of alkynnes resoun
For þere nys syke ne sori &raisedpoint; ne non so moche wrecche
Þat he ne may louye & hym lyke &raisedpoint; and lene of his herte
Goed wille & good worde &punctuselevatus; bothe wisshen and willen
Alle manere men &raisedpoint; mercy & forȝifnesse
And louye hem liche hym-self &raisedpoint; and his lyf amende
I may no lenger lette quod he &raisedpoint; and lyarde he pryked
And went away as wynde &raisedpoint; and þere-with I awaked
Wolleward and wete-shoed &raisedpoint; went I forth after
As a reccheles renke &raisedpoint; þat of no wo reccheth
And ȝede forth lyke a lorel &raisedpoint; al my lyf-tyme
Tyl I wex wery of þe worlde &raisedpoint; and wylned eft to slepe
And lened me to a lenten &raisedpoint; and longe tyme I slepte
And of crystes passioun and penaunce &raisedpoint; þe peple þat of-rauȝte
Rested me þere and rutte faste &raisedpoint; tyl ramis palmarum
Of gerlis & of gloria laus &raisedpoint; gretly me dremed
And how osanna by orgonye &raisedpoint; olde folke songen
¶ One semblable to þe samaritan &raisedpoint; & some-del to Piers þe plowman
Barfote on an asse bakke &raisedpoint; botelees cam pryke
Wyth-oute spores other spere &raisedpoint; spakliche he loked
As is þe kynde of a knyȝte &raisedpoint; þat cometh to be dubbed
To geten hem gylte spores &raisedpoint; or galoches ycouped
¶ Þanne was faith in a fenestre &raisedpoint; and cryde a fili dauid
As doth an Heraude of armes &raisedpoint; whan aunturos cometh to iustes
Olde iuwes of ierusalem &raisedpoint; for ioye þei songen
Benedictus qui venit in nomine domini
¶ Þanne I frayned at faith &raisedpoint; what al þat fare be-ment
And who sholde iouste in Iherusalem &raisedpoint; Ihesus he seyde
And fecche þat þe fende claymeth &raisedpoint; Piers fruit þe plowman
Is Piers in þis place quod I &raisedpoint; & he preynte on me
Þis Ihesus of his gentrice &raisedpoint; wole iuste in piers armes
In his helme & in his haberioun &raisedpoint; humana natura
Þat cryst be nouȝt biknowe here &raisedpoint; for consumatus deus
lg.marginalia: memorandumO17.26. A rubricated dot precedes "memorandum," but at such a distance from it that it does not seem to punctuate it.
lg.l: In Piers paltok þe plowman &raisedpoint; þis priker shal ryde
For no dynte shal hym dere &raisedpoint; as in deitate patris
Who shal iuste with Ihesus quod I iuwes or scribes
¶ Nay quod he þe foule fende &raisedpoint; and fals dome & deth
Deth seith he shal fordo &raisedpoint; and adown brynge
Al þat lyueth or loketh &raisedpoint; in londe or in watere
Lyf seyth þat he likthe &raisedpoint; and leyth his lif to wedde
Þat for al þat deth can do &raisedpoint; with-in þre dayes
To walke and fecche fro þe fende &raisedpoint; piers fruite þe plowman
And legge it þere hym lyketh &raisedpoint; and lucifer bynde
And forbete and adown brynge bale deth for euere
O mors ero mors tua
¶ Þanne cam pilatus with moche peple &raisedpoint; sedens pro tribunali
To se how doughtilich deth sholde do &raisedpoint; & deme her botheres riȝte
Þe iuwes and þe iustice &raisedpoint; aȝeine Ihesu þei were
And al her courte on hym cryde &raisedpoint; crucifige sharpe
Tho put hym forth a piloure &raisedpoint; bifor pilat & seyde
This ihesus of owre iewes temple &raisedpoint; iaped & dispised
To fordone it on o day &raisedpoint; and in thre dayes after
Edefye it eft newe &raisedpoint; here he stant þat seyde it
And ȝit maken it as moche &raisedpoint; in al manere poyntes
Bothe as longe and as large &raisedpoint; bi loft & by grounde
¶ Cru[ci]fige quod a cacchepolle &raisedpoint; I warante hym a wicche
Tolle tolle quod an other &raisedpoint; and toke o kene þornes
And bigan of kene thorne &raisedpoint; a gerelande to make
And sette it sore on his hed &raisedpoint; and seyde in envye
Aue rabby quod þat Ribaude &raisedpoint; and þrew redes at hym
Nailled hym with þre nailles &raisedpoint; naked on þe Rode
And poysoun on a pole &raisedpoint; þei put vp to his lippes
And bede hym drynke his deth yuel &raisedpoint; his dayes were ydone
And ȝif þat þow sotil be &raisedpoint; help now þi-seluen
If þow be cryst & kynges sone &raisedpoint; come downe of þe Rode
Þanne shul we leue þat lyf þe loueth &raisedpoint; and wil nouȝt lete þe deye
¶ Consummatum est quod cryst &raisedpoint; & comsed forto swowe
Pitousliche and pale &raisedpoint; as a prisoun þat deyeth
Þe lorde of lyf & of liȝte &raisedpoint; þo leyed his eyen togideres
Þe daye for drede with-drowe &raisedpoint; and derke bicam þe sonne
Þe wal wagged and clef and al þe worlde quaued
Ded men for that dyne &raisedpoint; come out of depe graues
And tolde whi þat tempest &raisedpoint; so longe tyme dured
For a bitter bataille &raisedpoint; þe ded bodye sayde
Lyf and deth in þis derknesse &raisedpoint; her one fordoth her other
Shal no wiȝte wite witterly who shal haue þe maystrye
Er sondey aboute sonne rysynge &raisedpoint; & sank with þat til erthe
Some seyde þat he was goddes sone &raisedpoint; þat so faire deyde
Vere filius dei erat iste &raisedpoint; &c
And somme saide he was a wicche &raisedpoint; good is þat we assaye
Where he be ded or nouȝte ded &raisedpoint; doun er he be taken
¶ Two theues also &raisedpoint; tholed deth þat tyme
Vppon a crosse bisydes cryst &raisedpoint; so was þe comune lawe
A cacchepole cam forth &raisedpoint; and craked bothe her legges
And her armes after &raisedpoint; of eyther of þo theues
Ac was no boy so bolde &raisedpoint; goddes body to touche
For he was knyȝte & kynges sone &raisedpoint; kynde forȝaf þat tyme
Þat non harlot were so hardy &raisedpoint; to leyne hande vppon hym
¶ Ac þere cam forth a knyȝte &raisedpoint; with a kene spere ygrounde
lg.marginalia: He citeth a lye out of the Legendandi[?]Cr3.18.82
lg.l: Hiȝte longeus as þe lettre telleth &raisedpoint; and longe had lore his siȝte
Bifor pilat & other peple &raisedpoint; in þe place he houed
Maugre his many tethe &raisedpoint; he was made þat tyme
To take þe spere in his honde &raisedpoint; & iusten with ihesus
For alle þei were vnhardy &raisedpoint; þat houed on hors or stode
To touche hym or to taste hym &raisedpoint; or take hym down of Rode
But þis blynde bacheler þanne &raisedpoint; bar hym þorugh þe herte
Þe blode spronge down by þe spere &raisedpoint; & vnspered þe kniȝtes eyen
Þanne fel þe knyȝte vpon knees &raisedpoint; and cryed hym mercy
Aȝeyne my wille it was lorde &raisedpoint; to wownde ȝow so sore
He seighed & sayde &raisedpoint; sore it me athynketh
For þe dede þat I haue done &raisedpoint; I do me in ȝowre grace
Haue on me reuth riȝtful ihesu &raisedpoint; & riȝt with þat he wept
¶ Thanne gan faith felly &raisedpoint; þe fals iuwes dispise
Called hem caytyues &raisedpoint; acursed for euere
For þis foule vyleynye &raisedpoint; veniaunce to ȝow alle
To do þe blynde bete hym ybounde &raisedpoint; it was a boyes conseille
Cursed caytyue &raisedpoint; kniȝthod was it neuere
To mysdo a ded body &raisedpoint; by day or by nyȝte
Þe gree ȝit hath he geten &raisedpoint; for al his grete wounde
¶ For ȝowre champioun chiualer chief knyȝt of ȝow alle
Ȝelt hym recreaunt rennyng &raisedpoint; riȝt at ihesus wille
For be þis derkenesse ydo &raisedpoint; his deth worth avenged
And ȝe lordeynes han ylost &raisedpoint; for lyf shal haue þe maistrye
And ȝowre Fraunchise þat fre was &raisedpoint; fallen is in thraldome
And ȝe cherles & ȝowre children &raisedpoint; chieue shal ȝe neure
Ne haue lordship in londe &raisedpoint; ne no londe tylye
But al bareyne be &raisedpoint; & vsurye vsen
Which is lyf þat owre lorde &raisedpoint; in alle lawes acurseth
Now ȝowre good dayes ar done &raisedpoint; as Danyel prophecyed
Whan cryst cam &raisedpoint; her kyngdom &raisedpoint; þe croune shulde [cesse]
Cum veniat sanctus sanctorum cessabit vnxio vestra
¶ What for fere of þis ferly &raisedpoint; & of þe fals iuwes
lg.marginalia: to dessenditF14.115, end of gloss cropped
lg.l: I drowe me in þat derkenesse &raisedpoint; to decendit ad inferna
And þere I sawe sothely &raisedpoint; secundum scripturas
Out of þe west coste &raisedpoint; a wenche as me thouȝte
Cam walkynge in þe wey &raisedpoint; to helle-ward she loked
Mercy hiȝt þat mayde &raisedpoint; a meke þynge with-alle
A ful benygne buirde &raisedpoint; and boxome of speche
¶ Her suster as it semed &raisedpoint; cam softly walkyng
Euene out of þe est &raisedpoint; and westward she loked
A ful comely creature &raisedpoint; treuth she hiȝte
For þe vertue þat hir folwed &raisedpoint; aferd was she neuere
¶ Whan þis maydenes mette &raisedpoint; mercy and treuth
Eyther axed other &raisedpoint; of þis grete wonder
Of þe dyne & of þe derknesse &raisedpoint; and how þe daye rowed
And which a liȝte and a leme &raisedpoint; lay befor helle
Ich haue ferly of þis fare &raisedpoint; in feith seyde treuth
And am wendyng to wyte &raisedpoint; what þis wonder meneth
¶ Haue no merueille quod mercy &raisedpoint; myrthe it bytokneth
A mayden þat hatte marye &raisedpoint; and moder with-out felyng
Of any kynnes creature &raisedpoint; conceyued þorw speche
And grace of þe holygoste &raisedpoint; wex grete with childe
With-outen wem &raisedpoint; in-to þis worlde she brouȝt hym
And þat my tale be trewe &raisedpoint; I take god to witnesse
Sith þis barn was bore &raisedpoint; ben xxx wynter passed
Which deyde & deth þoled &raisedpoint; þis day aboute mydday
And þat is cause of þis clips &raisedpoint; þat closeth now þe sonne
In menynge þat man shal &raisedpoint; fro merkenesse be drawe
Þe while þis liȝte & þis leme &raisedpoint; shal Lucyfer ablende
For patriarkes & prophetes &raisedpoint; han preched her-of often
Þat man shal man saue &raisedpoint; þorw a maydenes helpe
And þat was tynt þorw tre &raisedpoint; tree shal it wynne
And þat deth doun brouȝte &raisedpoint; deth shal releue
¶ Þat þow tellest quod treuth &raisedpoint; is but a tale of waltrot
For Adam & Eue &raisedpoint; & abraham with other
Patriarkes & prophetes &raisedpoint; þat in peyne liggen
Leue þow neuere þat ȝone liȝte &raisedpoint; hem alofte brynge
Ne haue hem out of helle &raisedpoint; helde þi tonge mercy
It is but a trufle þat þow tellest &raisedpoint; I treuth wote þe sothe
For þat is ones in helle &raisedpoint; out cometh it neuere
Iob þe prophete patriarke &raisedpoint; reproueth þi sawes
Quia in inferno nulla est redempcio
¶ Þanne mercy ful myldly &raisedpoint; mouthed þise wordes
Thorw experience quod she &raisedpoint; I hope þei shal be saued
For venym fordoth venym &raisedpoint; & þat I proue by resoun
For of alle venymes &raisedpoint; foulest is þe scorpioun
May no medcyne helpe &raisedpoint; þe place þere he styngeth
Tyl he be ded & do þer-to &raisedpoint; þe yuel he destroyeth
Þe fyrst venymouste &raisedpoint; þorw venym of hym-self
So shal þis deth fordo &raisedpoint; I dar my lyf legge
Al þat deth dyd furste &raisedpoint; þorw þe deuelles entysynge
And riȝt as þorw gyle &raisedpoint; man was bigyled
lg.marginalia: sighteO18.165. A caret/punctus beside it and a solidus punctus above seeþ indicate that substitution was intended. O alone has seeþ. Most B manuscripts have sleighte.
lg.l: So shal grace þat bigan &raisedpoint; make a good sleighte
Ars vt artem falleret
¶ Now suffre we seyde treuth &raisedpoint; I se as me þinketh
Out of þe nippe of þe north &raisedpoint; nouȝt ful fer hennes
Riȝtwisnesse come rennynge &raisedpoint; reste we þe while
For he wote more þan we &raisedpoint; he was er we bothe
¶ That is soth seyde mercy &raisedpoint; and I se here bi southe
Where pees cometh playinge &raisedpoint; in pacience yclothed
Loue hath coueyted hir longe &raisedpoint; leue I none other
But he sent hir some lettre what þis liȝte bymeneth
Þat ouer-houeth helle þus &raisedpoint; [he] vs shal telle
¶ Whan pees in pacience yclothed &raisedpoint; approched nere hem tweyne
Riȝtwisnesse hir reuerenced &raisedpoint; for her riche clothyng
And preyed pees to telle hir &raisedpoint; to what place she wolde
And in her gay garnementz &raisedpoint; whom she grete þouȝte
¶ My wille is to wende quod she &raisedpoint; and welcome hem alle
Þat many day myȝte I nouȝte se &raisedpoint; for merkenesse of synne
Adam & Eue & other moo in helle &raisedpoint;
Moyses & many mo &raisedpoint; mercy shal haue
And I shal daunce þer-to &raisedpoint; do þow so sustre
For ihesus iusted wel &raisedpoint; ioye bygynneth dawe
Ad vesperum demorabitur fletus &raisedpoint; & ad matutinum leticia &raisedpoint;
Loue þat is my lemman &raisedpoint; suche lettres me sente
That mercy my sustre & I &raisedpoint; mankynde shulde saue
And þat god hath forgyuen &raisedpoint; & graunted me pees & mercy
To be mannes meynpernoure &raisedpoint; for euere-more after
Lo here þe patent quod pees &raisedpoint; in pace in idipsum
And þat þis dede shal dure &raisedpoint; dormiam & requiescam
¶ What rauestow quod riȝtwisnesse or þow art riȝt dronke
Leuestow þat ȝonde liȝte &raisedpoint; vnlouke myȝte helle
And saue mannes soule &raisedpoint; sustre wene it neure
At þe bygynnynge god &raisedpoint; gaf þe dome hym-selue
Þat Adam & Eue &raisedpoint; and alle þat hem suwed
Shulde deye doune-riȝte &raisedpoint; and dwelle in pyne after
If þat þei touched a tre &raisedpoint; and þe fruite eten
Adam afterward &raisedpoint; aȝeines his defence
Frette of þat fruit &raisedpoint; & forsoke as it were
Þe loue of owre lorde &raisedpoint; and his lore bothe
And folwed þat þe fende tauȝte &raisedpoint; & his felawes wille
Aȝeines resoun I riȝtwisnesse &raisedpoint; recorde þus with treuth
Þat her peyne be perpetuel &raisedpoint; & no preyere hem helpe
For-þi late hem chewe as þei chose &raisedpoint; & chyde we nouȝt sustres
For it is botelees bale &raisedpoint; þe bite þat þei eten
¶ And shal preue quod pees &raisedpoint; her peyne mote haue ende
And wo in-to wel &raisedpoint; mowe wende atte laste
For had þei wist of no wo &raisedpoint; wel had þei nouȝte knowen
lg.marginalia: Contraries are knowen bi the contraries .Cr3.18.206
lg.l: For no wiȝte wote what wel is &raisedpoint; þat neuere wo suffred
Ne what is hote hunger &raisedpoint; þat had neuere defaute
If no nyȝte ne were &raisedpoint; no man as I leue
Shulde wite witterly &raisedpoint; what day is to mene
¶ Shulde neuere riȝte riche man &raisedpoint; þat lyueth &raisedpoint; in reste & ese
Wyte what wo is &raisedpoint; ne were þe deth of kynde
So god þat bygan al &raisedpoint; of his good wille
Bycam man of a mayde &raisedpoint; mankynde to saue
And suffred to be solde &raisedpoint; to see þe sorwe of deyinge
The which vnknitteth al kare &raisedpoint; & comsynge is of reste
For til modicum mete with vs &raisedpoint; I may it wel avowe
Wote no wiȝte as I wene &raisedpoint; what is ynough to mene
¶ For-þi god of his goodnesse &raisedpoint; þe fyrste gome Adam
Sette hym in solace &raisedpoint; & in souereigne myrthe
And sith he suffred hym synne &raisedpoint; sorwe to fele
To wite what wel was &raisedpoint; kyndelich to knowe it
And after god auntred hym-self &raisedpoint; and toke Adames kynde
To wyte what he hath suffred &raisedpoint; in þre sondri places
Bothe in heuene & in erthe &raisedpoint; & now til helle he þynketh
To wite what al wo is &raisedpoint; þat wote of al ioye
¶ So it shal fare bi þis folke &raisedpoint; her foly & her synne
Shal lere hem what langour is &raisedpoint; & lisse with-outen ende
Wote no wighte what werre is &raisedpoint; þere þat pees regneth
Ne what is witterly wel &raisedpoint; til weyllowey hym teche
¶ Thanne was þere a wiȝte &raisedpoint; with two brode eyen
Boke hiȝte þat beupere &raisedpoint; a bolde man of speche
By godes body quod þis boke &raisedpoint; I wil bere witnesse
Þat þo þis barne was ybore &raisedpoint; þere blased a sterre
That alle þe wyse of þis worlde &raisedpoint; in o witte acordeden
That such a barne was borne &raisedpoint; in bethleem Citee
Þat mannes soule sholde saue &raisedpoint; & synne destroye
And alle þe elementz quod þe boke &raisedpoint; her-of bereth witnesse
lg.marginalia: heven or elemenF14.239, late-15th or early-16th C. scribe, end of third word cropped
lg.l: Þat he was god þat al wrouȝte &raisedpoint; þe walkene firste shewed
Þo that weren in heuene &raisedpoint; token stella comata
And tendeden hir as a torche &raisedpoint; to reuerence his birthe
Þe lyȝte folwed þe lorde &raisedpoint; in-to þe lowe erthe
Þat water witnessed þat he was god &raisedpoint; for he went on it
Peter þe apostel &raisedpoint; parceyued his gate
And as he went on þe water &raisedpoint; wel hym knewe & seyde
Iube me venire ad te super aquas
And lo how þe sonne gan louke &raisedpoint; her liȝte in her-self
Whan she seye hym suffre &raisedpoint; þat sonne & se made
The erthe for heuynesse &raisedpoint; that he wolde suffre
Quaked as quykke þinge &raisedpoint; and al biquasht þe roche
Lo helle miȝte nouȝte holde &raisedpoint; but opened þo god þoled
And lete oute symondes sones &raisedpoint; to seen hym hange on Rode
And now shal lucifer leue it thowgh hym loth þinke
For gygas þe geaunt &raisedpoint; with a gynne engyned
To breke & to bete dounn &raisedpoint; þat ben aȝeines ihesus
And I boke wil be brent &raisedpoint; but ihesus rise to lyue
In alle myȝtes of man &raisedpoint; & his moder gladye
And conforte al his kynne &raisedpoint; & out of care brynge
And al þe iuwen ioye &raisedpoint; vnioignen & vnlouken
And but þei reuerencen his Rode &raisedpoint; & his resurexioun
And bileue on a newe lawe &raisedpoint; be lost lyf & soule
¶ Suffre we seide treuth &raisedpoint; I here & se bothe
How a spirit speketh to helle &raisedpoint; & bit vnspere þe ȝatis
Attollite portas &c
A voice loude in þat liȝte to lucifer cryeth
Prynces of þis place &raisedpoint; vnpynneth & vnlouketh
For here cometh with croune &raisedpoint; þat kynge is of glorie
Thanne syked sathan &raisedpoint; & seyde to hem alle
Suche a lyȝte aȝeines owre leue &raisedpoint; Lazar it fette
Care & combraunce &raisedpoint; is comen to vs alle
If þis kynge come in &raisedpoint; mankynde wil he fecche
And lede it þer hym lyketh &raisedpoint; & lyȝtlych me bynde
Patriarkes & prophetes &raisedpoint; han parled her-of longe
Þat such a lorde & a lyȝte &raisedpoint; shulde lede hem alle hennes
¶ Lysteneth quod Lucifer &raisedpoint; for I þis lorde knowe
Bothe þis lorde & þis liȝte &raisedpoint; is longe ago I knewe hym
May no deth hym dere &raisedpoint; ne no deueles queyntise
And where he wil is his waye &raisedpoint; ac war hym of þe periles
If he reue me my riȝte &raisedpoint; he robbeth me by maistrye
For by riȝt & bi resoun &raisedpoint; þo renkes þat ben here
Bodye & soule ben myne &raisedpoint; bothe gode & ille
For hym-self seyde þat sire is of heuene
Ȝif Adam ete þe apple &raisedpoint; alle shulde deye
And dwelle with vs deueles &raisedpoint; þis þretynge he made
And he þat sothenesse is seyde þise wordes
And sitthen I seised &raisedpoint; seuene hundreth wyntre
I leue þat lawe nil nauȝte &raisedpoint; lete hym þe leest
¶ That is sothe seyde Sathan &raisedpoint; but I me sore drede
For þow gete hem with gyle &raisedpoint; & his gardyne breke
And in semblaunce of a serpent &raisedpoint; sat on þe appeltre
And eggedest hem to ete &raisedpoint; Eue by hir-selue
And toldest hir a tale &raisedpoint; of tresoun were þe wordes
And so þow haddest hem oute & hider atte laste
It is nouȝte graythely geten &raisedpoint; þere gyle is þe Rote
For god wil nouȝt be bigiled &raisedpoint; quod Gobelyn ne bi-iaped
We haue no trewe title to hem &raisedpoint; for þorwgh tresoun were þei dampned
Certes I drede me quod þe deuel &raisedpoint; leste treuth wil hem fecche
¶ Þis þretty wynter as I wene &raisedpoint; hath he gone & preched
I haue assailled hym with synne &raisedpoint; & some-tyme yasked
Where he were god or goddes sone &raisedpoint; he gaf me shorte answere
And þus hath he trolled forth &raisedpoint; þis two & thretty wynter
And whan I seighe it was so &raisedpoint; slepyng I went
To warne pilates wyf &raisedpoint; what dones man was ihesus
For iuwes hateden hym &raisedpoint; and han done hym to deth
I wolde haue lengthed his lyf &raisedpoint; for I leued ȝif he deyede
That his soule wolde suffre &raisedpoint; no synne in his syȝte
For þe body whil it on bones ȝede &raisedpoint; aboute was euere
To saue men fram synne &raisedpoint; ȝif hem-self wolde
And now I se where a soule &raisedpoint; cometh hiderward &raisedpoint; seyllynge
With glorie & with grete liȝte &raisedpoint; god it is I wote wel
I rede we flee quod he &raisedpoint; faste alle hennes
For vs were better nouȝte be &raisedpoint; þan biden his syȝte
For þi lesynges Lucifer &raisedpoint; loste is al owre praye
Firste þorw þe we fellen &raisedpoint; fro heuene so heigh
For we leued þi lesynges &raisedpoint; ylore we haue Adam
And al owre lordeship I leue &raisedpoint; alonde & a water
Nunc princeps huius mundi eicietur foras
¶ Efte þe liȝte bad vnlouke &raisedpoint; & Lucifer answered
What lorde artow quod lucifer &raisedpoint; quis est iste
Rex glorie &raisedpoint; þe liȝte sone seide
And lorde of myȝte & of mayne &raisedpoint; & al manere vertues &raisedpoint; dominus virtutum
Dukes of þis dym place &raisedpoint; anon vndo þis ȝates
That cryst may come in &raisedpoint; þe kynges sone of heuene
And with þat breth helle brake &raisedpoint; with Beliales barres
For any wye or warde &raisedpoint; wide opene þe ȝatis
¶ Patriarkes & prophetes &raisedpoint; populus in tenebris
Songen seynt Iohanes songe &raisedpoint; ecce agnus dei
Lucyfer loke ne myȝte &raisedpoint; so lyȝte hym ableynte
And þo þat owre [lorde] loued &raisedpoint; in-to his liȝte he lauȝte
And seyde to sathan &raisedpoint; lo here my soule to amendes
For alle synneful soules &raisedpoint; to saue þo þat ben worthy
Myne þei be & of me &raisedpoint; I may þe bette hem clayme
Al-þough resoun recorde & riȝt of my-self
That if þei ete þe apple &raisedpoint; alle shulde deye
I bihyȝte hem nouȝt here &raisedpoint; helle for euere
For þe dede þat þei dede &raisedpoint; þi deceyte it made
With gyle þow hem gete &raisedpoint; agayne al resoun
For in my paleys paradys &raisedpoint; in persone of an addre
Falseliche þow fettest þere &raisedpoint; þynge þat I loued
¶ Thus ylyke a lusarde &raisedpoint; with a lady visage
Theuelich þow me robbedest &raisedpoint; þe olde lawe graunteth
Þat gylours be bigiled &raisedpoint; & þat is gode resoun
Dentem pro dente & oculum pro oculo
Ergo soule shal soule quyte &raisedpoint; & synne to synne wende
And al þat man hath mysdo &raisedpoint; I man wyl amende
Membre for membre &raisedpoint; bi þe olde lawe was amendes
And lyf for lyf also &raisedpoint; & by þat lawe I clayme it
Adam & al his issue &raisedpoint; at my wille her-after
And þat deth in hem fordid &raisedpoint; my deth shal releue
And bothe quykke & quyte &raisedpoint; þat queynte was þorw synne
And þat grace gyle destruye &raisedpoint; good feith it asketh
So leue it nouȝte lucifer aȝeine þe lawe I fecche hem
But bi riȝt & by resoun &raisedpoint; raunceoun here my lyges
Non veni soluere legem &raisedpoint; sed adimplere
Þow fettest myne in my place &raisedpoint; aȝeines al resoun
Falseliche & felounelich &raisedpoint; gode faith me it tauȝte
To recoure hem thorw raunceoun & bi no resoun elles
So þat with gyle þow gete &raisedpoint; þorw grace it is ywone
Þow Lucyfer in lyknesse &raisedpoint; of a luther addere
Getest by gyle &raisedpoint; þo that god loued
¶ And I in lyknesse of a leode &raisedpoint; þat lorde am of heuene
Graciouslich þi gyle haue quytte &raisedpoint; go gyle aȝeine gyle
And as Adam & alle &raisedpoint; þorw a tre deyden
Adam & alle þorwe a tree &raisedpoint; shal torne aȝeine to lyue
And gyle is bigyled &raisedpoint; & in his gyle fallen
Et cecidit in foueam quam fecit
Now bygynneth þi gyle &raisedpoint; ageyne þe to tourne
And my grace to growe &raisedpoint; ay gretter & wyder
Þe bitternesse þat þow hast browe &raisedpoint; brouke it þi-seluen
Þat art doctour of deth &raisedpoint; drynke þat þow madest
¶ For I þat am lorde of lyf &raisedpoint; loue is my drynke
And for þat drynke to-day &raisedpoint; I deyde vpon erthe
I fauȝte so me þrestes ȝet &raisedpoint; for mannes soule sake
May no drynke me moiste &raisedpoint; ne my thruste slake
Tyl þe vendage falle &raisedpoint; in þe vale of iosephath
Þat I drynke riȝte ripe must &raisedpoint; resureccio mortuorum
And þanne shal I come as a kynge &raisedpoint; crouned with angeles
And han out of helle &raisedpoint; alle mennes soules &raisedpoint;
¶ Fendes and fendekynes &raisedpoint; bifore me shulle stande
And be at my biddynge &raisedpoint; where-so-eure me lyketh
And to be merciable to man &raisedpoint; þanne my kynde it asketh
For we beth bretheren of blode &raisedpoint; but nouȝte in baptesme alle
Ac alle þat beth myne hole bretheren &raisedpoint; in blode & in baptesme
Shal nouȝte be dampned to þe deth &raisedpoint; þat is with-outen ende
Tibi soli peccaui &c &raisedpoint;
It is nouȝt vsed in erthe &raisedpoint; to hangen a feloun
Ofter þan ones &raisedpoint; þough he were a tretour
And ȝif þe Kynge of þat kyngedome &raisedpoint; come in þat tyme
There þe feloun thole sholde &raisedpoint; deth or otherwyse
Lawe wolde he ȝeue hym lyf &raisedpoint; if he loked on hym
¶ And I þat am kynge of kynges &raisedpoint; shal come suche a tyme
There dome to þe deth &raisedpoint; dampneth al wikked
And ȝif lawe wil I loke on hem &raisedpoint; it lithe in my grace
Whether þei deye or deye nouȝte &raisedpoint; for þat þei deden ille
Be it any þinge abouȝte &raisedpoint; þe boldenesse of her synnes
I may do mercy þorw riȝtwisnesse &raisedpoint; & alle my wordes trewe
And þough holiwrit wil þat I be wroke &raisedpoint; of hem þat deden ille
Nullum malum inpunitum &c
Thei shul be clensed clereliche &raisedpoint; & wasshen of her synnes
In my prisoun purgatorie &raisedpoint; til parce it hote
And my mercy shal be shewed &raisedpoint; to manye of my bretheren
For blode may suffre blode &raisedpoint; bothe hungry & akale
Ac blode may nouȝt se blode &raisedpoint; blede but hym rewe
Audiui archana verba que non licet homini loqui
Ac my riȝtwisnesse & riȝt shal reulen al helle
And mercy al mankynde &raisedpoint; bifor me in heuene
For I were an vnkynde Kynge &raisedpoint; but I my kynde holpe
And namelich at such a nede &raisedpoint; þer nedes helpe bihoueth
Non intres in iudicium cum seruo tuo
Þus bi lawe quod owre lorde &raisedpoint; lede I wil fro hennes
Þo þat me loued &raisedpoint; & leued in my comynge
And for þi lesynge lucifer &raisedpoint; þat þow lowe til Eue
Thow shalt abye it bittre &raisedpoint; & bonde hym with cheynes
Astaroth and al þe route &raisedpoint; hidden hem in hernes
They dorste nouȝte loke on owre lorde &raisedpoint; þe boldest of hem alle
But leten hym lede forth what hym lyked &raisedpoint; and lete what hym liste
¶ Many hundreth of angeles &raisedpoint; harpeden & songen
Culpat caro purgat caro &raisedpoint; regnat deus dei caro
¶ Thanne piped pees &raisedpoint; of poysye a note
lg.marginalia: ☞R18.418, properly belongs only to KD408α, possibly marking strange inflection "solitus".
lg.l: Clarior est solito post maxima nebula phebus &raisedpoint; post inimicitias &c &raisedpoint;
After sharpe shoures quod pees &raisedpoint; moste shene is þe sonne

marginalia.note: R18.422, italic hand, with a symbol resembling a modern script capital H above, noting that the rest of 18, all of 19, and the first part of 20 are missing

lg.l: Is no weder warmer &raisedpoint; þan after watery cloudes
Ne no loue leuere &raisedpoint; ne leuer frendes
Þan after werre & wo &raisedpoint; whan loue & pees be maistres
Was neuere werre in þis worlde &raisedpoint; ne wykkednesse so kene
Þat ne loue & hym luste to laughynge ne brouȝte
And pees þorw pacience &raisedpoint; alle perilles stopped
Trewes quod treuth &raisedpoint; þow tellest vs soth bi ihesus
Clippe we in couenaunt & vch of vs cusse other
And lete no peple quod pees &raisedpoint; perceyue þat we chydde
For inpossible is no þyng &raisedpoint; to hym þat is almyȝty
¶ Thow seist soth seyde ryȝtwisnesse &raisedpoint; & reuerentlich hir kyste
Pees & pees here &raisedpoint; per secula seculorum
Misericordia & veritas obuiauerunt sibi iusticia & pax osculate sunt
Treuth tromped þo & songe &raisedpoint; te deum laudamus
And thanne luted loue &raisedpoint; in a loude note
Ecce quam bonum & quam iocundum &raisedpoint; &c
¶ Tyl þe daye dawed &raisedpoint; þis damaiseles daunced
That men rongen to þe resurexioun &raisedpoint; & riȝt with þat I waked
And called kitte my wyf &raisedpoint; and kalote my douȝter
Ariseth & reuerenceth &raisedpoint; goddes ressurrexioun
And crepeth to þe the crosse on knees &raisedpoint; & kisseth it for a iuwel
For goddes blissed body &raisedpoint; it bar for owre bote
And it afereth þe fende &raisedpoint; for suche is þe myȝte
May no grysly gost &raisedpoint; glyde þere it shadweth
Thus I awaked & wrote &raisedpoint; what I had dremed
And diȝte me derely &raisedpoint; & dede me to cherche
To here holy þe masse &raisedpoint; & to be houseled after
In myddes of þe masse &raisedpoint; þo men ȝede to offrynge
I fel eftsones a-slepe &raisedpoint; & sodeynly me mette
That Pieres þe plowman &raisedpoint; was paynted al blody
And come in with a crosse &raisedpoint; bifor þe comune peple
And riȝte lyke in alle lymes &raisedpoint; to owre lorde ihesu
And þanne called I conscience &raisedpoint; to kenne me þe sothe
Is þis ihesus þe iuster quod I &raisedpoint; þat iuwes did to deth
Or it is Pieres þe plowman &raisedpoint; who paynted hym so rede
Quod conscience & kneled þo &raisedpoint; þise aren Pieres armes
His coloures & his cotearmure &raisedpoint; ac he þat cometh so blody
Is cryst with his crosse &raisedpoint; conqueroure of crystene
¶ Why calle ȝe hym cryst quod I &raisedpoint; sithenes iuwes calle hym ihesus
Patriarkes & prophetes &raisedpoint; prophecyed bifore
Þat alkyn creatures &raisedpoint; shulden knelen & bowen
Anon as men nempned &raisedpoint; þe name of god Ihesu
Ergo is no name &raisedpoint; to þe name of ihesus
Ne none so nedeful to nempne &raisedpoint; by nyȝte ne by daye
For alle derke deuelles &raisedpoint; aren adradde to heren it
And synful aren solaced &raisedpoint; & saued bi þat name
And ȝe callen hym cryst &raisedpoint; for what cause telleth me
Is cryst more of myȝte &raisedpoint; & more worthy name
Þan ihesu or ihesus &raisedpoint; þat al owre ioye come of
¶ Thow knowest wel quod conscience &raisedpoint; and þow konne resoun
That knyȝte kynge conqueroure &raisedpoint; may be o persone
To be called a kniȝte is faire &raisedpoint; for men shal knele to hym
To be called a Kynge is fairer &raisedpoint; for he may knyȝtes make
Ac to be conquerour called &raisedpoint; þat cometh of special grace
And of hardynesse of herte &raisedpoint; & of hendenesse
To make lordes of laddes &raisedpoint; of londe þat he wynneth
And fre men foule thralles &raisedpoint; þat folweth nouȝt his lawes
¶ The iuwes þat were gentil men &raisedpoint; ihesu þei dispised
Bothe his lore & his lawe &raisedpoint; now ar þei lowe cherlis
As wyde as þe worlde is wonyeth &raisedpoint; þere none
But vnder tribut & taillage &raisedpoint; as tykes & cherles
And þo þat bicome crysten &raisedpoint; by conseille of þe baptiste
Aren frankeleynes fre men &raisedpoint; þorw fullyng þat þei toke
And gentel men with ihesu &raisedpoint; for Ihesus was yfolled
And vppon caluarye on crosse &raisedpoint; ycrouned kynge of iewes
¶ It bicometh to a Kynge &raisedpoint; to kepe and to defende
And conquerour of conquest &raisedpoint; his lawes & his large
And so ded Ihesus þe iewes &raisedpoint; he iustified & tauȝte hem
Þe lawe of lyf &raisedpoint; that last shal euere
And fended fram foule yueles &raisedpoint; feueres & fluxes
and fro fendes þat in hem was & fals bileue
Þo was he ihesus of iewes called &raisedpoint; gentel prophete
And kynge of her kyngdome &raisedpoint; & croune bar of þornes
¶ And þo conquered he on crosse &raisedpoint; as conquerour noble
Myȝt no deth hym fordo &raisedpoint; ne adown brynge
That he ne aros & regned &raisedpoint; and rauysshed helle
And þo was he conquerour called &raisedpoint; of quikke & of ded
For he ȝaf Adam & Eue &raisedpoint; and other mo blisse
Þat longe hadde leyne bifore &raisedpoint; as lucyferes cherlesHereafter follow 19.56-59 in KD, from alpha, but they are not annotated.
¶ And sith he ȝaf largely &raisedpoint; alle his lele lyges
Places in paradys &raisedpoint; at her partynge hennes
He may wel be called conquerour &raisedpoint; & þat is cryst to mene
¶ Ac þe cause þat he cometh þus &raisedpoint; with crosse of his passioun
Is to wissen vs þere-wyth &raisedpoint; þat whan þat we ben tempted
Þer-with to fyȝte & fenden vs &raisedpoint; fro fallyng in-to synne
And se bi his sorwe &raisedpoint; þat who-so loueth ioye
To penaunce & to pouerte he moste putten hym-seluen
And moche wo in þis worlde &raisedpoint; willen & suffren
¶ Ac to carpe more of cryst &raisedpoint; and how he come to þat name
Faithly forto speke &raisedpoint; his firste name was ihesus
Tho he was borne in bethleem as þe boke telleth
And cam to take mankynde &raisedpoint; kynges and aungeles
Reuerenced hym faire &raisedpoint; with richesse of erthe
Angeles out of heuene &raisedpoint; come knelyng & songe
lg.marginalia: THe gyftes that þe iii . kyngs offered .Cr3.19.71
lg.l: Gloria in excelsis deo &c
¶ Kynges come after &raisedpoint; kneled & offred
Mirre & moche golde &raisedpoint; with-outen mercy askynge
Or any kynnes catel &raisedpoint; but knowlechyng hym soeuereigne
Bothe of sonde sonne & see &raisedpoint; & sithenes þei went
In-to her kyngene kyth &raisedpoint; by conseille of angeles
And there was þat worde fulfilled &raisedpoint; þe which þow of speke
Omnia celestia terrestria flectantur in hoc nomine Ihesu
For alle þe angeles of heuene &raisedpoint; at his burth kneled
And al þe witte of þe worlde &raisedpoint; was in þo þre kynges
Resoun & riȝtfulnesse &raisedpoint; & reuth þei offred
Wherfore & whi &raisedpoint; wyse men þat tyme
Maistres & lettred men &raisedpoint; Magy hem called
¶ That o kynge cam with resoun &raisedpoint; keuered vnder sense
Þe secounde kynge sitthe &raisedpoint; sothliche offred
Riȝtwisnesse vnder red golde resouns felawe
Golde is likned to leute &raisedpoint; þat last shal euere
And resoun to riche golde &raisedpoint; to riȝte & to treuthe
The þridde kynge þo cam &raisedpoint; knelyng to ihesu
And presented hym with pitee &raisedpoint; apierynge by myrre
For mirre is mercy to mene &raisedpoint; & mylde speche of tonge
Thre yliche honest þinges &raisedpoint; was offred þus at ones
Þorw þre kynne kynges &raisedpoint; knelynge to ihesu
¶ Ac for alle þise preciouse presentz owre lorde prynce ihesus
Was neyther kynge ne conquerour &raisedpoint; til he gan to wexe
In þe manere of a man &raisedpoint; & þat by moche sleight
As it bicometh a conquerour &raisedpoint; to konne many sleightes
And many wyles & witte &raisedpoint; þat wil ben a leder
And so did ihesu in his dayes &raisedpoint; who-so had tyme to telle it
Sum-tyme he suffred &raisedpoint; & sum-tyme he hydde hym
And sum-tyme he fauȝte faste &raisedpoint; & fleigh otherwhile
And some-tyme he gaf good &raisedpoint; & graunted hele bothe
Lyf & lyme &raisedpoint; as hym lyste he wrought
As kynde is of a conquerour &raisedpoint; so comsed ihesu
Tyl he had alle hem &raisedpoint; þat he fore bledde
¶ In his iuuente þis ihesus &raisedpoint; atte iuwen feste
Water in-to wyn tourned &raisedpoint; as holy writ telleth
And þere bigan god &raisedpoint; of his grace to dowel
For wyn is lykned to lawe &raisedpoint; & lyf of holynesse
And lawe lakked þo &raisedpoint; for men loued nouȝt her enemys
And cryst conseilleth þus &raisedpoint; & comaundeth bothe
Bothe to lered & to lewed &raisedpoint; to louye owre enemys
So atte feste firste as I bifore tolde
Bygan god of his grace & goodnesse to dowel
And þo was he cleped & called nouȝt holy cryst but Ihesu
A fauntfyn ful of witte &raisedpoint; filius marie
¶ For bifor his moder marie &raisedpoint; made he þat wonder
Þat she furste & formest &raisedpoint; ferme shulde bilieue
That he þorw grace was gete &raisedpoint; & of no gome elles
He wrouȝt þat bi no witte &raisedpoint; but þorw worde one
After þe kynde þat he come of &raisedpoint; þere comsed he dowel
And whan he was woxen more &raisedpoint; in his moder absence
He made lame to lepe &raisedpoint; & ȝaue liȝte to blynde
And fedde with two fisshes &raisedpoint; & with fyue loues &raisedpoint;
Sore afyngred folke &raisedpoint; mo þan fyue thousande
Þus he conforted carful &raisedpoint; & cauȝte a gretter name
Þe whiche was dobet &raisedpoint; where þat he went
For defe þorw his doynges to here &raisedpoint; & dombe speke he made
And alle he heled & halpe &raisedpoint; þat hym of grace asked
And þo was he called in contre of þe comune peple
For þe dedes þat he did &raisedpoint; fili dauid ihesus
For dauid was douȝtiest &raisedpoint; of dedes in his tyme
The berdes þo songe &raisedpoint; Saul interfecit mille &raisedpoint; et dauid decem milia &raisedpoint;
For-þi þe contre þere ihesu cam &raisedpoint; called hym fili dauid
And nempned hym of nazereth &raisedpoint; & no man so worthi
To be kaisere or kynge &raisedpoint; of þe kyngedome of iuda
Ne ouer iuwes iustice &raisedpoint; as ihesus was hem þouȝte
¶ Where-of caiphas hadde enuye &raisedpoint; & other of þe iewes
And forto doun hym to deth &raisedpoint; day & nyȝte þei casten
Kulleden hym on crosse-wyse &raisedpoint; at caluarie on fryday
And sithen buryden his body &raisedpoint; & beden þat men sholde
Kepen it fro niȝt-comeres &raisedpoint; with knyȝtes yarmed
For no frendes shulde hym fecche &raisedpoint; for prophetes hem tolde
Þat þat blessed body &raisedpoint; of burieles shulde rise
And gone in-to galile &raisedpoint; and gladen his apostles
And his moder Marie &raisedpoint; þus men bifore demed
¶ The knyȝtes þat kepten it &raisedpoint; biknewe it hem-seluen
Þat angeles & archangeles &raisedpoint; ar þe day spronge
Come knelynge to þe corps &raisedpoint; & songen cristus resurgens
Verrey man bifor hem alle &raisedpoint; & forth-with hem he ȝede
¶ The iewes preyed hem pees &raisedpoint; & bisouȝte þe knyȝtes
Telle þe comune þat þere cam &raisedpoint; a compaignye of his aposteles
And bywicched hem as þei woke &raisedpoint; & awey stolen it
¶ Ac Marie Magdeleyne &raisedpoint; mette hym bi þe wey
Goynge toward galile &raisedpoint; in godhed & manhed
And lyues & lokynge &raisedpoint; & she aloude cryde
In eche a compaignye þere she cam &raisedpoint; cristus resurgens
lg.marginalia: Luke.24 Why Christ appeared fyrste to a woman,Cr3.19.158
lg.l: Þus cam it out þat cryst ouer-cam &raisedpoint; rekeuered & lyued
Sic oportet cristum pati & intrare &c &raisedpoint;
For þat wommen witeth &raisedpoint; may nouȝte wel be conseille
¶ Peter parceyued al þis &raisedpoint; & pursued after
Bothe iames & Iohan &raisedpoint; Ihesu for to seke
Tadde & ten mo &raisedpoint; with Thomas of ynde
And as alle þise wise wyes &raisedpoint; weren togideres
In an hous al bishette &raisedpoint; & her dore ybarred
Cryst cam in & al closed &raisedpoint; bothe dore & ȝates
To peter & to his aposteles &raisedpoint; and seyde pax vobis
And toke Thomas by þe hande &raisedpoint; and tauȝte hym to grope
And fele with his fyngres &raisedpoint; his flesshelich herte
¶ Thomas touched it &raisedpoint; & with his tonge seyde
Deus meus & dominus meus
Thow art my lorde &raisedpoint; I bileue &raisedpoint; god lorde ihesu
Þow deydest & deth þoledest &raisedpoint; and deme shalt vs alle
And now art lyuynge & lokynge &raisedpoint; & laste shalt euere
¶ Crist carped þanne &raisedpoint; and curteislich seyde
Thomas for þow trowest þis &raisedpoint; & trewliche bileuest it
Blessed mote þow be &raisedpoint; & be shalt for euere
And blessed mote þei alle be &raisedpoint; in body & in soule
That neuere shal se me in siȝte &raisedpoint; as þow doste nouthe
And lellich bileuen al þis &raisedpoint; I loue hem & blesse hem
Beati qui non viderunt &c &raisedpoint;
¶ And whan þis dede was done &raisedpoint; dobest he tauȝte
And ȝaf Pieres power &raisedpoint; and pardoun he graunted
To alle manere men &raisedpoint; mercy & forȝyfnes
Hym myȝte men to assoille &raisedpoint; of alle manere synnes
In couenant þat þei come &raisedpoint; & knewleche to paye
lg.marginalia: Pierces pardon is pay that þouoweste .Cr3.19.186
lg.l: To pieres pardon þe plowman &raisedpoint; redde quod debes
¶ Thus hath pieres powere &raisedpoint; be his pardoun payed
To bynde & to vnbynde &raisedpoint; bothe here & elles
And assoille men of alle synnes &raisedpoint; saue of dette one
¶ Anone after an heigh &raisedpoint; vp in-to heuene
He went & wonyeth þere &raisedpoint; & wil come atte laste
And wil rewarde hym riȝte wel &raisedpoint; þat reddit quod debet
Payeth parfitly as pure trewthe wolde
And what persone payeth it nouȝt &raisedpoint; punysshen he þinketh
And demen hem at domes-daye &raisedpoint; bothe quikke & ded
Þe gode to þe godhede &raisedpoint; & to grete ioye
And wikke to wonye &raisedpoint; in wo with-outen ende
Þus conscience of crist &raisedpoint; & of þe crosse carped
And conseilled me to knele þer-to &raisedpoint; & þanne come me þouȝte
One spiritus paraclitus &raisedpoint; to Pieres & to his felawes
In lyknesse of a liȝtnynge &raisedpoint; he lyȝte on hem alle
And made hem konne & knowe &raisedpoint; alkyn langages
¶ I wondred what þat was &raisedpoint; & wagged conscience
And was afered of the lyȝte &raisedpoint; for in fyres lyknesse
Spiritus paraclitus &raisedpoint; ouer-spradde hem alle
¶ Quod conscience & kneled &raisedpoint; þis is crystes messager
And cometh fro þe grete god &raisedpoint; & grace is his name
Knele now quod conscience &raisedpoint; & if þow canst synge
Welcome hym & worshipe hym &raisedpoint; with veni creator spiritus
¶ Thanne songe I þat songe &raisedpoint; and so did many hundreth
And cryden with conscience &raisedpoint; help vs god of grace
And þanne bigan grace &raisedpoint; to go with piers plowman
And conseilled hym & conscience &raisedpoint; þe comune to sompne
For I wil dele to-daye &raisedpoint; & dyuyde grace
To alkynnes creatures &raisedpoint; þat kan her fyue wittes
Tresore to lyue by &raisedpoint; to her lyues ende
And wepne to fyȝte with &raisedpoint; þat wil neure faille
For antecryst & his &raisedpoint; al þe worlde shal greue
And acombre þe conscience &raisedpoint; but if cryst þe helpe
¶ And fals prophetes fele &raisedpoint; flatereres & glosers
Shullen come & be curatoures &raisedpoint; ouer kynges & erlis
And pryde shal be pope &raisedpoint; prynce of holycherche
Coueytyse & vnkyndenesse &raisedpoint; cardinales hym to lede
For-þi quod grace er I go &raisedpoint; I wil gyue ȝow tresore
And wepne to fiȝte with &raisedpoint; whan antecryst ȝow assailleth
And gaf eche man a grace &raisedpoint; to gye with hym-seluen
That ydelnesse encombre hym nouȝt &raisedpoint; envye ne pryde
Diuisiones graciarum sunt &c &raisedpoint;
¶ Some he ȝaf wytte &raisedpoint; with wordes to shewe
lg.marginalia: The gyftes of the holy gost .
lg.l: Witte to wynne her lyflode with &raisedpoint; as þe worlde asketh
As prechoures & prestes & prentyce of lawe
Þei lelly to lyue &raisedpoint; by laboure of tonge
And bi witte to wissen other &raisedpoint; as grace hem wolde teche
¶ And some he kenned crafte &raisedpoint; & kunnynge of syȝte
With sellyng & buggynge &raisedpoint; her bylyf to wynne
And some he lered to laboure &raisedpoint; a lele lyf & a trewe
And somme he tauȝte to tilie &raisedpoint; to dyche & to thecche
To wynne with her lyflode &raisedpoint; by lore of his techynge
And some to dyuyne & diuide &raisedpoint; noumbres to kenne
And some to compas craftily &raisedpoint; & coloures to make
And some to se & to saye &raisedpoint; what shulde bifalle
Bothe of wel & of wo &raisedpoint; telle it or it felle
As Astronomyenes þorw astronomye &raisedpoint; & philosophres wyse
