¶ And some to ryde & to recoeure &raisedpoint; þat vnriȝtfully was wonne
He wissed hem wynne it aȝeyne &raisedpoint; þorw wightnesse of handes
¶ And fecchen it fro fals men &raisedpoint; with foluyles lawes
And some he lered to lyue &raisedpoint; in longynge to ben hennes
In pouerte & in penaunce &raisedpoint; to preye for alle crystene
And alle he lered to be lele &raisedpoint; & eche a crafte loue other
And forbad hem alle debate &raisedpoint; þat none were amonge hem
Thowgh some be clenner þan somme &raisedpoint; ȝe se wel quod grace
Þat he þat vseth þe fairest crafte &raisedpoint; to þe foulest I couth haue put hym
Þinketh alle quod grace &raisedpoint; þat grace cometh of my ȝifte
Loke þat none lakke other &raisedpoint; but loueth alle as bretheren
¶ And who þat moste maistries can &raisedpoint; be myldest of berynge
And crouneth conscience kynge &raisedpoint; & maketh crafte ȝowre stuward
And after craftes conseille &raisedpoint; clotheth ȝow & fede
For I make Pieres þe plowman &raisedpoint; my procuratour & my reve
And Regystrere to receyue &raisedpoint; redde quod debes
My prowor & my plowman &raisedpoint; Piers shal ben on erthe
And for to tulye treuthe &raisedpoint; a teme shal he haue
¶ Grace gaue Piers a teme &raisedpoint; foure gret oxen
Þat on was Luke a large beste &raisedpoint; and a lowe-chered
And marke & mathew þe þrydde &raisedpoint; myghty bestes bothe
And ioigned to hem one Iohan &raisedpoint; most gentil of alle
Þe prys nete of Piers plow &raisedpoint; passyng alle other
¶ And grace gaue pieres &raisedpoint; of his goodnesse foure stottis
Al þat his oxen eryed &raisedpoint; þey to harwe after
On hyȝte Austyne &raisedpoint; & ambrose an other
Gregori þe grete clerke &raisedpoint; & Ierome þe gode
Þise foure þe feithe to teche &raisedpoint; folweth pieres teme
And harwed in an handwhile &raisedpoint; al holy scripture
Wyth two harwes þat þei hadde &raisedpoint; an olde & a newe
Id est vetus testamentum & nouum
¶ And grace gaue greynes &raisedpoint; þe cardynales vertues
And sewe it in mannes soule &raisedpoint; & sithen he tolde her names

marginalia.note: O19.267. This rubric appears as two lines, with each word begun below and continued above, an arrangement not seen elsewhere in the manuscript.

lg.l: Spiritus prudencie &raisedpoint; þe firste seed hyȝte
And who-so eet þat &raisedpoint; ymagyne he shulde
Ar he did any dede &raisedpoint; deuyse wel þe ende
And lerned men a ladel bugge &raisedpoint; with a longe stele
Þat cast for to kepe a crokke &raisedpoint; to saue þe fatte abouen

marginalia.note: W19.282, shaped like punctus elevatus sans point

lg.l: ¶ The secounde seed hiȝte spiritus temperancie
He þat ete of þat seed &raisedpoint; hadde suche a kynde
Shulde neuere mete ne mochel drynke &raisedpoint; make hym to swelle
Ne sholde no scorner ne scolde &raisedpoint; oute of skyl hym brynge
Ne wynnynge ne welthe &raisedpoint; of wordeliche ricchesse
Waste worde of ydelnesse &raisedpoint; ne wykked speche meue
Shulde no curyous clothe &raisedpoint; comen on hys rugge
Ne no mete in his mouth &raisedpoint; þat maister Iohan spiced
¶ The thridde seed þat Pieres sewe &raisedpoint; was spiritus fortitudinis
And who-so eet of þat seed hardy was eure
To suffre al þat god sent &raisedpoint; sykenesse & angres
Myȝte no lesynge ne lyere &raisedpoint; ne losse of worldely catel
Maken hym for any mournynge &raisedpoint; þat he nas merye in soule
And bolde & abydynge &raisedpoint; bismeres to suffre
And playeth al with pacyence &raisedpoint; & parce michi domine
And couered hym vnder conseille &raisedpoint; of catoun þe wyse
Esto forti animo cum sis dampnatus inique
¶ The fierthe seed þat pieres sewe &raisedpoint; was spiritus iusticie
And he þat eet of þat seed &raisedpoint; shulde be euere trewe
With god & nouȝt agast &raisedpoint; but of gyle one
For gyle goth so pryuely &raisedpoint; þat good faith other-while
May nouȝte ben aspyed &raisedpoint; for spiritus iusticie
¶ Spiritus iusticie &raisedpoint; spareth nouȝte to spille
Hem þat ben gulty &raisedpoint; & forto correcte
Þe Kynge ȝif he falle &raisedpoint; in gylte or in trespasse
For counteth he no kynges wratthe &raisedpoint; whan he in courte sitteth
To demen as a domes-man &raisedpoint; adradde was he neure
Noither of duke ne of deth &raisedpoint; þat he ne dede þe lawe
For present or for preyere &raisedpoint; or any prynces lettres
He dede equite to alle &raisedpoint; euene-forth his powere
¶ Thise foure sedes pieres sewe &raisedpoint; and sitthe he did hem harwe
Wyth olde lawe and newe lawe &raisedpoint; þat loue myȝte wexe
Amonge þe foure vertues &raisedpoint; and vices destroye
¶ For comunelich in contrees &raisedpoint; kammokes & wedes
Fouleth þe fruite in þe felde &raisedpoint; þere þei growe togyderes
And so don vices &raisedpoint; vertues worthy
Quod Piers harweth alle þat kunneth kynde witte &raisedpoint; bi conseille of þis doctours
And tulyeth after her techynge &raisedpoint; þe cardinale vertues
¶ Aȝeines þi greynes quod grace &raisedpoint; bigynneth for to ripe
Ordeigne þe an hous quod Piers &raisedpoint; to herberwe in þi cornes
¶ By god grace quod Piers &raisedpoint; ȝe moten gyue tymbre
And ordeyne þat hous &raisedpoint; ar ȝe hennes wende
¶ And grace gaue hym þe crosse &raisedpoint; with þe croune of þornes
That cryst vpon caluarye &raisedpoint; for mankynde on pyned
And of his baptesme & blode &raisedpoint; þat he bledde on Rode
He made a maner morter &raisedpoint; & mercy it hiȝte
And þere-with grace bigan &raisedpoint; to make a good foundement
And watteled it and walled it &raisedpoint; with his peynes & his passioun
And of al holywrit &raisedpoint; he made a rofe after
And called þat hous vnite &raisedpoint; holicherche on englisshe
And whan þis dede was done &raisedpoint; grace deuised
A carte hyȝte cristendome &raisedpoint; to carye pieres sheues
And gaf hym caples to his carte &raisedpoint; contricioun & confessioun
And made presthode haywarde &raisedpoint; þe while hym-self went
As wyde as þe worlde is &raisedpoint; with pieres to tulye treuthe
¶ Now is Pieres to þe plow &raisedpoint; & pruyde it aspyde
And gadered hym a grete oest &raisedpoint; to greuen he þinketh
Conscience and al crystene &raisedpoint; and cardinale vertues
Blowe hem doune & breke hem &raisedpoint; & bite atwo þe mores
And sent forth surquydous &raisedpoint; his seriaunt of armes
And his spye spille-loue &raisedpoint; one speke yuel byhynde
Þise two come to conscience &raisedpoint; and to crystene peple
And tolde hem tydynges &raisedpoint; þat tyne þei shulde þe sedes
That Pieres þere hadde ysowen &raisedpoint; þe cardynal vertues
And Pieres berne worth broke &raisedpoint; & þei þat ben in vnite
Shulle come out &raisedpoint; & conscience &punctuselevatus; & ȝowre two caples
Confessioun & contricioun &raisedpoint; and ȝowre carte þe byleue
Shal be coloured so queyntly &raisedpoint; and keuered vnder owre sophistrie
Þat consci[ence] shal nouȝte &punctuselevatus; knowe by contricioun
Ne by confessioun &punctuselevatus; who is cristene or hethen
Ne no maner marchaunt &raisedpoint; þat with moneye deleth
Where he wynne wyth riȝte &raisedpoint; with wronge or with vsure
¶ With suche coloures & queyntise &punctuselevatus; cometh pryde yarmed
With þe lorde þat lyueth after &raisedpoint; þe luste of his body
To wasten on welfare &raisedpoint; and on wykked kepynge
Al þe worlde in a while &raisedpoint; þorw owre witte quod pruyde
¶ Quod conscience to alle crystene þo &raisedpoint; my conseille is to wende
Hastiliche in-to vnyte &raisedpoint; & holde we vs þere
And preye we þat a pees were &raisedpoint; in Piers berne þe plowman
For witterly I wote wel &raisedpoint; we beth nouȝte of strengthe
To gone agayne pryde &raisedpoint; but grace were with vs
¶ And þanne cam kynde wytte &raisedpoint; conscience to teche
And cryde & comaunded &raisedpoint; al crystene peple
For to deluen a dyche &raisedpoint; depe aboute vnite
That holycherche stode in vnite &raisedpoint; as it a pyle [weere]
¶ Conscience comaunded þo &raisedpoint; al crystene to delue
And make a muche mote &raisedpoint; þat myȝte ben a strengthe
To helpe holycherche &raisedpoint; & hem þat it kepeth
¶ Thanne alkyn crystene &raisedpoint; saue comune wommen
lg.marginalia: Who thi be that neuer repent .Cr3.19.371
lg.l: Repenteden & refused synne &raisedpoint; saue they one
And fals men flateres &raisedpoint; vsureres and theues
Lyeres and questmongeres &raisedpoint; þat were forsworen ofte
Wytynge and willefully &raisedpoint; with þe false helden
And for syluer were forswore &raisedpoint; sothely þei wist it
¶ Þere nas no crystene creature &raisedpoint; þat kynde witte hadde
Saue schrewes one &raisedpoint; suche as I spak of
That he ne halpe a quantite &raisedpoint; holynesse to wexe
Somme þorw bedes byddynge &raisedpoint; and some þorw pylgrymage
And other pryue penaunce &raisedpoint; and some þorw penyes delynge
¶ And þanne welled water &raisedpoint; for wikked werkes
Egerlich ernynge &raisedpoint; out of mennes eyen
Clennesse of þe comune &raisedpoint; & clerkes clene lyuynge
Made vnite holicherche &raisedpoint; in holynesse to stonde
I care nouȝte quod conscience &raisedpoint; þough pryde come nouthe
Þe lorde of luste shal be letted &raisedpoint; al þis lente I hope
Comeþ quod conscience &raisedpoint; ȝe cristene and dyneth
Þat han laboured lelly &raisedpoint; al þis lente tyme
Here is bred yblessed &raisedpoint; and goddes body þer-vnder
Grace þorw goddes worde &raisedpoint; gaue Pieres power
Myȝtes to maken it &raisedpoint; & men to ete it after
In helpe of her hele &raisedpoint; onys in a moneth
Or as ofte as þey hadden nede &raisedpoint; þo þat hadde ypayed
To pieres pardoun þe plowman &raisedpoint; redde quod debes
¶ How quod al þe comune &raisedpoint; þow conseillest vs to ȝelde
Al þat we owen any wyȝte &raisedpoint; ar we go to housel
¶ That is my conseille quod conscience & cardynale vertues
Þat vche man forȝyue other &raisedpoint; and þat wyl þe pater noster
Et dimitte nobis debita nostra &raisedpoint; &c &raisedpoint;
And so to ben assoilled &raisedpoint; & sithen ben houseled
¶ Ȝe bawe quod a brewere &raisedpoint; I wil nouȝt be reuled
Bi ihesu for al ȝowre ianglynge &raisedpoint; with spiritus iusticie
Ne after conscience by cryste &raisedpoint; whil I can selle
Bothe dregges & draffe &raisedpoint; and drawe it at on hole
Þikke ale and þinne ale &raisedpoint; for þat is my kynde
And nouȝte hakke after holynesse &raisedpoint; holde þi tonge conscience
Of spiritus iusticie &raisedpoint; þow spekest moche an ydel
¶ Caytyue quod conscience &raisedpoint; cursed wrecche
Vnblessed artow brewere &raisedpoint; but if þe god helpe
But þow lyue by lore &raisedpoint; of spiritus iusticie
Þe chief seed þat Pieres sewe &raisedpoint; ysaued worstow neure
But conscience þe comune fede &raisedpoint; and cardynale vertues
Leue it wel þei ben loste &raisedpoint; bothe lyf & soule
¶ Thanne is many man ylost quod a lewed vycory
I am a curatour of holykyrke &raisedpoint; and come neure in my tyme
Man to me þat me couth telle &raisedpoint; of cardinale vertues
Or þat acounted conscience &raisedpoint; at a cokkes fether or an hennes
I knewe neure cardynal &raisedpoint; þat he ne cam fro þe pope
And we clerkes whan þey come &raisedpoint; for her comunes payeth
For her pelure and her palfreyes mete &raisedpoint; & piloures þat hem folweth
Þe comune clamat cotidie &raisedpoint; eche a man to other
Þe contre is þe curseder &raisedpoint; þat cardynales come Inne
And þere they ligge and lenge moste &raisedpoint; lecherye þere regneth
For-þi quod þis vicori &raisedpoint; be verrey god I wolde
That no cardynal come &raisedpoint; amonge þe comune peple
But in her holynesse &raisedpoint; holden hem stille
At Auynoun amonge þe iuwes &raisedpoint; cum sancto sanctus eris &c
Or in Rome as here rule wole &raisedpoint; þe reliques to kepe
And þow conscience in kynges courte &raisedpoint; & shuldest neure come þennes
And grace þat þow gredest so of : gyour of alle clerkes
And Pieres with his newe plow &raisedpoint; & eke with his olde
Emperour of al þe worlde &raisedpoint; þat alle men were cristene
¶ Inparfyt is þat pope &raisedpoint; þat al peple shulde helpe
lg.marginalia: Pierce foloweth þe example of GodCr3.19.433
lg.l: And sendeth hem þat sleeth suche &raisedpoint; as he shulde saue
And wel worth piers þe plowman &raisedpoint; þat sueth god in doyng
Qui pluit super iustos &raisedpoint; & iniustos at ones
And sent þe sonne to saue &raisedpoint; a cursed mannes tilthe
As bryȝte as to þe best man &raisedpoint; & to þe beste woman
Riȝte so Pieres þe plowman &raisedpoint; peyneth hym to tulye
As wel for a wastour &raisedpoint; & wenches of þe stuwes
As for hym-self & his seruauntz &raisedpoint; saue he is firste yserued
And trauailleth & tulyeth &raisedpoint; for a tretour also sore
As for a trewe tydy man &raisedpoint; al tymes ylyke
And worshiped be he þat wrouȝte al &raisedpoint; bothe good & wykke
And suffreth þat synful be &raisedpoint; til some tyme þat þei repente
And god amende þe pope &raisedpoint; þat pileth holykirke
And cleymeth bifor þe kynge &raisedpoint; to be keper ouer crystene
And counteth nouȝt þough crystene ben &raisedpoint; culled & robbed
And fynt folke to fyȝte &raisedpoint; and cristene blode to spille
Aȝeyne þe olde lawe & newe lawe &raisedpoint; as Luke þer-of witnesseth
Non occides michi vindictam &c
It semeth &raisedpoint; by so &punctuselevatus; hym-self hadd his wille
That he ne reccheth riȝte nouȝte &raisedpoint; of al þe remenaunte
And cryst of his curteisye &raisedpoint; þe cardinales saue
And tourne her witte to wisdome &raisedpoint; & to wele of soule
For þe comune quod þis curatour counten ful litel
Þe conseille of conscience &raisedpoint; or cardinale vertues
But if þei sowe as by syȝte &raisedpoint; somwhat to wynnynge
Of gyle ne of gabbynge &raisedpoint; gyue þei neuere tale
For spiritus prudencie &raisedpoint; amonge þe peple is gyle
And alle þo faire vertues &raisedpoint; as vyces þei semeth
Eche man sotileth a sleight &raisedpoint; synne forto hyde
And coloureth it for a kunnynge &raisedpoint; and a clene lyuynge
¶ Thanne loughe þere a lorde &raisedpoint; & by þis liȝte sayde
I halde it ryȝte & resoun &raisedpoint; of my reue to take
Al þat myne auditour or elles my stuwarde
Conseilleth me by her acounte &raisedpoint; & my clerkes wrytynge
¶ With spiritus intellectus &raisedpoint; they seke þe reues rolles
And with spiritus fortitudinis &raisedpoint; fecche [it] I wole
¶ And þanne come þere a kynge &raisedpoint; & bi his croune seyde
I am Kynge with croune &raisedpoint; þe comune to reule
lg.marginalia: XG20.459. This corresponds to a similar sign in the table of contents. Possibly these marks were made by WH.
lg.l: And holykirke & clergye &raisedpoint; fro cursed men to defende
And if me lakketh to lyue by &raisedpoint; þe lawe wil I take it
Þere I may hastlokest it haue &raisedpoint; for I am hed of lawe
For ȝe ben but membres &raisedpoint; & I aboue alle
And sith I am ȝowre aller hed &raisedpoint; I am ȝowre aller hele
And holycherche chief help &raisedpoint; & chiftaigne of þe comune
And what I take of ȝow two &raisedpoint; I take it atte techynge
Of spiritus iusticie for I &raisedpoint; iugge ȝow alle
So I may baldely be houseled &raisedpoint; for I borwe neuere
Ne craue of my comune &raisedpoint; but as my kynde asketh
¶ In condicioun quod conscience &raisedpoint; þat þow konne defende
And rule þi rewme in resoun &raisedpoint; riȝt wel & in treuth
Take þow may in resoun as þi lawe asketh
Omnia tua sunt ad defendendum set non ad depredandum
Þe vyker hadde fer home &raisedpoint; & faire toke his leue
And I awakned þere-with &raisedpoint; & wrote as me mette
Thanne as I went by þe way &raisedpoint; whan I was þus awaked
Heuy-chered I ȝede &raisedpoint; and elynge in herte
I ne wiste where to ete &raisedpoint; ne at what place
And it neighed nyeghe þe none &raisedpoint; & with nede I mette
That afronted me foule &raisedpoint; and faitour me called
Coudestow nouȝte excuse þe &raisedpoint; as dede þe Kynge & other
Þat þow toke to þi bylyf &raisedpoint; to clothes and to sustenance
As by techynge & by tellynge &raisedpoint; of spiritus temperancie
And þow nome namore &raisedpoint; þan nede þe tauȝte
And nede ne hath no lawe &raisedpoint; ne neure shal falle in dette
For þre thynges he taketh &raisedpoint; his lyf forto saue
That is mete whan men hym werneth &raisedpoint; & he no moneye weldeth
¶ Ne wyght none wil ben his borwe &raisedpoint; ne wedde hath none to legge
And he cauȝte in þat cas &raisedpoint; & come þere-to by sleighte
He synneth nouȝte sothelich &raisedpoint; þat so wynneth his fode
And þough he come so to a clothe &raisedpoint; and can no better cheuysaunce
Nede anon-riȝte &raisedpoint; nymeth hym vnder meynpryse
And if hym lyst for to lape &raisedpoint; þe lawe of kynde wolde
That he dronke at eche diche &raisedpoint; ar he for thurste deyde
So nede at grete nede &raisedpoint; may nymen as for his owne
Wyth-oute conseille of conscience &raisedpoint; or cardynale vertues
So þat he suwe & saue &raisedpoint; spiritus temperancie
¶ For is no vertue by fer to spiritus temperancie
Neither spiritus iusticie &raisedpoint; ne spiritus fortitudinis
For spiritus fortitudinis &raisedpoint; forfaiteth ful oft
He shal do more þan mesure &raisedpoint; many tyme & ofte

marginalia.note: R20.1, italic hand noting what passus we're in when R resumes

lg.l: And bete men ouer bitter &raisedpoint; and somme of hem to litel
And greue men gretter &raisedpoint; þan goode faith it wolde
¶ And spiritus iusticie &punctuselevatus; shal iuggen wolhe nolhe
After þe kynges conseille &raisedpoint; & þe comune lyke
And spiritus prudencie &raisedpoint; in many a poynte shal faille
Of þat he weneth wolde falle &raisedpoint; if his wytte ne were
Wenynge is no wysdome &raisedpoint; ne wyse ymagynacioun
Homo proponit & deus disponit &raisedpoint; & gouerneth alle good vertues
Ac nede is next hym &raisedpoint; for anon he meketh
And as low as a lombe &raisedpoint; for lakkyng of þat hym nedeth
Wyse men forsoke wele &raisedpoint; for þey wolde be nedy
And woneden in wildernesse &raisedpoint; & wolde nouȝte be riche
¶ And god al his grete ioye &raisedpoint; gostliche he left
And cam & toke mankynde &raisedpoint; and bycam nedy
So nedy he was as seyth þe boke &raisedpoint; in many sondry places
Þat he seyde in his sorwe &raisedpoint; on þe selue Rode
Bothe fox & foule &raisedpoint; may fleighe to hole & crepe
And þe fisshe hath fyn &raisedpoint; to flete with to reste
Þere nede hath ynome me &raisedpoint; þat I mote nede abyde
And suffre sorwes ful sowre &raisedpoint; þat shal to ioye tourne
For-þi be nouȝte abasshed &raisedpoint; to byde and to be nedy
Syth he þat wrouȝte al þe worlde &raisedpoint; was wilfullich nedy
Ne neuer none so nedy &raisedpoint; ne pouerere deyde
¶ Whan nede had vndernome me þus &raisedpoint; anon I felle aslepe
And mette ful merueillously &raisedpoint; þat in mannes forme
Antecryst cam þanne &raisedpoint; and al þe croppe of treuthe

lg.l: Torned it vp-so-doune &raisedpoint; and ouertilte þe rote
lg.marginalia: ipsa papaG21.54. Glosses "false." The addition is smudged and may have been added in the wrong place and then partially deleted.
lg.l: And fals sprynge & sprede &raisedpoint; & spede mennes nedes
In eche a contre þere he cam &raisedpoint; he cutte awey treuthe
And gert gyle growe þere &raisedpoint; as he a god were
lg.marginalia: . Freres .O20.57, surrounded by the long Latin gloss beginning opposite KD20.54.
lg.l: Freres folwed þat fende &raisedpoint; for he ȝaf hem copes
And religiouse reuerenced hym &raisedpoint; and rongen here belles
And al þe couent forth cam &raisedpoint; to welcome þat tyraunt
And alle hise &raisedpoint; as wel as hym &raisedpoint; saue onlich folis
Which folis were wel leuer to deye þan to lyue
Lengore sith lenten &punctuselevatus; was so rebuked
And a fals fende antecriste &raisedpoint; ouer alle folke regned
And þat were mylde men & holy &raisedpoint; þat no myschief dredden
Defyed al falsenesse &raisedpoint; and folke þat it vsed
And what Kynge þat hem conforted &raisedpoint; knowynge hem any while
They cursed and her conseille &raisedpoint; were it clerke or lewed
¶ Antecriste hadde thus sone &raisedpoint; hundredes at his banere
And Pryde it bare &raisedpoint; boldely aboute
With a lorde þat lyueth &raisedpoint; after lykynge of body
That cam aȝein conscience &raisedpoint; þat kepere was & gyoure
Ouer kynde crystene &raisedpoint; and cardynale vertues
¶ I conseille quod conscience þo &raisedpoint; cometh with me ȝe foles
In-to vnyte holy cherche &raisedpoint; and holde we vs there
And crye we to kynde &raisedpoint; þat he come & defende vs
Foles &raisedpoint; fro þis fendes lymes &raisedpoint; for Piers loue þe plowman
And crye we to alle þe comune / þat þei come to vnite
And þere abide and bikere &raisedpoint; aȝein beliales children
¶ Kynd conscience þo herde &raisedpoint; and cam out of þe planetes
And sent forth his foreioures feures and fluxes
Coughes and cardiacles &raisedpoint; crampes and tothaches
Rewmes & radegoundes &raisedpoint; and roynouse scalles
Byles and bocches &raisedpoint; and brennyng agues
Frenesyes & foule yueles &raisedpoint; forageres of kynde
Hadde yprykked and prayed polles of peple
Þat largelich a legioun &raisedpoint; lese her lyf sone
¶ There was harrow and help &raisedpoint; here cometh kynde
With deth þat is dredful &raisedpoint; to vndone vs alle
¶ The lorde that lyued after lust &raisedpoint; tho alowde cryde
After conforte a knyghte &raisedpoint; to come and bere his banere
Alarme alarme quod þat lorde eche lyf kepe his owne
¶ And þanne mette þis men &raisedpoint; ar mynstralles myȝte pipe
And ar heraudes of armes &raisedpoint; hadden descreued lordes
¶ Elde þe hore &raisedpoint; he was in þe vauntwarde
And bare þe banere bifor deth &raisedpoint; by riȝte he it claymed
Kynde come after &raisedpoint; with many kene sores
As pokkes and pestilences &raisedpoint; and moche poeple shente &raisedpoint;
So kynde þorw corupciouns &raisedpoint; kulled ful manye
¶ Deth cam dryuende after &raisedpoint; and al to doust passhed
Kynges & Knyȝtes &raisedpoint; kayseres and popes
Lered ne lewed &raisedpoint; he let no man stonde
That he hitte euene &raisedpoint; þat euere stired after
Many a louely lady &raisedpoint; and lemmanes of knyghtes
Swouned and swelted &raisedpoint; for sorwe of dethes dyntes
¶ Conscience of his curteisye &raisedpoint; to kynde he bisouȝte
To cesse & suffre &raisedpoint; and see where þei wolde
Leue pryde pryuely &raisedpoint; and be parfite cristene
¶ And kynde cessed tho &raisedpoint; to se þe peple amende
lg.marginalia: The maner of men when plages ceaseCr3.20.109
lg.l: Fortune gan flateren thenne &raisedpoint; þo fewe þat were alyue
And byhight hem longe lyf &raisedpoint; and lecherye he sent
Amonges al manere men &raisedpoint; wedded & vnwedded
And gadered a gret hoste &raisedpoint; al agayne conscience
¶ This lecherye leyde on &raisedpoint; with a laughyng chiere
And with pryue speche &raisedpoint; and peynted wordes
And armed hym in ydelnesse &raisedpoint; and in hiegh berynge
He bare a bowe in his hande &raisedpoint; and manye blody arwes
Weren fethered with faire biheste &raisedpoint; and many a false truthe
Wit his vntydy tales &raisedpoint; he tened ful ofte
Conscience and his compaignye &raisedpoint; of holicherche þe techeres
¶ Thanne cam coueityse &raisedpoint; and caste how he myȝte
Ouercome conscience &raisedpoint; and cardynal vertues
And armed hym in auaryce &raisedpoint; and hungriliche lyued
His wepne was al wiles &raisedpoint; to wynnen & to hyden
With glosynges and with gabbynges &raisedpoint; he gyled þe peple
Symonye hym sent &raisedpoint; to assaille conscience
And preched to þe peple &raisedpoint; and prelates þei hem maden
To holden with antecryste &raisedpoint; her temperaltes to saue
And come to þe kynges conseille &raisedpoint; as a kene baroun
And kneled to conscience in courte afor hem alle
And gart gode feith flee &raisedpoint; and fals to abide
And boldeliche bar adown &raisedpoint; with many a briȝte noble
Moche of þe witte and wisdome &raisedpoint; of westmynster halle
He iugged til a iustice &raisedpoint; and iusted in his ere
And ouertilte al his treuthe &raisedpoint; with take þis vp amendement
And to þe arches in haste &raisedpoint; he ȝede anone after
And torned Ciuile in-to symonye &raisedpoint; and sitthe he toke þe official
For a mentel of menyuere &raisedpoint; he made lele matrimonye
Departen ar deth cam &raisedpoint; & deuos shupte
¶ Allas quod conscience & cried þo &raisedpoint; wolde criste of his grace
That coueityse were cristene &raisedpoint; þat is so kene a fiȝter
And bolde and bidyng &raisedpoint; while his bagge lasteth
¶ And þanne lowgh lyf &raisedpoint; and leet dagge his clothes
And armed hym in haste &raisedpoint; in harlotes wordes
And helde holynesse a iape &raisedpoint; and hendenesse a wastour
And lete leute a cherle &raisedpoint; and lyer a fre man &raisedpoint;
Conscience and conseille &raisedpoint; he counted it a folye &raisedpoint;
¶ Thus relyed lyf &raisedpoint; for a litel fortune
And pryked forth with pryde preyseth he no vertue
A careth nouȝte how kynde slow &raisedpoint; and shal come atte laste
And culle alle erthely creature &raisedpoint; saue conscience one
Lyf leep asyde &raisedpoint; and lauȝte hym a lemman
Heel & I quod he &raisedpoint; and hieghnesse of herte
Shal do þe nouȝte drede &raisedpoint; noyther deth ne elde
And to forȝete sorwe &raisedpoint; and ȝyue nouȝte of synne
¶ This lyked lyf &raisedpoint; and his lemman fortune
And geten in her glorie &raisedpoint; a gadelyng atte laste
One þat moche wo wrouȝte &raisedpoint; sleuthe was his name
Sleuthe wex wonder ȝerne &raisedpoint; and sone was of age
And wedded one wanhope &raisedpoint; a wenche of þe stuwes
Her syre was a sysour &raisedpoint; þat neure swore treuthe
One Thomme two tonge &raisedpoint; ateynte at vch a queste
¶ This sleuthe was war of werre &raisedpoint; and a slynge made
And threwe drede of dyspayre &raisedpoint; a dozein myle aboute
For care conscience þo &raisedpoint; cryed vpon elde
And bad hym fonde to fyȝte &raisedpoint; and afere wanhope
¶ And elde hent good hope &raisedpoint; and hastilich he shifte hym
And wayued awey wanhope &raisedpoint; and with lyf he fyȝteth
And lyf fleigh for fere to fysyke after helpe
And bisouȝte hym of socoure &raisedpoint; and of his salue hadde
And gaf hym golde good woon &raisedpoint; þat gladded his herte
And þei gyuen hym agayne a glasen houve
Lyf leued þat lechecrafte &raisedpoint; lette shulde elde
And dryuen awey deth &raisedpoint; with dyas and dragges
¶ And elde auntred hym on lyf &raisedpoint; and atte laste he hitte
A Fisicien with a forred hood &raisedpoint; þat he fel in a palsye
And þere deyed þat doctour &raisedpoint; ar thre dayes after
Now I see seyde lyf &raisedpoint; þat surgerye ne Fisyke
May nouȝte a myte auaille &raisedpoint; to medle aȝein elde
And in hope of his hele &raisedpoint; gode herte he hente
And rode so to reuel &raisedpoint; a ryche place and a merye
The companye of conforte &raisedpoint; men cleped it sumtyme
And elde anone after me &raisedpoint; and ouer myne heed ȝede
And made me balled bifore &raisedpoint; and bare on þe croune
So harde he ȝede ouer myn hed &raisedpoint; it wil be seen eure
¶ Sire euel ytauȝte elde quod I &raisedpoint; vnhende go with the
Sith whanne was þe way &raisedpoint; ouer men hedes
Haddestow be hende quod I &raisedpoint; þow woldest haue asked leue
¶ Ȝe leue lordeyne quod he &raisedpoint; and leyde on me with age
And hitte me vnder þe ere &raisedpoint; vnethe may ich here
He buffeted me aboute þe mouthe &raisedpoint; & bett out my tethe
And gyued me in goutes &raisedpoint; I may nouȝte go at large
And of þe wo þat I was in &raisedpoint; my wyf had reuthe
And wisshed ful witterly &raisedpoint; þat I were in heuene
For þe lyme þat she loued me fore &raisedpoint; and leef was to fele
On nyȝtes namely &raisedpoint; whan we naked were
I ne myght in no manere &raisedpoint; maken it at hir wille
So elde and she sothly &raisedpoint; hadden it forbeten
¶ And as I seet in þis sorwe &raisedpoint; I say how kynde passed
And deth drowgh niegh me &raisedpoint; for drede gan I quake
And cried to kynde &raisedpoint; out of care me brynge
Loo elde þe hoore &raisedpoint; hath me biseye
Awreke me if ȝowre wille be &raisedpoint; for I wolde ben hennes
¶ Ȝif þow wilt ben ywroken &raisedpoint; wende in-to vnite
And holde þe þere eure &raisedpoint; tyl I sende for þe
And loke þow conne somme crafte ar þow come þennes
lg.marginalia: Nature wolde we shoulde kearne to loue.Cr3.20.206
lg.l: Conseille me kynde quod I &raisedpoint; what crafte is best to lerne
Lerne to loue quod kynde &raisedpoint; & leue of alle othre
¶ How shal I come to catel so &raisedpoint; to clothe me and to fede
And þow loue lelly quod he &raisedpoint; lakke shal þe neure
Mete ne wordly wede &raisedpoint; whil þi lyf lasteth
¶ And þere by conseille of kynde &raisedpoint; I comsed to rowme
Thorw contricioun & confessioun &raisedpoint; tyl I cam to vnite
And þere was conscience constable &raisedpoint; cristene to saue
lg.marginalia: The seu capitall sinnes besieged conscience.Cr3.20.214
lg.l: And biseged sothly &raisedpoint; with seuene grete gyauntz
Þat with Antecrist helden &raisedpoint; hard aȝein conscience
¶ Sleuth with his slynge &raisedpoint; an hard saut he made
Proude prestes come with hym moo þan a thousand
In paltokes & pyked shoes &raisedpoint; & pisseres longe knyues
Comen aȝein conscience &raisedpoint; with coueityse þei helden
¶ By Marie quod a mansed preste &raisedpoint; of þe marche of yrlonde
lg.marginalia: Woulde god there were no such priestes in englande.Cr3.20.221
lg.l: I counte namore conscience &raisedpoint; bi so I cacche syluer
Than I do to drynke &raisedpoint; a drauȝte of good ale
And so seide sexty of þe same &raisedpoint; contreye
And shoten aȝein with shotte &raisedpoint; many a shef of othes
And brode hoked arwes &raisedpoint; goddes herte & his nayles
And hadden almost vnyte &raisedpoint; and holynesse adowne
¶ Conscience cryed helpe &raisedpoint; clergye or ellis I falle
Thorw inparfit prestes &raisedpoint; and prelates of holicherche
Freres herden hym crye &raisedpoint; and comen hym to helpe
Ac for þei couth nouȝte wel her craft &raisedpoint; conscience forsoke hem
¶ Nede neghed tho nere &raisedpoint; and conscience he tolde
That þei come for coueityse &raisedpoint; to haue cure of soules
lg.marginalia: Curates oughte to haue a com petent lyuyng certayneCr3.20.232
lg.l: And for þei arn poure par-auenture &raisedpoint; for patrimoigne hem failleth
Thei wil flatre to fare wel &raisedpoint; folke þat ben riche
And sithen þei chosen chele &raisedpoint; and cheytifte pouerte
Lat hem chewe as þei chese &raisedpoint; and charge hem with no cure
For lomer he lyeth &raisedpoint; þat lyflode mote begge
Þan he þat laboureth for lyflode &raisedpoint; & leneth it beggeres
And sithen Freres forsoke &raisedpoint; þe felicite of erthe

marginalia.note: O20.238. The first of these additions appears in the extreme left margin, the other in the left margin just opposite the line.

lg.l: Lat hem be as beggeres &raisedpoint; or lyue by angeles fode
¶ Conscience of þis conseille þo &raisedpoint; comsed for to laughe
And curtei[s]lich conforted hem &raisedpoint; and called in alle freres
And seide sires sothly &raisedpoint; welcome be ȝe alle
To vnite and holicherche &raisedpoint; ac on thyng I ȝow preye
Holdeth ȝow in vnyte &raisedpoint; and haueth none envye
To lered ne to lewed &raisedpoint; but lyueth after ȝowre rewle
And I wil be ȝowre borghe &raisedpoint; ȝe shal haue bred and clothes
And other necessaries anowe &raisedpoint; ȝow shal no thyng faille
With þat ȝe leue logyk &raisedpoint; and lerneth for to louye
For loue laft þei lordship &raisedpoint; bothe londe and scole
Frere Fraunceys and Dominyk &raisedpoint; for loue to ben holy
¶ And if ȝe coueyteth cure &raisedpoint; kynde wil ȝow teche
That in mesure god made &raisedpoint; alle manere thynges
And sette it at a certeyne &raisedpoint; and at a syker noumbre
And nempned names newe &raisedpoint; and noumbred þe sterres
Qui numerat multitudinem stellarum &raisedpoint; & omnibus eis &c
¶ Kynges & knyghtes þat kepen and defenden
Han officers vnder hem &raisedpoint; and vch of hem certeyne
And if þei wage men to werre &raisedpoint; þei write hem in noumbre
Wil no tresorere hem paye &raisedpoint; trauaille þei neure so sore
Alle other in bataille &raisedpoint; ben yholde bribours
Pilours and pykehernois &raisedpoint; in eche a place ycursed
¶ Monkes and monyals &raisedpoint; and alle men of Religioun
Her ordre and her reule wil &raisedpoint; to han a certeyne noumbre
Of lewed and of lered &raisedpoint; þe lawe wol and axeth
A certeyn for a certeyne &raisedpoint; saue onelich of freres
lg.marginalia: The Fryers are with out numbreCr3.20.266
lg.l: For-þi quod conscience by cryst &raisedpoint; kynde witte me telleth
It is wikked to wage ȝow &raisedpoint; ȝe wexeth out of noumbre
Heuene hath euene noumbre &raisedpoint; and helle is with-out noumbre
For-þi I wolde witterly &raisedpoint; þat ȝe were in þe Registre
And ȝowre noumbre vndre notarie sygne &raisedpoint; & noyther mo ne lasse
¶ Enuye herd þis &raisedpoint; and heet freres to go to scole
And lerne logyk and lawe &raisedpoint; and eke contemplacioun
And preche men of plato &raisedpoint; and preue it by seneca
Þat alle þinges vnder heuene &raisedpoint; ouȝte to ben in comune
¶ And ȝit he lyeth as I leue &raisedpoint; þat to þe lewed so precheth
For god made to men a lawe &raisedpoint; and Moyses it tauȝte
Non concupisces rem proximi tui
And euele is þis yholde &raisedpoint; in parisches of engelonde
For parsones and parish prestes þat shulde þe peple shryue
Ben curatoures called &raisedpoint; to knowe and to hele
Alle þat ben her parisshiens &raisedpoint; penaunce to enioigne
And shulden be ashamed in her shrifte &raisedpoint; ac shame maketh hem wende
And fleen to þe freres &raisedpoint; as fals folke to westmynstre
lg.marginalia: Thei that went to þe Fryers to thrift er like santuary men.Cr3.20.286
lg.l: That borweth and bereth it þider &raisedpoint; and þanne biddeth frendes
Ȝerne of forȝifnesse &raisedpoint; or lenger ȝeres leue
¶ Ac whil he is in westmynstre &raisedpoint; he wil be bifore
And make hym merye with other mennes goodis
And so it fareth with moche folke &raisedpoint; þat to þe freres shryueth
lg.marginalia: confession made to FryersR20.263, secretary hand
lg.l: As sysours and excecutours &raisedpoint; þei wil [yeue þe] freres
A parcel to preye for hem &raisedpoint; & make hem-self myrye
With þe residue and þe remenaunt &raisedpoint; þat other men biswonke
And suffre þe ded in dette &raisedpoint; to þe day of dome
¶ Enuye herfore &raisedpoint; hated conscience
And freres to philosofye &raisedpoint; he fonde hem to scole
The while coueytise and vnkyndenesse &raisedpoint; conscience assailled
In vnite holycherche &raisedpoint; conscience helde hym
And made pees porter &raisedpoint; to pynne þe ȝates
Of alle taletellers &raisedpoint; and tyterers in ydel
Ypocrisye and he &raisedpoint; an hard saut þei made
Ypocrysie atte ȝate &raisedpoint; hard gan fiȝte
And wounded wel wykkedly &raisedpoint; many wise techer
Þat with conscience acorded &raisedpoint; and cardinale vertues
Conscience called a leche &raisedpoint; þat coude wel shryue
Go salue þo þat syke ben &raisedpoint; þorw synne ywounded
Shrifte shope sharpe salue &raisedpoint; and made men do penaunce
For her mysdedes þat þei wrouȝte hadden
And þat piers were payed &raisedpoint; redde quod debes
¶ Somme lyked nouȝte þis leche &raisedpoint; and lettres þei sent
Ȝif any surgien were þe sege &raisedpoint; þat softer couth plastre
lg.marginalia: # syr leff to live in lecherye
lg.l: Sire lief to lyue in leccherye &raisedpoint; lay þere and groned
For fastyng of a fryday &raisedpoint; he ferde as he wolde deye
Ther is a surgiene in þis sege &raisedpoint; þat soft can handle
And more of phisyke bi fer &raisedpoint; and fairer he plastreth
One frere flaterere is phisiciene and surgiene
Quod contricioun to conscience &raisedpoint; do hym come to vnyte
For here is many a man herte &raisedpoint; þorw ypocrisie
¶ We han no nede quod conscience &raisedpoint; I wote no better leche
Than persoun or parissh prest &raisedpoint; penytancere or bisshop &raisedpoint;
Saue Piers þe plowman &raisedpoint; þat hath powere ouer hem alle
And indulgence may do &raisedpoint; but if dette lette it
I may wel suffre seyde conscience &raisedpoint; syn ȝe desiren
That frere flaterer be fette &raisedpoint; and phisike ȝow syke
¶ The Frere her-of herde &raisedpoint; and hyed faste
lg.marginalia: Nother patron nor bishop, regardeth his dutyeCr3.20.324
lg.l: To a lorde for a lettre &raisedpoint; leue to haue to curen
As a curatour he were &raisedpoint; and cam with his lettres
Baldly to þe bisshop &raisedpoint; & his brief hadde
In contrees þere he come in &raisedpoint; confessiouns to here
And cam þere conscience was &raisedpoint; and knokked atte ȝate
¶ Pees vnpynned it &raisedpoint; was porter of vnyte
And in haste asked &raisedpoint; what his wille were
In faith quod þis frere &raisedpoint; for profit and for helthe
Carpe I wolde with contricioun &raisedpoint; & þerfore come I hider
¶ He is sike seide pees &raisedpoint; and so ar many other
Ypocrisie hath herte hem &raisedpoint; ful harde is if þei keure
I am a surgien seide þe segge &raisedpoint; and salues can make
Conscience knoweth me wel &raisedpoint; and what I can do bothe
I preye þe quod pees þo &raisedpoint; ar þow passe ferther
What hattestow I preye þe &raisedpoint; hele nouȝte þi name

lg.marginalia: [probably by more than one hand, some of it cropped, partial erasure.]S20.335
lg.l: ¶ Certes seyde his felow sire penetrans domos
Ȝe go þi gate quod pees &raisedpoint; bi god for al þi phisyk
But þow conne somme crafte &raisedpoint; þow comest nouȝt her-Inne
I knewe such one ones &raisedpoint; nouȝte eighte wynter passed
Come in þus ycoped &raisedpoint; at a courte þere I dwelt
And was my lordes leche &raisedpoint; & my ladyes bothe
And at þe last þis limitour &raisedpoint; þo my lorde was out
He salued so owre wommen &raisedpoint; til somme were with childe
Hende speche het pees &raisedpoint; opene þe ȝates
Late in þe frere and his felawe &raisedpoint; and make hem faire chere
He may se and here &raisedpoint; so it may bifalle
That lyf þorw his lore shal leue coueityse
And be adradde of deth &raisedpoint; and with-drawe hym fram pryde
And acorde with conscience &raisedpoint; and kisse her either other
Thus thorw hende speche entred þe frere
And cam in-to conscience &raisedpoint; and curteisly hym grette
Þow art welcome quod conscience canstow hele þe syke
Here is contricioun quod conscience &raisedpoint; my cosyn ywounded
Conforte hym quod conscience and take kepe to his sores
The plastres of þe persoun &raisedpoint; and poudres biten to sore
He lat hem ligge ouerlonge &raisedpoint; and loth is to chaunge hem
Fro lenten to lenten &raisedpoint; he lat his plastres bite
¶ That is ouerlonge quod this limitour &raisedpoint; I leue I shal amende it
And goth and gropeth contricioun &raisedpoint; and gaf hym a plastre
Of a pryue payement &raisedpoint; and I shal praye for ȝow
lg.marginalia: The olde maner of cares shrifte made synners negligentCr3.20.364
lg.l: For alle þat ȝe ben holde to &raisedpoint; al my lyf-tyme
And make ȝow my lady &raisedpoint; in masse and in matynes
As freres of owre fraternite &raisedpoint; for a litel syluer
¶ Thus he goth and gadereth &raisedpoint; and gloseth þere he shryueth
Tyl contricioun hadde clene forȝeten &raisedpoint; to crye & to wepe
And wake for his wykked werkes &raisedpoint; as he was wont to done
For confort of his confessour &raisedpoint; contricioun he lafte
Þat is þe souereynest salue &raisedpoint; for alkyn synnes
¶ Sleuth seigh þat &raisedpoint; and so did pryde
And come with a kene wille &raisedpoint; conscience to assaille
Conscience cryde eft &raisedpoint; and bad clergye help hym
And also contricioun &raisedpoint; forto kepe þe ȝate
He lith and dremeth &raisedpoint; seyde pees &raisedpoint; and so do many other
The Frere with his phisik &raisedpoint; þis folke hath enchaunted
And plastred hem so esyly &raisedpoint; þei drede no synne
¶ Bi cryste quod conscience þo &raisedpoint; I wil bicome a pilgryme
And walken as wyde &raisedpoint; as al þe wordle lasteth
lg.marginalia: XF16.380, drypoint noting omission of next line
lg.l: To seke Piers þe plowman &raisedpoint; þat pryde may destruye
And þat freres hadde a fyndyng &raisedpoint; þat for nede flateren
And contrepleteth me conscience &raisedpoint; now kynde me auenge
And sende me happe and hele &raisedpoint; til I haue piers þe plowman
lg.marginalia: And siththeR20.359, modern pencil, to clarify unclear main text
lg.l: And sitthe he gradde after grace &raisedpoint; til I gan awake
lg.marginalia: [pass]us ijus de DobestBx20.387: [pass]us ijus de Dobest: Written in the margin in LR, and so presumably Bx. See Introduction 4.2.
William ButtesR20.359, secretary hand, above trailer "Passus ijus de dobest"
